column2: Byron De La Beckwith was found not guilty today of carrying a live time bomb and a pistol on a midnight drive into New Orleans from Mississippi.

The celebrity-packed jury at the Rachmaninoff Competition in 1948 would undoubtedly have been astonished to learn that the brilliant young pianist they had just picked as first-prize winner was merely biding his time at the keyboard until he could land a conductor's job.

It will come as no great shock to the financial community that I have decided to get out of the stock market. Brokerage houses will not collapse. The Dow Jones industrial average will pay no attention. And Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith will continue to be bullish on America.
Robert E. Lehmann, owner of the 1970 Kentucky Derby winner, Dust Commander, died at Golden Chance Farm today. He was 52 years old.

The engagement of Miss Mary Frances O'Hara to Cyr Annan Ryan has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Patrick O'Hara, Parents of the future bride. Her fianc, O'Hara, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is a son of Mrs. William Shields Jr. of New York and Allmuchy, N. J., and the late Cledenin James Ryan, and a great-grandson of Thomas Fortune Ryan, the financier.

Cars, buses and trucks skidded and crashed, and pedestrians slipped and tumbled through the night and into the morning yesterday on a coating of ice left by a storm that glazed roads and sidewalks throughout the metropolitan area.

GROSS NATIONAL PRODUCT, in real terms, grew 1.3 per cent in the final quarter of 1973, to a total of $1,334billion [annual rate]. It was the smallest gain since the last quarter of 1970 .... Industrial production dropped 0.5 per cent in December, the deepest decline in two years, as automobile output fell .... Consumption of electricity deelined 4.1 per cent in the first week of daylight saving.
Permassiveness in the field of culture is under attack in China, where the relaxed atmosphere of last year is giving way to demands for stricter censorship and more intensive propaganda.
To the Editor: Richard Kluger's review of William H. Harbaugh's book, "Lawyer's Lawyer: The Life of John W. Davis," (Dec. 30) hardly does justice to either the author or the subject.
Evidence that a large, ancient Finger Lake once filled New York's Genesee Valley has been uncovered by geologists and anthropologists at the State University at Geneseo.

Leaders of the soft coal industry agreed today to begin contract negotiations with the United Mine Workers in February to avert "eleventh-hour bargaining" when the present contract expires next November.

ACTORS' CAFE-THEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East Orange--Terence Rattigan's "The Browning Version" and Pirandello's "The Man With the Flower in His Mouth," twin bill of one-act plays. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. $3.50-$3.90; students, $2.50-$2.90. (201) 6751881.

President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt toured Arab capitals today in an at tempt to get the most important Arab leaders to underwrite the agreement signed by Egypt and Israel yesterday on the disengagement of their forces along the Suez Canal.
Tizna took advantage of her 116-pound impost today to score a half-length victory over favored Susan's Girl in the 17th running of the $46,050 Santa Monica Handicap at Sannta Anita.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin B. Naumoff of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Naumoff, to Chaim Garncarz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Zvi Garncarz of Tel Aviv. The Wedding will take place here March 24.

To the twin inevitabilities of death and taxes, the major oil companies of this country, amply assisted by the United States Government and a variety of Arab sheikdoms, have sought to add a third - the inevitability of sharply higher oil prices.
France said today that she would float the franc for six months, setting it free of fixed rates by ending support for it on the exchange markets.
Five Soviet citizens, including a senior diplomat and two other members of the Soviet Embassy staff, were expelled from China today on charges that they engaged in espionage activities.

The stock market returned to higher ground last week, despite a sharp decline in the final day of trading, which followed a Government report of a slowdown in the "real" gross national product during the last quarter of 1973.

What would you command if you were allowed one last great meal on this earth? I have my answer. The menu would move blissfully from caviar with vodka (Stolichnaya, by choice) to, in due course, a fine fat squab stuffed with truffles and foie gras. It would end with an elegant ice. Now, preferences in food are highly subjective and there may be those who would question my choice. of squab.
Ed Coyle of the Racquet and Tennis Club and John Greco of the University Club, the top-seeded team, advanced to the semifinals in the Metropolitan open doubles squash racquets tournament yesterday.

To the traveler looking north from the Punjab plain in India, the Himalayas rise seemingly as a great, sudden, impermeable wall. But this is an illusion. Before the mountains begin, there are foothills with valleys behind or between. Other valleys, some wide, some mere clefts in the wall, run deep into the mountains. The most famous of these,

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair,
Groan, a Kentucky-bred competing in the silks of Kimball Firestone, contributed an upset in the Virginia Belle, today's feature event at Bowie Race Course.

There are two signs on the edge of this friendly town in the north woods. The smaller one reads simply: "Eagle River. Population 1,326." The larger screams in technicolor: Welcome to the Snowmobile Capital of the World."
FAIR LAWN -- Viewers of the innovative art exhibits offered by the Fair Lawn Public Library may not always like what they see. But that does not dismay library officials.
Frank Ellis, who provides toll free telephone ski information service for enthusiasts from Maine to California had two visitors yesterday afternoon.

More than 3,800 Eskimos and other Alaskan natives had good reason to celebrate this week as the Alaska Supreme Court dismissed a case by 12 oil and pipeline related plaintiffs that had fought the incorporation of the North Slope Borough.

Sensing victory in the statewide elections this year, the Democratic state Committee called today on all candidates for their party's nominations to avoid personal attacks on one another in the primary and to support the winners for election in November.
Indictments charging misuse of public-school funds in central Harlem are to be announced tomorrow by Alfred J. Scotti, Acting District Attorney of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON--To his regret, nothing Vice President Gerald Ford said during his 25 years in Congress has been repeated as often, both with scorn and approval, as his description of what constitutes an impeachable offense. "The only honest answer," he said in 1970, "is that an impeachable offense is, whatever majority of the House of Representatives considers it to be at a given moment in history;
Tomorrow will present the last call for the 1973. 74 football season with the Pro Bowl game in Arrowhead Stadium.

ON the surface, David Bromberg does not seem like much of a candidate for superstar. He shambles out on a stage looking like the most uncouth object since the Abominable Snowman--tall, gangling, with a shaggy eruption of dark hair, a fringe of whiskers circling his face, peering through large, thin-rimmed glasses.

It is taken as received opinion that R. Austin Freeman's detective stories featuring Dr. Thorndyke occupied the most important position in the field between the great period of Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes and the appearance in the 1920's of such authors as Dorothy Sayers and Agatha Christie.

There was very little wrong with Susan Salm's playing in her local debut recital on Jan. 10 in Carnegie Recital Hall. The Chicago-born, Juilliardtrained cellist was being presented as an auditions winner by the Concert' Artists Guild,
George Bush, the Republican National Chairman, said today if President Nixon was "hounded out of office" it would be damaging to the nation's stability.

Retailers are zeroing in on producers of defective goods. In an attempt to relieve's source of long frustration, aroused merchants have agreed to exchange data on suppliers who ship goods that don't come up to snuff.

A major and most egregious omission in the article "Lower East Side Tests Homeowners" [Jan. 6] must be noted. I refer to the failure to mention the recent highly successful efforts of New York City's Cooperative Conversion Program to assist in the acquisition of older tenement buildings and their rehabilitation and conversion to cooperative ownerships by their tenants.

IT was after his sweeping re-election triumph against an ineffectual opponent that his troubles really be gan. One scandal after another erupted. Harassed businessmen had been forced to make illegal contributions to his campaign. The Democrats discovered that their campaign had been sabotaged.
Lou Goldfine, trainer of the American sprint champion Shecky Greene, proved a pretty good handicapper at Gulfstream Park todaymuch to his regret.

The engagement of Miss Kerry Frances Mahoney to Thomas Gerard Brown has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Mahoney, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Campbell Brown of Pelham Manor.
U.C.L.A.'s record 88game basketball winning streak came to an end today on the same court where the Bruins had last lost three years ago.
A feminist newspaper that has analyzed Congressional voting records on feminist issues gives Vice President Ford a score of zero and five prominent Democrats each 100.
For several years, Harding and Mary Lawrence were the highest paid executives in their industries, and that's more than a slight coincidence.
Add another name to the list of athletes who play pitchman on the television commercial circuit. The Soviet gymnast, Olga Korbut, will be making a pitch for the Expo '74 Worlds Fair.
Boris Spassky, the former world chess champion, defeated Robert Byrne, the American grandmaster, yesterday in the third game of their world championship quarterfinals match in San Juan, P.R.

The Defense Department has begun developing a new type of missile warhead that can be maneuvered to avoid enemy defenses or eventually could home in with high accuracy on such targets as missile silos.

The nation's top environmental official says the dimensions of the energy crisis" are far bigger than is generally appreciate and call for both altered national life-styles and new govrnmental mechanisms.

Elwin B. Dixon, assistant foreman of the delivery department of The New York Times since 1954, died early yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, on his arrival home from work. He was 56 years old and lived at 80-64 258th Street, floral Park, Queens.

The Miami Dolphins, National Football League champions, placed five men on the first all-pro team which was selected by the Pro Football Writers of America, yesterday but the Super Bowl hero, Larry Csonka, had to settle for second string running back

Miss Maire Pasley, a silversmith, and Edward Phillip Freeman, who is in his second year at the Suffolk University School of Law in Boston, were married here this morning. Somerset County Judge Thomas B. Leahy performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. William J. Pasley.
Johnny Miller still led after 54 holes in the $150,000 Dean Martin-Tucson open today but his edge diminished to two strokes.

Mount Vernon High School set a national record of 22 seconds for the 180yard high hurdles relay last night in the Westchester coaches and officials scholastic track games in the West Point fieldhouse.

Aside from students' possible passing acquaintance with Milton's "Comus," the court masque is probably the least known of Renaissance art forms. The masque in Stuart England was a strange mixture of mythological poetry, political theory and polemic, opera, awe-provoking spectacle, amateur ballet,

A gunman who held 13 hostages in a supermarket for 10 hours was captured tonight shortly after he made his escape, the police said.

To the Financial Editor: Mary J. Wilson gives the impression that Social Security is getting out of control and becoming a monstrous bite on taxpayers' money ("Social Security: An Inflation Hedge?" Jan. 13).
IN his "Journal" for Feb. 22, 1860. Delacroix wrote: "Realism is the great resource of the innovators at those periods when the schools are becoming languid and turning to mannerism;

There are a hundred different voices in the January wind. It can bellow, it can shout, it can scream, it can whisper. It can rip and tear and with one scream darken a thousand homes. You hear it roaring through the leafless maples, murmuring through the pines on a hillside. Of an evening, you may hear it whistling down the chimney, to set the hearth-fire to dancing.

Bernard L. Barker says that he would do it all again. Since he was arrested a year and a half ago crouching behind a desk in the Democratic party's Watergate headquarters, Mr. Barker has become sick, broke and saddened b the loss of old friends, including E. Howard Hunt Jr., whom he once idolized. e idolized.

Wolfgang Zimmerer and Peter Utzschneider of West Germany held a comfortable lead at the halfway stage of the world twoman bobsled championships today and seem well on the way to winning the title for the third consecutive year. In today's two runs Zimmerer piloted his sled in the fastest times down the. icy 1,722-yard course, leading from St. Moritz down to Celerina.

William T. Seawell, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways, and Mrs. Seawell of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Crichton Seawell, to Adam Benjamin Robinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson of Pine Bluff, Ark.

MINEOLA, L.I.--The chaos of the Federal take-over of local payments to the aged, blind and disabled this month has brought confusion, despair and in some cases hunger to thousands on Long Island, many of them shortchanged or inadvertently dropped from the rolls.

The Federal Government, through salaries, contracts, grants, welfare, veterans' benefits and other payments, accounts for a smaller percentage of the total personal income of New York State residents than it provides for the residents of all but seven states.
Olympia and York Developments, Ltd., of Toronto has purchased 2,000 acres of Wooded land at the intersection of Routes 9 and 18 in Madison Township, N.J.
In a "revolutionary offensive" in 1968, Premier Fidel Castro began a drive against all remaining private trade. Thousands of small businesses, including street stands, were confiscated.

Mr. and Mrs. James F. Darr have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judy Ann Darr of New York, to Charles Paterson Eaton, an institutional salesman with the New York borkerage firm of H. C. Wainwright

A FEW weeks before I attended Dial/Delacorte's semi-annual sales conference at the Summit Hotel in early December, I read Bruce Bliven's revealing New Yorker profile of a travelling book salesman, George Fabian Scheer. What Mr. Scheer looks for at a sales conference, he says, is "The proper 'handle' for each of the new books.

Reflecting the skepticism of many Americans about the extent of the oil shortage and the worries of others that it is all too real and may cost thousands of jobs, a number of Congressional committees have begun to ask some hard questions about the mysteries of the oil industry.

City authorities said today that anyone who tried to destroy Japanese-made cars or other products would be shot. The capital was still under a curfew after this week's student demonstrations and riots during a visit by Premier Kakuel Tanaka of Japan but it was in force only from 11 P.M. to 3 A.M.

Depending on your environmental viewpoint, suburbia is either salvation or damnation. It is the good life or the destroyer of cities. One thing is beyond argument: it has reshaped the face of America since World War II and profoundly affected the country's life and institutions.

Karen Ecker, a 17-year-old high-school student, is leaving the car in the garage and taking the school bus these days-even though It means leaving early. "I'm doing it for myself, really," said the East Hampton High School senior.

Whitney Tower of New York and Mrs. Hugh W. Fosburgh of Bedford, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Fell Tower, to Thomas Day Thacher 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Thacher of the Bronx.

In what was billed as a historic first for both the women's movement and the broadcasting industry, a major Boston television station yesterday canceled its soap operas, quiz shows and all other regular programming except news to broadcast 16 hours of programming on women's issues.
In an effort to lighten the gloom and sacrifice attending the drive to conserve energy, a perky new theme song has been introduced by the Newark Boys Chorus.

The City Commission on Human Rights and local civic organizations in eastern communities of Brooklyn and Queens are collaborating on a pilot program designed to keep speculators and unethical real estate dealers from bringing about the deterioration of neighborhoods as a device to spur real estate activity.

TRENTON - New Jersey's Green Acres Preservation Program, looked upon as the ideal way to protect open space when it was started in 1961, has run into an increasingly familiar problem: How to guard parkland and recreation areas while municipalities struggle for added sources of tax revenue.
Having waited in vain for a golden harvest, many corporate giants are sadly coming to the conclusion that the farming business is not for them.

YOU see them everywhere in La Paz, their jaunty bowler hats with brims upturned and their cheeks burned. a reddish gold by the sun of the Andes. You see them scampering nimbly through the crowded streets of the Bolivian capital, bowed double by the weight of their merchandise or bouncing their blanket-swaddled babies on their backs.

European Common Market sources said today that the French decision to free the franc from currency ties inside the Common Market was a sign of dislocation caused by the recent fourfold increases in oil prices and represented a setback for hopes of European monetary union by the end of this decade.

Mr. Fearons, a retired real estate operator, was a trustee of St. Patrick's Cathedral here and of St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I., at which a wing has been named for him and his wife. He was also vice president and treasurer of the and of Stony Brook museums.
A Mafioso who spent 22 years of his prime in the United States is cast in the role of an accuser in a Roman scandal.

The Nixon Administration has decided to ask Congress for almost $99-billion in new spending authority for defense, including $92.6-billion in the new budget and $5.9-billion in supplemental funds for the previous year.
OAKLAND--New Jersey's elderly residents will receive special group-discount rates for admission to the 1974 New Jersey Flower and Garden Show.

Miss Brenda Lynn Kaplan and Henry Levine, graduates of Union College, plan to marry next year. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kaplan, parents of the bride-to-be, whose fiance is the son of Mrs. Sidney Levine of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Levine.
The National Committee for an Effective Congress has predicted that President Nixon will be impeached as a result of legal and political developments this year in the Watergate case.

" Our kitchen is the heart of the house," says Hungarianborn George Lang, writer, cook and adviser to hotels, restaurants and shipping lines on the planning of their foodpreparation centers. And it really is where the pulsing life of the Lang household is centered. It's where George and his wife Karen cook, eat,
Yoshimasa Wada is a Japanese-born former sculptor who has lived in this country for the last seven years and who has devoted himself to sound for the last five.

TRENTON -- In 1971, when New Jersey revised its divorce laws for the first time in 50 years, the legislation included a little-noticed provision that is currently causing shock waves in the state's system of dividing marital property.

The impending collapse of Europe has been announced by a great many thinkers in our time from Spengler to Sartre and beyond. But none of the prophets of doom had sufficient imagination to envisage that the fatal crisis could be triggered by the Emir of Kuwait and the Sheik of Abu Dhabi.
BERGENFIELD -- Bins, barrels and apothecary jars filled with Mary Janes, lollipops, Tootsie Rolls, bubblegum and cherry suckers priced at a penny each crowd a new shop here called Midnight Munchies.

HONIARA, Solomon Islands--Early in World War II, Japanese military power was expelled from the wild, malarial Solomon Islands by United States forces in a series of jungle skirmishes and spectacular naval battles.
All young people on Zanzibar aged 18 to 20 will have to go to boarding school to learn discipline, the island's President has announced.
The Soviet Union plans to send a group to the North Pole on skis this year to test the physical and psychological re distance of men plodding daily against searing winds across the polar ice cap.
Members of the 93d Congress went home last month in search of a Watergate mandate and came back this weekend without a mandate but bearing a plea: Get it over with.

A writer looking for a funny ending to his interview with Bob Hope asked the comedian recently if he thought there was still sex after 65. "You bet," said Hope, "and awfully good, too. [Pause for a heat of exquisite timing. I Especially the one in the fall."
Sammy James of Miami won the 200-mile Jockey Club Sea Talk national ocean race today, averaging 72 miles an hour in a 38-foot BertramWhittaker Moppie.

Mrs. Ann Wiley Hanson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kathryn Ann Hanson, to Leigh Joseph Bechtle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry S. Bechtle of Thornton, Pa. A wedding in September is planned.

Jessie Bollier is a 13-year-old white youth who lives in New Orleans early in the 1840's. He likes to sit on the docks and play his fife, and one day he is overheard by two men. That night he is captured by them and taken aboard a slave ship bound for West Africa.

60-Yard Dash--Herb Washington (defender), Steve Williams, Hasely Crawford, Ivory Crockett, Marshall Dill, Bob Ware, Larry Black, Ford Dennis, Dr. Delano Meriwether. 60-Yard High Hurdles--Rod Milburn (defender), Larry Shipp, Charles Foster, Willie Davenport, Tom Hill, Charles Dobson, Bruce Collins, Harold Schwab, Joe Myatt, Larry Bunting.

MENTION radio drama to those who reached adolescence before the early fifties and they are likely to go limp and soggy with nostalgia. Listen to the new "CBS Radio Mystery Theater" series, and the nostalgia itself goes limp and soggy. The series is offering a different story seven nights a week on more than 200 stations, most of them CBS affiliates. (In New York, it is being carried on station WOR.)

SHORT of the cold-eyed, critical "Life and Times" which has never been written, Dorothy Norman's "Alfred Stieglitz: An American Seer" (Random House, $35) is probably the most useful biography of Stieglitz to be expected. It traces the broad outlines of his career.
Mrs. Clara Edwards, a song writer who was a member of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers since 1925, died Thursday at her home, 29 East 64th Street. Her age was 95.

Frederick F. Guyott Jr., New England sales manager of architectural construction systems for the Johns Manville Corporation, died yesterday in Norwalk Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at West Branch Road here.
Mrs. Edmund F. Ebert of Scarborough has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Marie Ebert, to Timothy Simes Rothermel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Rothermel of Winchester, Mass.

They are currently Chicago's No, 1 young-coupleabout-town, and the fact that she is a Rockefeller and recently came into an estimated $35-million obviously doesn't hurt any.

THE Santa Fe Opera, off in the wilds of the Southwest, does not seem bothered by the energy crisis. In its plans for next summer it has not hesitated to expand a bit, and it will give 30 performances instead of the 27 it gave last year. On the other hand, it is submitting to a fiscal economy;
Four persons were arrested today while protesting a speaking appearance by Dr. William B. Shockley of Stanford University, proponent of controversial views about intelligence and race.
TRENTON -- A three-yearold report that accused lawyers of earning excessive fees from bond-counseling work and recommended sweeping reforms may soon lead to tighter controls on such fees.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan has returned to Tokyo after 10 turbulent days of touring five nations of Southeast Asia, and at his final stop in Indonesia, he found the most violent demonstrations of all. But it was clear in Jakarta that more than anti-Japanese feelings had brought thousands of demonstrators into the streets: They were also protesting the policies of their own government, and Mr. Tanaka's visit gave them the excuse to do so.

IT is sobering to reflect that while 92 per cent of the households in this country have television, only 86 per cent have indoor plumbing. I read somewhere that TV is now regarded as a necessity for families on welfare and no doubt it is.

Aaron Shapinsky's cello recital last Sunday afternoon at Tully Hall, accompanied with familial sympathy by his son, Ian, was something of a model of understated authority. Mr. Shapinsky is not an extroverted virtuoso of the platigorsky sort.

THE 30 or so art galseries of SoHo, increasingly interspersed with boutiques these days, are an odd lot. Ranging from vast, glossy showrooms to dusky little storefronts, they carve up a territory as much psychological as esthetic. Bach gallery has its own constituency of artists and audience and its own complex ambience.

To the Editor: Having barely survived (emotionally) another Season to Be Jolly, I am writing in response to Raohel Gallagher's article, "The Best Christmas Present of All Is a Trip Out of Town" (Travel Section Dec. 16). I plead with those who plan these trips to put together an escape which is truly that and not just a transplanted version of the domestic celebration without relatives.

Disengagement The military disengagement between Egypt and Israel may be, as the text of the agreement. says, only "a first step" toward peace in the Middle East; but it is a first step of fundamental importance and is the most hopeful development to have taken place in Arab-Israeli relationships in many years.
David W. Schorer, the American vice consul in Leningrad, was roughed up by unidentified Russians in the streets of that city earlier this month, State Department officials said today.

France has proposed a world conference on energy resources to be held under United Nations auspices. The proposal was made in a letter to Secretary General Waldheim, which a United Nations spokesman said today would be made public on Monday, apparently after the twopage text is given to the other eight members of the European Common Market.
Miss Charlotte Mason Frieze and Jonathan Phelps Blum were married this afternoon in the Colebrook Congregational Church by the Rev. Harry Chase, a Presbyterian minister.

Harry Theyard had been scheduled to make his Metropolitan Opera debut Friday night, as Des Grieux in "Manon Lescaut." But then John Alexander fell victim to the flu, and Mr. Theyard was pressed into duty a day early, in the title role of "Les Contes d'Hoffmann."

Mr. and Mrs. William C. Ludi have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Barbara Ludi of Mountain View, Calif., to Edward Wyllis Scripps 3d, also of Mountain View. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W, Scripps of Hillsborough, Calif., and Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas.
Miss Ilajayne Presberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Presberg, and Lawrence H. Silverman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Silverman of Kings Point, plan to marry in September.

The Asian lion, which once roamed from southern Europe to India, is in danger of extinction and a battle is on to save it. Adopted by many peoples as a symbol of fearlessness and power, the Asian lion is now confined to one diminishing Indian forest, the victim of man's hunger for land, according to the World Wildlife Fund, based here.

Dr. Robert Steele, biochemist of the Brookhaven National Laboratories here and a former member of Brookhaven's council, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home at Arthur Avenue in Blue Point. He was 58 years old.

The Environmental Protection Agency and the Texas Department of Agriculture reached agreement here this week to start an experimental predator control program permitting the use of the previously banned M-44 cyanide gun in combating coyotes.

As the much-criticized "ugly American" of the past gradually fades out of prominence in Southeast Asia, his place increasingly is being taken by the "ugly Japanese." A serious attempt to change this image has been mounted since accession to power in 1972 of Premier Kakuei Tanaka; but Mr. Tanaka's goodwill tour of Southeast Asia has, ironically, touched off demonstrations in Indonesia and Thailand and criticism elsewhere of Japanese "economic imperialism."

FROM Britain to Brooklyn has come the Royal Shakespeare Company, opening a substantial visiting season with John Barton's staging of "Richard II." Mr. Barton's production is a scholar's dream. Unfortunately, a scholar's dream can become an audience's slumber.

The Netherlands has accepted President Nixon's invitation to attend a conference of oil-consuming countries in Washington Feb. 11, the Dutch foreign ministry said here today. MILLBROOK, N.Y. - The State Department of Environmental Conservation announced last week that nine varieties of evergreen seedlings were available at a minimum cost for spring planting.

The disengagement pact reached by Israel and Egypt calls for a sharp realignment, within 40 days, of their armies as presently deployed. Israel is required to withdraw all her troops from the bridgehead on the western bank of the Suez Canal to a zone marked by an uneven line--B on the "After Withdrawal" map-running from the Mediterranean to the Gulf of Suez.

A special Joint session of the National Assembly voted today to amend the Constitution so that President Nguyen Van Thieu can run for a third term in 1975. The amendments also extend the term from four years to five.
