Now that the draw to pair the 16 countries into four groups and the first-round schedule for the World Cup have been settled, reaction from the federations and other national soccer authorities involved has been mixed--and predictable.

Notre Dame's basketball team had an unusually strong belief -in its ability to beat the University of California, Los Angeles, yesterday. It carried the Irish to the stunning 71-70 victory over the Bruins and snapped their record 88game, three-year winning streak.

PLAIN SPEAKING. An Oral Biography of Harry S. Truman. By Merle Miller. 448 pages. Berkley/Putnam $8.95. There's: no denying it: this is an immensely appealing book, this "Oral Biography of Harry S. Truman" salvaged by Merle Miller from a television documentary that was floated and sunk in the early nineteen-sixties (sunk because, according to Mr. Miller, "Harry Truman was in the winter of 1962 still 'a controversial figure.'"). Merle Miller

The military Reserves could be trimmed by about one-third and still meet essential commitments, according to a study made public today by the Brookings Institution. In urging a reduction of about 300,000 men in the present force of 900,000, the study estimates that a streamlining could reduce defense spending by $1.4billion a year.

The United States should spend far more than at present to prevent malnutrition in infants and mothers, according to a Senate committee staff report published today. The report, from the Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs, said there was a "staggering" prevalence of prematurity or low birth weight among babies born to poor families.

The political police have arrested a prominent Brazilian educator and Roman Catholic lay leader, church sources said today. Maria Nilde Mascellani, a pioneer in vocational education in Brazil, was arrested Friday in her office, according to close friends. They said she was taken to the headquarters of the political police, where she is still being held.

Johnny Miller completed a record sweep of the first three tournaments on the pro golf circuit today as his spectacular 16-under-par 272 won the 72-hole Dean MartinTucson open. The 26-year-old United States Open champion shot a four-under-par 68 for a three-stroke edge over his 22-year-old rookie challenger, Ben Crenshaw of Austin, Tex. Johnny Miller holding the ball he sank for his last putt at Dean Martin-Tucson open

The pressure for reform at all levels of government that has been mounting throughout the country in the wake of Watergate has had some impact on the State Legislature in Albany this year-but not much. Despite Assembly Speaker Perry Duryea's warning that "we are learning the bitter lessons of government too closely held," New York legislators have shown a persisting reluctance to open up their proceedings to public scrutiny, especially in the Assembly.

Worldwide sales of .Sotheby Parke-Bernet in 1973 totaled $206.5-million, the company has announced. This was a 60.3 per cent gain over 1972 sales, which totaled $128.8-million. Sotheby, established in 1744, is the world's largest dealer in works of art sold at auction. Figures given are "net," which means that they represent sales of art that actually changed hands and do not include merchandise bought back by the original owners.

The Actors Equity Association called a strike last night against the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers. The action, which involves about 120 performers and stage managers, will shut down nine current productions and one that was to begin rehearsal tomorrow. Since there are no Monday performances on Off Broadway, the effect of the strike will not be felt until tomorrow.

The American Jewish Committee announced today that Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, would receive its Isaiah Award for "Pursuit of Justice" at a luncheon here Jan. 28. Mr. Jackson has been a leader in efforts on behalf of Soviet Jews and has been a strong supporter of Israel.

John P. Kildahl, a clinical psychologist and professor at New York Theological Seminary, said here today that the Pentecostal practice of speaking in tongues constituted "learned behavior." He rejected assertions by Pentecostal Christians that the practice, also known as glossolalia, was inherently spiritual and said that its religious significance depended entirely upon how it was used.

Israel will start to pull back her troops from the western bank of the Suez Canal on Friday, it was announced today by Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, the Israeli chief of staff. General Elazar, on the Israeli radio, told of the planned withdrawal after meeting today with his Egyptian counterpart, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Abdel Ghany el-Gamasy, on the Cairo-Suez road.

Before the mid January thaw this week, a foot of snow and below-zero temperatures covered the undulating prairies of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, giving the traditional home of the Oglala Sioux a remarkable resemblance to Arctic tundra. The thaw, which turned the snow into rivulets of ice cold water and fields of slush, came in time to permit heavy campaigning for the $13,500-a-year job of tribal president.

Fourteen members of the safe Return Amnesty Committee were given summons at Fort Dix after they entered the Army base to distribute leaflets asking exoneration of military deserters and resisters. Military policemen apprehended them after they had broken off from a group of about 50 demonstrators rallying outside the post's main gate and refused a request by Col. Arthur Friedman, the provost marshal, to leave the base.
Bernie Bernstrom, penitentiary inmate, plays music he composed for "Parole," Ch. 13 at 8 P.M.

Laurence E. Young, a retired hat buyer for R. H.- Macy Co. and a former treasurer of Young's Hat Company, died to- i day in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 36 Iselin Terrace. Surviving are his widow, Rosalie; a son, Kenneth; a brother, Robert, and three grandchildren.

Somewhat the worse for wear, the New York Knicks returned to New York yesterday and prepared to enter a new phase of their National Basketball Association season. A 112-89 defeat in Phoenix Saturday night, on the heels of a 96-90 loss in Houston Friday, underlined their current problems, just as the three victories in Chicago, Seattle and Oakland displayed their basic strengths.

Secretary of State Kissinger flew from Damascus to Israel to inform Israeli officials that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria had made proposals for beginning troop separation talks with Israel and in finding a way to release a list of Israeli prisoners. He told newsmen that Mr. Assad had made "very constructive suggestions" on both disengagement talks and on a final accord. [1:8.]

The swearing-in of a new Grenada governor failed to take place as planned yesterday while demonstrations against Prime Minister,Eric Gairy's government continued. Mr. Gairy told a meeting on Thursday that a new Governor -- the successor to Dame Hilda Bynoe, who resigned in the face of similar demonstrations a week ago -- would be sworn in yesterday morning.

State officials insisted today that New Jersey's successful sale of bonds to finance the Meadowlands sports complex would not jeopardize former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's three-month, old plan to build an 80,000-seat stadium and two race tracks on a 300-acre site in Sunnyside, Queens.

A Brooklyn elementary school was heavily damaged over the weekend by vandalism that the police and Board of Education Officials suggested was linked to the labor disputes that crippled the school system last week. Electricians, machinists and maintenance workers were sent last night to the school-Public School 5 at 820 Hancock Street in the Bedford-Stuyves. ant section-to make repairs to the heating controls, principals office and lunchroom and permit reopening of the building today.

Heavy rain forced postponement of the National Association for Stock Car Automobile Racing's $103,000 Winston Western 500 today, with Bobby Allison of Hueytown, Ala., holding the lead when the race was halted at the end of 63 laps. With 165 miles in the books, the 500-miler will be completed over Riverside's 2.62-mile course Saturday.

Burns Bennett, a newspaperman and public official, died early today of a stroke. He was 60 years old. Mr. Bennett worked. on Arkansas newspapers and came to Montgomery with United Press in the nineteen-forties. In 1951 he was named to the cabinet-level post of state director of publicity and information by Alabama's Gov. Gordon Persons.' He was also the Governor's press secretary.

After three years of delays, work has at last begun on a massive copper-mining project at La Caridad in northern Mexico. The $500-million complex aims for an annual output of 150,000 metric tons, all for export, Production is scheduled to begin in mid1977.

Sequoyah Industries, Inc., announced over the weekend that its board of directors authorized the company to seek Protection under the Federal bankruptcyy Act and that the Necessary documents would be filed early this week.

Miss Alice G. Chasan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Chasan of Jersey City and Deal, was married here at noon today to Matthew L. Edelman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Edelman of New York and Newtown, Conn. Rabbis Laurence J. Silberstein and Samuel A. Berman performed the ceremony in Temple Beth-El. Mrs. Samuel Estreicher and Steven M. Simons attended the couple.

Thorbjorn Ryen was beaten today by Arthur Tokle Jr. for his first loss of the 1974 ski jumping season. He had won five tournaments in a row. Tokle, a nephew of the late Torger Tokle who holds the previous record of 180 feet here, won the Mount Beacon tournament with flights of 142 and 147 feet for 195 points. Ryen covered 138 and 156 feet for 177.3.

Senator Hugh Scott said today that he had information that would clear President Nixon of any wrongdoing in some aspects of the Watergate scaridals. The Senate Republican leader made the statement during a television interview but declined to say what the information was. Senator Hugh Scott facing news cameras yesterday.

The jury selection in the murder trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark E. Squire, which is entering its fourth week at the Morris County courthouse here, has aroused casual interest in the white community and mixed reaction among the black residents in this town of nearly 18,000 people.

Gorgeous may be the word that best describes the objects in the new show at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts-in the way that a circus can be gorgeous or a panoplied procession or a box full of jewels. For the point of the multimedia show Is the growing use by craftsmen of embellishment and adornment. But this is not just a question of simple surface decoration.
Millicet H. Fenwick is temporarily staying on as State Consumer Affairs Director, which prompted her to remark, "As Ben Jonson said, Millicent H. Fenwick
Trans World Airlines will revise its advertising about free movies, music and cocktails for coach passengers, among other things, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.
France's decision to float its franc in the currency markets points up the nationalistic hurdles that still confront European integrationists, as well as the early effects of the energy crisis.
The supply side of at least one bond market equation remains heavy this week with underwriters, traders and investors facing a large tax-exempt calendar.

Our country desperately needs a national food policy. The United States today is dangerously short of food. What is worse, we are dangerously short even of farmers. We are dangerously short of farming capacityof machinery and breeding stock and production supplies. We are dangerously short, above all, of morale among our farm people. All this portends that our danger will grow worse unless we correct its cause.

The White House-sponsored proposals for a new national cable television policy that were released last Wednesday were notable, if not remarkable, for the lack of political mischief, in the view of many concerned with the development of cable TV. The report, which advocated almost total freedom from Government control for television-by - wire,

George T. Palley, a corporate vice president and director of Lane Bryant, Inc., the diversified retail apparel and shoe chain, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 45 East 72d Street. He was 65 years old. Mr. Palley was a director and past president of the Educational Alliance. In World War II he served in the Army Transportation Corps in the European theater and rose to the rank of major.

Somewhat the worse for wear, the New York Knicks returned to New York yesterday and prepared to enter a new phase of their National Basketball Association season. A 112-89 defeat in Phoenix Saturday night, on the heels of a 96-90 loss in Houston Friday, underlined their current problems, just as the three victories in Chicago, Seattle and Oakland displayed their basic strengths.

Miss Renee Jan Brody, a candidate for a master's degree in fine arts at Columbia University, and Laurence Howard Kahn, a student at the Columbia Law School, were married here this afternoon. Rabbis Joachin Prinz and Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony in Temple B'nai Abraham. Mrs. Laurence H. Kahn, was Renee Jan Brody.

Miss Sara Beth Honig, a senior at Finch College, was married here yesterday to Gregory Paul Terhune, who will graduate next month from the New York City Police Academy. Jewish and Roman Catholic ceremonies were performed in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company plans capital expenditures of some $300-million in 1974, following its rec ord investment of $278-millior in 1973, Richard A. Riley, president and chief executive, told shareholders at the annual meeting in Akron, Ohio, or Saturday. He said the company would continue to expand its radial tire production capacity and increase manufacturing capabicities in a variety of other fields:

" You wouldn't believe the people who know about this school now," said Bob Fazio, a basketball star at Edward Williams College, a junior college affiliate of Fairleigh Dickinson University. "They used to say, 'Edward what?'"

Elvin Hayes scored 20 points and hauled down 21 rebounds tonight as the Capital Bullets defeated the Houston Rockets, 111-105. HOUSTON (105)-TomJanovich 9 4.5 22; Coleman 4 2-2 10; Meely 6 0-C 12; Newlin 9 0.1 18; Ratleff 4 1-1 9; Smith 5 2-2 12; Marin 8 4-4 20; Guokas 1 0-0 2. Total46 13.15.

The military Reserves could be trimmed by about one-third and still meet essential commitments, according to a study made public today by the Brookings Institution. In urging a reduction of about 300,000 men in the present force of 900,000, the study estimates that a streamlining could reduce defense spending by $1.4 billion a year.

The Rev. Dr. Charles B. Foelsch, pastor of Christ Luthern Church, 355 East 19th Street, since 1966, and earlier of Holy Trinity Church, Central Park West and 65th Street, died Saturday at the Cabrini Health Care Center. He was 82 years old and lived at 450 East 20th Street. Dr. Foelsch had been president of the Chicago Lutheran Theological Seminary and later of the Pacific Lutheran Theological Seminary at Berkeley, Calif.

A pilot program that seeks out victims of violent crime in the Bronx and assumes responsibility for getting them medical, financial and social aid has opened at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. The program, the Crime Victims Service Center, is said to be the first of its kind in the city. It is being financed by a $300,000 grant from the Criminal Justice Coordinating Council of the Mayor's office.

Centenary defeated Lamar Tech, 83-65, Saturday night in Beaumont, Tex. There were about 3,000 people at the game, no national television or publicity. Hardly anyone cared about the outcome except for the student bodies of the schools and some people in Shreveport, La., and Beaumont. Centenary and Notre Dame are the only undefeated major college basketball teams in the nation. The Gentlemen have won 12 games and are not in the national rankings.

Christian Neureuther of West Germany won his second straight World Cup slalom today in the Lauberhorn races. Bob Cochran of Richmond, Vt., turned in his best performance of the season, placing fourth. Neureuther, a medical student from Partenkirchen, had an aggregate time of 1 minute 3223 seconds for the two runs of 59 gates each. Gustav Thoeni, Italy's World Cup holder led the field after the first run, but he fell in the second heat.

William H. Brayer, who retired in 1964 as executive vice president of Cone Mills, textile manufacturer, died Friday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street. Mr. Brayer was a director of the Rob Roy Company, manufacturers of boys' shirts, and a former director of Spartan Industries.

All of the city's 947 schools were scheduled to open this morning-some buildings still dirty, but most now warm enough-after members of two custodial unions voted overwhelmingly yesterday to end the strikes that had virtually shut down the school system last week.

In his radio address on the oil shortage, President Nixon pledged to do "everything in my power to prevent the big oil companies and other major energy producers from making an unconscionable profit out of this crisis." But the steps he is proposing are more in the nature of window dressing than the long-overdue reform of the taxation of the oil industry's domestic and foreign earnings.

All of the city's 947 schools were scheduled to open this morning-some buildings still dirty, but most now warm enough-after members of two custodial unions voted overwhelmingly yesterday to end the strikes that had virtually shut down the school system last week.

Chief Justice Burger believes that at least one-third of the 375,000 lawyers in the country are not competent to argue a case in court. He urges basic revision in legal education and certification to establish more exacting standards for trial practice. A similarly low estimate of the caliber of many practitioners comes from Chief Judge Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for this busy circuit.

To the Editor: After reading your Jan. 10 editorial "Governor's Non-Message," I turned to another page for the complete text. This is a much appreciated luxury frequently available to your readers. Then, staying with the same issue I read the Albany dispatch by Francis X. Clines and the comments entitled "Birth of a Campaign," by Frank Lynn. These are good pieces and furnish a picture substantially at variance with the editorial.

The Soviet Union has announced that in 1973 it became world's leading producer of chemical fertilizer, surpassing the United States for the first time. The contention, made by the Minister of the Chemical Industry, comes at a time when American industry, through the Occidental Petroleum Corportion, is preparing to implement an $8-billion, 20-year deal to develop Soviet fertilizer production further.

State Senator John J. Marchi, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, will ask the seven appointees to the State Correction Commission to appear before the committee before their appointments are confirmed. Six of the seven are currently members of the commission who have been reappointed.

In what many court observers regard as a display of political acumen, Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel last week reached back to a proposal advanced 12 months ago and set up the post of state administrative judge.

Roger Guedes, a 20-yearold Brazilian studying engineering at Hampton Institute, upset first-seeded John James of Australia, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4, in the fourth round of the New York State men's indoor tennis championship today at the Cove Racquet Club. Tom Dughi of Essex Fells, N.J., seeded 10th, was also upset, losing to Lou Monte of West Hempstead, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6.

A crowd of 12,653 turned out at Nassau Coliseum today to watch the New York Nets and the Kentucky Colonels battle for control of first place in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division. Julius Erving of the Nets scoring a layup against Artis Gilmore of Kentucky in the second period at the Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., yesterday. Nets lost, 106-105.

THE CHIEF AWARDS Children's Hunter Championship--Champion, Amy Weiss's Gllnockys Britas Bay, 8 points; reserve, tie between Hans Richter's Gwyredd Ask Me and Marie Debaney's Billy Blastoff, 6 each. Medal Class--Irene Jaffee, Norwalk, Conn. Maclay Trophy--Carolyn Evans, Weston, Conn.

Centenary defeated Lamar Tech, 83-65, Saturday night in Beaumont, Tex. There were about 3,000 people at the game, no national television or publicity. Hardly anyone cared about the outcome except for the student bodies of the schools and some people in Shreveport, La., and Beaumont.

The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching announced yesterday the formation of a permanent panel to examine higher education in the nation and help develop policies in the field. The group, known as the Carnegie Council on Policy Studies in Higher Education, will be headed by Dr. Clark Kerr, who had served as chairman of the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education.

Mayor Robert Cahill will ask the city council tomorrow night for a resolution proclaiming Digger Phelps Week. It was the city's way of honoring its favorite son, the Notre Dame basketball coach, whose team defeated the University of California, Los Angeles, yesterday and halted the Bruins' 88-game winning streak.

A 13-year-old boy and two 15-year-olds were arrested yesterday and charged with stabbing a 17-year-old subway passenger to death Friday afternoon. Detectives of the Bronx homicide squad, working with Transit Authority investigators, arrested the suspects at their homes on the basis of information provided by witnesses to the fatal stabbing of Jose Ramirez.

When the models came skipping down the runway in Geoffrey Beene's showroom the other day in sheer voile shirts with nothing underneath, there weren't any audible gasps because, Left: Shirt styling is extended to dress length in floating tent with billowing sleeves and cool neckline, by Geoffrey Beene. Right: Kimberly's full skirt is pleated and its belted top has a cool, scooped neckline.

The energy squeeze has aggravated the fertilizer crunch in food hungry Asia and, even with conservation measures, the expected shortfall will cut down Asian harvests in rice alone by as much as seven million metric tons, according to experts in the region. The shortages developing could easily exceed 200,000 metric tons of nitrogen for 1974 and over 300,000 for 1975," said Paul Stangel, a United States Agency for International Development adviser on fertilizer marketing.

Carol Vadnais and Ken Hodge knocked in two goals apiece tonight as the Boston Bruins beat the Los Angeles Kings, 5-2, running their National Hockey League home record to 20. victories and two ties in 23 games.

Flight controllers puzzled over a continually faltering stabilization device aboard Skylab 3 today. The space station's controlling gyroscope No. 2, one of only two good ones still working to keep the lab in the right position in orbit, momentarily slowed down three times today. It also stumbled in its work three times yesterday.

Senator Hugh Scott said today that he had information that would clear President Nixon of any wrongdoing- in some aspects of the Watergate scandals. The Senate Republican leader made the statement during a television interview but declined to say what the information was. Senator Hugh Scott facing news cameras yesterday.

A ranking official of the Lubavitcher movement--the Worldwide body of Hasidic Jews--sharply criticized yesterday the Hasidic episodes on the Public Broadcasting Service's "Religious America" series for failing to depict the "widespread influence of the Chabad-Lubavitch philosophy" on the mainstream of Jewish religious life.

The Committee for Economic Development, expressing its "deep concern about the erosion of public confidence in the democratic process," urged President Nixon today to "re-establish the integrity of the Presidential office." The committee describes itself as "a nonprofit, nonpolitical research and policy organization of 200 corporate and university executives. Its board chairman is Emilio G. Collado, executive vice president of the Exxon Corporation.

The Beethoven that Washington's National Symphony Orchestra emphasized in a program given over to that composer's music yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall was the monumental sculptor, not the Romantic tone painter. In the Piano Concerto No. 3 in C minor, splendidly played by the soloist, Peter Frankl, the orchestra under Antal Dorati set the basic style and the pianist contributed graceful variations.

A study of 149 major American companies with full-time consumer affairs departments concludes that these departments "represent a positive approach to the same forces giving rise to the consumerism movement."

Cardinal Cooke, making his first appearance in the pulpit of St. Thomas Episcopal Church as Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, blessed and dedicated yesterday a new stained-glass window containing a portrait of the late Pope John XXIII. The service, witnessed by nearly 1,000 worshippers, marked the city's formal observance of the annual Week of Prayer for Christian Unity, which began last Thursday.

PARIS-"I don't care a hoot about the quarreling of the experts. I remain very small," wrote Wolfgang Schulze - better known as Wols-some 30 years ago. Wolfgang Schulze--Wols--pioneered role, in Old World, attributed to Pollock In the New

A Federal Court judge in Alabama, in a landmark decision that may help American women everywhere, has ruled that a housewife is not automatically liable for Federal income taxes simply because she signs a joint tax return.

The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

Firemen, using thousands of gallons of foam flown in from six states, subdued today a blaze on a wrecked oil tanker that blocked shipping near the mouth 'of the Mississippi River. The tanker Key Trader, which collided with Norwegian freighter Baune in Mississippi River south of New Orleans Friday, as firemen yesterday fought remaining fires.

Top-secret messages intended for Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker or other high civilian officials in Saigon were routinely passed on to the Joint Chiefs of Staff, says a man who worked as a document coordinator in South Vietnam. Steven M. Davis, 23 years old, said in an interview that it was common practice at the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation communications center in Saigon for such messages to be retransmitted to Adm.

Arnold Schoenberg and Charles Ives, two of the greatest creators in modern music, were born in 1874, and Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, the Gregg Smith Singers gave the first concert we have had celebrating their centenary. It must be said that the celebration began with some of the most challenging works Schoenberg and Ives wrote; their choral music is incredibly difficult. Gregg Smith conducting

Mayor Beame yesterday appointed Robert A. Low-a Councilman from 1961 to 1969 and author of the city's airpolution-control law-as Environmental Protection Administrator. Herbert Elish, who has been serving as Administrator and as Sanitation Commissioner, "has agreed to continue as Sanitation Commissioner through the winter months," Mr. Beame reported.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the first major copper company to report on its performance in 1973, announced yesterday sharply higher income for the fourth quarter and the year. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, the company's net income climbed to $46.6 million, or $1.41 a share, compared with income of $25.2-million, or 76 cents a share, before extraordinary charges, in the fourth quarter of 1972.

New Yorkers overwhelmingly reject the idea that their city is ungovernable and should be broken up, although those who live in the four outer boroughs very much resent what they believe to be the domination of Manhattan.

The Iraqi press agency said today that Arab oilproducing countries were expected to resume normal production of petroleum and to cancel their embargo on shipments to the United States in view of the Egyptian-Israeli disengagement accord. Reporting from Cairo, the agency said the decisions would be made at a meeting of 10 Arab oil ministers scheduled for the Egyptian capital on Tuesday.

A gunman invaded Delmonico's Hotel in midtown last night and robbed and shot the vice president of a philanthropic group that had just concluded its annual charity dinner. The official, Dimitri Galitzine, of the Russian Nobility Association, was about to descend the stairway from the hotel's grand ballroom with other dinner guests when the man approached him at about 8:30 P.M.
When Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan and his entourage left Jakarta for Tokyo Thursday morning, they had to slip away like cowboys who have been told by the sheriff to get out of town before

Elvin Hayes scored 20 points and hauled down 21 rebounds tonight as the Capital Bullets defeated the Houston Rockets, 111-105. Mike Riordan paced the Bullet attack with 27 points and Archie Clark added 23 for the Central Division leaders. Wes Unseld matched Hayes's total of 21 rebounds.

President Nixon is expected to change the Jan. 29 date for his State of the Union Address to Congress because of a conflict with a Washington dinner honoring the returning members of Congress. Mr. Nixon was considering the change because, on the same evening, the Washington Press Club is scheduled to hold an annual dinner at which representatives of the three branches of the Government are to speak.

What started the whole thing was my wife's orthopedic surgery. The result for her: seven weeks of plaster and crutches. For me: seven weeks in which-with a little help from our friends-I kept house. It is tempting to say that I faced this prospect with apprehension, having read the allegations of certain militant feminists that housekeeping (a) occupies the Average American Housewife for approximately eighty hours a week and (b) is degrading.

Hugo Nindl of.Austria won the slalom today completing a two-day sweep of the McDonald Cup at Buck Hill and moving into a commanding lead in the over-all standing of the professional ski circuit. He has 145 points. Nindl beat Spider Sabich in the final when Sabich faltered and skied off the course. Nindl, who won the giant slalom yesterday, took home $8,000 over the weekend, increasing his total to $19,400.

Government investigators have been told by two lawyers for President Nixon that the lawyers "back-dated" his VicePresidential papers to the National Archives in 1969, according to the current issue of Newsweek. The donation of Mr. Nixon's Vice-Presidential papers resulted in a $576,000 tax reduction for the President.

The Daily News announced yesterday that it would install the country's first six-page-wide printing presses, in a prototype experiment designed to increase production by 50 per cent. Conventional - newspaper presses are four pages wide. The News is America's largest-circulation newspaper, with a daily circulation of more than two million and a Sunday circulation of three million.

A cleaning lady comes into my office every evening, empties the wastebasket, wipes out an ashtray, makes a pass at some dust with a rag and is gone. We nod at each other with some civility, and say "Happy New Year" at the appropriate time, but I am not moved to inquire into her life, and her interest in my work extends only to hoping I do not make too much of a mess.
Postal Workers at the Jersey City bulk-mail facility, which sorts all incoming mail for New York City and parts of New Jersey, plan to protest a planned change in their work schedules tomorrow.

A new plan to ease the work load of the Supreme Court without limiting litigants' access to its review has been drafted by a committee of the American Bar Association. The proposal represents an alternative to creation of a new national court of appeals to screen out 90 per cent of the high court's cases, which was recommended over a year ago by a committee appointed by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger.
White most of the attention has been focused on the Democratic gubernatorial and Senate candidates, a half dozen or more Democrats have been playing host at receptions for

The National Association of Broadcasters has said that a suggestion for broadcast stations to reduce their hours on the air to conserve energy "would not be in the national interest." The suggestion was made by Herbert G. Klein, former White House director of communications.

Tom Johnson is probably best known as the new-music critic for The Village Voice. But he is also a composer, and he is next-best known for a series of concerts over the last year devoted to his theatrical music -either quietly theatrical, as in his "Four Note Opera," or slyly theatrical, as in his various efforts that involve theatrics in their performance.

Like initiates coming to hear master, New Yorkers are gathering to listen to John E. Zuccotti, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, and members of his staff unravel the complexities of the city's zoning laws.

The strange case of the admirals, the yeoman and the Kissinger files is beginning to appear as silly as the Watergate "caper"-and perhaps as serious. More questions were raised than answered by the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Admiral Moorer, when he acknowledged publicly that he was a receiver of purloined White House documents.

The Florida Mining Materials Corporation said yesterday it had signed a contact with the J. A. Jones Construction Company for construction of a 3-million barrel cement mill representing a total investment of approximately $35-million. It would be located near Brookville, Fla., on a company site and is expected to be operating In the latter part of 1975.

Marine Midland Banks, Inc., a statewide New York bank holding company, reported a drop in fourth-quarter and fullyear operating earnings, and a sharp decline in the profit margin and rate of return on its stockholders' equity for 1973.

Life as seen from the vantage point of a consumer protection official in the metropolitan region is a series of shady deals, cornercutting and downright illegality. And more and more, the state, city or county consumer offices - relatively recent arrivals on the governmental scene - as well as some Federal offices, are the places where put-upon and frustrated consumers are finding a sympathetic ear and a willingness to act in their behalf.
Willie Wise scored 28 points, including a basket with four seconds left, to give the Utah Stars a 113112 American Basketball Association victory over the Carolina Cougars tonight.

The city and the negotiating committee of the largest municipal union here accepted the recommendations yesterday of an impasse panel for a new three-year contract covering employment conditions for 130,000 city employes.

The Assembly today passed and sent to the Senate a bill that would automatically reduce automobile-insurance premiums for cars equipped with air bags as soon as statistics show that the bags actually reduce passenger injuries.

Six men, including three who have served on Community School Board 5 in Harlem, were charged yesterday with using and attempting to use public funds in the school-board election campaign of three of the men.

Herbert L. Porter, former scheduling director for the Committee for the Re-election of the President, waived today a formal indictment on a charge of lying to the F.B.I. and is apparently prepared to admit his guilt.

WASHINGTON-A year ago today Americans watching the nightly news broadcasts saw television commentators pick up the red emergency telephones and repeat the bulletin from Texas: Lyndon Baines Johnson, 36th President of the United States, was dead.

Nicholas Brady has been chairman of the Jockey Club for a week now, and no changes have been made in thoroughbred racing by that distinguished group. And the chances are that any change, when it does come, will be after much consideration on the part of the new chairman.
In a private ceremony in his City Hall office, Mayor Beame yesterday swore in Moses L. Kove as chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission-for the second time.
The Skylab 3 astronauts photographed a Mississippi cotton patch today in an experimental effort to give farmers a better yield from each acre they plant.

Striking warehousemen and porters ratified a new three-year contract yesterday and ended their five-day wildcat walkout at the Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx. The 1,600 members of Local 202 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters began returning to work at noon. Supplies of fruit and vegetables began leaving the market by nightfall.

The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a free speech case involving pretrial publicity by a controversial lawyer but refused to review another in which a protest administrator was convicted for disturbing a Billy Graham rally.

President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger briefed Congressional leaders on Mr. Kissinger's 10-day Middle East trip, including unpublished details that helped produce the Egyptian-Israeli agreement on separation of troops along the Suez Canal. The Congressmen were given a generally optimistic outlook by Mr. Kissinger. [1:8.]

Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union took a two-game lead over Robert Byrne of the United States yesterday by winning the fourth game of their quarter-finals chess match in San Juan, P.R., one of four matches under way to determine who will challenge Bobby Fischer for the world championship next year.

Mrs. Ann Klein, Governor Byrne's nominee to be State Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies, missed her scheduled confirmation by the Senate today because she had not yet filed the complete financial disclosure required 'by the new administration.
The three leading aluminum companies had good news for their stockholders yesterday as each reported major gains in net income for 1973.

Boris Spassky showed all his old fire in pulling off a startling speculative queen sacrifice leading to his victory over me in the third game of our quarterfinals candidates match. The first two games were draws, so Spassky needed two more victories to take the match. If neither player achieves a three-point lead after 16 games, whoever is ahead wins.
Mrs. Edna Robinson Musnik, for many years vice president and director of the scholarship and welfare fund of the Hunter College Alumni Association,died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital.

President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger briefed Congressional leaders on Mr. Kissinger's 10-day Middle East trip, including unpublished details that helped produce the Egyptian-Israeli agreement on separation of troops along the Suez Canal. The Congressmen were given a generally optimistic outlook by Mr. Kissinger. [1:8.]

The 93d Congress returns for its second session to face a more distasteful task than any Congress has confronted since the 40th wrestled with the fate of Andrew Johnson. The question of whether or not to oust the President of United States is bound to fix the climate on Capitol Hill for months to come--unless Mr. Nixon should suddenly decide to make his whole Administration "inoperative."

The day-old Off Broadway theater strike ended yesterday as Actors Equity Association and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers agreed to submit their salary difference to binding arbitration.

Walt Frazier went from Phoenix, Ariz., where tne team played Saturday night, to Southern Illinois University, where his college uniform number (52) was retired in ceremonies between halves of the game against Florida State last night. Frazier played on the 1967 Saluki team that won the National Invitation Tournament.

Richard Walker Bolling once wrote that a political leader "must be willing to accept less than 100 per cent, but if he is convinced 50 per cent will not solve the problem, he must have the courage to say so and to see his carefully nurtured legislative effort temporarily fail."
Reliable sources said today that military authorities had rounded up 10 persons and accused them of trying to restore the deposed President George Papadopoulos.

Adm. Hyman G. Rickover has married a Navy commander he met some months ago when he was a patient at Bethesda Naval Hospital and she was his nurse. The marriage, revealed yesterday by the bride's father, took place Saturday in a Chicago suburb.

A 50-pound mountain lion killed and partly devoured an 8-year-old boy yesterday on a hike with his younger stepbrother, the state police reported. The victim was Kenneth Clark Nolan, stepson of a state policeman, David Cordry, who lives about five miles south of this northern New Mexico community.

Steel production for the week ended Jan. 19 rose by 1.8 per cent to 2,887,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index rose to 118.3 from 116.2 in the preceding week when production totaled 2,835,000 tons.
Colin C. Carpi, taking the witness stand in his own defense, testified in a crowded courtroom today that he had absolutelyy nothing" to do with the murder of his estranged wife, Laura.
The finance ministers of five members of the European Economic Community decided tonight to keep their currencies in a joint iloat and improve consultations on monetary and economic policy.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has asserted that the Soviet Union would benefit by allowing free discussion of the penal system abuses detailed in his controversial new book, "The Gulag Archipelago, 1918-1956."
" Are we choking on democracy?" asked a lecturer at prestigious Chulalongkorn Univer-j sity recently. His answer was a qualified "Yes" and an ap-, peal for moderation in student activism in Thailand.

A man was found stabbed to death last night in a self-service elevator at a building on West End Avenue, apparently a victim of a robbery. The police said that they found $612 in cash in the dead man's coat pocket, but that the man's wallet was missing.

Amid expressions of optimism over the city's economic future, a new administrationsponsored coalition of business, labor and civic leaders was formed by Mayor Beame yesterday and charged with the task of keeping established businesses in, and attracting new business to. the city.

Taking advantage of the St. Louis Symphony's visit to New York, the St. Louis Quartet, staffed by the orchestra's principal string players, made its local debut late Sunday afternoon at the New School.

Alengthy criticism of the state's Job Development Authority as an agency that overstated its accomplishments while incurring excessive costs in making loans to industry was issued today by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

PIEDMONT, Calif. - By 10:30 or 11 o'clock at night the house quiets down and, as the wind blows through the towering redwoods that shade the big Spanish house, Dorothy and Robert DeBolt ease finally into the peace and silence of being along.

The first of 20 new bar cars for the New Haven division of the Penn Central was unveiled yesterday on a brief wellstocked run to New Rochelle, One or two of the cars, called cafe cars by the railroad, are expected to be in service by Feb. 1, and the rest by next spring.
Communist insurgents fired four rockets into the center of Phnom Penh today, killing two people and wounding eight, the military command reported.

The spectators crowd into the Nassau County Courthouse for the rare case of a doctor accused of murdering a patient. And the drama is intensified because the District Attorney is trying his first case in 12 years.
All Kraft macaroni and cheese dinners suspected of being tainted with food poisoning have been traced to eight states, the manufacturer and the Food and Drug Administration said today.

A suggestion for simplifying the maze of service-district lines that confronts New Yorkers-for city departments such as police, sanitation, hospitals was offered yesterday by the State Charter Study Commission.

Close to a majority of Americans believe President Nixon should be impeached if he is found to have been negligent in taking care of the Watergate tapes, the Harris Survey reported yesterday, according to United Press International.

The word that troubled duPont Walston, Inc., was seeking to sell its assets to two or more stronger firms adds emphasis to the efforts of a task force that will suggest amendments to the Federal Securities Investor Protection Act.

Commissioner James J. Sheeran of the State Department of Insurance ordered all automobile insurance companies in New Jersey today to reduce their rates by as much as 20 per cent for vehicles participating in car pools.
President Nixon will deliver his State of the Union message to Congress the night of Jan. 30, the White House announced today.
DuPont Walston, Inc., the Wall Street concern that operates the nation's second largest network of stock-brokerage offices, announced yesterday that it plans to quit the securities business.

In the downstairs room at Jimmy's restaurant yesterday, Henry Aaron sat at a small table with his bride, Billye, as the man from Magnavox addressed the news conference. "We're happy to announce," the man said, "a long-term, comprehensive association with Henry Aaron that will mean $1-million to him over a period of the next five years."

Recapitalization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad has been completed with the issuance of new preferred and common stock, the Alleghany Corporation, the Missouri Pacific Railroad and the Mississippi River Corporation of St. Louis announced jointly yesterday.
The Department of Transportation has proposed that tire and motor vehicle equipment manufacturers should have to file reports of safety defects in their products.

Eli Goldston, chairman and chief executive officer of Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates, who was a leading proponent of corporate responsibility for social welfare, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his Cambridge home. His age was 53.

Findings in a study conducted by a University of Pennsylvania anthropologist indicate that United States white students score higher on intelligence tests than nonwhites because of environmental factors rather than genetics.

Life as seen from the vantage point of a consumer protection official in the metropolitan region is a series of shady deals, cornercutting and downright illegality. And more and more, the state, city or county consumer offices - relatively recent arrivals on the governmental scene - as well as some Federal offices, are the places where put-upon and frustrated consumers are finding a sympathetic ear and a willingness to act in their behalf.
The Defense Department said today that it had cautioned the Seventh Fleet not to get involved in the fighting between South Vietnam and China for control of the Paracel Islands.

Post offices across the country are adequately stocked with 8cent stamps to meet customer needs during the two-month delay in implementing the 10cent, first-class letter rate, according to a spokesman for the United States Postal Service.
OPERA ORCHESTRA OF NEW YORK With Schola Cantorum and Renato Bruson, baritone; Nlcolai Gedda, tenor; Chrlstlane Eda-Pierre, soprano; John West, bass. Conducted by Eve Queler. At Carnegie Hall.
The Soviet Union, in apparent retaliation against China, today expelled a young Chinese diplomat accused of spying, foreign Communist sources said here.

The Norfolk Western Railway--one of the most profitable of the nation's rail carriers--reported yesterday a 15 per cent drop in its earnings in the fourth quarter of 1973. For the full year, however, the road's net income rose by 5 per cent to $68.3-million, or $8.29 a share.
DuPont Walston, Inc., the Wall Street concern that operates the nation's second largest network of stock-brokerage offices, announced yesterday that it plans to quit the securities business.
The House Democratic leader, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, said today that President Nixon's resignation "would be in the
GustavoThoeni of Italy captured the World Cup giant slalom race today, but runner-up Piero Gros, also of Italy, took the lead in the Cup standing with 120 points.

The energy crisis has brought no shortage of suggestions for the Middle East oil producers about how they should handle their wealth. Yesterday, David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, proposed that they might use a sizable part of the dollar funds they were now accumulating for development projects in their own areas.

The commander of the Israeli forces in the October war traded charges publicly today with the war's most popular hero. The hero, Maj. Gen. Ariel Sharon, protested that the Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, had ended his appointment as a reserve division commander as "a purely political act." General Sharon,
Rain-swept Wall Street was trying yesterday to digest the news that mammoth duPont Walston, Inc., an amalgam among amalgams, is seeking to get out of the securities business after
Mayor Beame announced yesterday that Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, would serve in a new unsalaried post as special adviser on labor relations.

Two teams of top-ranked experts tied for first place in the Grand National qualifying contest played in Flushing, Queens, during the weekend. More important than winning, however, was qualifying for the knockout stages, which begin here Feb. 23.
Receiving general anesthesia during the first two years of life may be a factor in predisposing children to develop asthma or hay fever, a team of specialists told a medical meeting today.
If there is one team in the National Hockey League that the Islanders pride themselves in picking on, it's the California Golden Seals, who play the New Yorkers at 7:35 tonight at Nassau Coliseum.
Corporate bond prices were lower yesterday in moderate trading. Government issues also lost some ground but the taxexempt list showed little change in advance of this week's heavy calendar.
Marty Liquori won't put his trust in "rabbits" this week, even if it means missing the first sub-four-minute Wanamaker Mile Friday night at Madison Square Garden.
Is there anything Henry Kissinger cannot do? Several things, according to his agent, Rollo Whipple, who is in charge of booking Mr. Kissinger around the world.
" We want clean government," said one student after another. "If the top is clean and not corrupt, then the people below will also be clean." Who at the top is corrupt? they were asked.
The state said today it would prove that the alleged slaying of a terminally ill cancer patient by Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano at the Nassau County Medical Center was "a murder of convenience."
A 21-year-old Bronx man pleaded guilty yesterday to ??aping an 83-year-old woman luring an alleged campaign of error in an apartment buildng last summer.
The White Houte acknowledged today that all members of the White House staff had been told to report all contacts with the news media to the press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler.

H. Ross Perot, the wiry Texas millionaire who has pumped almost $100-million into Wall Street, apparently in a losing cause, was remonstrating with a visitor last March about his critics in the financial community.
The Supreme 'Court agreed today to decide whether the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad must pay "set off" claims when it sues to collect back debts outside the bankruptcy court in Philadelphia.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka, just back from a tumultuous tour through Southeast Asia, said today that he and his compatriots "should give ear humbly to reasonable criticisms against Japan, correct what we should correct and improve our mutual relationships with a long-range perspective."

The Network Project, a New York-based watchdog organization, brought suit in Washington yesterday against the Federal Communications Commission, challenging its decision to permit construction of domestic communications satellite systems by some of the nation's largest communications and aerospace corporations.
Edmund Blunden, the poet and writer, died last night at his home near Sudbury, Suffolk. He was 77 years old. A prolific writer, Mr. Blunden published many volumes of poetry and prose.

Officials said today that $1.7-million worth of cotton was destroyed by fire that swept through 62 cars of a freight train that derailed on a curve in a canyon before dawn yesterday. There were no injuries to the five-man crew.
John L. Sullivan of Olympia, Wash., kept his undefeated record intact tonight, stopping Dino Del Cid of Panama in the fifth round of a scheduled 10-round middleweight fight at the Felt Forum.
Like most employed Off Broadway actors, Antony Tenuta was not happy about the Actors Equity strike against the producers but supported his union's demand for higher salaries. "If only,"
Public school systems cannot force female teachers to take maternity leave months before they expect to give birth, the Supreme Court ruled today.

Two Mount Sinai Hospital doctors who fed baboons the equivalent of a fifth of liquor every day for up to four years have shown that cirrhosis and other liver damage results directly from the toxic effects of alcohol, not from a concurrent poor diet, as generations of medical students have been taught.

The importance of these days to the peoples of the Middle East is not found in the details of military disengagement now taking place on the banks of the Suez Carnal. What is significant is that Israel and its most powerful Arab neighbor have, for the first time, entered into a contract to co-exist.

The transit police and Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx accused the Transit Authority yesterday of permitting an illegal din in the subways that matched the clamor of a close-up jackhammer.
A pregnant young mother, her husband and their 2-yearold son, struggled with the Brooklyn and Queens subway lines last night trying to get to a hospital in time, but they did not make it.

The Xerox Corporation continued its record-breaking sales and earnings for the entire year and the final quarter last year, the annual report showed yesterday. The final quarter was the highest for any three-month period in its history.
A Seattle pathologist proposed today that hardening of the arteries might start in a manner similar to cancer, with a change in cells that causes them to grow into tumors.

Whittaker Moppie, a 38-foot Bertram, took first place in Saturday's Jockey Club-Sea Talk ocean race. Sammy James, the driver, and Jack Stuteville, copilot, covered the 200-mile course from Miami to the Florida Keys at an average speed of 72 miles an hour, beating Billy Martin of Clark Township, N. J., by 30 seconds.
Talks between the New York Stock Exchange and the Pacific Stock Exchange on merging some of their facilities, initiated with high hopes nearly a year ago, have apparently faded away.

Oil is the latest point of contention in the rivalry between the Soviet Union and China. Moscow, which has been negotiating long and hard with the Japanese for a huge 20year oil deal, sharply denounced Chinese efforts to lure away Japanese customers.

To the Editor: I am somewhat dismayed to read that many Americans are reluctant to accept the idea of impeachment because of its possible traumatic effect on the country. This seems to me a shortsighted and potentially dangerous attitude.

Vito (Babe) Parlill and Mike Giddings were named yesterday to head coaching jobs in the new World Football League. The 43-year-old Parilli, a pro quarterback for 16 years and assistant coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers for the last three seasons, will be the head coach of the Boston Bulls.

In the matter of corrupt election practices, an attitude of "everybody does it" is as unacceptable an excuse for corporations as for politicians. That is the heart of a report just issued by the Committee for Economic Development, which makes it clear that the system of representative government as well as of free enterprise is indeed being jeopardized by prostitution of the political process.
The Georgia Society for the prevention of Cruelty to Animals is investigating the deaths of 70 cottontail rabbits, found dead in their shipping crates at the Atlanta airport this weekend.

President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger-briefed Congressional leaders today on Mr. Kissinger 10-day Middle East trip, including unpublished detaiis that helped produce the Egyptian-Israeli agreement on separation of troops along--the Suez Canal.

The French franc lost 4 per cent of its value against the dollar today and the price of gold soared to record levels, above $140 an ounce, following France's announcement Saturday that it would let the franc float.

A spot check of brokers yesterday suggested that only moderate public interest had materialized for the bonds of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority in the wake of an underwriting agreement signed last Friday.
Robert H. Finch, a former White House adviser, saying the Watergate scandal would obscure the issues, decided today against running for Governor or the United States Senate this year in California.

A scheduled visit to Cuba by the Soviel Communist party leader, Leo nid I. Brezhnev, is now expected to begin Jan. 28 or 29 according to sources close tc his delegation. Some Westerr diplomats expect Mr. Brezhnev to use the occasion for a gathering of Communist lead ers from Latin America.
Federal civil complaints were filed here yesterday seeking court injunctions and financial penalties against five gasoline stations accused of charging excessive prices.
Four health bills, including three authorizing a total of $533.2-million, were overwhelmingly approved by the House today despite some objections by the Nixon Administration.
Rear Adm. Lewis L. Strauss, U.S.N., retired, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, died yesterday of cancer at his- home, Brandy Rock Farm, in Brandy Station, Va. He was 77 years old.
Personnel agencies specializing in advertising people may not be all that pessimistic, but a check with major ad agencies makes it plain enough that this is no time for job-hunting.

What has happened to "The Petrified Forest" now that it has been petrified? It has become hilarious--a lovely laughable, but technically moderately adroit melodrama like "Marie Marten, or The Murder in the Red Barn."

Jonnny Miller, winner of the first three 1974 Professional Golfers' Association tournaments, said he would pass up the Andy Williams tourney in San Diego this week and try to get rid of a cold. "Four in a row is nice and everything,"
All academic activity at Concordia Seminary of St. Louis was halted today by a student strike in protest over the suspension of the school's president, the Rev. Dr. John H. Tietjen.

The official line was that Frank McGuire, the South Carolina coach, came to New York yesterday to help promote the ticket sales for his nationally ranked team's appearance in Thursday and Saturday night college basketball double-headers at Madison Square Garden.
The New York Giants are tired of Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City and they're looking for another in-season training facility, General manager Andy Robustelli said today.

Dartmouth College announced yesterday a new approach to student loans designed to ease the increasingly heavy borrowing burden on students, especially those from middle-income families who rarely qualify for existing forms of financial aid.
The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today that it had decided to exempt most manufacturers of birth control pills from putting their pills in child-proof packages.

Vito (Babe) Parilli and Mike Giddings were named yesterday to head coaching jobs in the new World Football League. The 43-year-old Parilli, a pro quarterback for 16 years and assistant coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers for the last three seasons, will be the head coach of the Boston Bulls.
Should the United States be able to fight a nuclear war as well as deter one? That question has been raised by Secretary
Many car seats designed for young children are dangerously inadequate though they pass the Federal Government's safety standard, Consumers Union charged today.

C.B.S. News did some muckraking in its own backyard on Sunday night's "60 Minutes" program. Mike Wallace's report on press junkets-which named his own network, the Columbia Broadcasting System, as a giver of free trips to the press, and its leading anchorman, Walter Cronkite, as one who has accepted junkets in the past-reverberated within the company yesterday.

Jeff Fosnes, a sophomore, scored 20 points to pace a balanced Vanderbilt scoring attack tonight as the seventh-ranked Commodores crushed Tennessee, 82-65, in a Southeastern Conference basketball game.

" Bill Moyers' Journal," switching this week to Tuesday evenings at 8 on the Public Broadcasting Service, has been expanded to an hour tonight as a special for a broad examination of "The Question of Impeachment." Mr. Moyers, calmly but crisply, considers three questions: What is impeachment? What constitutes an impeachable offense? And is the 37th President of the United States a proper target for impeachment proceedings?
The $100,000 United States pro tennis championships lost eight seeded players by withdrawals and three others by defeats today.
The Pentagon said today it had temporarily halted its investigation of alleged military spying on the White House office of Henry A. Kissihger in 1971.

Activity at the Jersey City bulk-mail facility virtually came to a halt here today amidst a bitter dispute between United States Postal Service officials and the Metro Area Postal Union over changes in employee work schedules due to be implemented this week.
The House Democratic leader, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, said today that President Nixon's resignation "would be in the...
Finance Minister Takeo Fukudawarned Japan today to brace for a "year of ordeal" in fighting inflation and trying to reverse deep deficits in the balance of payments.

Ross Corbit, president of Hiram Walker, Inc., from 1948 until his retirement in 1964, and a former vice president and director of the parent distilling organization, Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., of Walkerville, Ontario, died here Saturday at the age of 74.
Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz raised no objection today to France's decision to float the franc and let her exchange rate decline.
There will be more Diplomats in the nation's capital in 1974 and they will all operate out of Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.
Finance Minister Takeo Fukudawarned Japan today to brace for a "year of ordeal" in fighting inflation and trying to reverse deep deficits in the balance of payments.

Executives of the seven largest oil companies, representing half the sales of the United States petroleum industry, strove today to convince skeptical Senate investigators that the energy crisis is real and that they did not contrive it.
Mrs. Beatrice Ashe Maher, widow of Vice Admiral James Maher, died yesterday in the Camelot convalescent home. She was 76 years old.

The Houston Rockets are still trying to sell pro basketball in football country and not having much success. They are the worst draw in the National Basketball Association with an average home attendance of 4,100.

The use of solar energy to heat and cool homes is much closer to reality than most people believe, a group of experts agreed here yesterday. But the development of large power stations that will distribute electricity generated directly from sunlight is decades away, they said.

Executives of the seven largest oil companies, representing half the sales of the United States petroleum industry, strove today to convince skeptical Senate investigators that the energy crisis is real and that they did not contrive it.

There will be more Diplomats in the ration's capital in 1974 and they will all operate out of Robert F. Kennedy Stadium. A group of businessmen, headed by Nick Mangione, a builder and investor from Baltimore, and Mike Finci, an insurance company owner, yesterday were awarded a North American Soccer, League franchise and promptly named the Washington team the Diplomats.

Twenty-six minutes after the second session of the 93d Congress convened today with its members shaking hands and wishing each other a belated happy new year, the Senate began a partisan squabble over whether a committee should investigate a tax dispute that its newest member is having with the Internal Revenue Service.

A court deposition from a former official of the nation's largest dairy cooperative indicates that the concern sought to gain control of all milk supplies in the United States. The cooperative, Associated Milk Producers, Inc., is facing Government antitrust action for allegedly illegal monopoly practices.
Two inmates at the Trenton State Prison who disclosed details of the scalding death of another prisoner were placed in solitary confinement today for "violation of prison rules and regulations."

The Association of American Publishers has called upon the United States Government to voice its concern for the safety of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident Soviet author, and to take all steps possible to obtain assurances from the Soviet Government that his-freedom and personal safety will be protected.
Bearish news developments depressed the stock market yesterday although a rally in the last half hour of trading erased many of the earlier losses.

Governor Byrne said today that the Cost of Living Councl had ruled: that he could take the $15,000 raise voted him by the Legislature in three annual steps. The increases would still be well above Federal wage guidelines.
The Government is about to publish regulations that would leave local officials with considerable latitude in deciding to use Federal money to pay for sterilization operations in public clinics.
BEAUMONT-Andre Alden. Brother of Elsie Beaumont French and E. B. Beaumont. In lieu of flowers contributions to the James B. Munn Scholarship Fund of New York Universltv are suggested.

A young Ecuadorean hijacked a Colombian domestic airliner today, stopped at the western city of Cali and at Barranquilla on Colombia's Caribbean coast for fuel and repairs, and then took off for Cuba, authorities reported. Most of the passengers were released at the two stops.

The French franc lost 4 per cent of its value against the dollar today and the price of gold soared tc record levels, above $140 an ounce, following France's announcement Saturday that it would let the franc float.

In the fall of 1972 The Miami Herald editorially criticized Pat L. Tornillo, the executive director of the Florida Classroom Teachers Association and a candidate for the State Legislature. Under date of Sept. 30, 1972, Mr. Tornillo wrote The Herald:
The Defense Department is considering establishing a naval base in the Indian Ocean on the British-held island of Diego Garcia.
Dancing dragons and serpentine chains of costumed children will take over the streets of Chinatown tomorrow as thousands of ChineseAmericans usher in their New Year.

Campaigning has begun for Italy's referendum on repeal of the threeyear-old law permitting divorce. Houses all over Rome are covered with such slogans as "Family, yes-divorce, no!" and "Divorce plus abortion equals cancer."

Herbert L. Porter, former scheduling director for the Committee for the Re-election of the President, waived today a formal indictment on a charge of lying to the F.B.I. and is apparently prepared to admit his guilt.
The National Urban League today announced that it would begin a voter-registration drive in Yonkers as part of a twoyear nationwide effort to encourage minority participation in elections.
Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz raised no objection today to France's decision to float the franc and let her exchange rate decline.
If you rape a woman and steal her television in New York, a writer in The Times Magazine observed two years ago, you may be punished-for stealing the television set.

6-10 A.M., WNCN. King Lear Overture, Berlioz; Morning Papers Waltz, J. Strauss; Eight Russian Folk Songs for Orchestra, Liadov; Barcarolle, Tchaikovsky; Dance from Music for the Theatre, Copland; Asturiana, Granados; Gavotte from Iphigenia in Aulis, Gluck; String Trio in G (Op. 53 No. 1), Haydn; A Musical Snuff Box, Liadov; Pavan and Galliard, Byrd; Spanish Caprice, Moszkowski; Concerto Grosso No. 9 in F, Corelli; String Quartet in C (K. 157), Mozart.
Joe Thomas, general manager of the Baltimore Colts, dismissed two assistant coaches today and incurred the wrath of his head coach, Howard Schnellenberger.

Britain announced today another massive trade deficit for December and indicated that the sharply higher oil prices posted by the producer nations during and after the Middle East war were partly to blame.
Colin C. Carpi, taking the witness stand in his own defense, testified in a crowded courtroom today that he had absolutelyy nothing" to do with the murder of his estranged wife, Laura.

Two Mount Sinai Hospital doctors who fed baboons the equivalent of a fifth of liquor every day for up to four years have shown that cirrhosis and other liver damage results directly from the toxic effects of alcohol, not from a concurrent poor diet, as generations of medical students have been taught.

Notre Dame replaced the University of California, Los Angeles, as the No. I college basketball team in the nation yesterday as a result of the Irish's astonishing 71-70 triumph over the Bruins at South Bend on Saturday.

President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger briefedCongressional leaders today on Mr. Kissinger's 10-day. Middle :East trip, including unpublished details that helped produce' the Egyptian-Israeli agreement on separation of troops along the Suez Canal.

Amid expressions of optimism over the city's economic future, a new administrationsponsored coalition of business, labor and civic leaders was formed by Mayor Beame yesterday and charged with the task of keeping established businesses in, and attracting new business to, the city.

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: ATTORNEYS Agreed to review a decision prohibiting a Federal district judge from refusing to let a lawyer represent an accused prisoner on the grounds that the lawyer had made improper public statements before the trial (No. 73-841, Holder v. Banks).

NORTHBROOK, Ill.--A successful art dealer in this Chicago suburb has announced a new, 8-point way to start collecting rare porcelain plates with the potential of becoming heirlooms of the future with exceptionally high resale value.,
VERSE Times change, forms change, outlooks change but change, and constancy, are old themes for poets, and youngsters in our city's high schools are still writing poetry.

Jerome B. Wolff, one-time close associate of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, testified today that he had made cash kickbacks to Baltimore County's Executive, N. Dale Anderson, through an intermediary.

Harry W. Albright Jr., New York State's Superintendent of Banks, in a major policy statement yesterday on the problems resulting from the growth of bank holding companies in New York and the rapid expansion of foreign banking in the United States criticized the bills on the subject now before Congress.

Venture Out in America, Inc., a subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation, was disclosed yesterday as the purchaser of Ringling Bros.-Barnum and Bailey Combined Shows, Inc., from Mattel, Inc., of Hawthorne.
With investors apparently concerned about the state of the economy, prices dropped slightly on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market yesterday.
Public school systems cannot rorce female teachers to take maternityy leave months before they expect to give birth, the Supreme Court ruled today.

A production of Alban Berg's "Lulu," to be staged by Roman Polanski, designed by Richard Lindner and conducted by Christopher Keene, will be one of the major events at the 17th Festival of Two Worlds at Spo leto, Italy, next summer.
Those who enjoy walking ocean beaches in winter may, says the American Littoral Society, add a new dimension to their pleasure. Whales and other marine mammals sometimes beach themselves and die.
An all-male jury was completed yesterday to decide the' state's conspiracy-and-officialmisconduct case against former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens.

NORTHBROOK, Ill-A successful art dealer in this Chicago suburb has announced a new, 8-point way to start collecting rare porcelain plates with the potential of becoming heirlooms of the future with exceptionally high resale value.,
Two inmates at the Trenton State Prison who disclosed details of the scalding death of another prisoner were placed in solitary confinement today for "violation of prison rules and regulations."

Among the few educational issues on which there is substantial agreement is the role of the principal in de termining a school's quality. The proposal to evaluate the individual effectiveness of New York City's principals ought to receive wide support.

With the strikes by 6,000 custodial workers over, the city's schools reopened yesterday largely without incident and immediately tackled the three-day backlog of classwork and housecleaning. Dr. Seymour P. Lachman, the president of the Board of Education, said he was "very pleased by the speed with which virtually all of the city schools were able to resume their normal activities."

An educational reform project to determine the necessary characteristics of an effective educational system from the perspective of New Jersey black, Spanish and white urban residents has been announced by Gustav Heningburg, President of the Greater Newark Urban Coalition.

Four Americans returning from a two-week trip of inquiry to South Vietnam said here yesterday that contrary to what they had been told by the United States Ambassador in Saigon, South Vietnamese jails were full of political prisoners.
Rear Adm. Lewis L. Strauss, U.S.N., retired, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, died yesterday of cancer at his home, Brandy Rock Farm, in Brandy Station, Va. He was 77 years old.
Those who enjoy walking ocean beaches in winter may, says the American Littoral Society, add a new dimension to their pleasure. Whales and other marine mammals sometimes beach themselves and die.

South Korean Army authorities announced the arrest of 10 Protestant clergymen here today on charges of violating , the presidential decree banning criticism of the 1972 Constitution.

Frank A. Digaetano, 52-yearold vice chairman and chief financial and operations officer for Bache Co., Inc., was named yesterday to additional responsibilities in a broadening of the brokerage house's top management structure.

Activity at the giant Jersey City bulk-mail facility virtually came to a halt here today amid a bitter dispute between United States Postal Service officials and the Metro Area Postal Union over changes in employee work schedules due to be implemented this week.

Following the rise in gold prices to a record high in London, the price of nearby March silver futures on the Commodity Exchange here jumped to a record of $3.90 6/10. The price was 10 cents an ounce above Friday's high point.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave the nation's railroads permission to file for a 10 per cent increase in the export rate for grain and grain products. The increase is subject to protest and to possible suspension. It would be effective Feb. 22 and would remain in effect for one year.

The adoption of Vietnamese children - a frustrating and tortuous process in the past--is getting easier for Americans. Still far from simple, but easier. The Holt Adoption Program of Eugene, Ore., has just received a license from the Government of South Vietnam that enables it to act there with the kind of legal power accorded agencies operating in the United States.
The flute and the harp mix so congenially that the relative scarcity of concerts exploiting this combination seems curious, even granting that the repertory is not overloaded with substantial pieces.
Albert: A Biography of the Prince Consort, by Reginald Pound (Simon Schuster, $10). Clean Water: Nature's Way to Stop Pollution, by Leonard A. Stevens (Sunrise Book Dutton, $10).

Reggie Miller, a 6-foot-6-inch forward for Pleasantville High School, is only a sophomore, but already is drawing the attention of college basketball coaches. He is part of a young team with visions of capturing the first state championship for the school. Last season Pleasantville reached the Group 2 finals in the southern section.

Th short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in the month ended Jan. 15 fell to 17,490,934 shares, the exchange reported yesterday. This was down 130,604 shares from the Dec. 14 total of 17,621,538 shares.

The fight in the new session of Congress over taxing the prospective "windfall profits" of oil companies will get under way formally tomorrow with a Senate committee hearing aimed solely at discrediting legislation that is before both houses of Congress.
Jerome Tureck is a bassbaritone from Montana whose not-quite-finished vocal technique suggests something caught uneasily between bass and baritone, rather than extending to include them both.
When the New York Rangers acquired Real Lemieux, a 29-year-old forward, from the Los Angeles Kings on Nov. 20 along with Gilles Marotte, a defenseman.

Rejecting the Opposition's angry charge of one-sided Israeli withdrawal, Parliament today approved the new troop-pullback agreement signed with Egypt last week. Defense Minister Moshe Dayan talking with Premier Golda Meir at session at which the Israeli Parliament approved the agreement with Egypt on disengagement of forces.

Eleven of 13 harness drivers indicted on race-fixing charges have appealed to the State Racing and Wagering Board for reinstatement pending the outcome of their trial. A spokesman for the Board said yesterday hearings would be held "as soon as possible" for the drivers, who have been suspended from all direct and indirect harness-racing activity.

Governor Wilson sent to the Legislature today an election-year budget of $9.38-billion that offered few major spending initiatives, provided little in additional tax relief and devoted most of a proposed $772-million increase in spending to maintaining existing programs.
