Defense Minister Moshe Dayan talking with Premier Golda Meir at session at which the Israeli Parliament approved the agreement with Egypt on disengagement of forces.

President Nixon is ignoring rising demands that he resign, is determined "not to be consumed for another year" by Watergate and fully intends to serve out the three years remaining in his term, Ronald L. Ziegler, his press secretary, said today.

The Nassau County Department of Social Services was ordered yesterday to provide emergency funds for the elderly, disabled and blind who have been shortchanged because of administrative errors in the Federal take-over of the program. Judge Bertram Harnett signed the temporary order in State Supreme Court in Mineola at the request of Carl Jay Nathanson, associate director of the Nassau County Law Services Committee, Inc.

There are signs that New York's long downhill slide in private employment may be leveling off, despite the generally pessimistic outlook for jobs created nationally by, the energy crisis. Indeed, the shortage of oil adds to the attractiveness of the central city as a headquarters location. Low-cost, speedy mass transit to the outer reaches of Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens helps promote fresh interest in industrial parks within the city limits.

A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn has for weeks been hearing evidence collected during the most extensive investigation of organized-crime gambling operations ever conducted in the metropolitan area by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Traders took profits and evened up their positions yesterday pending the Government's report on acreage estimates for the wheat, corn and soybean crops, which were due for release after the close of trading, causing some sharp declines in the commodities on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Reports or a confidential Vatican circular to bishops, along with a Vatican statement last week on confession, have caused speculation here that the Roman Catholic Church may be planning to ease its opposition to birth control, The Vatican has denied, that there would be any relaxation of its rigorous stand on the Issue.
A bipartisan panel of tax experts told the Senate Finance Committee today that the plan to tax "windfall profits" of oil companies that is contained in the emergency energy bill is unworkable.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, has told committee staff members that he is willing to resume public hearings and continue them for several weeks, according to persons who have met with him.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York reported yesterday net income of $207,706,754 for 1973, compared with $148,127,302 for 1972. The net income last year includes a gain of $26.1-million, or 61 cents a share, through a change in method of accounting for fuel costs that was approved last week by the Public Service Commission.

The Southern Railway, which in 1972 was the second most profitable railroad system in the country - after the Union Pacific - reported yesterday that its net income in 1973 increased 13.1 per cent, setting a record for the eighth consecutive year.
A state appeals court ruled today, that Middletown Township could not automatically prohibit garden apartments in the community.

Two inmates at the Trenton State Prison who disclosed details of the scalding death of another prisoner have been released from solitary confinement pending their appeals to charges of having violated prison regulations.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he expected an early end to the Arab oil embargo against the United States to result from his role in bringing about the agreement between Egypt and Israel on separating their forces near the Suez Canal.
An insurgent force estimated to number 2,000 men reportedly withdrew from positions eight miles northwest of Phnom Penh today as Government troops advanced on them from four direactions.
The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the state could not reduce welfare payments to a mother and her child merely because the woman's household included her lover.
The Navy moved today to prevent the Standard Oil Company of California from draining oil from the one-billion-barrel Naval Petroleum Reserve in Elk Hills, Calif.

Mrs. Esther Adler Klingenstein, wife of Joseph Klingenstein, a senior partner in the investment banking firm of Wertheim Co. and chairman emeritus of the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died in the hospital there on Monday. She was 74 years old and lived at 1120 Park Avenue.

The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Thomas R. Bomar, predicted today that there would be an adequate supply of mortgage money during 1974 but that it would be more expensive than in previous periods of adequate supply.

E. F. Hutton Co., Inc., reported yesterday a sharp improvement in December-quarter profits, but showed lower earnings for all of 1973. The major brokerage firm has been profitable every year since its found. ing in 1904.

New methods of diagnosing and treating infants born with life-threatening heart defects are saving babies who might otherwise have succumbed to the traumas of open heart surgery. At Babies Hospital here Dr. Ehud Krongrad, right, monitors screen, left, recording findings of electronic probe used to locate area to be avoided in open-heart surgery.

Government lawyers today completed the presentation of their case for deporting an American missionary. An official testified that the American participated in. a protest march on behalf of some southern Philippine farmers in 1971, and the lawyers cited this as evidence of his undesirability as an alien here.

More than 80 airliners worth more than $500-million hav teen grounded by the na tion's airlines since the oil em ergency erupted according to survey by The New York Times
Allegations that top secret messages to American officials in Saigon were improperly routed to the Joint Chiefs of Staff in Washington were denied today by the Pentagon.

Coach Bob Boyd said today that Clint Chapman, suffering a bruised ligament in his left knee, would not ,accompany the Southern California basketball team to New York for games Thursday night against Seton Hall and Saturday night against Fordham.
Upstairs at the Downstairs, for the last 30 years a theatrical breeding ground for some of the country's best comedy and musical talents, closed its doors yesterday for the last time.
The Rawasaki Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it would go into the production and assembly of motorcycles in the United States, the first foreign manufacturer to do so.
Dr. Helen I. Walbridge, the first woman interne in the old New York Hospital on West 16th Street, in 1918, died Monday in the Bayview Nursing Home in Babylon, L. I. She was 94 years old.

Governor Wilson sent to the Legislature today an election-year budget of $9.38-billion that offered few major spending initiatives, provided little in additional tax relief and devoted most of a proposed $772-million increase in spending to maintaining existing programs.

Justice David Ross of State Supreme Court was named yesterday as citywide court administrator in a move designed to speed up the processing of cases by placing all city and state courts here under a single management. Justice David Ross as his appointment was announced here yesterday.

District Attorney Nicholas Ferraro of Queens has started an investigation of Creedmoor State Hospital and of the Queens residences in which mental patients are placed after being released from state institutions.

The Miller Brewing Company, a subsidiary of Philip Morris, Inc., will build an Eastern brewery within 200 miles' of New York on "one of several sites under considetation," a spokesman announced yesterday.

The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee warned today that the inquiry into the impeachment of President Nixon 'could be delayed into 1975 if the Watergate special prosecutor did not turn over relevant grand jury evidence to the committee.

A Federal judge today fined greyhound Lines, Inc., and its parent concern, the Greyhound Corporation, $600,000 on a charge of anticompetitive and discriminatory treatment of its chief competitor in the pacific northwest. Chief District Judge Edwin A. Robson imposed the fine for criminal contempt.
Dr. Christoph Bertram, a young West, German lawyer and defense expert, was appointed today as, director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies.

Following are the major parts of Governor Wilson's proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1: Budget-A total of $9.38-billion, an increase of $772million over a revised 1973-74 budget of $8.61-billion.

Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski asked permission today from the United States District Court to turn over to the Internal Revenue Service information on possible illegal corporate campaign contributions.

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday it had learned that Secretary of State Kissinger had told two highranking Israeli ministers he believed President Nixon would leave office within six months.

The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the reopening of a cost-cutting study of its National Aviation Facilities Experimental Center in Pomona. The order, from F.A.A. Administrator Alexander P. Butterfield, signaled at least a temporary victory for politicians and business leaders from New Jersey who had lobbied intensively against closing the facility 10 miles northwest of Atlantic City.

Describing himself as "an available, unemployed bureaucrat" without a job prospect, Rich.. ard J. Sullivan, the outgoing, State Commissioner of Environmental Protection, listed today some of the key programs for which his administration could' claim credit by the time he leaves office Feb. 1.
Raul Ramirez of Mexico upset fourth-seeded Stan Smith, 7-6, 3-6, 7-6, in a third-round match of the $100,000 United States professional indoor tennis championship today.
Troops and policemen are fighting Communist-led insurgents for control of a district in northeastern Thailand near the Laotian border, the Government Defense Minister said today

The Soviet Union protested at a meeting here today that burglars armed with a knife broke into the apartment of Gleb Smirnov, a Russian representative, last night and threatened his 13-year-old son, Aleksandre.

The Atlantic Richfield Company reported yesterday that its stocks of gasoline were down from a year ago, but that middle distillates, including home heating oil, were up. Crude oil inventories were substantially higher.

Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano requested an autopsy on the body of Eugene Bauer shortly after his death and was refused permission by the family, according to testimony elicited today at the murder trial of Dr. Montemarano.

John H. Powell Jr., with President Nixon at his side, was sworn in yesterday as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, succeeding William H. Brown 3d, whose term as a member and chairman expired last summer. John H. Powell Jr. at his induction yesterday.

The state today officially took .possession of Peobles Island, one of the largest islands in the Hudson River, as part of a long-range program to develop the islands and parts of the Hudson River line into a park system.

The antiques dealers are on Park Avenue, displaying antiques in the 20th annual show at the Seventh Regiment Armory. This year there are 59 dealers, and in a way they are more interesting than their antiques.

The Progressive Architecture magazine design awards, one of the country's most important architectural competitions, were marked this year by a consciousness of limited resources for building. Progressive Architecture's only top design-award winner: Michael and Susan Southworth's plan for the rehabilitation of a 19th-century mill complex into a new community center. One year ago today, President Nixon announced we had achieved "peace with honor" in Vietnam as a cease-fire agreement was reached. He called on us to be proud of the two and a half million young Americans who served in Vietnam.

Two matinees on the weekend brought two Balanchine programs for the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater. They showed the vast range of the master, from the conventional "La Source" to the slinkily experimental "Variations Pour Une Porte et Un Soupir."

Attorneys for Howard R. Hughes and two other men indicted in the Air West stock manipulation case filed a motion for dismissal of the charges today in Federal District Court.

The Rev. Dr. William Grime, former rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Great Neck, L. I., where he served for 35 years, died Sunday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

Reversing a two-day losing streak, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday in slightly stepped-up trading. In the over-the-counter market prices were up, but sales were down slightly.
Notre Dame, rated No. 1 in college basketball, blew most of a 14-point halftime lead tonight before holding on for a 76-74 victory over Kansas before a sellout crowd of 17,100.

Leon Volkov. a Soviet Air Force pilot who defected in 1945 and for the last 20 years was Newsweek magazine's Soviet affairs specialist, died Monday at Suburban Hospital in Bethdesda, Md., after a heart attack. He was 59 years old and resided in Bethesda.

The Monsanto Company, a leading diversified chemical producer, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the fourth quarter and year, according to preliminary unaudited results from the company's St. Louis headquarters.

John Sabo of South Orange, is a handball player and the recipient of the Newark Boys' Club's New Jersey amateur athlete of the year award. He was a star football player at Rutgers in the late 1940's and is now finding success in four-wall handball.

Three reputed Mafia figures were acquitted in Federal Court here yesterday on charges that they had tried to extort $100,000 from two stock promoters.

Senate Democrats moved today to begin a study of energy problems and bring the disarray of multiplying investigations into focus under one special committee such as the one created to inquire into the Watergate scandals.

Charles Bluhdorn, chairman and chief executive officer of Gulf Western Industries, proposed to the Motion Picture Association of America yesterday a price increase on American films shown in countries that supply oil and other commodities to the United States.

The General Motors Corporation announced today that about 75,000 production workers would be laid off temporarily at 14 of its assembly plants that produce large cars. Richard C. Gerstenberg, G.M.'s chairman, said that the layoffs of one or two weeks were due to cutbacks in the production of standard and luxury cars, which are not selling well because of customer concern over the fuel shortage.

The Police Department said yesterday that during 1973 there was a 3.3 per cent drop in the number of reported violent crimes against the person and a decrease of-0.6 per cent in over-all major crimes. This marked the second consecutive year in which there was a slight decline in reported serious crime here.
Senator Floyd K. Haskell, Democrat of Colorado, asked the Justice Department today to try to delay the sale of the Signal Oil and Gas Company to Burmah Oil Inc.

Edward F. Merrey who was said to be the oldest practicing lawyer in New Jersey when he retired in 1972 after 77 years of general practice, died today at the Van Dyk Nursing Home, North Ridgewood. He was 99 years old.

A New York student freed after two years in a Syrian prison passed through London today on his way home. Jonathan Bates, 32 years old, of 37 Washington Square West in Manhattan, had been held on spying charges.

Chandler A. Mackey, the founder in 1914 and president since then of C. A. Mackey Co., importer of green coffee, died Wednesday in Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 84 years old and lived at 455 East 19th Street, Brooklyn.

Cable television began in the United States as a technical means of bringing a clearer picture over mountains or around high city buildings. Today there are over 8,000 systems connecting almost eight million households.

Robert S. McNamara, the president of the World Bank, said today that the vote yesterday by the House of Representatives to deny new United States contributions to the bank was "an unmitigated disaster for hundreds of millions of people in the poorest nations of the world."

The new government guidelines on the use of Federal money for sterilization operations provide that a decision on a person's competence to decide whether to be sterilized would be made by local family-planning officials receiving Federal grants, not welfare officers as The New York Times reported in Tuesday's issue.

Funds for the Office of Minority Business Enterprise, the agency that coordinates the Administration's minority capitalism program, will remain at $52-million in the new budget, according to Department of Commerce sources.

A grand jury indicted 13 men today on charges of conspiracy to fix three harness races in 1972 at two Cook County race tracks. The Cook County state's attorney, Bernard Carey, said the grand jury returned 15 indictments charging bribery, perjury and conspiracy.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a major overhaul of the complicated information-reporting system it requires of brokerage firms.

MORRISTOWN, Jan. 24--A prospective juror in the murder trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark Squire was dismissed today after admitting reading in the Morris County courthouse a former police official's book dealing in part with Mrs. Chesimard.

The Mayor of Cleveland, Ralph J. Perk, announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate. State party leaders indicated they expected Mr. Perk to have little or no opposition.
Twenty-three teen-age boys were killed in a Catholic school dormitory fire here last night that police sources say may have been caused by a youth smoking in bed.

The second- and third-largest oil companies in the nation the Mobil Oil Corporation and Texaco, Inc. - reported yesterday substantially higher profits for the fourth quarter of 1973, when the Arab embargo began.

Henry O. Dormann, a former publicity man, is under consideration for a post in the Beame administration according to sources at City Hall. He is siad to be going through the Clearance process for possible appointment as No. 2 man in the Economic Development Adminstration, an agency that Mayor Beame has promised to broaden in power and in importance.
The Justice Department announced today that the Government would not appeal a court decision prohibiting the State Department from requiring applicants for passports to take loyalty oaths.

Rejecting a last-minute appeal from Prime Minister Heath, leaders of Britain's miners' union ordered a strike vote that could lead to a shutdown of the nation's coal mines. The major setback to efforts to settle the wage dispute came as the Government reported the largest monthly increase in unemployment since 1945. [1:6-7.]

Record profits and sales of three companies reporting reflected the strong demand last year for many products, in the face of raw-material shortages and escalating costs.
The Cost of Living Council said today that as as interim measure it would permit hospitals, nursing homes and other health institutions to raise prices enough to offset higher energy costs.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the. United States had received additional messages from the Syrian Government in the last few days that he hoped would lead to negotiations between Syria and Israel for troop disengagement.

The San Diego Conquistadors, on the strength of a 38-point fourth quarter, beat the Virginia Squires, 125:108, tonight in the American Basketball Association. Travis Grant scored 25 points and Stew Johnson 20 for San Diego, while Virginia was led by George Gervin's 27 points.
Lawrence S. Waterbury, a traffic engineer, died of pneumonia Sunday. He was 77 years old and formerly lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.

The State Department of Health today warned that New Jersey had a serious measles epidemic, with more than a ten fold increase in cases over last year. One stricken child has died from measles complications.

Bird Averitt scored a career-high 36 points tonight in leading the San Antonio Spurs to a 93-84 victory over the Kentucky Colonels in an American Basketball Association game. Averitt hit 15 of 31 fieldgoal attempts for his best percentage night as well as his best scoring night as a pro. He also converted six of 10 free throws.

A woman and seven children died here today in a fire that raced through a three-story apartment building a few hours before dawn. Eleven persons, including two firemen, were taken to hospitals and two persons are still unaccounted for.
Business loans at New York City banks dropped $287-mil lion during the week ended Wednesday, preliminary figure released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed yesterday.
George Foreman will defend his world heavyweight boxing championship against Ken Norton, on Tuesday, March 26, at Caracas, Venezuela, Video Techniques announced yesterday.

Charles P. Rothmann, vice president of Moran, Stahl Boyer, Inc;, a New York realestate consulting organization, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived here.
After two weeks of testimony, a pretrial hearing for Elmer Wayne Henley Jr., 17 years old, who is accused of mass murder, came to an end today.

A 40-year-old woman who had been living in the city's parks and subways for seven months, panhandling for food money, gave birth in the predawn hours yesterday to a boy on the floor of a subway car in Brooklyn.
Albert C. Smith, a retired Army major general, died yesterday of kidney failure in Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 79 years old.

Hughes to purchase a Las Vegas hotel and casino in return for the $100,000 cash contribution that associates of Mr. Hughes gave to Charles G. Rebozo, a friend of President Nixon.
Seven more money-center banks, including the two largest in the United States, yesterday announced reductions in their prime or base lending rates to 9 1/2 per cent from 9 3/4 per cent.
Souh 'Vietnam proposedd today that Saigon and Hanoi establish diplomatic relations "in a new effort to break the deadlock and to, explore all the paths susceptible to lead to beace."

SOMERVILLE, Mass. -- I recently visited several young men in an Israeli hospital. These days the hospitals are filled with the casualties of the October war with Syria and Egypt. The young men I had gone to see had no flowers by their beds, and I was the only visitor they had seen all week; These men were captured Syrian soldiers recuperating from injuries in a Government hospital south of Tel Aviv.

A Greek court has acted with courage in handing down a sharp and unequivocal judgment against two Arab terrorists who sprayed machine-gunfire and grenades through the Athens airport terminal last August, killing five innocent victims and injuring 55 others.

It is often said that the small investor has no effective voice in Congress. And some observers, both in and out of Wall Street, who have followed the cumbersome liquidation of Weis Securities, Inc., under the Federal Securities Investors Protection law believe the legislation supports that point of view.

The Chinese Foreign Ministry charged today that the Soviet police, under the pretext of a smallpox alarm, had kidnapped a Chinese diplomat from a train on the Trans-Siberian Railway and had flown him to Moscow for questioning.

Indonesia, the biggest oil producer in Southeast Asia, has decided to increase her take from the rising prices of oil by keeping some of what she considers the "windfall" profits of the foreign oil companies operating here.
The Franklin New York Corporation, parent of the Franklin National Bank, reported yesterday higher operating earnings before securities transactions
A police review board in Queens has found that a de* tective acted "within police guidelines" when he shot and wounded an off-duty patrolman last month in Queens.
Nothing can be tougher for a newcomer to wine than ordering in a restaurant. Should you consult the waiter or should you forge ahead, pick something from the list and see what happens?

Fabienne Serrat won a giant slalom today for the first World Cup ski triumph of the season for the once-powerful French team. Fabienne Serrat of France on the way to winning the World Cup giant slalom in Austria

Weather changes, notably a southward migration of the monsoons, combined with a sharp reduction in fertilizer production, threaten food supplies for a considerable part of the world population, according to experts on climate and agriculture who completed a two-day meeting yesterday at the Rocke feller foundation.

DuPont Walston, Inc., the big brokerage house that announced last Monday plans to sell its headquarters and 143office branch network, reported late yesterday afternoon that it had arranged for the sale of 70 offices so far.

Yale University announced, today that its prized "Vinland Map," showing North America as discovered by Leif Ericson centuries before Columbus, had been determined to be an elaborate and highly skillful forgery. Laurence Witten, New Haven book dealer who "discovered" map and sold it.

Defense Minister Moshe Dayan has banned Israeli and foreign news correspondents from covering the opening stage of the troop disengagement and withdrawal on the Suez Canal front. Mr. Dayan told several foreign newsmen today they would not be permitted to visit the canal area until Egypt also began withdrawing troops. This s expected next week.

Governor Wilson asked the State Legislature today to exempt privately owned local bus companies from state and local sales, and fuel taxes, and to continue -for another year, the 1 per cent reduction in the state's take of there parimutuel handle at racetracks operated by the New-York Racing Association.

White House lawyers are apparently looking for a way to rule out as a precedent the position taken by President Nixon in 1970 when he opened Administration files to an impeachment inquiry aimed at a Supreme Court Justice.
Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan head of state, flew here today and met with President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia for further discussions on the projected merger of their two nations.

China has informed the United States that she is holding an American Embassy observer who was reported missing last weekend during a battle, between Chinese and South Vietnamese forces in the Paracel Islands, the State Department said today.
The members of the Vikings, the highly-rated varsity basketball team at South Shore High School in Brooklyn, carries the idea of togetherness beyond the boundaries of the gymnasium.

Ferhando Bujones, the new male star of American Ballet Theater, is almost unusual type of dancer. He is a pure virtuoso classicist, and the purity of his classicism is as important as the excitement of his virtuosity.
Four men were seized yes- ti terday in Prospect Park for allegedly trying to steal the 31/2-foot, 300-pound bronze bust of the man who wrote the, song "Home, Sweet Home."

The Washington Redskins have acquired the rights to Joe Theismann, former star quarterback at Notre Dame, from the Miami Dolphins, Coach George Allen announced today. In exchange, the Dolphins will get the Redskins' first-round draft choice in 1976.
Operations at the New York Bulk and Foreign Mail center were nearly normal today as hundreds of postal workers returned to work, abiding by ? court recommendation for a one-week cooling-off period.

Major religious groups are stepping up their stockholder challenges against certain practices of American corporations. The increased activity involves an issue they have confronted tor three years-investments in white-ruled African areas -as well as new issues. Dr. Sterling Cary, the president of the National Council Of Churches, told of South African resolutions.
Emerson Fittipaldi, a hometown hero, drove his McLaren M23 around the track in 2 minutes, 32.97 seconds for the fastest lap in time trials today for Sunday's Brazilian Grand Prix auto race.
The death of a 21/2-year-old child a day after she was refused admission to Jacobi Hospital set off three separate investigations yesterday.

Most postal workers returned to their jobs at the New York Bulk and Foreign Mail Center in Jersey City yesterday during the first day of a one-week cooling off period ordered by the courts in the dispute between labor and management over changes in hours. Postal service spokesmen said negotiations between union leaders and postal service officials from Washington might begin this weekend.

Bariem Prep closed its doors as an independent school yesterday. The class of 1974, the school's seventh and last before the city takes it over, was graduated in an emotion-filled ceremony in the Martin Luther King Auditorium at Harlem Hospital.

To the Editor: In its report to the President, the Cabinet Committee on Cable Communications suggests a plan which may appeal to many on its surface. The plan, nonetheless, will dismay public-interest groups seeking the best in education, art, entertainment and public discussion of community issues.

Simon, the Federal energy administrator, gave conditional support today to the idea of a rollback in some prices of crude oil but declined to specify when or by how much, or to back any of several bills offered in Congress to accomplish the purpose.. Federal Energy Administrator William E. Simon, center, at Senate hearing yesterday on oil. Flanking him are two aides: Gerald Persky, left, and Deputy Administrator John C. Sawhill.

Officials of the Federal agencies that license industry to use Government-owned inventions have a new problem: a judge in United States District Court here has declared unconstitutional the granting of exclusive licenses without Congressional approval and has voided the licensing regulations of the General Services Administration. Joseph P. Kerwi, the astronaut, wore cap ot material patended by NASA on Skylab 2 missions.
Fred Kropke, former Hudson County Police Chief and a defendant in the 1971 "Hudson 8" case, pleaded guilty today to four counts of illegally obtaining county funds.

ThePalestinian guerrilla leadership appealed to the Greek Government today to spare the lives of two Arab guerrillas sentenced to death in Athens last night for their attack at the Athens airport last August.

The clearing of President Nixon's name by Egil Krogh Jr. yesterday applies only to the 1971 burglary of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist, Mr. Krogh's lawyer said today.

The proposal of the New York Legislature's joint committee on higher education to offer tuition aid grants to students in accordance with family income could be the beginning of a rational resolution of the conflict between public and private colleges. At the same time, such an approach would prevent the kind of inflation in education costs that threatens to shut the campuses to the poor and the modest middle class.

The Mobil Oil Corporation yesterday followed up its Thursday announcement of higher profits by declaring both an increase in its regular quarterly dividend and an extra dividend.

In the most dramatic moment so far in the nine-day murder trial of Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano, the chairman of the surgery department of the Nassau County Medical Center broke down on the witness stand today as he was testifying that Dr. Montemarano had confessed killing a terminally ill cancer patient.

Foes of Prime Minister Eric M. Gairy of the Caribbean island of Grenada are fleeing to Trinidad 90 miles to the south. The 133-square-mile island, which is scheduled to become independent from Britain on Feb. 7, has been torn by demonstrations against Mr. Gairy for several weeks. On Monday, the protests resulted in a street battle between the Prime Minister's opponents and supporters.
" What I call the limit-move syndrome gripped the commodity markets," Charles K. Levitt, director of commodities in W. E. Hutton Co.'s Chicago office, commented yesterday.

Israeli forces on the western bank of the Suez Canal formally began their withdrawal today, pulling out tanks, trucks and tons of other heavy equipment from the bridgehead they have occupied since the Oct. 24 cease-fire.
The leaking of secret grand jury testimony would become a crime under a recommendation of Chief Judge John J. Sirica and his colleagues on the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reinstated yesterday a suit against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Republican National Committee over a $100, 000 convention contribution by an I.T.T. subsidiary.

Federal Energy Administrator William E. Simon, center, at Senate hearing yesterday on oil. Flanking him are two aides: Gerald Persky, left, and Deputy Administrator John C. Sawhill.

Leaders of the Roman Catholic church here told President Hugo Banzer Suarez today that inefficiency and corruption in high places were to blame for the worst crisis in his 29 months in office.

Playing without their sixth man, John Roche, who was traded to Kentucky earlier in the day, the New York Nets broke their two-game losing streak tonight by defeating the San Antonio Spurs, 93-89, before a crowd of 9,714 in the Nassau Coliseum. John Roche

Dr. Addeke H. Boerma, director general of the Food and Agriculture Organization, has declared that the drought in the sub-Sahara region is worse this year than ever before, while pledges of aid have fallen far short of needs. Victims of the drought in northern part of Upper Volta

John Michael Graney,- executive director for construction of the Business Roundtable and former president of the National Constructors Association, died Thursday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a two-month illness.
The American Motors Corporation and the General Motors Corporation are studying proposals for AMC to resume building a V-6 engine and sell some 200, 000 units a year to G.M.

A former schoolteacher, Joseph McGowan, who has pleaded guilty to murdering a Brownie Girl Scout, was refused sentencing today by Superior Court Judge Fred C. Galda, who said the slaying should be classified as a sex crime.

Yale University announced today that its prized "Vinland Map," showing North America as discovered by Leif Ericson centuries before Columbus, had been determined to be an elaborate and highly skillful forgery. Laurence Witten, New Haven book dealer who "discovered" map and sold it.

The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today that it would investigate what control financial institutions have over the nation's airlines. The inquiry results from complaints filed by the Aviation Consumer Action Project, a group affiliated with Ralph Nader, against various financial institutions.

Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and two staff aides left for Japan today on a one-week tour of that country's judicial system that is being financed by the State Department's Bureau of Education and Cultural Affairs.
The Mitsubishi Petrochemical Company confirmed today that it planned to develop tar sands in the Canadian province of Alberta jointly with the Great Canadian Oil Sand Company.

A new, intimate revue with still another importedchanteuse and four impersonators may not sound like what the world needs now. But "French Dressing,'" which opened Thursday evening at Greenwich Village's Top of the Gate, is a smashing good show.
Jury selection in the murder trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark Squire was postponed today after Mrs. Chesimard became ill in her cell at the Morris County Jail. Judge
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday the following spat primary prices for the week ended Jan. 15.

The Peronist-controlled Congress today passed a controversial terrorism bill virtually doubling prison sentences for kidnappers, conspirators and armed extremists and turning over internal-security functions to the federal police rather than local law-enforcement officers.

DEBUT One of the most momentous musical events in' recent years takes place tonight at 8 in Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street (CI 7-7459). The New Jimmie Lunceford. His beat is heard again.

One hundred three violations against fuel delivery trucks in New Jersey have been uncovered in a statewide check of 640 tank trucks, the State Division of Consumer Affairs said yesterday. The check covered trucks transporting home-heating oil, gasoline, liquid propane gas and other fuels and was made during the weekend of Jan. 11-13.

The first stage in reopening the Suez Canal-removing wrecks that have. Trapped 14 vessels could be completed within a six-month period, according to salvage experts here. They calculate that the further work required in renoving three causeways built across the canal by Egyptians and Israelis in last October's war, and the small amount of dredging needed to remove accumulations of silt, especially lear the wrecks, would be a comparatively small job.
River Downs Race Track, scene of a fire last June in which 16 horses died, has been ordered to make grandstand, jockey quarter and clubhouse repairs to meet state fire regulations, officials said.
Mrs. Marga Eyland Davidson, widow of William Ward Davidson Sr., inventor of paper-handling and graphic arts equipment, died Wednesday at her home in San Mateo, Calif. She was 87 years old
Britt Ekland and Bert Lahr in "The Night They Raided Minsky's" (1968), Ch. 4 at 9 P.M.
Vice President Ford said today that he had decided not to examine evidence that the White House asserted would clear President Nixon of involvement in the Watergate affair and its cover-up.
Negotiations between West Germany and the United States on a new agreement aimed at offsetting the cost of maintaining American troops here have been at a standstill since November.

A 19-year-old Queens youth, Wai Chiu Mah, was charged with homicide yesterday in the deaths of two teen-age brothers who were shot in their Brooklyn apartment after four youths invaded it last Jan. 18.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has begun an inquiry into allegations that William H. Moore, while he was president of the Penn Central Transporstation Company, had, together with other unidentified officials of the railroad, misappropriated its funds and properties.

The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson reared back, gazed up at the marble facing on an immense, almost completed skyscraper and said to several hundred followers: "See that building? That's why you can't get gas. While that building was going up, employment was Roing down." Women picketing in Chicago outside the Standard Oil Building. They expressed disbelief in an "energy crisis."
James Pope-Hennessy, the writer, died in a hospital today of injuries received in a knife attack at his home here. He was 57 years old. James Pope-Hennessy
Sir Hubert Rance, a major general who was the last British Governor of Burma before it gained independence in 1948, died in a hospital yesterday. He was 75 years old.

Britain concluded a multimillion-dollar oil agreement with Iran today, signing a bilateral deal of the kind heavily criticized by American officials. It was the first such arrangement worked out between Britain and an oil-producing nation since the cutback in production
The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today it was investigating whether banks, insurance companies and other major creditors of the airline industry exert undue influence on airline management.
Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, asked the General Accounting Office today for a legal opinion on the precise authority of Congress to oversee government intelligence agencies.

The funds requested by Governor Wilson in his budget for the 1974-75 fiscal year for the support of the arts would go a "substantial way" toward meeting the operrating deficits of more than 800 organizations supported by the New York State Council on the Arts, according to Eric Larrabee, executive director of the council.
A theft as simple as a dimestore shoplifting took place in Tiffany's at midday yesterday, but the object stolen, a Jean Schlumberger wreath choker of rubies and diamonds, was worth S45,000.
The Skylab 3 astronauts entered the record books again today in logging-the greatest total time in space. They said they were anxious to, return home after the 84-day mission.
The Government granted steel producers today another price increase and took steps aimed at relieving shortages of steel items used in production of petroleum, coal and agricultural products.
Following are excerpts from a paper presented in English at a conference in Houston, on human rights that commemorated the 25th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
At least some journalists reported missing in Southeast S Asia are being held by Cambodian insurgent forces, a committee headed by Walter Cronkite has asserted.
ADES--Joseph, beloved and devoted brother of Fanny and Lena Lusman. Loving uncle and great uncle. Funeral services Sunday 10:15 A.M. Garllck Funeral Home 1700 Coney Island Ave. and Ave. N Brooklyn.

Robert Byrne of the United States and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union played to a, draw yesterday in the fifth game of their quarterfinal Candidates Match in the world chess championship' preliminaries.

The State Supreme Court decision dismissing charges of election fraud against Assembly Speaker Duryea and high-ranking legislative associates is hardly the "vindication" they are so effusively proclaiming. On the contrary, Justice Burton B. Roberts could scarcely have been more caustic in condemning political misrepresentation of the type alleged against Mr. Duryea.

Valdemar Cronstedt, an aviation engineer, and in recent years a consultant, died Wednesday in the Williamsport Hospital. He was 76 years old. Mr. Cronstedt, who became a pilot in 1918, studied and flew aircraft in Britain, France and Germany as a neutral Swedish observer in World War I. He later earned a doctorate in science at Gottingen University in Germany.

Jim (J.J.) Jennings, the top collegiate football scorer in the nation last fall, was a delight to the fans on The Banks of the Old Raritan. The Rutgers tailback ran over and around opponents so well that he even earned the acclaim of sports writers.

I was born and reared in New York City and have lived here, apart from college and' law-school years, all my life. On Friday night, "Jan. 4, while walking' on 75th Street between Amsterdam 'and Columbus Avenues, on my way home from dinner 'at my parents' apartment, I was robbed, for the 'first time ever, by two individuals whom I have come to think of as "the perpetrators."

The deed for President Nixon's donation of his VicePresidential papers to the National Archives was signed long after his eligibility had expired for tax deductions that he claimed for them, the California Secretary of State's office said today. Vice President Ford speaking to reporters in Columbus
A Federal Appeals Court ruled today that President Nixon Illegally delayed by three months a 1972 pay rise for the Government's civilian employes and that they are entitled to the income they missed.

China has informed the United States that she is holding an American Embassy observer who was reported missing last weekend during a battle between Chinese and South Vietnamese forces in the Paracel Islands, the State Department said today.

Carmine Tramunti, a reputed Mafia boss, was described at the opening of his narcotics trial here yesterday as the "Mr. Big" who financed the wholesale distribution of heroin in a highly organized conspiracy.

Like a baby taking his first faltering steps, success comes in bits and pieces. So, too, with the young New York Islanders of the National Hockey League, who meet the Boston Bruins tomorrow night in the Nassau Coliseum.

The Federal Energy Office in Washington is investigating a report filed by an unidentified oil company indicating it has been allocating gasoline to the Northeast region on a basis lower than the 80 to 85 per cent of the 1972 base period that applies nationally.
President Nixon suspended import restrictions on wheat today but the White House denied that the action signaled an impending grain shortage.

The Boston Celtics, led by Jo Jo White and John Havlicek, scored a 112-97 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight, their 18th straight victory over the 76ers since February, 1971. Celtics' Dave Cowens (18) blocking a shot by 76ers' Larry Jones (22) in the first period last night in Boston. At the right is Don Chaney. Celtics won, 112-97.

The Arabian American Oil Company, the world's largest petroleum producer, conceded yesterday that since October it has refused to supply oil to United States military forces around the world on instructions from Saudi Arabia, its only source of crude oil.
The state's second highest court today upheid a 1971 state law that regulates funds established to preserve gravesites and the grounds of private cemeteries.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has begun an inquiry into allegations that William H. Moore, while he was president of the Penn Central Transportation Company, had, together with other unidentified officials of the railroad, misappropriated its funds and properties.

Marques Johnson, a freshman reserve, provided some extra bounce in the University of California, Los Angeles to-. night as the Bruins prepared for their basketball rematch with Notre Dame tomorrow night.
Commodity futures trading set another record last year. A total of 25,826,747 commodity contracts changed hands on the nation's commodity exchanges, or 40 per cent above the 1972 level.

The Levingston Shipbuilding Company of Orange Tex., said it had signed a contract to build a jack-up drilling platform for K-S Norway Jack-up, a three-corn pany group. Total price is in excess of $18-million.

Pilobolus by any other name would be easier to pronounce, but would hardly be more enjoyable. This formerly all-male dance .company, which last summer added its first women dancers, gave its initial New York performance of the year at the Hunter College Playhouse on Wednesday evening.
The Detroit goalie, Jim Rutherford turned away 38 shots tonight to preserve a 2-2 tie for the Red Wings against the Atlanta Flames in a National Hockey League game.

Boston Garden, the scene of a violent outburst by fans at a National Hockey League game last night between the Brains and Chicago Black Hawks, took steps today in attempt to curb future demonstrations.
President Nixon suspended import restrictions on wheat today but the White House denied that the action signaled an impending grain shortage.

Vice President Ford said today that he had decided not to examine evidence that the White House asserted would clear President Nixon of involvement in the Watergate affair and its cover-up. Vice President Ford speaking to reporters in Columbus

John C. Sawhill, the deputy administrator of the Federal Energy Office, said today that despite the nation's improved supplies of heating oil, he expected no relaxation of fuel-conservation requirements, not even next winter.
Dr. Paul F. Berlin, senior obstetrician at Southside Hospital, died there yesterday after a long illness. He was 51 years old and lived here.
Tom Kite Jr. led Ben Crenshaw by two strokes In the race between the two Austin, Tex. golfing pals after 36 holes today in the $170,000 Andy Williams-San Diego open golf tournament.

The Washington Redskins have acquired the rights to Joe Theismann, former star quarterback at Notre Dame, from the Miami Dolphins, Coach George Allen announced today. In exchange, the Dolphins will get the Redskins' first-round draft choice in 1976.
The United States Court of Appeals ruled here yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration acted illegally in not holding hearings before it banned the livestock growth drug DES.
The three national television networks plan to rotate live coverage of the Senate Watergate committee hearings when they are resumed next week.
A major group of landlords has won court decisions in two boroughs to force the city government to approve delayed rent-control increases.

Following Is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable In the capital shares of dual-purpose investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market Prices of best over-the-counter dollar-to-dollar asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount on premium) between the not asset value and the asked prices of the capital shares.
Members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association ratified a new one-year contract with the city by a narrow margin, the union announced yesterday.

A Federal judge here asked President Nixon today to tell the court personally whether he was still relying on executive privilege as a defense against the Senate Watergate committee's subpoena for five crucial White House tape recordings.

Walter Susskind brought the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, and devoted his entire program to "A Mass of Life" by Frederick Delius. The work is not heard very often; it demands a big orchestra, chorus and four soloists.

The Wall Street adage-"It's not a stock market but a market of stocks"-was proved anew yesterday. While the over-all market showed little positive direction, either up or down, specialty items dominated the interest of many investors on a slow trading day. The Dow-Jones industrials slipped 3.69 points to 859.39.
The president of District 28 Community School Board announced yesterday that the board had balanced its projected $1.2-million deficit by dropping 46 substitute teaching positions.

The Armco Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth largest steel producer based on tonnage shipments, reported yesterday that its profits were up 26 per cent in the fourth quarter on a sales gain of 31 per cent.

In the most dramatic moment so far in the nine-day murder trial of Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano, the chairman of the surgery department of the Nassau County Medical Center broke down on the witness stand today as he was testifying that Dr. Montemarano had confessed killing a terminally ill cancer patient.

Lawyers for Howard R. Hughes successfully forestalled today the issuance of a bench warrant for their billionaire client-at least until next Wednesday. Robert A. Maheu, left, arriving at District Court in Reno with Morton Galane, his lawyer.

The supply of trained specialists has not kept pace with a tremendous increase in Federal money and is hampering efforts to mount a national attack on cancer, according to scientists who are updating the National Cancer Plan.

George P. Shultz reportedly has finally decided to resign as Secretary of the Treasury. One of his friends predicted yesterday that Mr. Shultz would be out of the Government by April 1. Another mentioned "the Ides of March."

The White House acknowledged today that President Nixon met last May with Richard G. Danner, a Las Vegas gambler who delivered a $100,000 payment in 1970 from Howard R. Hughes to Charles G. Rebozo, Mr. Nixon's close friend. Richard G. Danner
American Petrofina, a medium-size oil company, announced yesterday a 215 per cent increase in its fourthquarter profits for 1978 and an over-all rise of 104 per cent for the year.

Weather changes, notably a southward migration of the monsoons, combined with a sharp reduction in fertilizer production, threaten food supplies for a considerable part of the world population, according to experts on climate and agriculture who completed a two-day meeting yesterday at the Rocke feller foundation. Joseph A. Savoldi, who gained fame as a fullback on undefeated football teams at the UniverSity of Notre Dame in 1929 and 1930, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 65 years old. Joseph A. Savoldi

The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission announced plans today to lift the six-month-old Federal ban on 13 brands of aerosol spray adhesives March 1 but said this did not represent an endorsement of the products' safety.

Determined not to repeat the mistakes of the past, the state is preparing a new transportation bond issue that will concentrate on mass transit in deference to the protests by environmentalists, which played a major part in the defeat of a transportation bond proposal two years ago.
The Federal Communications Commission has adopted new rules for the apportionment of network and local time In the peak viewing hours.
Dr. Isidora Davila-Katz, a psychiatrist, died last Dec. 31 in Paris, according to word received here yesterday. She was 29 years old and had practiced there since 1968.

Dr. Addeke H. Boerma, director general of the Food and Agriculture Organization, has declared that the drought in the sub-Sahara region is worse this year than ever before, while pledges of aid have fallen far short of needs.
The General Motors Corporation said today that some 26,500 new intermediate-size cars may have seat belts that could fail to hold front-seat occupants securely in an accident or during hard braking.

Valentino certainly wasted no time setting the mood for his spring collection. The first mannequin down the runway was the insouciant Alva Chen, wearing a quiet beige suit with matching stockings and open-toed shoes. An American, Alva is Feminist demonstrator outside Valentino salon hands leaflet to Mr. and Mrs. Ruggero Bises.

Curt Knight, Washington Redskin place-kicker, has joined Mike Lucci, retired Detroit linebacker, in rapping the head coach. Knight said, "George Allen" made it seem like a high crime or treason" every time he missed a field goal last season. Knight said he expected to be let go by Allen in the off season.

For the fourth straight day, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday. Prices in the over-the-counter market dropped again after only a two-day rise. Volume rose on the Amex but fell slightly in the counter market.

In line with the recent decision by the nation's oil companies to improve their public image, the Mobil Oil Corporation has named Herman J. Schmidt to the new post of vice chairman, with specific responsibility for public affairs. Herman J. Schmidt

Dick Tayler of New Zealand captured the 10,000-meter track gold medal today in the Commonwealth Games after David Bedford, the world recordholder, had scrapped and elbowed for the lead with three Kenyans.

President Nixon's political situation becomes each aay more untenable. The widespread confusion and lack of public trust in the Administration's statements concerning the oil shortage only demonstrate that the essential links of confidence between President and people are severed.

Representative Fred B. Rooney, Democrat of Pennsylvania, asked the General Services Administration today to move in the Maryland state courts to recover public money used to improve the suburban home of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

Once again at least eight British antiques dealers arrived here in time to take in the Winter Antiques Show, on through tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street. They came to search both the show and shops around town for the English period furnishings necessary to replenish depleted stocks in their London shops.

Gold and the dollar moved indecisively on European money markets today. The dollar's general drift was downward, though exceptional markets priced it higher. Gold jumped sharply in Paris and Frankfurt, but dropped in London and Zurich. Paris again provided the gold bullion highlight, where it closed at $145.86 an ounce, a jump of $3.14 during the day.
Mayor Beame yesterday appointed John T. Burnell, an executive of the New York City Central Labor Council, as the city's chief labor negotiator with municipal unions. John T. Burnell
Ray A. Kroc, who has agreed to buy the San Diego Padres for an estimated $10.1-million, said today he considered National League approval assured. The price Ray A. Kroc at news session in San Diego.

About 80 miles away, Muhammad Ali is completing his training in the rustic setting of Deer Lake in the Pocono mountains. But here, across the street from the rumble of the grimy North Philadelphia railroad station, Joe Frazier toils in relative splendor.

Stringent economies and improved management have saved a number of colleges and universities-though by no means all-from what not long ago seemed a threat of imminent collapse. Regrettably, efforts to deal resolutely with the fiscal depression have been matched by no similar determination to reverse the universities' depression of the spirit.
There seems to be an extra bounce in the Bruins of University of California, Los Angeles as they prepare for their basketball rematch with Notre Dame tomorrow night.

1. Vote on tabling motion to investigate a tax dispute between Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum and the Internal Revenue Service. Motion tabled, 53 to 22. Jan. 21. 2. Vote on rivers and harbors authorization bill, which passed. 78 to 6, Jan. 22.

Turkey's first left-of-center Cabinet was formed today, a coalition of a moderate socialist party and an Islamic party. Exactly 100' days after inconclusive elections last October, Bulent Ecevit, leader of the Republican People's party, which is Social Democratic, and Necmettin Erbakan, of the National Salvation party signed the coalition agreement. They became respectively Premier and Deputy Premier in a 25member cabinet.

Although David Parkin's animals aren't like any you'll meet on safari or at the zoo, you'll have no trouble identifying his hippo, camel, tortoise, elephant and lion. The former industrial designer has used artistic license in his "Nature of the Beast" collection of aluminum sculptures, but has based them on the study of nature.

MILAN, Italy--Some years ago an astute European ambassador confessed: "I cannot figure these people out. They slip' from crisis to crisis and one almost always assumes they are doomed. But Italy is like a cat. It can fall off the roof--but always lands on its feet and scampers away intact."

The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, the world's largest passenger shipping line; announced yesterday in London that it had made a bid to acquire Bovis, Ltd., a major British construction company. Members of the Bovis board said they would accept the bid. They control 15.8 per cent of Bovis's common shares.

Willie Mosconi, the 60-yearold former world pocket billiards champion, beat the British snooker champion, Rex Williams, last night to take the Black Velvet challenge series and win $15,000. The two billiards experts concluded the 17-day, six-city tourney in snooker and straight-pool at the Illinois Athletic Club. Mosconi was 88 points ahead before Chicago. The pair went 20 innings in a tight final pool match before Mosconi won, 150-58.
The price of crude oil being auctioned on the open market by Arab oil interests has moved upward in some areas, mostly because of the effects of the Arab production cutbacks instituted last fall.
Robert C. Weinberg, an architect and regional planner, died of cancer last evening in Memorial Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Washington Square and in Ridgefield, Conn.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday a 3-cent-apound increase in the price of its primary aluminum ingot sold outside the United States.

The deed for President Nixon's donation of his VicePresidential papers to the National Archives was signed long after his eligibility had expired for tax deductions that he claimed for them, the California Secretary of State's office said today.

President Nixon will hold his first news conference of the year shortly after His State of the Union Message delivering next Wednesday, the White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said yesterday.

A Pentagon investigator who was involved in the 1971 inquiry into military snooping in the White House denied today that he had attempted to "shake down" President Nixon last year in an effort to be named director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
When the party is over, let the wife and not the husband do the driving. That is the advice given for most drinking couples in a state - sponsored study aimed at cutting down drunken driving.

PRINCETON-In the base. ment of a Princeton Theological Seminary building are six soundproof booths, most of them occupied all day. From these cubicles comes enlightment for blind studdents and professionals in many parts of the United States.

Miss Joan Scott Findlay, daughter of Comdr. G. Scott Findlay, U.S.N., retired, of New York and Mrs. Herman Eckhoff of Valle de Bravo, Mexico, was married here yesterday afternoon to Wolcott Balestier Dunham Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Dunham of Southwest Harbor, Me.

SAIGON, South VietnamIt has been said sardonically that South Vietnam is a wholly owned American subsidiary. An exaggeration of course, but not without a seed of truth, for the United States subsidizes most of the country's imports and provides most of the cash for the Saigon Government's budget.

A Queens civic organiza tion will begin a campaign this week to elicit the support of state and city officials in their campaign against the building of highrise apartments in the borough.

Closing fast under a fine ride by Tony Agnello, Terriobu carried the silks of Bayard Sharp to victory today in the $24,450. Goss L.. Stryker Handicap. The seven-furlong race for horses registered in Maryland attracted a crowd of 13,710 and a field of 10 contestants.

Akins, the Unite States Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, has indicated in Congressional testimony that the AdministratiOn's 1971 approval of joint bargaining by the major oil companies included an agreement by the companies in Libya to share their oil in the event that the Government there shut down some of them.

A young man was killed last night when fire swept through his room at the Diplomat Hotel at 108 West 43d Street. The victim was identified as Peter Green, in his mid-20's, who had lived at the hotel for the last five years.
One of the first sights tourists see on their way from the International Airport to the eternal city Is a cluster of new buildings in a bend on the Tiber River.

THE Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street, an accredited community college of the State University of New York, is offering three courses in photography during the coming semester, with registration to take place at the college on Wednesday evening from 6 to 8.

The tax lawyer who handled President Nixon's claims of a tax deduction for the gift of his papers to the National Archives contended today that the process was legal. Frank DeMarco Jr. said the papers were given to the Archives in April, 1969, before the law allowing such a donation expired.

The Archbishop of Rio de Janeiro today denounced rigid anti-Communism and rejected charges of Communist influence in the church. Eugenio Cardinal de Araujo Sales's statement was a clear response to attacks made at an anti-Communist congress meeting here this week.

THAT New York phenomenon, the longlonglonglonglong movie line, was carried to new lengths in recent weeks after William Friedkin's Christmas offering, "The Exorcist," opened on Dec. 26 at Cinema I. This time, people stood like sheep in the rain, cold and sleet for up to four hours to see the chilling film about a 12-year-old girl going to the devil.

The Rev. and Mrs. Dudley Johnson Stroup of Scarsdale and Madison, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Stroup, to Roger Mansfield Wolters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Wolters of Ossining.

MADRID-The Iberian Peninsula, surrounded by sea and mountains, looks a bit isolated from the rest of Europe and the world. But 34 million Spaniards and 9.5 million Portuguese became aware in 1973, as rarely before, how vulnerable they are to the economic and political problems that afflict other peo-. ples.

I've visited four exhibits without finding more than half a dozen images really worth looking at again, and have worked my way half through a book whose premise I consider Inordinately significant but whose execution leaves much to be desired.

BARNS have been on Melvin Kaplan's mind for some time. Two and a half years ago, the well known oboist, concert manager and teacher, bought a farm in East Charlotte, Vt., and remodeled a barn on the property into a house. As a member of the New York Chamber Soloists, he played one year at the Touraine Festival in France, which is held in a barn. He was impressed by the experience.

The beaming, bearded face of Kentucky's Colonel Harlan Sanders is a familiar billboard sight in Hong Kong; McDonald's is booming on the Ginza. Even in the more remote corners of the world these days, franchising everything from houseboatrentals to pizza - is becom. ing big business indeed.
President Nixon has nominated Prof. Thomas V. Falkie, head of the department of mineral engineering at Pennsylvania State University to be director of the United States Bureau of Mines.
The organizers of the Comrades Marathon, South Africa's leading long-distance race, announced today that black runners would be barred despite .calls for the race to be open to all athletes.

George Papadopoulos, two unanswered questions still confound the people of Greece: Which men rule the country and where are they leading it? TRENTON--The New Jersey Housing Finance Agency could be out of business by the and of the year, its director dourly predicts. The agency is being pummeled by the year-long freeze on Federal rent-subsidy funds, the energy crisis, environmental battles and municipalities halting construction of housing.

ATHENS-The appetizing aroma of grilled meat that fills the air of downtown Athens each noon, bears witness to the changing habits of Athenians. Some 3,450 souvlaki stands now cook midday snacks of skewered meat and onion for many Athenians who have broken with the tradition of going home for lunch.

Henry Ross Perot, the Texas computer millionaire who became Wall Street's biggest backer three years ago, decided recently he had had enough. He had pumped enough money into the securities business, and he was getting out.
Two hundred and fifty antiwar demonstrators marched on the State Department today in a vain attempt to present Secretary of State Kissinger with the "Ignoble War Prize for 1973."

A spokesman for Texaco, Inc., said yesterday that the company supplied United States military forces with 87 million gallons of petroleum products from its non-Arab sources during the Arab oil embargo over the last three months.

Dr. Max Stegel, a protessor of education at Brooklyn College, and Mrs. Siegel of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shelley Ann Siegel, to Martin H. Zimmerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Zimmerman of Brooklyn. A December wedding is planned.

Unless means are found to resume the full flow of Japan's fuel imports, now disrupted by Middle Eastern disturbances, our country will face a near economic disaster. This year will prove to be a critical turning point for Japan's economy.

Independent truckers in Ohio will vote tomorrow on an offer aimed at ending a violence-marred three-day shutdown, a spokesman said today. The report of the offer came after scattered shootings and other acts of violence were reported in several areas in Ohio and Pennsylvania.

Jordan and Israel have been engaged in preliminary negotiations on disengaging their forces in the Jordan Valley region, according to reliable Arab diplomatic sources. Miss Valerie C. Mirto and Robert Joseph Rothschild were married yesterday after noon in the St. Joseph Patron Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. Msgr. Raphael J. Testagrossa performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

Mr. and Mrs. Hyman J. Portnoy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Robin Portnoy, to Stephen Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goldberg of New Haven. The couple, graduates of Adelphi University, plan to be married March 17 at the Woodbury (L.I.) Country Club.
TORONTO-The skyline of Toronto, which has changed drastically in a decade, is now getting an addition that the builders say will be the tallest self-supporting structure in the world.

Vice President Ford, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York are in close competition among Republican voters as the leading choices for their party's nomination for President in 1976, according to the latest Gallup Poll.
A President may be impeached and removed from office for an offense that need not be a violation of criminal law, according to a study released 'yesterday by the New York City Bar Association.

Lose one, win one. That was the story for Coach Red Holzman of the Knicks yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Before his team turned in its finest offensive performance of the season by romping over the Philadelphia 76ers, 122-96, Holzman lost $5 to Willis Reed, the injured captain of the Knicks.

Miss Linda Karen Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stern of New York and Atlantic Beach, L. I., was married here this afternoon to Kevin Caulfield Reilly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Reilly of Westport, Conn.

Automobile racing, which got off to a wet start this year when the first big event of the American season, the Western 500, was halted last week by rain at Riverside, Calif., continued in the shadow of the umbrella. This time it was politics raining on its parade.

PATERSON - The Health Department here will begin a campaign tomorrow to vaccinate all unprotected children in this city against measles. Officials hope to prevent "a measles outbreak of epidemic proportions" this spring when cases traditionally peak.

LONG BRANCH - An innovative program for troubled children as young as 5 weeks old is under way in Monmouth and Ocean Counties. It provides training and ongoing diagnostic facilities for the youngsters and counseling for their parents as early as possible.

RIO DE JANEIRO-When Adam and Eve were expelled from here, so the Brazilian saying goes, the Lord hid their paradise from the rest of the world. Invisible or not, and still far from being the "Garden of Eden" it was, the world's fifth largest country, nevertheless, emerged in 1973 as a dynamic economic and industrial world power.

Blocked since the six-day war of 1967, the 100-mile waterway, which will be 105 years old this year, will again become a major thoroughfare of commerce.

But a year after the signing of the Paris peace agreements "their war" - the struggle that still goes on and has taken almost 60,000 more Vietnamese lives since the cease-fire - has become just another fact of life here.

A painted Greek chamber tomb of the third-century B.C. and some sith-century B.C. Greek-style tomb paintings excavated in Western Turkey excited interest among art historians at the annual meeting of the College Art Association here.

The World Football League held its first player draft last week and the National Football League starts drafting on Tuesday, so it is that time again when folks like George Scully might wish they' were talented defensive backs graduating from Ohio State.

The New York City Housing and Development Administration needs to take "drastic and immediate action" to curb abuses in the Mitchell-Lama middle-income housing program and to restore the program to a sound financial base, an audit by State Controller Arthur Levitt concluded today.

Governor Wilson, contending that the traditional June primary resulted in "unduly long political campaigns" and magnified "the risks of electoral abuse and questionable financing," asked 'he Legislature today to establish a permanent fall primary on the second Tuesday after Labor Day, beginning with a primary this year on Sept. 10.

BANGKOK, Thailand When a group of Indonesian officials visited Bangkok recently to negotiate the purchase of 500,000 tons of rice, a senior That official pointed out that Thailand would be exporting only about I million tons in 1974 and that a major portion of it was already committed to other customers.

ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaFor developing Africa, 1973 was the year that might have been. Through the year, the steady upturn of prices for almost all major African exports-coffee, cocoa, minerals and other commoditieswas a buoyant change from the generally depressed prices of previous years.

To the Editor: Tania Grossinger's delightful recollectons in 'Growing Up at Grossingers" (Travel Section, Jan. 13) will bring a twinge of nostalgia to all who knew Grossinger's as it then was-between 1945 and 1960. There was nothing like it before or since, with Jennie Grossinger reigning like a queen in all her glory.

A Turkish jetliner crashed and burst into flames on takeoff from Izmir's military airport today, killing 63 of the 73 persons aboard, Turkish Airlines reported. Officials identified two of the dead as Dr. and Mrs. Horace W. Gerarde of Tenafly, N. J. They said that the Gerardes had been on a vacation tour.
Nancy Class of St. Paul, last year's Senior Women's champion, was in fourth place today after two events in the national outdoor speed skating championships at Lake Como.

Darrell Elston's ball control and sharp, long-range shooting keyed a second-half North Carolina burst that lifted the Tar Heels to an 82-73 victory over Maryland today in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

Ross Brooks, the other goalie of the Bruins, played like an all-star tonight in. Nassau Coliseum as Boston defeated the New York Islanders, 4-0. The shutout in. the Nationai Hockey League game was Brooks's second in succession.

Shares of United States corporations, offering bits of the world's largest and most active industrial economy, have a natural fascination for investors all over the World. Commitments can be made through Wall Street, but lately more and more of the world's stock exchanges have been welcoming American listings.

A 270-foot Bulgarian stern trawler carrying 79 men and a 182-ton catch of mackerel was seized in international waters off the New Jersey shore early yesterday by a Coast Guard cutter that gave chase after allegedly sighting her fishing illegally inside the 12-mile coastal limit.

Soviet environmentalists have complained that a natural-gas pipeline above the Arctic Circle is hindering the migrations of the nearly 400,000 reindeer in the Taimyr Peninsula above northern Siberia.

CARACAS-In the growing worldwide struggle for energy supplies South America appears barely likely to hold its own, let alone contribute much to North America's energy needs. Indeed, for the rest of the decade the good fortune of having energy supplies within one's national boundaries may be a major indicator of a country's potential for growth. And the gap between have and have-not nations on the continent may widen even further.

NEW DELHI--Soviet officials, having proved themselves adept at capitalistic bargaining for American wheat a year and a half ago, are now using the grain to reap political dividends in the Third World.

MOSCOW-Robert B. Costello has cut back on those long, lingering business lunches. His low-90's golf game is suffering. He has had to change from liftassisted downhill skiing to the more laborious crosscountry variety. And he spends more of his social life mixing with diplomats than with other business executives.

Norman Cousins scored a personal victory last year when he reacquired control of his old magazine, the Saturday Review, and consolidated it with his new publication, World magazine. But now that he's back and ready to go, he's been scrambling for the paper he needs to publish.

SEOUL - Most of the world's large cities have a distinctive mark - New York's skyline, the boulevards of Paris, the fountains of Rome, Tokyo's maze of narrow, twisting streets. In Seoul, it's buses-big green buses mounted on flat-bed truck frames, crammed with people most of the time and almost always spewing black fumes from their worn, laboring engines.

Two American foundations have pledged financial support to enable archeologists to uncover fully the Agora, the treasurepacked ancient market place of Athens north of the Acropolis.
