The man who, in the opinion of some scholars, was most instrumental in designing Prospect Park, will be honored by the Friends of Prospect Park in a series of programs marking the sesquicentennial of his birth next month.

"The money did kind of become something you expect," said Mrs. Alice Kiick, wife of the Miami Dolphins' running back, Jim. Great expectations-to the tune of $15,000-are what every Dolphin on the Super Bowl roster received for defeating the Minnesota Vikings.

Wiktor Labunski, composer and pianist, who retired three years ago as dean and artist-in-residence at the Conservatory of Music of University died there yesterday. He was 78 years old and lived in Lenexa, Kan.

Exploited by the white man and threatened by the encroachments of the 20th century, the primitive Ache Indians in the jungles of eastern Paraguay are in danger of losing their Stone Age culture. Only a few cultures characterized, as Stone Age are known still to exist. Others are in Brazil, Australia, New Guinea and the Philippines.

DURING the two or three days that have passed since I sat on bleachers in Brooklyn listening to three white-gowned women, impersonal as sea gulls, chant fragments of the history and fragments of the poetry of Sylvia Plath, and before pushling myself to my desk to record my impressions of the event, I have found myself ducking people.

To the Editor: I am a 15-year-old student in the 11th grade and I never learned how to divide under new math ("Does new math add up?" by Frank Kendig, Jan. 6). They (teachers) taught me the logic behind division, why to divide, but never how.

BUDAPEST - After long years of austere living crowding in stores for inadequate and inferior goods, cramped housing and a pervading sense of grayness Eastern European consumers are gradually moving toward a better way of life.

To those who could not resist the pun, the high-level discussion of the oil industry last week produced considerable heat but little light: Senatorial indignation was high and corporate executives defended themselves with strong language, but gasoline supplies were still dropping and the public had learned little more than it already knew about why that was happening.

The Consolidated Edison Company announced that its 873,000-kilowatt Indian Point No. 2 nuclear generator, in Buchanan, N. Y., resumed partial service yesterday for the first time since a cracked water line put it out of service on Nov. 13. Officials said that the generator would be Mr. tested at varying operating levels for the next few weeks before full operations are restored.

Adela Holzer, who sponsored the Galt MacDermot - Gerome Ragni musical "Dude," last season, is shaping up as one of New York's busiest producers this season. On Feb. 3 she will present Terrence McNally's comedy "Bad Habits" at the Astor Place Theater, and next spring she will open a new musical, "Brainchild," on Broadway.

Joanne D. Chesimard's lawyer confirmed reports yesterday that her client was pregnant and expressed the belief that Mrs. Chesimard's trial for the murder of a New Jersey state trooper would be postponed.

After a busy day in their drugstores, a growing number of pharmacists, mostly from the Washington Heights area, have been meeting periodically for lectures about pharmacology that could upgrade the medical care their customers receive.

An opening bid of one club has two advantages for the makers of systems. It permits a maximum of exploration before the-game level is reached; and it names a suit that is rarely used for the final contract.

NEW DELHI-Some years ago, citing India as an instance, I wrote that a traveler moving around the world could learn a good deal of the different political systems he would encounter merely by glancing at the local press. If it is filled with bad news, he is in a democracy. Good news can be an ill omen.

DID you stuff an ash tray into your suitcase before checking out of that motel last summer? Not such a heinous crime, perhaps, but the fact remains that the purloining of such "souvenirs" from hotels and motels throughout the country has reached absolutely staggering proportions.

Sir Roger Casement's life was a personal tragedy enshrined in the seemingly unending collective tragedy of Britain's relations with Ireland. Born in 1864 near Dublin (but educated in Ulster), he was by nationality British and only gradually came to regard himself as an Irishman pure and simple.
TAIWAN-The last several years, politically among the bleakest that Taiwan has experienced, have ironically been the most outstanding economically.

UNION-Austria and New Jersey are, of course, an ocean apart, but a visit to Cafe Mozart. right in the heart of this township's business district, can result in one imagining that he Is spending.a brief interlude in Vienna or, perhaps, Salzburg.
Three fishermen who put out to sea on Jan. 12 for a planned five-day trip are back home this weekend, exhausted but otherwise in good health despite a two-week ordeal on the stormy North Atlantic.

To the Editor: Talk of impeachment or resignation seems unnecessarily limited. Wouldn't there be merit in a concurrent resolution of Congress, along these lines: (1) Praise for the President's historic successes abroad.
Plants are in. Rare Is the home these days that doesn't have at least one or one dozen house plants. Supplying the demand for indoor greenery is a big hustle in the nursery industry.

No evidence to substantiate widely publicized rumors of the existence of a "secret trust fund" belonging to President Nixon has been found thus far by investigators for the Senate Watergate committee, according to knowledgeable sources.

Every now and then, after a mild winter or two, someone announces that the climate is changing, that we soon will be growing date palms in New England. And just about the time this theory seems almost plausible, along comes a winter that makes grandfathers remember their boyhood.

WASHINGTON-As has nothing before, the Arab oil embargo and the current fuel shortage in this country have focused the attention of the American people and the Congress on multinational companies and their connections with United States foreign policy.

The paper shopping bagthat clue to taste and status-is-becoming an endangered species. Now is the time to invest in your own bag to carry around all the paraphernalia that seems essential for women on the go.

Miss Judith Lynn Tunstall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Tunstall of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to James Andrew Kennedy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy of Short Hills, N. J.

"More thah- anything else I felt motion in the landscape; in the fresh, easy-blowing morning wind, and in the earth itself, as if the shaggy grass were a sort of loose hide, and underneath it herds of wild buffalo were galloping, galloping...." As in this sentence from "My Antonia," Willa. Cather always writes of the world in a way to show it's alive.

Ron Steele, competing on his home hill, won the national ski-jumping championship today. Tom Dargay of Minneapolis had the longest ride of the day at Bakke Hill-322 feet in the first round-but his second jump was 290.

THIS writer is not one who believes that only whales or sea captains should review books like "Moby Dick" and no matter the rationale, I will not look for Eddie Egan's review of "Adam-12," but I do think It appropriate that a professional firefighter comment on a new series like ABC's "Firehouse" (Thursdays at 8:30 P.M.).

Ralph W. Piersall Jr., a partner in the international accounting firm of Haskins Sells, who directed the continuing education program at its executive offices at 1114 Avenue of the Americas, died Friday of a heart ailment in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived at 76 Birch Lane in Greenwich.

"Classroom tennis" has become a popular and profitable spinoff .of the boom in the game across the country. People are flocking to enroll in an "academy" or "institute" or "school" for an average course of a one-hour lesson 'a week for eight weeks at $50. It's a 'million-dollar, year-round business.
Leaders of 21 Western European Communist parties began a threeday conference here today in an attempt to define a common strategy on domestic and international issues.

ALBANY--One darK morning this week, Louise Strassenburg woke up at 4:45 A.M., left her house in Belle Terre at 6 o'clock, met her car pool in Rockland County two and a half hours later, and finally arrived at the State Capitol here at noon. Her day was just beginning.
No ban was imposed today by .the International Lawn Tennis Federation on professionals signing with World Team Tennis, but the threat was still there.

Members of the Cleveland Orchestra have voted, 83 to 2, to go on strike after tomorrow night's concert unless a new contract agreement is reached with the Musical Arts Association, which operates the orchestra.

Russian movie makers and Edward Lewis, the American producer of such films as "Spartacus" and "The Iceman Cometh," have joined to make a musical version of Maurice Maeterlinck's "The Blue Bird" in what Mr. Lewis termed "the first Soviet-American co-production."

The Federation of American Scientists proposed today that one way out of the atomic arms race would be for the United States and the Soviet Union to agree on the phased elimination of their land-based missile forces.

Syrian artillery today fired on Israeli engineering units in the Golan Heights, a military spokesman said here. He said that the Syrians prevented the Israeli units from carrying out engineering work in the central and southern sectors of the front, destroyed equipment and inflicted several casualties.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia The grim mood of expected austerity in which 1973 began for Yugoslavs turned out to be not so grim after all. There was belt-tightening to clear up a troubling lack of liquidity among enterprises, some small factories went bankrupt and closed, but the tidal wave that had been forecast did not appear.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, who plans to run this year for a fourth term, is considered the undoubted front runner even by his Democratic opponents. As the race begins to take shape, a number of factors in addition to the Republican Senator's ability as a campaigner and vote-getter are being cited by politicians of varying shades as making him the favorite.

WASHINGTON-For some years the military has been troubled by a seeming paradox of the nuclear age. It possessed nuclear weapons it probably could never use. And even if the weapons could be used, the military had more than it needed to destroy all the Russian cities. This was obviously an unnatural situation for military men reared on a notion that weapons are obtained to fight with as well as to deter wars.

A Puerto Rican-born banker who heads the Commonwealth's economic development office in New York, Ivan E. Irizarry, has been picked by Mayor Beame to be the city's Finance Administrator-the first member of the Puerto Rican community to head a superagency in the city government.

The Barnard College gymnasium floor was crossed with black circles and white lines for game and performance markers. As dancers dressed in simple black and white practice clothes traveled across the floor in the geometrically defined paths of Sandra Neels's "Excerpts" on Friday night, the interaction of the two geometries provided a compelling visual experience.

THE CONSUMER price index rose in December to 138.5 per cent of the 1967 base, indicating an 8.8 per cent increase in the cost of living for 1973. The rise in December alone was 0.7 per cent.... Auto deliveries by United States manufacturers in the Jan. 11-20 period dropped more than 30 per cent from the year-earlier
Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigaton said today that more than $400,000 stolen in an airport bank robbery last year had been recovered.

WASHINGTON-Major criminal indictments in the Watergate scandals are now only weeks away. Former White House heavyweights who never used to pause in anyone's outer offices, now sit and wait in the anterooms of the Watergate Special Prosecutor's office to see the small, well-manicured Texas lawyer who means so much to their future.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand--The clamant world demand for meat has recently, brought drastic changes in New Zealand's economic thinking. Traditionally New Zealand has been considered one big farm, producing butter, meat and wool for the British market.

WASHINGTON--"I suppose that it would sound Incredible to many people who did not know how I operate," said President Nixon last October in describing to the nation how he had refused to be told who had contributed to his 1972 campaign until after the election. Since that time, one of the President's own white papers has damaged his credibility on that score.

THE gasoline shortage and tight money appear to have put the brakes on the feverish development of campground facilities across the United States. In addition, campground operators are cutting rates and stepping up promotional efforts to offset a drop in business.

IF that's not football on the Columbia Broadcastng System Sundays at 6 P.M., it must be "60 Minutes." After a curious, if not highly questionable, vacation of four months, the CBS News hour is back.

Tucker of Princeton University published the first installment of a projected threevolume biography of the Soviet leader, tracing his career up to the consolidation of his dictatorship in 1929.
The number of smallpox cases reported worldwide doubled from 1972 to 1973, but the National Center for Disease Control said yesterday that this was no cause for alarm.

"I have a card from the company that says my job will be waiting for me. I've been working here 10 years and I really don't worry about it."

Miss Alexandra Mary Pletrasanta of New York, daughter of Mrs. Donald C. Malcom of Monte Carlo, Monaco, and the late Count Vittorio Pietrasanta of Genoa, Italy, plans to be wed, to Peter Henry Rose, also of New York. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's mother.

Leather coats and sportswear have become hot items in the Seventh Avenue market, and garment manufacturers are devoting a growing portion of their capacity to this type of apparel. The energy crisis nas thrown into question Japan's "economic miracle." Higher prices alone will add close to $10-billion to the country's balance- of- payments drain, this year, even assuming that imports are held down to last year's level.

Rorem is one of those composers who write most gracefully and interestingly about music and I enjoy both agreeing and disagreeing with him. Here in this new book, one phrase caught my mind. "Critics of words use words. Critics of music use words."

Mr. and Mrs. Curtis T. Ettinger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Carol Ettinger, to Dr. Wolf-Peter Kloevekorn, a surgical resident at the German Heart Center in Munich, Germany. The wedding is planned for June 9 here.

The administration of Gov. Robert Docking has been rocked by 24 indictments alleging political kickbacks. Those indicted by a Shawnee County grand jury Tuesday included the Governor's brother, George Docking, a Kansas City attorney, indicted on a count of conspiring to commit bribery, and Richard L. Malloy, the Governor's appointments secretary until Nov. 25, on a count of bribery.

To the Editor I am a fan. I like to watch and play all kinds of games, but I have to raise a loud noncheer for (or against) that travesty called the Pro Bowl. Professional football has become mundane enough (3 yards and a cloud of AstroTurf) without greedily prolonging the season with a meaningless game for meaningless stakes.

And the day's shooting begins on the 100,000-acre estate of the Earl of Seafield.

About 12 hours after he had brought 15,000 spectators to their feet at the Millrose Games with a brilliant finishing kick in the invitation schoolboy mile run, Mark Belger toed the starting line yesterday in the 1,000-yard run at the 25th annual Cardinal Hayes Games.

Sanderson, struck by a puck fired by the Islanders' Brian Spencer, had his left leg placed in a cast at Massachusetts General Hospital. Doctors said he would wear the cast for four to six weeks.

David Bromberg was late for his concert at Town Hall on Friday evening because his band got caught in a traffic jam. And he had one of his numbers completely deflated when, at a moment of pin-drop quiet as he was setting a mood, an usher came down the aisle and shouted, "No smoking!"

Dr. Jacob J. Silverman, a cardiovascular specialist, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 80 North Wyoming Avenue. His office was at 100 Central Avenue,' St. George, S. I.
Reggie Jackson of the Oakland A's was honored last night as the major leagues' best performer of 1973 when New York's baseball writers held their 51st annual awards dinner and follies.

Jim Bottomley, Sam Thompson and were elected yesterday to the Hall of Fame by the Baseball Veterans Committee. They, along with Mickey Mantle and Whitey Ford of the Yankees, elected by the writers last month, will be inducted Aug. 12 at Cooperstown, N. Y. Conlan is the only one of the three still living.

Jury selection began today in Superior Court in the second murder trial of Gail Madden, 27 years old, and George Merritt Jr., 30, who are charged with beating a Plainfield policeman to death during riots in this Union County city on July 16, 1967.

Fair to partly cloudy skies and milder temperatures are forecast today for the Northeast. Cooler conditions and rain will prevail throughout the rest of the Eastern Seaboard with showers ending early in the day in the eastern Ohio Valley.

Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the sixth-largest oil company in the nation, yesterday joined the parade of industry leaders showing a dramatic earnings growth in the fourth quarter-up 53 per cent-and an over-all growth in yearly performance.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Jan. 22.
President Nixon, in a special message to Congress, asked today for an 8 per cent cost-ofliving increase for educational benefits to veterans.
Legislation to guarantee the pension rights of 25 million to 30 million Americans was tentatively approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

United States reserve assets at the end of 1973 totaled $14.38-billion, with most of that total-$11.65-billion-resting in the nation's gold stockpile, the Treasury Department said today. American holdings of Special Drawing Rights, or "paper gold," issued by the International Monetary Fund, totaled $2.17-billion.
Marianna Tcherkassky made a very springlike and floating first appearance in Eliot Feld's "At Midnight" Sunday evening at the City Center during the American Ballet Theater's current season.
The Soviet Union conducted its first long-range tests of a new intercontinental missile with multiple warheads last Friday and Saturday, the Defense Department announced today.
Her fist clenched, a tense Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today the President "is in great health and I love him dearly and I have great faith."

Some market observers have expressed surprise that the stock of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company has shown such resiliency in view of the anticipated offering today of 4.5 million new common shares.

Three months after the October war, the Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank of the Jordan River and in the Gaza Strip speak more openly against Israeli occupation than at any time since they were conquered six and a half years ago.
The Long Island Lighting Company filed a request with the Public Service Commission today to increase electric rates by $58-million a year, approximately 19 per cent.

A state appeals court in Trenton ruled that an Irvington antipornography ordinance was invalid on the ground that it sought to pre-empt the state's authority in defining and prosecuting obscenity. The ruling upheld a decision by the Superior Court in Essex County, in a suit by the owners of an adult-book store against the town.

Nicholas Johnson, a former member of the Federal Communications Commission, urged a Senate subcommittee today to reject his nominated successor to assure that the country's communications systems and policies "are not subjected to excessive White House control."

Anthony M. Natelli, partner in charge of the Washington, D. C., office of Peat Marwick Mitchell Co., an accounting firm, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal District Court here to a Federal Grand jury indictment charging him with false and misleading statements in proxy material of the National Student Marketing Corporation.
Any expert who returns from a regional championship having won one major event, finished equal second in another, and third in yet another is entitled to feel well content..

Homer Smith, an assistant coach at Georgia Tech and former head coach at Davidson College, has accepted the job as head football coach at Army, The Atlanta Constitution said in its Tuesday editions. The newspaper said the official announcement would be made later this week at the United States Military Academy.
Firemen have voted to strike Feb. 5 in a dispute involving working conditions, fringe benefits, and the disciplining of the local union president for speaking to the press.

Bob Dylan and company arrived at the Nassau Coliseum this evening about a half-hour before their first New York area concert to find their usual backstage spread awaiting them - food, drinks and a variety of exotic costumes they have never worn.

The slump in big car sales may have reached bottom, according to some auto industry officials. Ben E. Bidwell, general manager of the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company, said dealer orders for standard-size cars were up in mid-January after a steady decline for months.
In its annual silver market review published yesterday, Handy Harmin, silver refiner and processor, predicted that current high prices for silver might weaken this year.

G. D. Searle Co., which has been reducing its dependence on the ethical drug business, is further diversifying its operations by planning to buy Oxford Laboratories, a manufactuer of liquid-handling systems, related supplies and chemical diagnostic products for clinical laboratories.

William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, told the Senate today that his office would act this week to give homeowners in the Northeast more equitable treatment in the prices they pay for heating oil.

The fifth announced candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of California is Secretary of State Edmund G. Brown Jr., whose father had to step down from the Governorship in 1968 after Ronald Reagan defeated him for the office.
Michel Jobert, dubbed the "Kissinger of France" even before he was named Foreign Minister last April, bore few similarities to the American Secre tary of State until recently.

Ralph Nader prompted an angry debate today when he accused the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy of covering up hazards in the nation's nuclear plants and suggested that the committee disband.

Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., New Jersey's highly unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor last year, announced today that Vice President Ford would appear at a March 23 party fund-raising dinner in Atlantic City to help pay off last year's Republican campaign debt.

Dr. Janet Zaph Briggs, vice president for technical information of the Climax Molybdenum Company division of American Metal Climax, Inc., of New York, died Thursday in Tokyo after a heart attack, where she was on a business trip. She was 62 years old lived at 320 East 42d Street.

The Greek Government today described Gen. George Grivas, the underground leader of the campaign for a union of Cyprus with Greece, as a "national hero,", ut decided against having his funeral in Athens.
An astute observation by a mother in Ireland of her son's injured hand has led an Irish doctor to report a simple new diagnostic test of the function of damaged nerves.

The United States' foreign trade showed a record surplus of exports. over imports in December and completed 1973 with a large and unexpected surplus of nearly $1.7-billion, the Commerce Department reported, bringing the trade balance up from a record deficit of almost $6.4-billion in 1972.
A Soviet trade official offered yesterday to sell wheat to the United States to help replenish grain stocks that have been drawn down to low levels after heavy exports over the last two years.

Methane from deep in a coal bed began to be piped into a commercial line today, demonstrating the practicality of a Government-developed technology that Interior Department researchers say, could almost double the nation's reserves of natural gas.

A military tribunal today condemned in absentia 62 fugitives who had been convicted of try ing to overthrow King Hassan II in an armed uprising last spring.
Muhammad Ali scored a 12-round decision over Joe Frazier last night at Madison Square Garden before 20,748 fans who created the first nontitle $1-million indoor gate in boxing history.
Tony Waldrop recorded his third sub-four-minute mile in 10 days, 3:58.9, and again stunned Marty Liquori on the last lap, this time in the last few strides of tonight's Philadelphia Track Classic.

Bob Dylan and The Band's first concert in the New York area at the Nassau Coliseum tonight probably represented about the average level of the current tour. Some of it was very, very good. Some of it was perfectly wretched. Most of it added up to convincing, if idiosyncratic, performances of some of the great songs of the nineteensixties.

Rabbi Solomon Shapiro, a chaplain of the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan, died Saturday of a heart attack at his office, 7 Park Avenue. He was 57 years old and lived at 230 West 79th Street.

The Arabian American Oil Company said yesterday that it was continuing to expand its petroleum capacity despite Arab oil restrictions although at a slower rate than had been planned before the Saudi Arabian embargo and production cutbacks.

Members of the Cleveland Orchestra agreed early this morning to sign a new 3 1/2year contract. They had been performing without a contract since last September and had voted to go on strike after last night if no agreement was reached.

Wharton Poor, an admiralty lawyer who was senior partner in the New York law firm of Haight, Gardner, Poor Havens, died Sunday in Flushing Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 141-49 33d Avenue, Flushing, Queens.
James T. Gies, a retired stockbroker in the Philadelphia office of Smith, Barney Co., Inc., died Friday at the Naval Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 68 years old and lived in Rosement Pa.

The president of the union representing floor personnel and clerical employes at the New York Stock Exchange warned yesterday of a possible strike next Monday if current contract talks failed to resolve differences.

David Quax of New Zealand, a distance runner, was suspended today from his country's team for publicly accusing the kenyans of rough tactics yans of rough tactics in the 10,000 meters race in the Commonwealth Games last Friday. Members of Congress, the Cabinet and top Federal officials are scheduled for pay rises exceeding 7 per cent in early March-and more again in 1975 and 1976.
Light heating oil in the Rotterdam mar ket, which influences the level of prices of petroleum products in the European market, has fallen more than 50 per cent from the high of early December.

Efforts of the Democratic majority in the State Assembly to enact a series of reforms designed to open up the Assembly committee system to the public were stymied today by the Republicans.

Sheik Ahmed Zaki al-Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum si Affairs, stressed here today that any reduction in his country's oil prices must be part of a joint reduction with the five other oil-producing countries of the Persian Gulf.

Temple University can become the seventh team in intercollegiate basketball history to reach the 1,000-victory plateau when the Owls host Drexl tomorrow night. Kentucky is the winningest team with 1,100 victories, followed by Kansas, Oregon State, St. John's, Pennsylvania, North Carolina and Temple.

Herbert L. Porter, the former scheduling director for the Committee for the Re-election of the President, pleaded guilty today to a charge of lying to the F.B.I. during its early investigation of the Watergate scandals.

Betty Lane, a soprano from Detroit who has studied in Atlanta and at the Juilliard School, gave a most impressive recital Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. The program was presented by the Harlem School of the Arts, where Miss Lane is studying with Dorothy Maynor, as part of its 10th anniversary celebrations.

Adler and Sullivan's Garrick Theater was leveled for a parking garage some years ago in Chicago; their Wainwright Building was scheduled to be torn down for a parking lot in St. Louis this spring. That is the classic route to oblivion for America's landmark buildings. The way to blacktop is paved with this country's architectural heritage.

Defense Secretary Schlesinger's explanation last week of the Administration's altered nuclear strategy answered some-but not all-of the major concerns advanced by its critics. The new strategy involves re-targeting some Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBM's) for a "counterforce" role of striking at Soviet military installations, including missile sites, as well as cities.

The Saigon Government ?? today arrested James M. Markham, Saigon bureau chief of the New York Times, as he emerged from a week in a Vietcong-held area near the central coast of South Vietnam, According to officials at the United States consulate in Nha Trang, Mr. Markham was taken into custody in Binh Dinh Province and was being held in the province capital of Qui Nhon, about 260 miles northeast of Saigon.
Abandoned automobiles, an ugly by-product of American affluence, have begun to disappear from roadsides, backyards and junkyards.

Representative James Harvey, a seven-term Republican from Saginaw, Mich, formally resigned his House seat today effective Thursday. He will be sworn in as a Federal judge for the eastern district of Michigan on Feb. 1.

The closed circuit telvision feed of the MuhamAli-Joe Frazier heavyweight fight failed minutes before the opening bell tonight at the Convention Center. About 3,000 fans, who paid up to $12.50 a ticket, were able only to hear the round-byround description.

Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, said yesterday that the energy crisis was not just a crisis of shortage but especially one of price, particularly for poor nations. He cited a fourfold rise in the price of light crude oil in two years. "We estimate that this price increase will cause the developing countries to spend $10billion more this year than they did last year, assuming they're able to continue their oil import."

Alfred H. Good, who retired as an assistant vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in 1955 after 51 years of service, died Saturday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco. He was 86 years old and lived here.

Republican members of the House Judiciary Committee have reached informal agreement that President Nixon could not be impeached for criminal acts of subordinates without evidence of his personal knowledge or direction.

Thick-bodied, strong and with a heavy-lipped mouth and powerful teeth that can crush mussels, barnacles or fiddler crabs with ease, the tautog is not a handsome fish, but he makes a splendid chowder. Known in Massachusetts as the tautog, he is also called a tiderunner and in parts of Connecticut and points south the blackfish.

A drafting committee completed work today on a new constitution that promises more individual rights to Thais than any of the nine previous constitutions. The charter now goes to the National Assembly for ratification.

A group of 13 women and children left Buffalo to return to their homes in Atlantic City today after Canadian officials had thwarted their attempt to flee a tidal wave that the group had feared would hit the famed convention city.
The trial of Mrs. Joanne Chesimard, who is accused of murdering a New Jersey state trooper, was postponed today for five days because she is in danger of having a miscarriage.
Richard M. Altman, assistant prosecu tor for Mercer County, told th jury in the Carpi murder cas today that the defendant mad not one but three "fatal errors."
John D. Ehrlichman, the indicted former top aide to President Nixon, plans to seek a subpoena tomorrow compelling Mr. Nixon to appear at a court hearing here Feb. 26, The Los Angeles Times reported.

The new World Football League yesterday shocked the established National Football League on the eve of its draft by announcing the signing of three prominent players-Jim McAlister and Kermit Johnson of the University of California, Los Angeles, and Booker Brown of Southern California.

United States Attorney Paul J. Curran filed a civil action in Federal Court yesterday seeking forfeiture of the Bulgarian fishing trawler Limoza, which was seized off the New Jersey Coast early Saturday morning.

William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, told the Senate today that his office would act this week to give homeowners in the Northeast more equitable treatment in the prices they pay for heating oil.

Joseph V. McKee Jr. has been named chairman, president and chief executive officer of the National Union Electric Corporation. He succeeds C. Russell Feldmann, who founded the floor-care equipment and air-conditioning company in 1947 and who died last month.

Negotiators for the union representing 2,800 teachers at the eight New Jersey state colleges said today they were going ahead with plans to strike the entire system on Monday.

The page width of both The Wall Street Journal and The National Observer will be reduced by about 2 inches to standard newspaper size in March, to stretch tight newsprint supplies and to save about $2.3-million a year, Dow Jones Co., Inc., the publisher, announced yesterday.

The Atomic Energy Commission said today it was proposing changes in its procedures for licensing nuclear power plants, in an effort to shorten the time needed to put such plants into operation.

" Super Fly is coming." Those words, stamped across envelopes leaving Austin Peay University in Clarksville, Tenn., herald the arrival of James (Fly) Williams, the school's sophomore basketball star, a product of the slums of Brooklyn.

The three major commercial television networks said yesterday they were setting aside time Friday night for the Democratic party's response to President Nixon's scheduled State of the Union Message on Wednesday night to Congress, according to an Associated Press report.

The United States Navy yesterday awarded an additional $79-million contract to the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, a unit of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, for continued development of the Trident submarine-launched ballistic missile.

President Suharto took command of the powerful state security agency today while abolishing the controversial posts of personal presidential assistant. Maj. Gen. Sudharmono the President's spokesman, said the steps had been taken in reaction to the student rioting earlier this month during a vis. it by the Japanese Premier, Kakuel Tanaka.

The scheduled resumption today of televised hearings by the Senate Watergate committee on financing of the 1972 Presidential campaign has been abruptly called off by Chairman Ervin. The cancellation came reportedly at the request of Paul J. Curran, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.
Foreign Minister Michel Jobert of France offered arms and large industrial investments to Kuwait today in exchange for long-term oil deliveries; Government sources reported.
Prime Ministerr Heath said tonight that he Government was considerng withholding unemployment benefitss from the families of oal miners in the event of a strike against the coal industry.
Corporate bond prices turned up yesterday, buoyed (partly at least) by the psychological lift of the broadening decline to a 9 1/2 per cent prime rate.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange raised the daily limits for world sugar prices yesterday. The three nearby contracts, March, May and July, promptly jumped the new 100-point limit, setting new contracts highs.

Mrs. Ann Klein was overwhelmingly confirmed by the State Senate today as Governor Byrne's Commissioner .of Institutions and Agencies after a week-long delay caused by questions raised by her husband's business interests.

"I can't say nothing bad about him," Ali admitted as he sat on an interview platform beside his defeated rival last night after Super Fight II at Madison Square Garden.
Insurgent gunners bombarded Phnom Penh for the fourth day today, hit ting the capital, a refugee camp and an area near Pochentong airport with artillery, rockets and recoilless-rifle fire.

The Long Island Rail Road management was unprepared for the ice storm that virtually paralyzed its operations of Dec. 16 and 17, and worsened the crisis by misjudging it, an investigatory board ruled yesterday.

" This is a pilgrimage; I ought to be crawling on my knees," a wet, bedraggled young man said tonight. He wasn't crawling. Instead, he was one of the 16,000 fans who had rushed through a downpour-many of them to hear Bob Dylan sing, in person, for the first time in their lives.

Three months after the October war, the Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank of the Jordan River and in the Gaza Strip speak more openly against Israeli occupation than at any time since they were conquered six and a half years ago.

A petition will be submitted In Washington this week by a United States Senator and a public health group calling for banning cigarettes containing 22 milligrams or more of tar. This would cover 20 per cent of the varieties on the market -27 brands-which account for 15 per cent of the cigarettes sold annually.

Replying to the Democratic party leadership's call for spending limitations in the party's primary, Representative Hugh L. Carey said today that he intended to spend "whatsoever is needed to reach the people."

The Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, flew to Cuba today on what he described as a friendly visit to "the island of freedom." The official visit, which had been originally expected to take place the end of December, is Mr. Brezhnev's first trip to Cuba, Premier Fidel Castro, who has been to the Soviet Union four times, last came here in December, 1972.

The Assembly passed and sent to the senate today a bill prohibiting chain-distributor schemes. Under such plans, a person is enticed into purchasing a line of usually worthless products and the right to sell distributorships for them.
An American captured by the Chinese on the Paracel Islands during fighting between Chinese and South Vietnamese forces will be released Thursday, China announced today.
New pressure to force a delay of Friday's scheduled beginning of mandatory automobile exhaust inspections in New Jersey surfaced today in the State Senate.
Lehman Brothers has completed a study of its role in the Government securities market and has decided not to trade Treasury bills, notes and bonds, Arthur W. Fried, partner, confirmed yesterday.
The Parole Board refused today to free former Representative Cornelius L. Gallagher for attempting to evade income taxes.

Hanna Kolesnik took total command of the stage at Hunter College's Assembly Hall Sunday night, communicating much of the presence and authority that she undoubtedly brought to the Ukrainian Kiev Opera, where she was a leading artist.
Julius-Patzak, noted Austrian tenor, died here Saturday. He; was 75 years old.

, an expert on chemical warfare and emeritus professor of chemistry at Columbia University, died Saturday in Livingston. He was 89 years old and lived here. His widow, the former Elizabeth K. Born survives.

The Long Island Rail Road management was unprepared for the ice storm that virtually paralyzed its operations on Dec. 16 and 17 and worsened the crisis by misjudging it, and investigatory board ruled yesterday.
Dr. Paul R. Stewart, president of Waynesburg College from 1921 to 1963, when he became chancellor, died yesterday. He was 86 years old.
The New England Whalers rallied for five goals in the final period tonight and defeated the Vancouver Blazers, 6-4. John French netted the deciding goal with less than nine minutes left to play.
The chairman of the State Senate Crime and Correction Committee today recommended shutting down virtually all of the Manhattan House of Detention as an "architectural monstrosity."

Some 8,000 persons attending the closed circuit attending the closed-circuit Ali-Joe Frazier fight in New York rioted at Hara Arena near here tonight when the video portion of the telecast went blank minutes before the bout started.
Thick-bodied, strong and with a heavy-lipped mouth and powerful teeth that can crush mussels, barnacles or fiddler crabs with ease, the tautog is not a handsome fish, but he makes a splendid chowder.

To the Editor: According to The Times of Jan. 21 Senator Adlai E. Stevenson has called hearings by a Senate subcommittee to review the potentially adverse effects of growing foreign investment in the country. However, such investment should be encouraged, not discouraged.

, chairman and chief executive officer of the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, conceded in a speech here today that the oil industry and his company had made mistakes in the past that had contributed to the energy crisis.

The nation's foreign trade showed a record surplus of exports over imports in December and finished the year 1973 with a large and unexpected surplus of almost $1.7-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

A loss In match play has a far more damaging psychological effect than a loss in tournament play because the match contestant must sit down again the next day to face the same victorious opponent. While it's advisable to put defeats out of mind before beginning a new game, that's scarcely possible when staring across the table at a face that all but creates the debacle all over again in imagination.
Mrs. Elizabeth Richardson Veblen, widow of Dr. Oswald Veblen, a mathematician, died Saturday at the Princeton Medical Center. She was 92 years old and lived at 452 Herrontown Road here.
The Insurance Institute for Highway Sefety said today that new American cars were generally no better, and in some cases were much worse, than last year's at avoiding damage in minor collisions.

Since they opened Odalisque, a boutique catering to sizes 16 through 24, a year ago Bonnie Munshin and Marlene Tokatyan have been fighting the conservatism to which large women have been conditioned and trying to get their customers into bright, pretty clothes. Clothes that.

Among the useful accomplishments of the "war on poverty" initiated by President Johnson a decade ago was establishment of a Government-funded but politically independent legal services program to assure highquality legal assistance in civil cases to those who would not otherwise be able to afford it.

Last May, Gen. George Grivas, still striving to achieve through terrorism the union of his native Cyprus with Greece, wrote to President Makarios: "You are to blame for our struggle turning from an aggressive one, such as that of EOKA, into a defensive one in the political field."
Pace University, just east of City Hall downtown (2853627) is back with its "Lunch and Learn" series, which involves stuffing your belly and brain at the same time.

In terms of scalping, The Fight II was worth only an Arabic number. "That one three years ago was an international event," said a scalper discreetly standing beyond Madison Square Garden's building line yesterday.
A Unitarian minister d was sentenced to three months in the county workhouse today for embezzling $109,000 from t a family counseling service while he was treasurer of the organization in 1972.

The defense in the trial of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell sought yesterday to show that people who invested in a cash-only getrich-quick scheme believed the operation was a "legitimate business enterprise."

The Securities and Exchange Commission will begin public hearings today in Washington on options trading in order to determine, among other things, whether certain exchanges should be allowed to start pilot programs.
Maj. Ranulf Compton, U.S.A, retired, a former United States Representative, died Saturday at his summer home here. His age was 92.

Mrs. Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the city's Human Rights Commission, disclosed yesterday that her agency had denied the Trans World Airlines request to reopen a 1969 case in which a former Jewish employe was awarded $11, 889 after the agency found the airline had tolerated religious discrimination.

Mrs. Nancy Dwyer Donovan, a financial analyst, who helped found the American Society of Security Analysts, died of cancer yesterday in French Hospital. She was 49 years old and lived at 210 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y.

The "best" players in the National Hockey League do not necessarily insure the best kind of hockey game, but the league's all-star game usually creates a lot of hoopla, and the 27th annual game, tomorrow night is expected to fill the 16,666 seats of Chicago Stadium.
Lee H. Hill, chairman of the New York management consultant firm of Rogers, Slade Hill, died here yesterday on a business trip.
Syracuse University's Chancellor, Dr. Melvin Eggers, and his new head football coach, Frank Maloney,

Production of steel during the week ended Jan. 26 rose by 0.5 per cent to 2.9 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index rose to 118.9 from 118.3 in the preceding week when production totaled 2,887,000 tons.

The Administration's national health insurance proposal, scheduled t go to Congress soon, would require workers to pay income tax on health insurance premiums contributed by their employers, Administration officials disclosed today.
President Nixon, as expected, announced today that he had redesignated as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board for a second four-year term.

If Secretary of the Treasury Shultz quits, and he is said to be ready to go, President Nixon may have to resign after all, not because of Watergate but because he is running out of people to run the Government.

The defense in the murder trial of 'Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano elicited testimony from the state's chief witness today that Eugene Bauer was dying, and could have been dead, when he was examined by the physician for vital life signs.

The institution of the night Mayor, which was ballyhooed at the start of the Lindsay era at City Hall but downgraded to near-disappearance in the waning weeks of the John V. Lindsay's tenure, returned in its original strength last Might.
No-fault auto insurance becomes compulsory Friday for New York 'State's estimated seven million motor vehicle operators.

Frank Kendrick sank two free throws with one second remaining to give Purdue a 67-65 victory over Ohio State tonight as the Boilermakers maintained their lead in the Big Ten Conference basketball race.
Syracuse University's Chancellor, Dr. Melvin Eggers, and his new head football coach, Frank Maloney, gave their versions yesterday of what they expect in the way of
" Europeans always liked gold more than paper money," Edward Wolf, a jeweler from McKees Rock, Pa., observed yesterday. "Now, Americans have gotten the gold fever."

Herbert L. Porter, the former scheduling director for the Committee for the Re-election of the President, pleaded guilty today to a charge of lying to the F.B.I. during its early investigation of the Watergate scandals.

The Association of the Bar of the city of New York said yesterdayy that it had received "numerous" requests for copies of its report on Presidential impeachment. The report con:luded that acts "which undermine the integrity of government" were sufficient grounds for impeachment.

ROME, Ides of March-Despite doomsayers' forecast of the end of the western part of the Roman Empire in this year A.D. 476, a survey by Danielius Yankelovicius, a leading publica opinion research organization, found that two-thirds of those questioned thought that Rome would not decline or fall. Only e pluribus unum, Gibbonius by name, believed that the Eternal City's long-term outlook was bleak.

Thirty members of the Police Department's Emergency Services Section will start school tonight in a new program that it is hoped will save as many as 4,000 victims of heart attacks in the city each year.
John Desmond Pagan, a vice president of Windsor Knit Company, New York apparel manuFacturer, died yesterday in Valley Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 105 North Pleasant Avenue.
Sometime Friday morning, within hours after the state's new no-fault auto insurance law takes effect, a small but vocal group of lawyers expects to launch a legal challenge to the statute.

The Israeli Army today lifted its siege of Suez city and evacuated a large surrounding area, handing it over to United Nations troops. Five hours later the area was transferred back to Egyptian armed forces who lost it last October.

David Quax of New Zealand, a distance runner, was suspended today from his country's team for publicly accusing the Kenyans of rough tactics in the 10,000-meters race in the Commonwealth Games last Friday.

A Federal appeals court affirmed a decision to free a narcotics defendant who had been arrested and searched under a state loitering law that was later declared unconstitutional. The case involved Leon Newsome, who appealed his conviction on a narcotics-possession charge that grew out of evidence seized when he was arrested for loitering in the lobby of a City Housing Authority building in Queens four years ago.

In a sweeping and harshly worded decision, a National Labor Relations Board judge accused the Farah Manufacturing Company of Texas today of wholesale "lawlessness" and ordered the company to restore all striking workers to their jobs and to permit union organization of its factories.

The International Air Transport Association said yesterday in Montreal that its member airlines had voted to raise passenger fares on most international routes by 7 per cent on March 1 to defray higher jet fuel costs.
The Omaha Civic Auditorium manager, Charlie Mancuso, said tonight the last-minute rush to see the closed-circuit television showing of the AliFrazier weight was "unlike anything I've seen before."

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest plywood producer with important positions in the lumber, chemical, paper and gypsum fields, reported yesterday that it had lifted its fourth-quarter net earnings by 44.9 per cent.
Ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment came up for a vote today in the Georgia legislature and was defeated. It will come up in Ohio in a week or so, and will probably pass.

Chief delegates to the four-nation International Control Commission will fly to Hanoi tomorrow, for the first time since the commission was founded one year ago, for talks with North Vietna?? officials.

The Beame administration is in the final stages of drafting a proposal to repeal the vacancy-rentdecontrol law and provide retroactive rent rollbacks for at least some of the nearly 400,000 apartments that have been decontrolled in the last three years.

After 12 busy rounds that were virtually an extension of their 1971 classic, Muhammad Ali was awarded a unanimous decision over Joe Frazier at Madison Square Garden last night before a $1,053,688 for a nontitle, indoor bout.

Fourth-quarter net income of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reached $143-million, or $2.93 a share, compared with $105-million, or $2.14 a share for the 1972 quarter, the nation's largest chemical producer said yesterday in a preliminary report.

After two years of economic crisis and political instability, Bangladesh has taken a few fragile steps forward. A five-year development plan has been shaped, bluntly concluding-that Bangladesh will remain in "dismal poverty" in the near future but charting a reconstruction program that has impressed some foreign economists.

As a rule, contemporary concerts deserve the neglect that they receive from the concertgoingg public. The quality of the works aside, most avant-garde programs are presented with no apparent intention to please anyone but the players, who rather often seem to regard music disinterestedly, with the objectivity of trained carburetor mechanics.
Terry Orr may not have got his girl in American Ballet Theater's "La Fille Mal Gardee" on Sunday afternoon, but he certainly won over the City Center audience.

Hanna Kolesnik took total command of the stage at Hunter College's Assembly Hall Sunday night, communicating much of the presence and authority that she undoubtedly brought to the Ukrainian Kiev Opera, where she was a leading artist.

An American was ordered expelled from Berlin today after the authorities found that he had been living here under a false identity and posing as a newsman. An American spokesman said that the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington had found through fingerprints that the man, known here as Calvin Williams, was Charles Davis, 46 years old, of Dallas.:He was charged with violation of American passport regulations;

Australia's Rod Laver, who beat Arthur Ashe in the final 'of the United States professional indoor tennis championship yesterday, beat Ashe for the second day in a row today, but in another sport-golf.

No-fault auto, insurance becomes compulsory Friday for New York State's estimated seven million motor vehicle operators. It will apply to all motor vehicles except for privately operated motorcycles electrically driven invalid chairs, vehicles on rails or tracks and snowmobiles.
, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, has decided once again to delay his muchdelayed departure for a professorship at the University of Virginia.

In June, 1970, when all President Nixon had to worry about were little things like Vietnam and the skyrocketing cost of living he went on television to bid Americans be of good cheer He had invented a device for checking inflation without forcing the nation down the slippery road of wageprice controls.

The trial of Henry Brown in the fatal shooting of two policemen on the Lower East Side two-years ago opened yesterday with the prosecutor telling the jury that Mr. Brown had, "in effect," confessed to acquaintances that he had shot the officers.

With most of the theaters that offered closed-circuit television of the Joe FrazierMuhammed Ali bout last night sold out of $12 unreserved seats, fight fans in the metropolitan area were forced to turn to more expensive locations if they hoped to view the nontitle 12-round contest.

Jorge Ahumada of Argentina put himself in line for a light-heavyweight title shot last night by knocking out Bobby Cassidy of Levittown, L.I., in the third round of their scheduled 10-rounder at Madison Square Garden.

Farreaching tentative proposals for the improvement and preservation of Long Island Sound -ranging from mandatory onboard or dockside sewage treatment facilities for the 80,000 boats on the Sound and its tributaries,

The Phelps Dodge Corporation reported yesterday preliminary fourthquarter income of $34.5-million, or $1.68 a share, up from the yearearlier $23.2-million, or $1.13 a share. The earnings in the 1972 quarter included a net capital gain of $4.3million, or 21 cents a share after income taxes, on sales of securities.

A bill authorizing more than $100-million a year for new programs of Indian education was approved without dissent today by the Senate Interior Comimittee. One section authorizes $45-million for Government contracts to assist school districts in the fiscal year starting early July 1, 1975, when the new act would take effect and $60-million a year for six years thereafter.

Ed Allen, a jazz trumpeter and cornetist who played with Earl Hines, King Oliver and Bessie Smith, died yesterday afternoon at Lincoln Hospital after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 700 East 139th Street.

6-10 A.M., WNCN. Overture and Minuet from Julius Caesar, Handel; Capriccio Brillante in B minor, Mendelssohn; Courtly Dances from Gloriana, Britten; Sonata for Violin Solo, Geminiani; Prelude, Fugue, and Riffs, Bernstein; Spanish Theater Music of the 17th Century, Various; Pastorale for Woodwind Quintet, Persichetti;

Despite widespread speculation that the Senate Watergate committee had held its last public session, Samuel Dash, the committee's chief counsel, insisted today that the hearings would resume and instructed his staff to continue to prepare for them.
One of the longest and strangest labor disputes in the history of France ended today with a partial and dearly bought victory for the workers and a sigh of relief from a watching nation.

The cordial greeting cabled to President Nixon by Leonid Brezhnev, "flying close to the shores of the United States" on his way to Cuba, symbolizes-if taken at face value-the improvement in Soviet-American relations of recent years.

The Uniformed Firefighten Association was fined $650,00( yesterday for conducting strike in defiance of a court order last November. The fine against the city fire men's union for the five-and-a half hour strike last Nov. 6, the first in the department's 108 year history, is believed by the Corporation Counsel's office to be the largest ever levied for a violation of the state's Taylon Law, which forbids walkouts by public employes.

King Baudouin dissolved the Belgian Parliament tonight after efforts to form a new coalition Cabinet had failed. As a result, new elections are mandatory within 40 days, and March 10 was mentioned as a likely date.

In ordering the housing authorities to play a major role in the integration of Mark Twain Junior High School, Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein has put the spotlight on the basic underlying cause of the increase in urban school segregation. Regrettably, the ruling followed up its perceptive diagnosis with the imposition of unrealistic remedies in the effort to balance the Coney Island school's racial composition.

WEIMAR, East GermanyReligion is tolerated, definitely not encouraged, under Communism in East Germany, but musicians here and in the other cities where Johann Sebastian Bach lived and worked from 1685 to 1750 are maintaining a lively tradition of church music, through sometimes difficult conditions.

There have been rumbles from Baltimore, where Sergiu Comissiona holds forth as conductor of the local orchestra. Reports have it that the Rumanian-born conductor is a supervirtuoso, a young Bernstein, a musician who drives audiences wild. But he has done relatively little work in New York.

A 7-year-old handicapped girl was critically injured today in a crash of the school bus in which she was riding and a small automobile at the intersection of Red Ground Road and Old Westbury Road, the Nassau County police said.

Egyptian troops in the Sinai along with soldiers and civilians in heavily damaged Suez city celebrated their reunion with the rest of Egypt in an explosion of joy, Soldiers and irregulars, who had beaten back an Israeli attempt to penetrate the core of the city three months ago, roamed the streets all day. They fired submachine guns, rifles arid revolvers into the air, and danced on the wrecks of Israeli tanks. [1:1-2.]

James M. Markham, Saigon bureau chief of The New York Times, was released last night after 39 hours in the custody of the Government police, who had arrested him for making a oneweek visit to a Vietcong-held area.
The Muhammad Ali-Joe Frazier fight last night put a strain on Frankfurt's telephone and water services.

Mario Andretti was injured today when his Indianapolis racing car spun at 185 miles an hour and hit the wall during tire tests at Ontario Motor Speedway. The 33-year-old ace was momentarily unconscious, but was reported "conscious and alert" at nearby San Antonio Community Hospital. He was said to have suffered a slight concussion and a whiplash.
Merck Co., Inc., a worldwide producer of pharmaceutical drugs, yesterday reported a record fourth-quarter net income of $42.3-million, or 57 cents a share, up 16 per cent from the 1972 level.
The Union Pacific Corporation, which owns the railroad of the same name, reported yesterday its earnings rose 9 per cent in the fourth quarter of last year and 22 per cent in the full year.
H. E. Bates, the author, whose best work was inspired by the English countryside, as in "the Darling Buds of May," died today in a hospital at Canterbury, Kent. He was 68 years old.
John Hicks, the No. 1 draft choice of the New York Giants, has no preference as to whether he plays offensive guard or tackle next year, as long as he plays.
The General Accounting Office told Congress today that President Nixon had no legal authority to order Secret Service protection for Spiro T. Agnew after Mr. Ag new resigned as Vice President.
Two Federal District Court judges ruled here today that 153 men accused in 1972 of draft evasion by the Government were deprived of their constitutional "protection against false accusation."
Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum Affairs told Japanese oil company officials today that his country hoped to increase the production of petroleum after peace returns to the Middle East.

The talks between Moscow and Washington on the limitation of strategic arms, which the Nixon Administration hoped would be resumed on Jan. 31, are now scheduled to resume early in February, according to an official source.

The president of the Chicago Board Options Exchange asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to refuse to permit other securities exchanges to trade in stock options until an integrated market system could be devised.

DOUALA, Cameroon -- Holding a cardboard figure of a man against a black cloth stretched across one classroom wall, Sam Kofi, an English teacher, asked, "Who is this man?" And 45 pupils told him in unison, "That is Mr. Jones."
Cazzie Russell scored 8 of Golden State's first 11 points in the last quarter, turning a close National Basketball Association game into a 128-121 Warriors' victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight.
Bob Dylan's second metropolitan-area concert started just like the first one tonight-a pleasant mature crowd sitting and listening to the words and the music.
Today we give you the early nineteenforties before the New Look, ancient Greece, Marjorie Morningstar Goes to Grossinger's and other irrelevancies.
The official Communist party newspaper, Pravda, today accused the Pentagon of trying to prevent American businessmen from engaging in trade with the Soviet Union.

Senate Watergate committee investigators have developed information that Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's close friend, may have converted Presidential campaign money to his personal use, according to well-placed committee officials.

Boris Spassky won his quarter-final match in the world chess championship preliminaries yesterday when he defeated Robert Byrne in the sixth game of their match in San Juan, P.R. The victory was Spassky's third in his match with Byrne.
John Shumat scored 27 points and Bill Paterno got 14 tonight, leading third-ranked Notre Dame to a 69-63 victory over No. 5 Marquette.

After conceding that they could and should have done more to prevent the resignation of Commissioner Richard J. Sullivan, some of New Jersey's leading environmentalists conferred with Governor Byrne today in an effort to advise him on Mr. Sullivan's successor as head of the State Department of Environmental Protection.
The ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee said today that President Nixon could not use executive privilege to withhold information from the impeachment inquiry.
The Metropolitan Opera, which seems to have had more than its share of difficulties this season, ran into another one yesterday that left a lot of operagoers disappointed last night.
President Nixon in his State of the Union Message tomorrow will propose what is described as a big, new income-maintenance program, a form of "negative income tax" for the poor.
Egyptian troops in the Sinai along with soldiers and civilians in this rubble-strewn city celebrated their reunion with the rest of Egypt in an explosion of joy today.

The Administration's plan to relinquish $2.2-billion rupees to India was denounced today at a House hearing, 'and a New York Congressman announced his intention to introduce a resolution that would condemn the move as "one of the greatest give-aways."
The headlines that confronted the Israeli newspaper reader today could hardly have brought cheer to the breakfast table:

Commission on Status of Women-10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Commission on Human Rights, committee on periodic reports-10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Working group on procedure for dealing with violations of human rights-10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

ABELSON--Mos, on Jan. 28, 1974. Beloved husband of Hattie. Devoted father of Sidney Abelson, Doris Goldblatt, Lubs Janell, Judith Kornblatt Shirley Cohen. Loving grandfather of 13 and great-grand-father. Brother of George, Services Wednesday 12 noon at Hirsch Sons Chapel, 1225 Jerome Ave. (at 167 St.), Bronx.
The Government ended today its array of controls over the outflow of dollars for lending and investing abroad. Some of the controls were more than a decade old.
Severe price controls, the cornerstone of President Juan D. Peron's economic policy, are contributing to large-scale smuggling of Argentine goods into neighboring countries.

The attitude toward the big one that got away is one of the many differences between the fisherman and the bridge player. The angler is eager to tell his story to any listener, but the declarer who has missed the chance to make the play of a lifetime is usually, reticent. Luckily his opponents, if observant, will insure that the deal is not lost to posterity.

While the Government warns that the nation still faces a "critical" heating-fuel situation, many dealers and distributors who provide fuel oil to homes in the Northeast say their storage tanks are full and the threat of a shortage this winter has been all but eliminated.
Japan surrered a record annual balance-of payments deficit totaling $10.07-billion in 1973, the Finance Ministry said today.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a 91.1 per cent increase in net income for the fourth quarter of 1973, and a gain of 107.5 per cent for the 12 months of 1973. However, the nation's largest steel producer still said that the return on sales was modest in comparison with other years.
Benjamin Steinberg, founder of the Symphony of the New World, died yesterday at his home, 520 East 90th Street. He was 58 years old.

The following list of some of the city's most popular "extra" men was culled from 'the address books of a number of' hostesses. Not all the men (alphabetically arranged) are on every list - each hostess has her own favorites.

Governor Wilson said today that he would submit to the Legislature a proposal requiring that automobile insurance companies pass on to their policyholders any savings brought about by the energy shortage.
The ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee said today that President Nixon could not use executive privilege to withhold information from the impeachment inquiry.

The disgraceful jurisdictional squabble between two House committees that blocked final action on pension reform last year has apparently been broken. The welcome-but still by no means certain-result is an improved prospect for enactment of legislation to rein- d force the private pension plans on which thirty million workers rely for an important part of old-age security.

When it comes to animal life, we've had the Disney version. Over and over again. For the moment, it's possible for a child to get another, less pat, view of the world of creatures, through the eyes of Heinz Seilmann, a filmmaker and zoologist. There are two of his films in the city. One is the much-acclaimed "Vanishing Wilderness." The other,
Microphone in, hand, a jubilant Muhammad. Ali informed the world yesterday that he "didn't need" George Foreman.
President Nixon returned to the White House tonight from Camp David, where he spent a long weekend preparing for his State of the Union message to Congress and the nation tomorrow night.
A Federal grand jury indicted a 31-year-old former sailor yesterday on charges of attempting to smuggle five pistols and 150 rounds of ammunition into Britain in the false bottom of a trunk.

CHARMED CIRCLE: GERTRUDE STEIN AND COMPANY. By James R. Mellow. 528 pages. Illustrated. Praeger. $12.95. It is tempting to say of Gertrude Stein, as F. R. Leavis said of the Sitwells, that she belongs more to the history of publicity than to the history of literature.

PARIS--Whatever happens at President Nixon's conference of petroleum consumers next month, the kind of united front both he and Secretary Kissinger have been proposing to our allies has seemingly vanished long before the opening session.
The Senate sent the energy emergency. bill back to a House-Senate conference today, raising doubts that Congress will give the Nixon
The question last summer was whether the President could be ordered to comply with a subpoena. A number of judges replied that he could.
The Penn Central Company said today it was challenging the constitutionality of certain provisions of a Federal law intended to aid financially ailing railroads.

A 10-year dispute over school busing in this community has grown more bitter in the last two years and, in the estimation of many' residents, now threatens to intensify divisions between some blacks and some whites.

The dismantling of United States controls on foreign investment by Americans was interpreted in Europe today as an effort to check the rise in the dollar's value abroad to preserve American trading surpluses.
Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz gave his personal answers today to three of the most controversial questions confronting the securities markets and their regulators. They were:

sources close to John D. Ehrlichman said today that the move to subpoena President Nixon in Los Angeles in no way indicated a personal break between Mr. Nixon and his former White House domestic adviser.
Nora Holt, music critic of The New York Amsterdam News for many years, died Friday in a nursing home in Los Angeles. She was 89 years old.
A gyroscope on Mariner 10, speeding through space toward Venus and Mercury acted erratically yesterday, wasting about 25 per cent. of the spacecraft's control fuel.

Followers of the late Gen. George Grivas became embroiled in a dispute today over where he would be buried. His widow asked that he be buried in Athens, but his lieutenants insisted on a grave near the battlegrounds in Cyprus.

Herb Garaner, whose playwriting credits include "A 'Thousand Clowns" and "The Goodbye People," has written a new play, "Thieves," that will have its Broadway premiere at the Broadhurst Theater on March 21.

Vincent F. Albano, the Republican leader in Manhattan, said yesterday that Governor Wilson would appoint a Democrat as interim district attorney to succeed the ailing Frank S. Hogan, who officially retires next Wednesday.

The city bar association's grievance committee apparently disregarded its own longstanding policy when it decided last week to initiate disciplinary action against William M. Kunstler, the outspoken defender of radical

The city's jail and prison population has dropped sharply, and observers of the criminal justice system say some of the reasons are reductions in both the crime rate and drug addiction as well as new alternatives to pretrial detention and more efficient court administration.
Mike Laughton scored a goal and picked up two assists tonight as the Jersey Knights beat the Toronto Toros, 6-1, and left the World Hockey Association's East Division cellar.

The Universal Gas and On Company , Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell one of three liquified petroleum gas carrier vessels under construction in France to an unnamed interrational shipping company for "32.5-million.
The head of the General Services Administration acted improperly in selling an Air Force facility to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation without bids, Senator William Proxmire said today.

Increased expenditures for exploration and refinery expansion were announced yesterday by two major oil companies. Texaco, Inc., the nation's third largest oil company and the largest seller of gasoline, said it was beginning a $240million construction program to increase its domestic capability to refine imported crude oil at four of its major refineries.

Premier Fidel Castro told a crowd gathered in Havana to welcome Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party Leader, tonight that Cuba would always be grateful to the Soviet Union for its help in coping with the United States' economic blockade of the island.

Dr. Marvin J. Stern, a chemistry professor and research scientist, died at his home here this afternoon at the age of 38. Dr. Stem, a doctoral graduate in physical chemistry from Rutgers University, was employed by the Schering Pharmaceutical Corporation.

The eligibility of four, of Governor Wilson's reappointments to the Commission of Correction came under challenge today as the Senate Finance Committee questioned the ability of the commission to fulfill its new role as a prison ombudsman. Opening the committee appointment hearings to the press for the first time, the chairman, Senator John J. March, indicate the panel would depart from the Senate tradition of routinely consenting to gubernatorial appointments.

WASHINGTON - Every other Tuesday at 6:30 A.M., before concentrating on matters of war and peace, a dozen admirals and generals assemble in the Secretary of the Army's private dining room at the Pentagon for coffee, doughnuts and 90 minutes of Bible study.

Four persons who were nearby when police officers Rocco Laurie and Gregory Foster were slain two years ago on the Lower East Side testified yesterday in the murder trial of Henry Brown, a reputed leader of a group that the police call the Black Liberation Army.
The United States Government has advised Americans in Grenada to leave the Caribbean island because of increasing political and economic tensions there.
David Wilkie, a student at the University of Miami, won Scotland's first gold medal of the Commonwealth Games today in the 200-meter individual medley swimming.

Carl Billman, national secretary of Phi Beta Kappa, the collegiate honor society, until his retirement Jan. 1 after 26 years as chief operating officer, died of a stroke Saturday in the Winchester (Mass.) Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Bethesda. Md.

An international consortium of major metals producers led by the Kennecott Copper Corporation announced yesterday a five-year research and development program to determine the feasibility of mining manganese nodules from the deep sea.

The Senate Judiciary Committee reported to the Senate floor today a bill that would establish a separate State Supreme Court part to mediate and try malpractice cases-a system long urged by the American Medical Association but one yet to be implemented anywhere in the country.

One of Britain's brightest repertory companies, the Actors Company, has come into town for a season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, as part of the academy's admirable British theater season. It opened last night with a rare but delightful Chekhov, his little-known "The Wood Demon."
Egyptian troops in the Sinai along with soldiers and civilians in this rubble-strewn city celebrated their reunion with the rest of Egypt in an explosion of joy today.

Independent truckers, intent upon a nationwide strike, disrupted some fuel deliveries and harassed working drivers yesterday. Violence was reported in two states. In Ohio, four trucks were shot at and the windshields on nine others were smashed.
Mrs. Irma Hirsch Ackerman, the wife of Myron H. Ackerman, president of Ackerman Associates, a textile manufacturer, died of anemia yesterday at her home, 1130 Park Avenue. She was 56 years old.

Dillon Anderson, a special assistant to President Dwight D. Eisenhower for national security affairs in 1955-56, died yesterday. He was 67 years old and had practiced law here since 1929.

After four hours of deliberation, a jury of seven men and five women in the Carpi murder trial demonstrated their uncertainty today by asking for a lengthy rereading of the testimony of four witnesses.

The season's second concert in the series known as "The Continuing AvantGarde," presented on Monday night by the Dorian Woodwind Quintet at Carnegie Recital Hall, held to a determinedly constricted view of contemporary music. Without exception, the five works on the program were immersed in theoretical corn plexities of the sort that schoolmen delight in but that do not necessarily add up to much musically.

Israel's Attorney General has rebuked the military commander who led the Israeli breakthrough to the west bank of the Suez Canal in the October war. At issue were newspaper interviews in which the commander criticized his superiors.

Both sides in the proceeding against the first defendant in this city's largest mass murder case agreed today that he could not get a fair trial in this area of Texas because of wide publicity about the 27 killings.

The eligibility of four of Governor Wilson's reappointments to the Commission of Correction came under challenge today as the Senate Finance Committee questioned the ability of the commission to fulfill its new role as a prison ombudsman.

The death on Saturday of Princess Emily Cito-Filomarino di Bitetto of Paris, widow of Prince Carlo of that Neapolitan princely family, was reported today by her cousin, Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island. She was 90 years old.
Two persons died and four were rescued by an oil tanker today 12 hours after their 61-foot schooner ran into a storm and hit shoals six miles at sea.

American Airlines, Inc.,, announced yesterday that it had sold two of its 747 aircraft to the Boeing Company, Seattle, Wash., at book value - about $18,5-million each. At the same time, the airline reported that it had placed an order with Boeing for 14 Boeing 727-200 at $7 to $8-million each.

Dr. Leslie Lukash, the Nassau County Medical Examiner, testified today that Eugene Bauer had died as a result of an injection of potassium chloride, among other physical reasons, but later conceded that there was no scientific basis for his conclusion.

An oil participation agreement was signed today giving Kuwait a 60 per cent controlling interest in operations of the Gulf Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., in this Persian Gulf sheikdom, semiofficial sources reported.

As those who go to the New York City Ballet know, Jerry Zimmerman is the company's piano soloist-the one with the spectacular halo of blond hair. Monday night he moved from the New York State Theater to Alice Tully Hall to make his debut here as a recitalist.
