A nationwide 3-cent-a-gallon increase in the price of gasoline to retailers was announced yesterday by the Mobil Oil Corporation amid indications that gasoline supplies generally would be shorter this month than they were in January.

Jack Dempsey won a technical knockout yesterday in his court fight to keep his Broadway restaurant from being evicted, but his landlord's seconds promised that there would be a rematch. The 78-year-old former heavyweight boxing champion has presided over the restaurant in the Brill Building, at 1619 Broadway, between 49th and 50th Streets. since 1937.

Algeria called today for a General Assembly meeting to discuss raw materials and economic development, a session that would open the way for a full-scale debate on the energy crisis by th e135 United Nations members.

President Nixon's State of the Union Address was a unique combination of legislative review and personal comeback appeal, The two sections of the speech were interdependent. The President's survey of his past and present legislative recommendations was intended to convey the image of an active, busy, working Chief Executive and thereby lay the basis for Mr. Nixon's emotional concluding appeal for an end to public preoccupation with the Watergate scandals.

" There is something the matter with me because I do not feel there is something the matter with me!" That is perhaps the key to a brief ut fascinating entertainment being presented in repertory by the Actors Company from Britain at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that profit for the fourth quarter of 1973 fell 22 per cent to $517million, equal to $1.80 a common share, from $667-million, or $2.32 a share, the year before. Revenues from sales of General Motors trucks remained strong, but were not enough to offset a fourth-quarter decline in sales of automobiles.

Mrs. Constance Rogers of Forest Hills, Queens, indicted in connection with race-fixing charges against New York harness drivers, was convicted yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court on three counts of giving false identification to the Internal Revenue Service. A jury of eight women and four men found Mrs. Rogers guilty of using false identity in cashing $57,347 worth of superfecta tickets last year at shops of the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

Officials of the city's proposed $200-million convention center said yesterday that they would proceed with construction, despite the failure of a Congressional committee to reccommend a declaration that would have waived the Federal Government's jurisdiction over the site.
Two women walking to their home in Sunnyside, Queens, in in late evening hours on Wednesday were attacked-one fatally-in separate incidents, the police reported yesterday.
Profit taking by professional traders trimmed prices of recently issued corporate bonds yesterday but elsewhere in the credit markets this week's firm tone persisted.

Rick Barry hit a 28-foot jump shot at the buzzer tonight give the Golden State Warriors a 109-108 National Basketball Association victory over the Houton Rockets.

UAL, Inc., which owns United Air Lines, the world's largest air carrier, as well as Western International Hotels, yesterday restored its stock to a dividendpaying basis, after reporting that 1973 profits were the best in three years.

A Pan American World Airways 707 jetliner crashed and burned yesterday while attempting to land in bad weather at Pagopago, American Samoa, and a Samoan government spokesman said that 95 of the 101 persons aboard were killed.

Protesting truck drivers began to day to reduce the flow of raw materials and foodstuffs it many parts, of the country prompting scattered closings of plants and warnings of short ages of fuel and food.

A Brooklyn accountant and a man described by the police as a major bookmaker have been indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on charges of attempting to influence State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts on the behalf of the bookmaker, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Fly is back in action. That will be good news to his Brooklyn neighbors and his Austin Peay State basketball teammates but bad news to Long Island University, which meets Austin Peay in Madison Square Garden tomorrow afternoon.

The price of silver for future delivery resumed its advance toward record levels yesterday in unusually heavy trading. The nearest, delivery, March, rose the daily permissible limit of 10 cents an ounce, with the more distant months closing a bit lower.

HARTFORD - The Urban League here has decided that for a year, at least, it will not distribute Its customary annual awards for accomplishment in providing equal opportunities to minorities. Robert B. Keane, president of Urban League of Greater Hartford, says insurance companies do much, but could! do more. He is with The Hartford Insurance Group. Verlyn Gilbert, a student at Weaver High School, works' after classes at offices of the Hartford group.
Wang Chia-hsiang, the first postrevolutionary Chinese Ambassador to Moscow and an early party leader, died Jan. 25, the official press agency Hsinhua said today. He was 68 years old.

A Pan American World Airways 707 jetliner crashed and burned yesterday while attempting to land in bad weather at Pagopago, American Samoa, and a Samoan government spokesman said that 95 of the 101 persons aboard were killed.
Congressional investigators and the Internal Revenue Service have raised a new issue concerning the propriety of President Nixon's tax returns, in addition to the two he has acknowledged publicly.

A prosecution witness in the trial of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell testified yesterday that he had received assurances from a former Queens County detective that "Mackell is in this."

Harry T. Byrne, a retired stockbroker and tax consultant, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 17 Dante Street. Mr. Byrne was a former partner in the investment firm of Gray Wilmerding and was later with Post Flagg.

The staff of the special Watergate prosecutor said today in Federal Court that it had no reason to believe that John W. Dean 3d had lied in the Watergate case. Dwight L. Chapin, former White House aide, arriving at U.S. District Court in Washington yesterday.
Kuwait is to pay $112-million compensation for a 60 per cent take-over of the Kuwait Oil Company, (K.O.C.) owned by the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., and the Gulf Oil Corporation.

The City Council Committee on Rules approved 15 changes in the Council's procedures yesterday, eliminating some practices that have long offended "good government' groups. Other proposals for more radical reform were voted down.
Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle with the Boeing Company to modify the 1974 and 1975 delivery schedules of B-727-231 aircraft on firm order.

Seven babies are born each minute in Bangladesh, 10,000 each day. The population of 75 million is expected to double in two decades. The nation is the eighth most populous in the world. Frederic Ohringer from Nancy Palmer Children of Dacca
Thirty-five wealthy contributors gave $1.4-million on Congressional candidates in 1972, according to a study released today by Common Cause.

Traditionally, except when Gmen were shooting down notorious bank bandits in the 1930's and wanted to build an image, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has viewed the press with the same friendliness it reserved for domestic Communists and the less exotic felons.

Today is the 27th birthday of Capt. Donald Dawson of the Air Force, who was charged with disobeying an order to fly a bombing mission over Cambodia, and he certainly has something to celebrate. Charles B. Rangel Heads caucus

The Continental Oil Company, the nation's eighth largest oil company, recorded a 91.6 per cent increase in profits for the fourth quarter of 1973, while income for the year rose 42.6 per cent over the 1972 level.

As commonly titled, it Is "I Vespri Siciliani" by Giuseppe Verdi. In English it is "The Sicilian Vespers." In French, the language in which it was originally sung, It is "Les Vepres Siciliennes." On the title page of the first Italian edition it is "Giovanna di Guzman." In Italy before the independence of 1861 it might have turned up as "Giovanna di Braganza" or "Betilde di Turenna."

Joseph J. Christian was reappointed as chairman of the City Housing Authority by Mayor Beame yesterday. The Mayor also appointed Harris J. Klein to the Human Rights Commission and Rabbi Samuel Fogelman to the Youth Board.

Eighty-one passengers defected from a Polish cruise liner earlier this week during stopovers in Denmark, Norway and West Germany, authorities said today. It was believed to be the largest mass defection that Communist Poland has had.

Michael McIntosh, who filed a lawsuit in January to gain access to the books of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, yesterday questioned the motivation of the company's projection of earnings Tuesday.

As campaigns open for next May's municipal elections, much political interest is focusing on the race for the Newark Municipal Council, and less on the mayoral contest, which drew most attention four years ago when this predominantly black city elected its first black Mayor. The market indexes used by the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market fell yesterday but advances outnumbered declines on both markets. The Amex index closed at 97.24, down 0.26 on a volume of 2,226,000 shares.
Rebel rocket teams fired three Soviet-built 122-mm. rockets into the western section of Phnom Penh and an airport complex today, wounding a Cambodian senator and 10 other persons.

Can a 24-year-old baseline tennis player from Detroit, having missed a year to have her baby, beat a 27-year-old Australian who is trying to come back after 10 months and an operation for a pinched nerve in her elbow?

President Anwar el-Sadat won support for his disengagement agreement with Israel from most of the other Arab leaders during his recent tour of their capitals, according to informed sources here, but there is a time limit on their commitment.

President Nixon has lost no time in letting Congress know that his Administration plans no retreat in its stand for reducing international trade barriers, and especially for opening American markets to imports from developing countries. He coupled this notice with a renewed call to provide a fair American share of economic assistance for the world's needy, particularly under International Development Association programs.
The South African Government today restricted for five years the freedom and rights of three white trade union officials involved in organizing black trade unions.
Representative John J. Rhodes, the House minority leader, said today that he was "very concerned" over the unusually large number of Republicans who do not plan to seek reelection this year.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 217.5 from 215.1 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 136.1 on Jan. 30, 1973.

It's "all in the family" so far as the basketball coaching jobs are concerned at Our Lady of the Valley High School. The boys' basketball coach is Ted Fiore, who guided Valley to a state championship in 1970. The girls' basketball coach is his young sister, Denise, a 1973 graduate of Montclair State College.

A mistrial was declared today in the murder trial of Mrs. Joanne D. Chesimard because of the problems of her pregnancy and the possibility that she might suffer a miscarriage.
The man arrested here as one of the 1963 gang of train robbers has denied that he is Roinald A. Biggs, diplomatic sources said tonight.
Jurgen Fassbender of West Germany and Clark Graebner of New York reached the semifinals in the $20,000 Baltimore tournament today. Fassbender had little difficulty in ousting South Afri-

Donald S. MacDonald, Canada's Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources, predicted today that Canada would reduce its exports of crude oil to the United States in the next two years and prohibit massive American investment to extract oil from the tar sands of Alberta.

new confrontation developed today in Bolivia's two-week-old political crisis when 4,800 tinminers announced a 48-hour wildcat strike to protest food shortages and the economic politics of President Hugo Banzer Suarez's Government.

BEIRUT-Roger E. Tamraz, who went from Lebanon to the United States to learn the techniques of big-time investment banking, has put his "know how" to work for Arab projects drawing on multinational Arab capital.

Phil Chenier scored 38 points as the Capital Bullets ended a four-game losing streak by defeating the Cleveland Cavaliers, 107-99, tonight. The Bullets jumped' to a first quarter lead of 37-25 as Kevin Porter hit seven of seven field goals.

Miss Maura Hurley and James Brackett, who are with the State Department's Agency for International Development, were married here this evening. The bride is chief of the Latin America Bureau's health, nutrition

TEL AVIV--Quietly, but with great intensity, Israeli Government and military officials, leaders of the economy and university scholars are debating an issue raised by the October war: How can Israel mobilize for long-lasting crises without crippling the life of the country?
A state judge today ordered the mass murder trial of Elmer Wayne Henley moved to San Antonio because of pretrial publicity in the Houston area.
Jefferson Ehrlich, a consulting patent attorney with Standard, Inc., formerly with the American Telephone Telegraph Company, died Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital.
Tim Kearns scored 26 points and Jim Cartwell got 21 rebounds as Yale beat Dartmouth, 73-63, tonight in college basketball.

United States corporations increased their after-tax profits in the fourth quarter of 1973 by an average of 25 per cent over the same period a year earlier, the First National City Bank reported yesterday. The increase was achieved, the bank noted, despite the energy crisis and signs of a possible recession.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Saturday, Feb. 1 (UPI)-Filbert Bayi of Tanzania shattered the world record for 1,500 meters with a time of a 3 minutes 32.2 seconds today to win his country's first gold medal on the final day of the Common. wealth Games.

Black-faced and filthy with coal dust, night workers climbedout of a rusty elevator atop the 840 foot vertical shaft at the Coedely colliery here this morningand trudged through the rain to a drab meeting hall.
With a final 8,500-mile-long photographic sweep of earth, the Skylab 3 astronauts brought to a close today one of man's most productive efforts to understand his planet.

Anatoly Karpov, the 22-yearold Soviet grandmaster who the Russians expect to be the next world champion, came close yesterday to moving into the semifinals of the world chess tournament to pick a challenger to the world champion, Bobby Fischer, of the United States.
Tony Rosenthal's sculpture "Five in One," whose parts have been lying all over Police Plaza since last September, is finally going up.

Frederick M. Bender, who had been vice president in charge of production of the Alco-Gravure division of the Publication Corporation in Hoboken, died yesterday in the Ward Homestead, where he lived. He was 90 years old.
Dr. John Louis Sengstack, chief of staff of the Huntington Hospital from 1955 to 1970, died Tuesday at his home on Greenlawn Road. He was 79 years old.

BETHESDA, Md.-Regrettably, after giving voice several years ago to America's "silent majority" on the issue of the Vietnam war, the Nixon White House has now undertaken to cow that majority back into silence by making them doubt their own decent instincts on an even more basic issue -executive responsibility and the rule of law in our democracy.

The United Steelworkers of America and the three major aluminum companies reached new 40-month agreements yes. terday that reduce the normal retirement age from 65 to 62 and provide cost-of-living supplements for workers who retire.
A mistrial was declared today in the murder trial of Mrs. Joanne D. Chesimard because of the problems of her pregnancy and the possibility that she might suffer a miscarriage.

Merlin Olsen of the Los Angeles Rams and Jim Wynn of the Los Angeles Dodgers shared the first round lead in the $30,000 American Airlines golf classic with Jeff Burroughs of the Texas Rangers and Bob Anderson of the Denver Broncos today at El Conquistador Club. Each duo carded a net 57.

Morris Kantor, an artist and leading teacher of painting in New York, died Thursday night In Nyack Hospital following a long illness. Mr. Kantor, who lived at 45 South Mountain Road in New City, was 77 years, old.
Glenn Morris, 1936 Olympic decathlon champion and a former movie Tarzan, died yesterday after a long illness. His age was 62.
Leonard L. Levinson, radio writer and author, died Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 69 years old and lived in Santa Monica, Calif.
Art deco is still a jigsaw puzzle, the pieces of which are being fitted together at a far slower pace than the public acceptance of this style.

The Houston Rockets of the National Basketball Association traded Jack Marin and Matt Guokas today for a 7-foot rookie center, Kevin Kunnert, and a 6-2 third-year guard, Dave Wohl, of the Buffalo Braves. Marin, 29 years old, a 6-6 forward, came to the Rockets from Baltimore in 1972 in exchange for Elvin Hayes. Guokas, 29, was acquired by the Rockets from Kansas City-Omaha earlier this season.
A Federal judge last night temporarily extended the life of the famous Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn, where workers were sitting in to protest the planned permanent closing of the plant.

A Federal Judge ordered the Metro Area Postal Union today to take its objections on a management plan to alter work-shift starting times at the giant New York Bulk and Foreign Mail facility in Jersey City to formal arbitration.

Although it wasn't one of his most scintillating performances from the floor, Julius Erving scored a game-high 29 points tonight to lead the New York Nets to a 95-91 victory over a tenacious San Antonio team at the Nassau Coliseum.

The United Steelworkers of America and the three major aluminum companies reached agreements yesterday that reduce the normal retirement age from 65 to 62 and provide cost-of-living supplements for workers who retire. Page 34.

President Anwar el-Sadat won support for his disengagement agreement with Israel from most of the other Arab leaders during his recent tour of their capitals, according to informed sources here, but there is a time limit on their commitment.

The Federal Trade Commission has approved an applicatin by the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation to reacquire control of Atlantic Department Stores, Inc. Arlen owns the E. J. Korvette Department store chain.
President and Mrs. Nixon are not California residents for state income tax purposes, Martin Huff, executive officer of the Franchise Tax Board, ruled today.

Deputy energy director John C. Sawhill said today that the nation cannot "break the back of the energy crisis this year" --a hope voiced by President Nixon--and urged consumers not to buy gasoline until their tanks were half empty.

Shortly before James (Fly) Williams was to leave his dormitory room at Austin Peay University for last Monday night's game with Western Kentucky, his phone rang. When he answered, he recognized the voice of Brenda Walker, his girl friend in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn where he grew up.

Gloomy economic and energy developments sent the stock market sharply lower yesterday in continued quiet trading. Shares on the New York Stock Exchange opened lower and then increased their losses throughout most of the session.
Second-seeded Tom Gorman of Seattle and fourth-ranked Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia made it to the semifinals of the World Championship Tennis stop here tonight.

The sorriest way to shore up decentralized government is to make end-runs to Albany or Washington to reverse decisions made by New York City's elected officials on purely municipal matters. That discredited device has now been used by Representative Bella Abzug of Manhattan's West Side to show that her heart is with neighborhood groups opposed to construction of a $200million convention center on Hudson River piers off West 48th Street.

For 12 years this country has been politically inert under a military regime that called itself "revolutionary" and "socialist." Now, in what for Burma amounts to a paroxysm of activity, the regime is giving itself a face lift.

Bjorn Borg and Ray Moore moved into the men's final of the Scandinavian tournament today after Leslie Charles of Britain won the women's final with a 6-4, 6-4 triumph over Ellen Grind. vold of Norway.

Four seasick Japanese and Arab guerrillas began their second night aboard a hijacked ferryboat with three hostages today after the Singapore Government reported difficulties in arranging their transport out of the country.

John W. Adams, 21 years old, walked around only dazed today after jumping from. the Golden Gate Bridge and landing on an embankment 190 feet below. The Stanford University student was hospitalized after the incident last night but did not suffer serious injury.

DuPont Walston, Inc., which decided Jan. 21 to get out of the brokerage business as its losses continued to mount, said lere yesterday that to date it had oral agreements with 22 brokerage firms to take over 114 of its 138 domestic branches

International Europe's economic prospects look brighter than they did a few months ago because oil is now flowing more plentifully. While concern remains that recessionary forces could get out of hand, reflecting the deflationary impact of the fourfold increase in oil prices, experts in Paris, Brussels and Bonn are no longer forecasting a deep recession this year.
Pam Higgins shot a five-under-par 68 today and took a twoshot, first-round lead in the $35,000 Burdines tournament, the first event on the 1974 Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

An eventual vote on the impeachment of President Nixon was virtually assured today when the ranking Republican in the House of Representatives predicted strong minority support for a move to give the House Judiciary Committee full constitutional authority to pursue its inquiry.

The Nixon Administration plans to increase the number of subsidized housing units by 100,000 and to provide $2.8-billion in the budget for the fiscal year 1975 to finance current community development projects

Like King Canute up to his ankles in the rising tide President Nixon has proclaimed, "There will be no recession in the United States of America." This is a nonsensical reassurance at a time when the economy already appears to have entered a recession. Unemployment, rising for three months, has just surged to 5.2 per cent.

President Nixon's proposal for a comprehensive health insurance program is the most concrete item in a 1974 agenda that abounds in vague pledges. In essence, the plan would require employers to pay 75 per cent of health insurance premium costs, with the employee adding the remaining 25 per cent. The Federal Government would pay the premiums of low-income families.
Dr Louis L. Dienes, who discovered in man the disease-produring Mycoplasma organism died yesterday of complications from a heart attack and a stroke. His age was 88.
In a precedent-setting ruling, Circuit Court Judge Joseph Munch ruled yesterday that a husband had no legal right to prevent his wife from having ,an abortion.

Following is the text of President Nixon's Economic Report to Congress: The United States enters 1974 in a position of leadership in the world economy. The dollar is strong, we have constructive economic relations throughout the world, and we have the greatest freedom of action resulting from our great capacity to produce.

Memorial service will be held on Thursday, Feb. 14, at 4 P.M., at the Loob Student Center, New York Universty, 566 LaGuardia Place (Washington Sq. South), Fifth Floor. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

Samuel Goldwyn was buried today in a private service with only members of his family as mourners. Rabbi Max Nussbaum presided at the service and the pioneer film producer's son, Samuel Jr., delivered a brief eulogy.

About 400 off-duty policemen from the metropolitan area picketed in front of Village Hall here today to protest a possible rollback in the recent contract settlement between Nassau County and the 5,600-member Nassau Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Raul Ramirez of Mexico advanced to the semifinals of the Dayton pro tournament today by defeating Australians.
The persons were found guilty today of having helped murder a Moroccan in the international war between Arab and Israeli agents.
Edward R. Holt, a veteran security analyst and former partner of Newburger, Loeb Co., was presented yesterday with the first Ralph A. Rot. nem Award for his contributions to security analysis.

The spreading fuel protest by independent truckers was seriously disrupting the shipment of fruit, produce, meat and steel today, forcing some distributors and plants to close and threatening others with shutdowns next week.
The nation's largest cantilever bridge, 43 stories high and nearly four miles long, opened today between here and Chester, Pa., ending 200 years of ferry service on the Delaware River.

The chief political commissar of the Soviet armed forces has told Soviet troops in East Germany that accommodation with the West "must not give birth to elements of pacifism, complacency and class vegetarianism" within Soviet military ranks.

PHILADELPHIA-Whether the energy crisis proves a real threat or simply an exaggerated alarm sounded by the oil interests, it will nevertheless have pointed up a. basic need for a strong national policy to regulate and allocate energy production. And for any policy to be effective, it must take account of regional variations both in energy requirements and supply capabilities.

A memorial service for Robert C. Weinberg, architect, regional planner and consultant, will be held at the Loeb Student Center of New York University, 566 LaGuardia Place (Washington Square South), Thursday, Feb. 14, at 4 P.M. Mr. Weinberg died Jan. 25 at the age of 72.

The head of The Union Oil Company, the country's 12th largest oil concern, urged Congress today to order a roll. back in the price of oil. Fred L. Hartley, Union's pres. ident and chief executive offi. cer, described before the Senate Interior Committee a for. mula that would result in sub. stantial cuts in the price of roughly one-quarter of the oil produced in the United States.

Two amateur teams, Gene Scott and Ralph Howe of New York, and Jerry Bijur and E. Newbold Black 4th of Philadelphia, reached the final of the United States open court. tennis doubles championship yesterday at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

The Federal Reserve operated actively in the money markets yesterday, pumping additional reserves into the banking system and driving short-term interest rates downward.

Almost self-consciously, slightly embarrassed by their status as one of Latin America's few remaining genuine democracies, 700,000 Costa Rican voters are preparing to pick the man who will govern them for the next four years.
United States automakers, reacting to sharply dropping big car sales, reported today that auto production in January was 31 per cent below a year ago and the worst yearly start since 1970.

Cloudy and cold weather Will cover the Northeast today. Rain is forecast for Metropolitan New York. Freezing rain and sleet may develop in southern New England, while snow is expected from northern New England across the northern border states to the interior Pacific Northwest.
Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson said yesterday that President Nixon could be held accountable for the Watergate break-in and cover-up even if he was not aware of them.

World-class athletes in a dozen events took part tonight in the 11th annual San Francisco Examiner Games at the Cow Palace, with a field of five sub-4-minute milers entered in the final event of the program.

A Federal magistrate said yesterday he was "amazed" that 13 harness drivers accused Dec. 20 of fixing superfecta races still didn't know the specifics of the Government's charges.

A 54-year-old woman was shot and killed in her rural farmhouse here last night. She was gunned down by a shotgun blast that ripped through a living room window just after she had been called to the telephone by her 8-yearold son.

The American Motors Corporation, announced today plans to add a second shift at its Lakefront plant in Kenosha, Wis., effective March 4. AMC said the move would increase production of the compact Hornet and subcompact Gremlin by 250 units a day.

Charles M. Stone, coordinator of station services for the National Association of Broadcasters, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

A special "emergency" court-martial at the South Korean Defense Ministry today sentenced two adversaries of the Government to 15 years in prison for criticizing the nation's Constitution in violation of a presidential decree.

Anti-government marchers staged a new demonstration through the streets of Grenada's capital today. The government radio broadcast warnings of "subversive activity" throughout the island, and cash rewards were offered for information on people who were behaving suspiciously.

Bridge Across the Delaware Opens A highway cantilever bridge nearly four miles long and 43 stories high was opened yesterday across the Delaware River between Bridgeport, N. J., and Chester, Pa., ending 200 years of ferry service on the river. The fivelane toll bridge is part of U.S. 322 between Harrisburg, Pa., and Atlantic City.

Jack Nicklaus, dead - serious amidst this city's holiday atmosphere, carded a five-under-par 67 today on top of his opening 65 and pulled away to a four-stroke lead in the $220,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament. His total was 132 for 36 holes.

It is generally recognized that the standard 4-3-2-1 point count has one major weakness: it undervalues the ace. In an attempt to allow for this some authorities suggest corrections, such as adding a point for a hand with four aces, or subtracting a point for an aceless hand.

When a piece of music happens to interest Pierre Boulez enough to engage his attention fully, the New York Philharmonic's musical director can inject his own brand of excitement into a concert. When he is less than absorbed, the result can be nebulous and ultimately unsatisfying, in spite of the polish and intellectual penetration that he achieves in almost any performance.

In a review yesterday in The New York Times of "The Flowering of American Folk Art 1776-1876 at the Whitney Museum," the name of Alice Winchester was dropped. Miss Winchester was guest curator of the exhibition and co-author of the catalogue.
Coach Chuck Daly declared his 14-man bench tonight as the University of Pennsylvania remained unbeaten in Ivy League basketball by routing Cornell, 8736.

Two amateur teams, Gene Scott and Ralph Howe of New York, and Jerry Bijur and E. Newbold Black 4th of Philadelphia, reached the final of the United States open court tennis doubles championship yesterday at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

Under a new Federal energy regulation, the city was forced yesterday to switch gasoline suppliers. But the official responsible for acquiring the 25 million gallons used by municipal agencies annually said he had no ideal why the switch was being made nor what the new supplier's price would be.
The murder trial of Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano started to wind down today when the defense began calling character witnesses.
Stelio E. Maris, an artist who specialized in stainedglass window designs, died Thursday at his home, 316 West 88th Street. His age was 66.

A 50-year-old man was killed last night when he was allegedly knocked in front of a subway train by another man who was later captured after a chase by witnesses along the platform at 50th Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

RIO DE JANEIRO - The news came as a national shock. Brazil, the world's foremost coffee producer, announced she would be importing coffee in substantial quantities in 1974.

The United Steelworkers of America and the three major aluminum companies. reached agreements yesterday that reduce the normal retirement age from 65 to 62 and provide cost-of-living supplements for workers who retire. Page 34.

Some college students see shift nowadays from "soft" drugs, like marijuana, to alcohol. The change, they say, is occurring at the same time liberalized administrative polIdes make alcoholic beverages easier to obtain on cant pus.

The Houston Rockets of the National Basketball Association traded Jack Marin and Matt Guokas today for a 7-foot rookie center, Kevin Kunnert, and a 6-2 third-year guard, Dave Wohl, of the Buffalo Braves. Marin, 29 years old, a 6-6 forward, came to the Rockets from Baltimore in 1972 in exchange for Elvin Hayes. Guokas, 29, was acquired by the Rockets from Kansas City-Omaha earlier this season.

The United States declared today its intention of seeking new international rules on "access to supplies," to go with the more traditional rules on access to markets, in the forthcoming international trade negotiations.

Members of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today preliminary information suggested that buyers of stock options increased their activity as the chances of making a profit diminished.

The Commerce Department estimated today that new homes, apartments, office and public buildings worth $135.5-billion were constructed in 1973, but the 9 per cent increase in value over the previous year was due to inflation. The Commerce Department said new construction was valued at $123.8-billion in 1972.

State Fish and Game officials have asked six research laboratories to determine what has caused cataracts in more than 200,000 fish at the state's fish hatchery in Hackettstown. The epidemic led to the destruction of 175,000 yearling brown trout in the last two weeks at the Charles O. Hayford State Fish Hatchery. The fish represent one-third of the total the hatchery raises annually to stock New Jersey waterways.

A team of researchers at the University of Utah and the University of Western Ontario have reported the successful stimulation of artificial sight in two blind patients, one of whom has seen nothing for 28 years.
The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, declared tonight that Congress and the courts must pursue their Watergate investigations "in order to cleanse the political processes of the nation."

"The rich were not getting richer and the poor were not getting poorer" in the United States in the years that have followed World War II, but the relative position of the poor was not getting any better, either, the President's Council of Economic Advisers said today.

Governor Wilson said yesterday that despite pessimism by others, he was optimistic about President Nixon's discussion of mass transportation in his recent State of the Union message. Speaking at a meeting of the Association for a Better New York, the Governor said that while the President's proposal "obviously does not do what is needed to be done," it was encouraging because it showed that the President was aware that Federal aid to transportation was needed.

George Gervin's field goal with four seconds remaining gave the Virginia Squires a 11-110 victory over the Kentucky Colonels tonight. Gervin, over whom the Squires were sued today by San Antonio, led Virginia with 32 points.

Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania said today that he was not "backtracking one single inch" on his charge that John W. Dean 3d had lied about President Nixon's role in the Watergate cover-up.
Ted McClain hit a 15-foot jump shot with four seconds left to give Carolina a 104102 victory over the Memphis Tams tonight. McClain, who finished with 28 points, scored 12 in the final quarter.
A California law allowing persons to deduct $125 from state income tax returns for each child attending private schools was declared undonstitutional today by a. Federal court.

DHJ Industries, Inc., the nation's largest producer of interlining and interfacings for the apparel industry, is expanding into the indigo dyed denim field through the acquisition of Swift Textiles, Inc., for more than $10-million cash.

The Solar Sporting Club occupies the fifth-floor loft of an old, gray building on Manhattan's West Side, and is serviced by a tired, rather decrepit elevator. When the lift does get a call for the Solar, it bumps to a halt before swinging its doors open to a large, plain training room.

Edward M. Graceman, a Florida businessman, flew to New York last week for an eye operation. While there is nothing very special about that, the circumstances surrounding Mr. Graceman's case highlight an unusual aspect of medical care insurance.
Scotland Yard announced tonight that Ronald A. Biggs, the last of the "Great Train Robbery" gang still free, was arrested today in a hotel in Rio de Janeiro.

In a long lifetime in Hollywood, Samuel Goldwyn produced films that met his own standard of what a motion picture theater should be: "A place where everybody can go and not blush over what they see on the screen." But this one-time glovemaker from Poland was more than a popular moviemaker. He was an independent long before the break-up of major studios and their chains.

Facing an almost certain barrage of regional resistance, the Department of Transportation insisted today that its plan to abandon 25 per cent of railroad trackage in the Northeast and Midwest would not impair passenger service.

Jerry Sloan, hitting from long range, stemmed a final Kansas City-Omaha rally with four baskets in the final minutes tonight to send the Chicago Bulls to a 99-88 triumph over the Kings.

New Mexico, ranked 17th nationally, continued its skid tonight as Larry Warren and Greg Grady, sophomores, and three freshmen led Florida State to a 90-71 victory.

Liam Cosgrave, Prime Minister of the Irish Republic, flew here secretly today by helicopter with seven of his Cabinet ministers for talks on establishing formal links between Northern Ireland and the Republic.
An investor in a pyramid investment scheme testified yesterday that a Queens detective - himself an investor in the scheme - interviewed him about the swindle but never asked him to sign a complaint.

The State Public Service Commission denied today a request by New York State Electric and Gas Corporation for interim electric rate increases totaling $13.2million and gas rate increases of $1.8-million.

Princeton quickly dissected Columbia's zone defense tonight and scored a 90-47 victory in the Ivy League. It was Princeton's fifth straight victory over Columbia.

Four more oil companies announced gasoline price increases today but a fifth said it was holding the price of gasoline and increasing the cost of diesel fuel and home heating oil only.

Reginald Berkowitz, a retired builder, died yesterday from the effects of a stroke he suffered last June. He was 75 years old and lived here. Mr. Berkowitz was born in Bucharest and was brought to this country at the age of 3.

The Consumers Power Company and the Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday agreements under which the chemical company will purchase process steam from the utility's Midland nuclear power plant and electric energy from its electric power network.

For a working girl or student with a practically nonexistent clothes allowance, the solution has long been to save nickels and dimes to buy a quality pair of shoes or a well-made pair of pants that will last long enough to offset the cost.

The leadership of New York's City Council fumbled an opportunity to make the Council a more respected and effective instrument of municipal government the other day when it rammed through a compliant Rules Committee a watered-down "reform" package that leaves glaring legislative deficiencies virtually untouched. Responding half-heartedly to the strong sentiment for general governmental reform generated by Watergate, Majority Leader Thomas Cuite and his faithful yes-men did allow some long-sought rules changes to go through.

Leithe Lende, the leader on the Can-Am women's circuit, finished fifth in the downhill competition today and skied off with the women's title in the 28th annual Roch Cup competition--the sixth on the 15-stop circuit.

Two of the nation's leading harness drivers, Stanley Banks and Walter Paisley, indicted Jan. 24 on charges of conspiring to fix races, have been reinstated to the tracks at least until their cases are decided.

An excellent, provocative one-hour television documentary titled "Gold on Blue" pays tribute to the New York City Police Department and courage in line of duty.

Silvercup Bakers, Inc., accused yesterday the Continental Baking Company and the American Bakeries Company, two of its competitors, of spreading false rumors that it was in financial distress and going out of business.

About 150 policemen from four agencies staged predawn raids on homes and Vassar College dormitories today, and arrested 43 persons on narcotics charges, including one female and eight male students of the college.

PARIS-General de Gaulle, with the suspicion of a haughty sniff, used to refer to "les Anglo-Saxons" when talking of England and America. However, his successor, President Pompidou, does not favor that generic term and avoids asperity when mentioning the English-speaking nations. Indeed, although there are evident policy differences between Paris and Washington, and others, less visible, with London, these disagreements are faced on the basis of courteous friendship.

The state's Department of Mental Hygiene, which has been looking into crime incidents at Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens, has extended the investigation to all 22 downstate facilities maintained by the department.

COLLECTED POEMS. By Paul Goodman. 465 pages. Random House. $12.95. Here's the story of an American life, recently ended, all set down in sonnets, ballads, haiku, lyrics and prayers, written to be read by anyone and filled with interesting details. It's a little more exotic than your usual American life. You might read it as the romance of the avant-garde writer in America (forty years of unread stories, novels, plays and poems).
The Beame administration was taken to task yesterday for not appointing more women to top city positions by a coalition of 15 women led by Representative Bella S. Abzug.
Bob Leiter scored two goals, one in the first and another in the third period, and the Atlanta Flames defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 5-3, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

A young American skier, "just a country boy," doesn't understand what fur coats and Rolls Royce have to do with a world "amateur" skiing championship. Andy Mill, 20 years old, will learn next week about the real rich world of Alpine skiing.

Adolph Boos watches as gallons of foaming beer gush onto the floor of the Rheingold plant in Brooklyn. By the end of the week, 62,000 gallons of beer had gone down the sewer as company officials prepared to close the 119-yearold brewery. They said the brewery had lost $9-million last year and could no longer operate profitably. Mr. Boos and 1,500 other employes are being laid off.

The murder trial of tne Tormer president of the United Mine Workers, W. A. Boyle, has been scheduled for March 25 in this Philadelphia suburb. Mr. Boyle is accused in the slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski and Mr. Yablonski's wife and daughter.

Moscow's complaint that the West is organizing "ideological subversion" of the Soviet Union by publishing Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's criticism of the secret police and prison camp system is replete with irony. It illustrates again the difficulty of achieving in practice the freer exchange of information and ideas to which the Kremlin has paid lip service at the Geneva Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.

Situated In a remodeled elementary school at 178 Barracks Street, the center will offer courses in mathematics, the society and culture of Puerto Rico, general psychology, business organization and management and English.

Miss Frances J. Schwartz, daughter of Mrs. Lucille Schwartz and the late David J. Schwartz of Fort Worth, was married here this afternoon to Donald Paul Sosin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gene Sosin. Cantor William Wolff performed the ceremony at the Schwartz home.

Four women died last night in a fire that swept through two stories of a tenement on the Lower East Side. Seven firemen and a police officer also needed treatment for smoke inhalation, the Fire Department reported.

Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania, chairman of the MidAtlantic Conference of Governors, asked independent truckers today to declare a 45-day moratorium on their strike and promised quick governmental action to relieve their hardships.

Shoppers across the nation are reacting with anger and frustration to sharply climbing food prices and the dire predictions of worse days to come. Instead of attempting to counterattack directly with a boycott or mass protests, most men and women simply shrug in hopeless resignation.
The Rev. Joseph F. Maguire, administrator of St. Pius V Roman Catholic Church, Ja. maica, Queens, since 1969, died Friday of a heart attack in the rectory. He was 53 years old.
Four men have been arrested in robberies of expensive, widebrimmed fur hats from Hasidic Jews in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, the police reported yesterday.

Bobby Riggs, wearing a variety of costumes ranging from a dress to a baseball catcher's outfit, defeated a hard-playing but frustrated Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds' outfielder, in an exhibition tennis match last night. Riggs won five games and Rose two in the seven-game set.

Willie Farah, one of the nation's top manufacturers of men's pants, was caught up this week in another round of his long-running battle with the Government, labor unions and the Roman Catholic Church over whether his eight factories should be unionized.

Unseeded Raul Ramiriz of Mexico won the Dayton pro tennis tournament today with a 6-1, 6-4, 7-6 victory over second - seeded Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Ramirez had eliminated the top-seeded player, Jaime Fillol of Chile, in the semifinals.

Mayor Beame said yesterday that he had asked the Federal Energy Office to divert at least 800,000 barrels of domestic crude oil daily to Caribbean refineries to produce fuel oil to make up a 25 per cent shortage in fuel for heating large apartment buildings and institutions here.

Truckers' Revolt The strike of independent truckers that has brought violence in at least seventeen states and the threat of nationwide economic dislocation is the most serious manifestation yet of an energy crisis that has been compounded by Federal bumbling. The brute tactics employed by some strikers cannot be tolerated; their recourse to gunfire and coercion requires resistance through use of National Guard and police escorts for essential deliveries.

World trade continued to expand through the third quarter of 1973 with world exports reaching an annual rate of $505-billion, according to the latest issue of the International Monetary Fund's international financial statistics. The third-quarter level was a gain of 42 per cent over the annual rate of $355-billion reached in the third quarter of 1972, the data showed.

Two Department of Correection officers on trial for manslaughter in the death of an inmate of the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men were ordered acquitted yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court. Justice Thomas J. Mirabile directed the jury of 10 men and two women to acquit on the ground that there was "legally insufficient evidence presented to ever warrant a conviction."

Portugal raised the price of, gasoline today, from $1.45 to $2.13 a gallon for premium and from $1.30 a gallon to $1.84 for regular.

The wholesale price of Amoco gasoline was cut yesterday by 2 cents a gallon. The action marked the first price reduction for gasoline announced by an oil company since the Arab oil embargo against the United States and production cutbacks began in October.

Harry T. Rohs, who retired as oil and utility editor of The Wall Street Journal in 1966 after an association of more than 40 years with the publication, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital.

The New York Cosmos switched their home soccer base yesterday from Hofstra University to Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. During the last two seasons at the Hempstead, L.I., collegiate facility, the Cosmos had averaged about 6,000 fans a game.

The most deadly terrorist attack in Britain since the present wave of violence started in Northern Ireland in 1969 left 11 dead today and moved the Government to an urgent study of new measures to counter Irish Republican Army attacks here. The latest attack came early this morning.

The Dow Chemical Company attained record results for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31. Sales exceeded $3-billion for the first time, according to financial figures issued yesterday from the company's headquarters in Midland, Mich.

The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to resume the talks on limitations of strategic arms on Feb. 19 in Geneva. But the Nixon Administration reportedly remained far From resolving its differences an a new American negotiating position.

What its sponsors call the first public. interest law center in the nation specializing in educational problems opened for business here today. The project, named the Education Law Center, Inc., is sponsored by a two-year, $450,000 grant from the Ford Foundation.

William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, indicated to Senate-House conferees today that he opposed their plan for a rollback in oil prices, but declined to say whether he would recommend a Presidential veto of the emergency energy bill to which the rollback amendment was added.

Stan Smith defeated Barry Phillips-Moore of Australia in straight sets tonight in the first round of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis tour event. Smith, playing in borrowed shoes, won by 6-3, 6-2.
Domestic new-car sales were off 21.5 per cent in late January but, auto executives and dealers said they detected signs of a slight improvement compared with the performance of previous weeks.

With enough votes in the presidential elections to put him safely above the 40 per cent minimum required for election on the first ballot, Daniel Oduber Quiros named his first cabinet member today.
The Boston Bulls of the World Football League have announced the signing of a former New York Jet wide receiver, George Sauer Jr., to a multiyear contract.
A granddaughter of the late William Randolph Hearst was abducted from her apartment last night by a white woman and two black men who covered their escape with rifle fire, the police said today.

Massachusetts moved yesterday to begin a voluntary gasoline rationing program next week, joining the list of gasoline-starved states in the Northeast contemplating such a move.

The domestic affiliates of the Exxon Corporation and the Gulf Oil Corporation, the largest and fourth largest in the industry, raised wholesale prices of gasoline and heating oil yesterday-one day after Amoco became the first major company to reduce prices since the imposition of the oil embargo against the United States last fall.

Satyendranath Bose, a, theoretical physicist who influenced the work of Albert Einstein, died yesterday at the age of 80. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi led the nation in mourning the man named in 1958 a "national professor," belonging to no single institution or state, because of the international acclaim his work won for the country.

Two dance companies--the Nikolais Dance Theater and the Murray Louis Dance Company--are sharing a Broadway season at the beautiful and cosy Lyceum Theater. The season started out last night with the Nikolais troupe giving the world premiere of "Cross-Fade" and two standards from the Nikolais repertory, the "Suite From Sanctum" and "Tower," both nearly 10 years old now.

The pain in Ilie Nastase's right arm has become almost as intense for him on serves and smashes these days as the personal heartache surrounding his fines and flareups with tennis linesmen and officials.

The Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy recommended today the repeal of vacancy decontrol, which allows rents to rise when a tenant moves out, and a rollback in rental bases to Jan. 1, 1973 levels.

The heads of the trust and investment departments of two of New York's largest banks told a Senate securities panel today that legislative limitation on stock holdings of pension fund managers would defeat their purpose and further confuse the unsettled equity market.

Mackell and others had. invested in the scheme and would take no action.

Pope Paul VI today removed Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, the exiled foe of communism in Hungary from the jurisdiction he still nominally retained there, and from his honorary function as his nation's Roman Catholic primate.

Reports from China describe the formation of small groups of activists to mobilize mass support for the campaign to criticize Lin Piao and Confucius, which is being presented as a people's war and a revolution in the spirit of the Cultural Revolution.

John P. Murtha, a Democrat and Vietnam war veteran, has apparently won the year's first Congressional election with a narrow, 220-vote victory here yesterday over his Republican opponent, Harry M. Fox.
The Ladies Home Journal has agreed to serialize Spiro T. Agnew's first novel with the initial excerpt appearing in the May issue, publishing industry informants reported yesterday.
The Newark Housing Authority announced today that it would close down the Stella Wright Housing Project April 7 and leave 700 families to fend for themselves.
Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's controversial new book on Soviet prison-camps was described as "folklore" by his former wife in an interview published here today.

President Nixon has reportedly refused to turn over requested White House tape recordings and other evidence to the Watergate special prosecutor, and thus is apparently headed for another major confrontation.
The Uris Buildings Corporation, which is controlled by the National Kinney Corporation, suffered a net loss of $17.4-million in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, it was reported yesterday.

Sheik Ahmed Zaki al-Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister Who is on a tour to explain Arab oil policies, declared here today that he had no knowledge of promises said to have been made by Arab oil producers to lift their embargo against the United States.

Tony Licata of New Orleans, employing an accurate left hand, won the United States middleweight title by outpointing the five-time world champion, Emile Griffith in a fast-moving 12-rounder tonight at Boston Garden.

What might be termed a full-court zone press has increasingly embroiled major professional sports, with legal actions in progress in hockey, basketball, football and baseball. Today's scheduled court appearance in Philadelphia by the National Hockey League and the World Hockey Association is only the tip of the iceberg.

The City Council, in a lastminute switch, voted yesterday to eliminate all proxy voting -- a course long advocated by "good government" groups. The move, sponsored by the Council's powerful majority leader, Thomas J. Cuite of Brooklyn, eliminated a practice that has, all agree, fallen into abuse.

Leslie M. Steele, who retired in 1970 as executive vice president of the Underwood Mortgage and Title Company, Irvington, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 75 years old and lived at 25 Burnside Drive.

??ing to New Jersey's worsening gasoline crisis, Commissioner James J. Sheeran of the State Department of Insurance announced today that he was preparing a major rollback of automobile insurance costs that most likely would exceed $100million.

Bill Mazeroski, who last season was third-base coach for the Pittsburgh Pirates after having spent 17 years as their second baseman. is retiring. The 38-year-old former star said he wanted to spend more time with his family.

A granddaughter of the late William Randolph Hearst was abducted from her apartment last night by a white woman and two black men who covered their escape with rifle fire, the police said today. PARIS-One' may assume France's President Pompidou is not disposed to minimize problems posed for the military defense of the North Atlantic Treaty Area as a consequence of the new energy crisis and financial developments including a float of the French franc plus fading prospects for international monetary reform.

Two more Nigerian universities were closed today after widespread disorders that began when the police broke up a student demonstration Friday in memory of a student killed daring a protest three years ago.

When the New York Islanders enter the lions' den tomorrow night to play the Rangers in Madison Square Garden, they will step with heads high and whips cracking confidently after taming the Minnesota North Stars tonight with a 6-2 lashing before a crowd of 11,063.

Lawyers from the office of District Attorney Joseph L. Busch talked for six hours in Washington yesterday with Egil Krogh Jr. as he began serving a six-month prison sentence for his role in the 1971 burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co., the prestigious national accounting firm, took the unusual step yesterday of asking a major client to provide financial information the company did not make available in a day-earlier announcement.

The Pity's new Controller, Harrison J. Goldin, has directed that contracts for further work on the city's proposed $200million West Side convention center be held up pending resolution of "legal issues," a spokesman for Mr. Goldin said last night.
The Controller of the Currency, James E. Smith, said his office was considering requiring bank trust departments to disclose their asset holdings and transactions in securities.

With repeated references to their string of failures in attempting to compete against the Rockefeller millions, the Democratic leaders of the Legislature today proposed stricter campaign-spending limitations, including a ceiling of $100,000 in contributions from candidate's family assets.

Legislation that would establish a class of Federally chartered stock savings and loan associations and allow their conversion from the traditional mutual, or depositor-owned, form to common stock ownership-was sent to Congress today by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
Last night's televised productior of Clifford Odets's "The Country Girl" was the Hallmark Hall of Fame at its best, which is saying plenty.

Borough President Donald H. Manes and 13 other Queens residents brought suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday, challenging as "discriminatory, excessive and burdensome" the court fees collected from city residents by New York State for the filing of legal documents.

In less than 12 minutes, William J. Porter, Ambassa dor-designate to Canada, breezed through his confirmation hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday.

Nearly three years and 400,000 runaway rents later, a commission named by former Governor Rockefeller has studied the effects of the Rockefeller-sponsored vacancy-decontrol law and pronounced it a fiasco. The report of the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and Economy finds that decontrol has yielded none of the benefits promised by Mr. Rockefeller or by the landlord groups that helped lobby through the change.

Russel Woodward, former executive vice president of Peters Griffin Woodward, Inc., television station representatives, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla., where he had been living. He was 71 years old and a former resident of New York and East Hampton, L. I.

Paul Elvstrom, the Danish yachtsman, clinched victory today in the World Soling Class championships when he finished second in the seventh and final heat sailed off Palm Beach. Elvstrom, who now holds 11 world titles and four Olympic gold medals, had four victories, one second, a seventh and an 11th placing for a total of 16 points10 ahead of David Forbes of Australia. Third over all.
The Italian Army, led by Sgt. Gustavo Thoeni, attacked on skis today and won the battle of the men's giant slalom in the world Alpine championships.

Senator James L. Buckley of New York today strongly turned down as "an invasion of privacy" a New York Times request for information on his personal finances.

It would be hard to exaggerate the economic and political debacle that confronts Britain with the 'union decision to call the nation's 260,000 coal miners out on strike at midnight Saturday. The miners' refusal since November to work overtime at existing wages has already cost Britain nine million tons of coal-the source for 70 per cent of its electric power-and has prompted the Government to invoke a three-day work week.
The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a complaint yesterday in the United States District Court here against Abatronix, Inc., of Stamford Conn., a manufacturer of electronic calculators;
Pete Maravich, who was a showboat in college and now is one of the National Basketball Association's major attractions, was suspended yesterday by Cotton Fitzsimmons, his Atlanta Hawk coach.

The Cabinet decided today to set up a joint Egyptian-Kuwaiti investment company with capital of $25-million, Government sources said.
Making its debut in the world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl in Venice next May will be the New Zealand team, which upset Australia in a recent playoff match.
Tony Canadeo, Bill George, Dick (Night Train) Lane and Lou (The Toe) Groza were named today to pro football's Hall of Fame.
A switch in a World Football League franchise from Memphis to Portland, Ore., appeared likely today as the new organization held the second phase of its collegiate draft.

Mariner 10, carrying out its elaborate sequence of preprogramed orders in what seemed a flawless manner, swept around Venus today, sending back to the earth pictures showing Venus to be enveloped in what appeared a well-defined shell of haze.

Following in unofficial translation from the Latin is the text of a letter dated Jan. 30 from Pope Paul VI to Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty: Our venerable and most beloved brother, greetings and our apostolic benediction!

For the second game in a row, the Knicks could not stand prosperity but wound up victors on the strength of their fabled defensive play, defeating the Phoenix Suns, 106-90, last night before a crowd of 18,884 at Madison Square Garden.

York College, for nearly a decade the controversial gypsy and panhandler of the city's senior colleges, will send down roots today and end its wanderings when students troop into gleaming laboratories and lecture rooms to open the college's science building in Jamaica, Queens.
Negotiators for ment and the Vietcong agreed today to exchange more than 4,000 civilian and military prisowners over a three-week period beginning Friday, the Vietcong announced.

Mrs. Abigail Adams Homans, the greatgreat granddaughter of John Adams, the second President of the United States, and the great-granddaughter of John Quincy Adams, the Sixth President, died here last night.

To compete in the national figure-skating championships is a difficult process. First, the skater must pass a series of tests to prove proficiency in the sport, such as the tracing of variations of the figure 8 on the ice or the exact pattern of steps in an ice dance. Then one must qualify by performing in various sectional and regional championships. Only the three top skaters in each division advance to the next level.

The British pound weakened against the United States dollar in late trading today on the news of Britain's impending nationwide coal strike. The dollar gained against several other major European currencies, and gold surged ahead.
A third heavyweight fight between Muhammad Ali and Jerry Quarry will probably be staged at Madison Square Garden next May, a reliable boxing source confirmed last night.

United States District Judge Miles W. Lord warned today that' the Reserve Mining Company's discharge of asbestostype fibers from its Silver Bay, Minn., plant created "a very substantial public health menace" and ordered the company to produce an on-land disposal system for its taconite waste.
Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 33 points and led a second-period comeback as the Milwaukee Bucks defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 102-87, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

The domestic paper industry has been relatively unaffected to date by the energy crises, the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
Lydia Sokolova, one of the leading dancers of the Diaghilev Ballet, died Saturday at her home in Sevenoaks, Kent. She was 77 years old.
Who says a Valentine's message has to be on a card? Not the Picture Pie Company, which is selling such things as breads and pastry disks adorned with messages for Valentine's Day.
Short-term rates continued to back down yesterday as the Treasury Department moved into the first phase of this week's $4.05-billion refinancing. Treasury bills were again strong.

Despite the rise in the cost of petroleum, Japan is still likely to remain overwhelmingly dependent on imported oil for her energy needs at least through the next decade and perhaps until the end of the century, experts here believe.

The White House announced today that Secretary of State Kissinger would visit Moscow late next month to prepare for President Nixon's return trip to the Soviet Union, expected in June.
In the New York musical community there is general sympathy for plight of Schuyler Chapin, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, who faces both economic and artistic problems.
Maurice Lucas sank a 20-foot jump shot at the buzzer tonight to give sixthranked Marquette a 59-58 basketball victory over Wisconsin.

One hundred handsome items representing this tradition are now on show (through March 17) at Japan House, 333 West 47th Street (832-1155).

Claudio Abbado's program Monday night, when he conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra at Avery FisherHall, had a weird and scrappy look on paper. But Mr. Abbado pieced the five oddly assorted works together into an interestingly offbeat concert.

Mrs. Billie Jean King's latest outburst against umpires and linesmen drew a strong response yesterday from Jack Stahr, chairman of the umpires' committee for the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

The Metropolitan Opera, worried about its ability to keep its deficit down to manageable proportions, is planning a reduction of from four to six weeks in the length of the season beginning in the fall of 1975.

Ryder System, Inc., one of the nation's largest truck renting and leasing concerns, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Toro Petroleum Corportation of Houston.

Angry housewives, students and independent gasoline-station operators charged at a public hearing today that the big American oil companies had contrived the oil shortage to raise prices and profits.

A prize of $50,000 for services to the conservation of wildlife, donated by J. Paul Getty, was announced here today.

A growing torrent of doctrinal verbiage is washing over the people of Yugoslavia as Communist leaders here seek to revitalize and strengthen the somewhat eroded authority of the party apparatus.
A 17-year-old high school student testified yesterday that he had seen Police Officers Gregory Foster and Rocco Laurie slain on a Lower East Side street two years ago.

Governor Wilson appointed Richard H. Kuh yesterday as Manhattan's first new District Attorney since World War II. The 52-year-old lawyer replaces his former boss, Frank S. Hogan, whose resignation after 32 years in one of the nation's most influential prosecutor's jobs takes effect today.

A new ballet company headed by the choreographer Eliot Feld is being formed with financial support from the Rockefeller Foundation and an offer of performing and rehearsal space from Joseph Papp of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

It would be easy to rag Mr. Beame for those highly publicized miscues that nearly tripped him up before he had an official leg to stand on. That would be the popular way, to make merry of Dinkins, Galiber and Terry, but like the head coach I eschew it. I will not savage the new Mayor for what reasonable men recognize as a contretemps.

Following are excerpts from a letter sent Jan. 30 by Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, dealing with the allegations of military snooping inside the White House, and excerpts from a statement made Jan. 29 by Secretary of State Kissinger before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in closed session:...
Massachusetts moved yesterday to begin a voluntary gasoline rationing program next week, joining the list of gasoline-starved states in the Northeast contemplating such a move.
After a year of struggle internally and with the Administration, the House Education and Labor Committee approved today a bill to replace the Federal Government's major education law.

Aggressiveness, both as prosecutor and as defense counsel, has been a conspicuous characteristic of Manhattan's newly designated District Attorney, Richard H. Kuh. The lawyer chosen by Governor Wilson to fill the gaping void left by the retirement of Frank S. Hogan is intelligent, articulate and energetic. He is also assertive' in ways that many find abrasive.

President Nixon named four Republicans today as good possibilities to succeed him in 1976. They are Vice President Ford, California Gov. Ronald Reegan, former New York Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and former Texas Democratic Gov. John Connally.

(Reports supplied to The Associated Press by resort owners.) NEW YORK Selleayre--6-to-42 inch base; 1 inch packed; skling good-to-excellent. Big Birch--6-36; 4-5 packed; good-excellent. Big Vanilla (Davos)--15-45; 4 packed; good. Dutchess--20-30; 1 powder; good-excellent.

President Nixon told a Federal district judge today that giving five White House tape recordings to the Senate Watergate committee would be giving them "to the world at large." He said that this would infringe on the confidentiality of his of. fice and would possibly prejudice criminal trials.

The Senate Rules Committee approved legislation today providing for the Federal financing of Presidential and Congressional elections. The legislation also provides a system of matching grants to help finance primary campaigns.

Thirty thousand one-ounce bottles of what was described by the police as "forged Chanel No. 5" and a large quantity of hi-fi, stereo and other electronic equipment believed to have been hijacked from trucks were seized by detectives yesterday in a warehouse operated by the 3-Way Trading Corperation, Inc., at 1165 Broadway, near 27th Street.

Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold said last night that numbers betting ought to be legalized in the state to reduce the profits and influence of organized crime. Mr. Gold said that numbers betting accounted for one-third of all illegal gambling and that organized crime invested up to $600-million in it here each year, collecting a yearly profit of $80-million.

The American Motors Corporation, enjoying booming sales in its small cars during an energyconscious period, reported today that earnings in the last three months of 1973 were up 23 per cent on a 16.5 per cent sales gain.

Those seeking evidence of an energy crisis, or of unemployment or a recession, may as well avoid the Quad Cities. Here, in what the local boost ers call the Farm The Talk Implement Capital of the World, many skilled Quad Cities workers this week were taking home an extra $100 a week in overtime pay.

IRENE, a musical, Jane Powell replaces Debby Reynolds, including additional songs. At the Minskoff Theater, West 44th Street, 6:45. CAROUSEL, the Equity Library Theater's revival of the Rodgers and Hamerstein musical "Carousel.' based on Ferenc Molnar's "Liliom." At the Equity Library Theater, Riverside Drive and 103d Street, 7:30, through Feb. 24.

Gov Thomas J. Meskill laid a record, election-year budget of $1.32-billion before the Genera Assembly today, and asked that more than $73-million in tax cuts he proposed in it be made effective as quickly as possible, without waiting for the end of the fiscal year in June.

Meat and poultry are expected to be in short supply in supermarkets in some parts of the nation next week as a result of the growing impact of the truckers' strike. There were also indications that the price of beef would rise sharply in coming weeks.

A cross-section of businessmen and economists yesterday characterized the Nixon Administration's two-and-a-half year attempt to control prices and wages as failure and said that they welcomed an end to the experiment.

What is an H dog? To a spaniel aficionado, it's a cocker from the kennel of Dr. and Mrs. Clarence Smith of Minneapolis. For all the Smith homebreds have a name starting News with H-Henriof etta, Handy Man, Hobbit-and the Dogs kennel name is Heyday.

The Nixon Administration recommended to Congress today that it let all wage-price controls expire on April 30 except for health care and petroleum products. Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz said the Administration opposed even stand-by controls because they "can become an inflationary force in and of themselves."

E. Cardon Walker, president of Walt Disney Productions told the annual meeting yesterday that attendance at the Walt Disney World park near Orlando, Fla,, had dropped 6.5 per cent since Oct. 1, 1973, compared with the previous year. Attendance at Disney Land in California, he said, was down 4.5 per cent.

Prof. Imre Lakatos, professor of logic at the University of London, died here Saturday. His age was 51. During the Nazi occupation of his native Hungary, Professor Lakatos worked for the underground resistance.

The Dearborn-Storm Corporation announced yesterday it had signed an agreement in principle with a group of private investors in Chicago for the sale of its portfolio of International Business Machines Corporation systems 360 computers for $17-million in cash.

Two former Queens County prosecutors took the witness stand yesterday to testify that they had received weekly cash interest payments, the dividends of a fast-money scheme, in the District Attorney's office in the Criminal Courts Building in Queens.

One hundred students and faculty members in the evening session at Fordham University's Lincoln Center campus staged a demonstration yesterday to protest what they maintain was the "forced" resignation of an associate dean of students who set up an adult-education program.

The dollar gained slightly on European money markets by the close today and the price of gold fell slightly on the main bullion markets. The dollar climbed above the five-franc mark on the Paris money exchanges. It had plunged below this level yesterday for the first time since France floated the franc Jan. 19.

A Democratic victory here yesterday in the year's first Congressional election - a race touted as a Watergate referendum-may have provided as many questions as answers about the mood of the American electorate. Government forces ran into heavy fire today from Communist-led insurgents on the east bank of the Bassac about eight miles from the capital, according to reports from the field. A force of about 1,000 rebels was concentrated on the river anti several Government outposts were endangered, the reports added.

President Luis Echeverria of Mexico arrived here today on his first official visit to West Germany. He began three days of talks with Bonn leaders by meeting with 74-year-old President Gustav Heinemann, and was to confer with Chancellor Willy Brandt tomorrow.

Prme Minister Eric M. Gairy, preparing to lead this tiny Caribbean island to independence at midnight, indicated today that he would take no reprisals against those who have joined in demonstrations against him.

Roger Field, a science specialist for radio station WINS in New York, bought a $219 telephone -answering device some time ago and installed it himself in his apartment here. Some time later, he bought a telephone and also installed it.

ABRASHKIN-Bernard. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Jened Foundation record with great sorrow the passing of out esteemed President and leader. His devotion and dedication are known to all. We extend heartfelt symparny to the beleaved family.

Campion is Bill Campion, the big center for Manhattan College who found a good match in the Miami Beach classic. And Barnes is Marvin Barnes.

The 25th member of the House of Representatives to announce any intention not to run again is Mrs. Julia Butler Hansen, Democrat of Washington. Mrs. Hansen, who has been in the House since 1960 but had been a local or state official since 1937, announced her retirement yesterday.

Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. suggested today that Presdent Nixon may have committed a criminal offense when he did not immediately report to the proper officials his information about the Watergate burglary.

While round-the-clock deliveries of gasoline were promised by many oil companies, the regional Federal energy administrator said here yesterday that other companies had reported that truck pickets were holding up deliveries once again.

To the Editor: The Jan. 25 letter on nuclear strategy by Robert Ellsworth is an excellent example or elective perception of the facts. Of all the complex components of nuclear strategy, only one is addressed, and conclusions are drawn without a single reference to the rest.

William T. Small, bureau chief for C.B.S. News in Washington for the last 12 years, has been promoted to senior vice president and director of news, in over-all charge of hard-news reporting and broadcasts for the Columbia Broadcasting System in New York.

Strongly hinting at possible turbulence in the mass movement getting under way in China, Peking today revived an early battle cry of the Cultural Revolution that stressed the need for "destruction." The dictum-"Without destruction there can be no construction"

" Leaving well enough alone is the secret to the delicious taste," it says on the back of a box of Quaker 100% Natural Cereal. "Every ingredient is natural. Nothing has been processed in. No artificial flavoring. No preservatives." However, the cereal, introduced to the New York area officially last week at a breakfast for writers, raises some questions about the use of the word natural and about the ingredients in this and other cereals.

Thousands of welfare recipients were bused yesterday to a National Guard armory and other sites that served as checkpoints throughout Tennessee in an attempt to remove ineligible persons from the welfare rolls. Some critics in the State Legislature likened the busing to a "cattle roundup."
