Two maintenance men were found stabbed to death early today in the Centre Bowl bowling alley, 1319 North Broad Street. The police refused to release details of the incident, but the Union County Prosecutor said both victims might have been killed after they surprised burglars inside the building upon arriving at work.

The Prosecutors in the murder trial of Dr. Robert F. Neulist, a wealthy North Shore dentist charged with shooting his wife to death in 1971, said today that the state's case would be based "largely on circumstantial evidence."

The royal Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao signed an agreement today that apparently resolved the last major dispute delaying the formation of a coalition government and the full effectiveness of the January, 1973, cease fire agreement in Laos.

The Consumer Product Safety Commission warned today that defects in thousands of socalled "rainbow lamps" could cause fatal electric shock. The commission said that 35,000 lamps have been sold in the United States in the last year. It urged that they be immediately disconnected.

The Senate Labor Committee approved a bill today to raise tile minimum wage to $2.20.an hour and extend coverage to an additional 7 million workers. The measure is similar to one vetoed last year by President Nixon. That veto was upheld by the House.

ALBANY, Feb. 6-In a clear note of party dissonance, a group of Republican legislators expressed dissatisfaction with Governor Wilson's response to the fuel shortage today as they announced that his rival Speaker Perry B. Duryea, had established an "Assembly gaso line crisis task force" to "begin immediate steps" to ease the problem.

France, finally announcing that she would take part in the conference of major oil-consuming nations beginning Monday in Washington, repeated her wariness today against involvement in anything like the "cooperative action program" proposed by the United States. Underscoring French insistence on the will and the right to go it alone, Foreign Minister

Anthony Mattone left the motor of his struck running yesterday morning when he dashed into a butcher ship at 42 Avenue C to make a quick delivery. But he wasn't quick enough. When he came out, the truck was gone-along with $15,000 worth of meat.
Top-seeded John Newcombe of Australia easily defeated Boro Jovanovic of Yugoslavia, 6-4, 6-2, tonight and gained the quarterfinal round of the $50,000 Raymond James World Championship Tennis Classic.

Two agreements signed this week between the French Compagnie Francaise des Petroles (E.F.P.) and the Algerian National Oil and Gas Company (Sonatrach), covering both offshore and Sahara oil prospection demonstrate Algeria's intention to step up her oil-exploration program.

The House of Representatives approved today a new set of rules of evidence governing criminal and civil trials in the Federal court system. The vote was 377 to 13. The 100-page code, promulgated by the Supreme Court late in 1972 and then extensively rewritten by a House Judiciary subcommittee,

Dipiomatic sources said today that Jordanian troops mutinied Sunday at a garrison near Amman because of discontent with their living allowance in a period of inflation. Because of teh uprising, the sources said, King Hussem returned from a visit to Britain last night, canceling a trip to Washington,

Sylvan Schwartz, a lawyer and president of First National Company, a manufacturers' outlet, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 240 Central Park South. Mr. Schwartz, a graduate of Long Island University and of Brooklyn Law School, was a panelist for the American Arbitration Association.

John T. Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, dreamed last year about the way he would get the Government out of the rigid mandatory wage-price controls of Phase 4. He still has that dream, despite the nightmare of inflation that has swept the country.

Television images of Venus transmitted by Mariner 10 as it flies away from that planet have revealed a system of bands and streaks roughly parallel to the Venusian equator and strikingly reminiscent of those in the clouds of Jupiter.
Food shortages began to show up and some industries began layoffs as the effects of the seven-day-old strike of independent truckers spread yesterday to the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area.

Jerry West of the Los Angeles Lakers may have to retire because of a persistent abdominal and groin muscle strain. In the slowest trading in more than four months, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday with the index down but with advances slightly outnumbering declines. Price indexes in the over-the-counter market, however, rose in most instances with advances also outnumbering declines in dull trading.

The novelist John Barth and 10 others in the arts have been elected to membership in the National Institute of Arts and Letters. They fill vacancies left by death during the year and bring the honor society's roster up to 242. Other writers elected were Anais Nin, Peter Matthiessen and James Wright.

Roy A. Medvedev, the dissident historian known in the West for his unofficial history of Stalinism, issued a long well-documented essay today praising and defending Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's latest book as a "mercilessly truthful" work providing more insight into Russian prison life than Dostoyevsky's writings.

Security Mortgage Investors reported yesterday that the North American Acceptance Corporation in Atlanta, which services $43-million of mortgage notes and land-sales contracts for Security Mortagage, had filed a Chapter XI proceeding in the Federal District Court in Atlanta under the Bankruptcy Act.

A fugitive who evidently could not stay away from court was arrested yesterday as he sat in the last row awaiting the late-starting morning session of the trial of Henry Brown in the murder of police officers Gregory P. Foster and Rocco W. Laurie on the Lower East Side two years ago.

ROME, Feb. 6-An assistant prosecutor who has been in charge of the inquiry into the way the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York acquired a Greek vase for about $1 million in 1972 today requested an investigating magistrate to take over the case and draw conclusions from the evidence so far gathered.

Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworskl, in a breach of Federal regulations restricting prosecutors from making outof-court statements about "the credibility of prospective witnesses," has gone on television to insist, "We have found no basis for a perjury charge" against Mr. Dean.

In the year 1973, by official count, there were 818,000 new refugees in South Vietnam-people who fled their homes to escape war. Hospitals admitted 43,000 civilian casualties. Upwards of 50,000 soldiers were killed, more than all the American war deaths in Vietnam since 1965.

Mayor Beame's ability to improve the efficiency of city government will be decided, to a large extent, by an unpublicized fragment of the city's Civil Service army of 250,000-middle management. Six American teen-agers charged with sacrilege for climbing a statue of Buddha pleaded guilty today before a Thai judge, who set sentencing for Friday, the United States

The Public Service Commission ordered the New York Telephone Company today to restructure its entire credit and deposit system within two months to offer service without any deposit at all to clients who answer "positively" three out of six questions.

The Acting United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Edward J. Boyd 5th, has been asked to investigate the former management of a Brooklyn laundry for possible misappropriation of funds and concealment of assets, a Federal bankruptcy judge said last night.

Twenty-two City Councilmen, expressing "deep concern" over the plight of Jews in the Soviet Union, ate what they said was a typical breakfast in the labor camps: an ounce of sardines and a slice of black bread served on tin plates and washed down with a cup of cold water.

Mrs. Lilian C. Heggie, widow of O. P. Heggie, the stage and screen character actor, died Monday at the Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived here and in Sierra Madre, Calif. She leaves two daughters, Mrs. Jean A. Storrs and Mrs. Barbara von Mathiessen; a son,

The Boston Celtics, down by 17 points in the second quarter, rallied tonight for a 105-104 National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Bucks on two free throws apiece by Don Chaney and John Havlicek in the last 42 seconds. Dave Cowens scored 12 of his 28 points in the fourth quarter to spark the Celtics,

A guerrilla group seized the Japanese Ambassador to Kuwait and several members of his staff at gunpoint yesterday in a, bid to win freedom for four other guerrillas trapped on a ferryboat they had commandeered in Singapore.

President Nixon sent his longawaited national health insurance proposal to Congress to day, saying that it would add about $5.9-billion a year to Federal spending and would for the first time, offer all Americans comprehensive health coverage.

Govenor Wilson announced today the re-appointment of Jerry A. Danzig of New York City as a member of the State Commission on Cable Television. Mr. Danzig, who will receive a salary ary of $20,000 a year, was a television adviser to former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. His term ends Jan. 1, 1979.

The president of a chain of subway concessions has been arrested on a charge of offering a $1,000 bribe to a Transit Authority official in an alleged attempt to secure a lower rental tal at one of his stands, Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta announced yesterday.

Cowles Communications, Inc., announced yesterday it would resume paying dividends on common stock with a payment of 5 cents a share April 5 to holders of record March. 15. Cowles paid its last dividend, also 5 cents a share, in December, 1969.

As principal flutist of the New York City Opera Orchestra, John Wion gets the chance to play many solos, mostly in old and familiar works. But on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, with Gilbert Kalish as his partner at the piano, Mr. Wion broke out of the cage.

The rationing of gasoline is spreading, despite opposition of President Nixon and fellow ideologues of laissezfaire. It is spreading not because of some socialist plot, but because "inconvenience has disintegrated into chaos," in the words of Gov. Francis Sargent of Massachusetts.

A $20.3-million damage suit was filed in Federal Court here today on behalf of a 17-year-old Edison youth who said he was shot by a rookie policeman during a chase after he surrendered and pleaded with the officer, "Please don't shoot me."

The Assembly voted today to raise from $100 to $500 the maximum fine that can be imposed against the operator of a migrant labor camp for violations of the Public Health Code. More than one Assemblyman likened supporting the bill to "voting for motherhood,"

New Jersey's second highest court today ordered the State Board of Higher Education to negotiate with state college teachers and administrators over rules governing outside employment. The Appellate Division of Superior Court overturned the board's unilateral adoption of the rules.

The Soviet Union has sweetened its offer to sell TU-154 airliners to India by pledging to provide the jet fuel required to operate them, Indian newspapers said today. The Soviet Union also offered to accept Indian rupees in payment for the fuel and to maintain stocks of spare parts on consignment in India.

The House of Representatives voted 410 to 4 today to grant the Judiciary Committee broad constitutional power to investigate President Nixon's conduct. The House thus formally ratified the impeachment inquiry begun by the committee last October
Camodian authorities today announced the explusion of Jean-Jacques Cazaux, a correspondent of Agence France-Presse. Mr. Cazaux said he planned to take the first plane out of Phnom Penh tomorrow.

The State Commission of Investigation tion has begun a major investigation into possible organizedcrime infiltration of the pornography industry in New Jersey. The investigation came to light here when Superior Court Judke George Y. Schoch ordered a Camden concern to appear in court Feb. 22 to answer a commission subpoena.

The Queen Elizabeth 2, moored at a Hudson River pier, will be the site of a birthday party for Mayor Beame on March 21. The party, reminiscent of many put on by John V. Lindsay's administration, will follow the new Mayor's 68th birthday by one day.

It would be easy to defend the view that the Southern Ocean Racing Conference this winter is offering the finest yachting competition in the world. The proof was in Tampa Bay today when 93 boats set sail in a sparkling but diminishing southerly wind of about 12 knots.

William Robertson Jr., a past president of the New Jersey chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, the Jersey City Real Estate Board and the Hudson County chapter of the American Institute of Architects, died Sunday at his home, 14 Duncan Avenue.

Rupp Industries in Mansfield Ohio said yesterday that it had renegotiated the repayment schedule on a $10.5-million loan that was in default. A total of $5-million will come due in five installments between July 31 and the end of the year, and the balance in two yearly payments in 1975 and 1976.

Frank McGuire, the South Carolina basketball coach, was released from the hospital today but he won't be back to work for about a week. McGuire was hospitalized Jan. 29. A university spokesman said McGuire had "acute gastritis" compounded by a ruptured blood vessel in the abdomen.

A guerrilla group seized the Japanese Ambassador to Kuwait and several members of his staff at gunpoint yesterday in a bid to win freedom for four other guerrillas trapped on a ferryboat they had commandeered in Singapore.

The Amerada Hess Corporation announced yesterday an almost tenfold increase in net earnings in 1973 on a 42.2 per cent rise in revenues. Fourth quarter earnings from operations showed a fivefold increase on a doubling of revenues.

A three-judge state court today disbarred John W. Dean 3d, former counsel to President Nixon, for what it called unethical, unprofessional and unwarranted conduct in the Watergate affair. The 35-year-old Mr. Dean, who has pleaded guilty to a Federal felony charge of obstructing justice and defrauding the United States, did not address the court in his own defense.

John J. McCloy, the Wall Street lawyer, told a Senate subcommittee today that, in representing 23 oil companies dealing with the oil-producing countries, he personally carried his clients' case to high Federal officials, including President Kennedy.

The Government securities market, pausing yesterday morning after a substantial advance for more than a week, started to slip yesterday afternoon. Prices relinquished much of their gains for the day. The Senate today refused for a second time to cut off a filibuster against United States ratification of the 25-year-old United Nations agreement to outlaw genocide. The vote on a motion to invoke the Senate's closure rule was 55 to 38, seven short of the required two-thirds majority.

Food shortages began to show up and some industries began layoffs as the effects of the seven-day-old strike of independent truckers spread yesterday to the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area. So far, over-all food supplies have been holding up,

A Federal judge ruled today that the American Basketball Association commissioner, Mike Storen, could not prevent the sale of George Gervin by the Virginia Squires to the San Antonio Spurs. The judge said Gervin was now the property of San Antonio and could play for the Spurs tomorrow night against the Utah Stars.

Several key leaders of the Conservative party said tonight that Prime Minister Heath was on the verge of calling a general election in the wake of the decision by the coal miners to strike on Sunday. The leaders thus added weight to the rising speculation in London that the announcement could come from Mr. Heath as early as tomorrow.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation was accused of sex discrimination in a class action suit filed yesterday in United States District Court here. The suit was filed by the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers and 22 of its women members,

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States had been led to expect that the Arabs' oil embargo would be lifted and that their failure to lift it would be regarded as "a form of blackmail."

Weavers visiting the city are often irresistibly attracted to the School Products Company, with its profusion of vivid yarns and the aroma of fleece. The company, at 312 East 23d Street, has looms set up in its fifth floor showroom to exhibit work in progress. And looms have been the basic business here for 25 years.

The directors of the Murphy 011 Company voted yesterday in El Dorado, Ark., to split its common shares on the basis of 2 for 1. Shareholders will vote on the split at the company's annual meeting on May 1. The directors also raised the quarterly dividend on the common stock to 24 cents, an increase of 8 cents over the former level of 16 cents,

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that military spying inside the White House "should not have taken place and should not have been tolerated." In a statement that otherwise praised Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Mr. Kissinger said that "I had no part in the decision to close any investigation or to reprimand or not to reprimand the participants."

The last crew of Skylab astronauts, preparing to leave their orbiting laboratory Friday after nearly three months in space, maneuvered the 100-ton craft a few miles higher above the earth this afternoon, so as to increase chances for a revisit by future space pilots.

Julius Erving did not act like a man ready to walk down the middle aisle in three days as he led the New York Nets to a 121-100 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight at the Fairgrounds Coliseum. Dr. J., who will be married to Turquoise Brown on Saturday, collected 40 points for the Eastern Division leaders of the American Basketball Association.

Two kidnapping, not one, were committed here Monday night and two white women, not one, helped the two black men who abducted 19-year-old Patricia Hearst in the second kidnapping, investigative sources said today.

The first anniversary of the Paris cease-fire accords that ended our ground combat role in Vietnam was marked Jan. 27. For me, that date also marked the end of my first month in the Fort Dix stockade, awaiting trial for desertion. My crime: refusal to accept military duty in Vietnam.

Copper futures plunged the 3-cent-a-pound limit yesterday, with the May delivery closing at 91.20 cents a pound, down from 94.20 cents on the Commodity Exchange. Traders were said to have sold upon a report that the Japanese Government had issued export licenses to sell a substantial amount of surplus refined copper in world markets.

In the 11 months since the musical "Irene" opened in the new Minskoff Theater, it has grossed about $6-million. It is taking in more money than any other show on Broadway. Last week, Debbie Reynolds's final week in the show-Jane Powell steps into the title role tonight - "Irene" grossed $149,542,

The House of Representatives approved today a new set of rules of evidence governing criminal and civil trials in the Federal court system. The vote was 377 to 13. The 100-page code, promulgated by the Supreme Court late in 1972 and then extensively rewritten by a House Judiciary subcommittee,

The Pittsburgh Penguins, on a five-game losing streak, discharged Coach Ken Schinkel today and appointed Marc Boileau, the coach of their Fort Wayne, Ind., farm, to succeed him. The Penguins' general manager, Jack Button, said he dropped Schinkel "with a deep sense of regret."

Joseph Kaplan, 27 years old, an Israeli citizen, said in Superior Court in Camden that he shot and killed Maurice Salvia, 31, in an argument last New Year's Day in Cherry Hill in Mr. Salvia's home, where Mr. Kaplan had lived for eight months.

Four oil companies, all members of the Royal Dutch Shell group-including the Shell Oil Company, one of the largest petroleum concerns in the United States - were charged yesterday in State Supreme Court with diverting and holding secretly in storage homeheating oil meant for New York area homeowners.

New Jersey, which probably has more giant fuel storage tanks and petrochemical aromas per acre than any state in the union, today seemed to be the archetypical victim of the national energy crisis. There was a great deal of anger, violence, anxiety and frustration-and little or no gasoline-in the state.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States had been led to expect that the Arabs' oil embargo would be lifted and that their failure to lift it would be regarded as "a form of blackmail."

Jose Raul Capablanca, whose genius was equalled only by his egotism, maintained, after losing his world championship to Alexander Alekhine in 1927, that, "if one were satisfied to draw, we believe that it would not be impossible to draw all the games."

Vida Blue, a holdout until late in spring training two years ago, agreed to terms for the coming season "in less than three minutes," the Oakland A's owner, Charles O. Finley. said today. The 24year-old left-handed pitcher had a 20-9 won-lost record and a 3.28 earned-run average last season for the world champions. Terms of his contract were not disclosed.

Last September I made a big decision. After a lifetime as a Roman Catholic, I was formally received into the Episcopal Church. Ordinarily such a move would have gone largely unnoticed, but because I had long been an editor or columnist for Commonweal and through the years had written on Catholic affairs for a variety of publications.

Earle M. Simonsen, a lawyer with the New York Telephone Company for 36 years until his retirement in 1963, died yesterday in the Staten Island Hospital, New Brighton. He was 75 years old and lived at 7484 Amboy Road, Tottenville, S. I. Mr. Simonson graduated from Columbia University in 1920 and from the Columbia Law School in 1922.

Consumer credit outstanding rose $704-million in December on a seasonally adjusted basis-the smallest monthly increase in almost two years. The Commerce Department report today noted that the increase in December followed a rise of $1.9-billion in November and brought total consumer credit outstanding to $180.5-billion.

In a significant victory for prison reformers, the Federal Bureau of Prisons has decided to dismantle its behavior modification project in Springfield, Mo. In the project, prison guards and doctors tried to alter the conduct of troublesome inmates by first locking them in cells for hours and depriving them of all privileges,

Bill Knight, although hobbled with a sore shoulder, scored 26 points tonight to lead Pitt to an 83-70 victory over Kent State and give the Panthers their 18th straight victory after an opening loss. Kent State led briefly in the first period by 9 points but Knight,

While round-the-clock deliveries of gasoline were promised by many oil companies, the regional Federal energy administrator said here yesterday that other companies had reported that truck pickets were holding up deliveries once again.

In celebrating the sacrament of penance both the priest and the penitent should prepare themselves by prayer above all. The priest should call upon the Holy Spirit to receive light and charity, the penitent should compare his life with the example and commands of Christ and ask God for the forgiveness of his sins.

After her husband and three children, Sharon Percy Rockefeller's chief preoccupation for the last six years has been Mountain Artisans. This is the crafts group she helped organize in Appalachia in 1968, a year after her marriage to John D. Rockefeller 4th, whom everybody calls Jay.

In a season already filled with frustrations for many Eastern race committees because of the snow shortage, officials of the Dartmouth Winter Carnival yesterday found themselves News falling into step. of They announced a readjustment of Skiing the schedule and sites-of the Big Green's annual skiing jamboree.

Only the thermometer and three golfers got into the 60's today as the 90-hole Bob Hope Desert Classic got under way in bright sunshine but uncharacteristically gusty breezes on the four courses used here.

Several months ago the newly formed Thoroughbred Racing Club of Queens College accepted an invitation from Jack Krumpe, New York Racing Association president, to visit Aqueduct and learn the details of the operation of the vast plant.

The New York Stock Exchange and the Securities Industry Association joined today in endorsing legislation to liberalize capital gains taxes as an inducement to broader participation of small investors in equity capital markets.

It has been said-only halffacetiously-that the less you know about the Superior Oil Company, the more you lilt it. Prompted by this line, a Wall Street wag commented yesterday that the facts must be emerging, for Superior stock is off more than 8 per cent from his closing price last week.

The Nixon Administration, a reluctant convert to wage-price controls thirty months ago, has decided to throw in the towel. Its recommendation that Congress kill mandatory controls April 30, except for curbs on health services and oil, is a confession of White House helplessness to do anything direct to arrest higher prices.

Stock prices rose slightly yesterday to post the first gain in the last five sessions. But the market's monumental lack of activity was seen in the volume of 11.61 million shares -the most meager turnover since Christmas Eve of 1973.

The Archdiocese of Newark, through its Institute of Social Relations, issued a "strong demand" today that Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson "take immediate action to avert the proposed shutdown of Stella Wright homes."

The way Steve Vickers sees it, in that self-effacing way of his, "any dummy" can score from the right goal post. Wrong. No dummy could be as alert and sharp as Vickers was last night, pouncing on opportunities.

The Defense Department, responding to Congressional criticism that the military was getting top-heavy with generals and admirals, has decided to abolish seven Army headquarters around the world. By cutting down on headquarters staffs though not on the size of the Army,

A two-year dispute over a new contract between local firemen and the City of Hackensack reached a climax with the fire men's union meeting tonight to decide what kind of job action it would take to win its demands.

Secretary of State Kissinger said the United States had been led to expect the lifting of the Arab oil embargo and would regard it as "a form of blackmail" if the embargo continued. Mr. Kissinger was responding to reports from the Middle East that the chances for the early end of the embargo were not as good as Washington believed they were. [1:4.]

The Nixon Administration recommended to Congress today that it let all wage-price controls expire on April 30 except for health care and petroleum products. Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz said the Administration opposed even stand-by controls because they "can become an inflationary force in and of themselves."

The Vatican published a revised liturgy for the sacrament of penance yesterday that makes possible a fundamental shift in the setting of the historic ritual from a simple encounter between priest and penitent to a communal rite.
The average rate on oneyear Treasury bills fell to 6.34 per cent today from 6.95 per cent in a similar sale a month ago. It was the lowest rate for one-year bills since February, 1973.

The cost of a market basket of 38 items commonly bought in the city's food stores rose 0.8 per cent last week, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs. The cost rose to $59.34 from $58.84. The average rise was lower than that of the two previous weeks. 1.1 and 1.4 per cent.

The imposter generally approaches a potential victim by asserting he is a police officer investigating another policeman,

ABRASHKIN-Bernard. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Jened Foundation record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed President and leader. His devotion and dedication are known to all. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. JACK SLATKIN, Treasurer.
Subfreezing temperatures forced a delay in the cleanup of almost 15,000 gallons of heating oil that spilled across the waters and ice floes on the Hudson River just south of the Bear Mountain Bridge.

The General Dynamics Corporation realized an increase of 125.7 per cent in fourthquarter earnings and of 70.3 per cent for all of last year on sales, which were up 11.3 and 6.7 per cent for the respective periods, according to yesterday's report from the company's headquarters in St. Louis. Lloyd Wright Fowles, retired chairman of the history department at the Loomis School, now the Loomis-Chaffee School, died in a nursing home here Saturday. He was 69 years old.

Najeeb E. Halaby, who remained on the financially embattled Pan American World Airways payroll until last Dec. 1 at his contract base pay of $100,000 a year even though he was forced to resign as the international Airline's chairman and chief executive officer almost two years ago, has hung out his shingle.

SpoKesmen for the Nixon Administration and the Sierra Club questioned today a Congressional proposal to put the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in charge of geothermal energy. And representatives of both the Sierra Club and industry expressed doubt that the $80million proposed for the sixyear research and development program would be enough.

Ten or 15 years ago, parishioners would line up at the confession booth at St. Jerome's Roman Catholic Church in the South Bronx seeking absolution for their sins. Today, the pastor, the Rev. Patrick Carney, sometimes sits in the box for the entire hour set aside for confession on Saturdays and nobody comes.

WNBC-TV, Channel 4, having made definite its plan to begin a two-hour evening newscast about May 1, is developing it as a "news-magazine in four parts that will 'be unified by three anchormen, to rotate singly or in pairs. That disclosure, was made by Lee Hanna, vice president of N.B.C. News. The program will run from 5 to 7 P.M. on weeknights.

A $2.7-million antitrust suit has been filed against the CocaCola Bottling Company of New York. The General Beverage Sales Company here charged yesterday in United States District Court that Coca-Cola terminated their contract last fall because the wholesale distributor shunned restrictions Coca-Cola placed on the sale of Mogen David and Tribuno wines.

William B. Bloeth, an editor on the staff of the Dow Jones News Service since 1966, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Baldwin, L.I. He was 61 years old and lived at 2549 South Grand Avenue. In 1938 Mr. Bloeth joined The New York World-Telegram, which was later merged with The Sun.

Talks between Rheingold Breweries and at least two prospective buyers continued as lawyers for the brewers' unions and Rheingold appeared before the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on the unions' motion to compel arbitration on several issues and to keep the Brooklyn brewery open until the arbitration is resolved.

President Nixon told a Federal district judge today that giving five White House tape recordings to the Senate Watergate committee would be giving them "to the world at large." He said that this would infringe on the confidentiality of his office and would possibly prejudice criminal trials.

The Board of Estimate yesterday began considering reforms to simplify and speed the oftenponderous procedure by which its eight members arrive at decisions on virtually all of the important questions facing the city's government.

The State Mental Hygiene Commissioner, Dr. Alan D. Miller, said today that he opposed any laws that would restrict the right of state employes to operate private vate homes for former mental patients-a restriction proposed by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz-because it "would eliminate some of the best possible people."

Arthur R. Taylor, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., assailed yesterday the "arbitrary and capricious misuse of Government power, how ever well intended," that has been eroding the broadcasters freedom and now is spreading to print journalism.

John Ellmers of Bloomfield was found guilty here today of driving in "willful or wanton disregard for the rights and safety of others," causing the death of two girls and injuries to a third in Madison last June 14. The misdemeanor charge carries a maximum sentence of three years in jail and a $1,000 fine.

Some oil companies are cutting back on credit extended to motorists. These days of gasoline shortages and long lines at the service station have also brought high profits to the oil companies. And the high profits and assured sales of all the gasoline they can produce have prompted some companies to stop promoting their own credit cards or to tighten credit requirements.

Essex County was described today as an organized crime "Wild West" by a Superior Court judge who assigned a special grand jury to investigate approximately 20 gangland assassinations, most of which occurred in the last two years.

Janice Cavalier, a soprano who gave her second New York recital Monday night in Alice Tully Hall, had mapped out for herself a symmetrical program. Four Handel arias and four songs each by Donaudy and Bizet preceded the intermission; thereafter came four songs each by Mozart, Joseph Marx and Peter Warlock.

The five major stockholders in a $6-million bid to gain a National Hockey League franchise for Seattle were identified today by Vince Abbey, vice-president of the Western Hockey. League's Seattle Totems.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make a list available this week.

The last crew of Skylab astronauts, preparing to leave their orbiting laboratory Friday after nearly three months in space, maneuvered the 100-ton craft a few miles higher above the earth this afternoon, so as to increase chances for a revisit by future space pilots.

House and Senate conferees approved a revised version of the long pending emergency energy bill today and sent it to both houses for another attempt at passage. President Nixon told Mayor Beams today that he wanted to help New York City with problems involving mass transit, the fuel shortage, narcotics treatment and antipoverty agencies. In a 45-minute meeting at the White House, the first time the two men had talked face to face, the President and the Mayor agreed to create a liaison committee that would iron out problems in Federalcity relations.

LSB Industries, Inc., said yesterday it had filed a suit in the United States District Court in Oklahoma City against the. International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for a minimum of $3.5-million in damages. LSB charges that a 1973 agreement to supply I.T.T. with air-handling and fan coil products through its environmental control division was breached.

F. Norman Hartmann, former president and a director of the Lily-Tulip Cup Corporation, died last evening at the General Hospital here. He was 67 years old and had lived at St. Simons Island since retiring on Dec. 31, 1970. Mr. Hartmann's first wife, the former Elizabeth Bellwoar of Philadelphia, died in 1972.

Citing soaring energy costs, inflation and poor stock-market performance, the president of Wesleyan University announced that the institution had suspended planning and had deferred construction of a proposal $10-million library. The library was to have been built this spring.

A winter storm warning was in., effect last night for the metropolitan area with forecasts of snow followed by sleet and freezing rain that would make driving treacherous and flooding a hazard. Snow began falling around 7 P.M. Up to an inch had fallen in Bergen County by 1 A.M.,

He's on the scene every year, perhaps because he never was in a championship game himself in 14 seasons. It wasn't his fault. His teams weren't quite good enough, but he just might have been the best cornerback ever.

A Cape Coral, Fla., man was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of cashing more than $43,000 in forged checks. United States Attorney Robert E. J. Curran said the man, Richard Schneider, drew 142 checks on a Jersey City bank and cashed them in Philadelphia between March 19, 1972, and March 19, 1973.

The Newark Archdiocese's request to avert the closing of the Stella Wright public-housing project was termed a "late and sad appeal" by Earl Phillips, director of public housing of the Newark Housing Authority. Mr. Phillips said today that the authority would have welcomed support from the archdiocese for any legitimate effort to keep the project from financial collapse.
A federal bankruptcy judge has thrown out 80,000 claims against Glenn W. Turner's embattled cosmetics cocern, Koscot Interplanetary, Inc.

Occidental Petroleum and the Diamond Shamrock Corporation have agreed not to require suppliers to buy from the two companies as a condition for getting orders, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

A decision to throw out a controversial murder conviction in the "Harlem Six" case was reversed yesterday by an appeals court. Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. had ruled last July 17 in Federal District Court here that Robert Rice, serving a life sentence for murder, must receive a new trial because doubt had been cast on important testimony and fingerprint evidence in the case.

In what appears to be the first serious split among anti-Marxists in Chile since the downfall of the Marxist government, the country's largest party has accused the ruling military junta of violating human rights,

A spectacular international gathering of unicorns will go on display today in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's noteworthy new show, "Masterpieces of Tapestry from the Fourteenth to the Sixteenth Century."

Chinese intellectuals are being called on to "make conscientious efforts to transform their world outlook" by taking part in the mass movement to condemn Confucius, who for 2,500 years has been the model of what a Chinese intellectual should be.

California Commissioner of Corporations Brian Van amp announced today the suspension of the license of the West Coast Commodity Exchange. The suspension was requested by officials of the exchange "due to a sudden decline in funds," Mr. Van Camp said.

Governor Byrne of New Jersey met for an hour today with William E. Simon, director of the William E. Simon, director of the Federal Energy Office, and the two then argued in front of newsmen, in the glare of television lights, over what exactly had been resolved.
Kuwait accepted a Japanese Government appeal yesterday to allow four guerrillas to fly here from Singapore in exchange for the release of Japanese diplomats held hostage here.

President Nixon told Congress today that nations supplying the world with important raw materials other than oil will have a much harder time than the oil-producing countries in radically raising world prices.

Tests by Consumers Union have shown that a mile-long line of idling six-cylinder cars burns up 150 gallons of gasoline every hour. The nonprofit product testing organization reported that idling eight-cylinder cars burned an estimated 67 per cent more gasoline.
The Cambodian command said today that Government troops had made gains on both banks of the Bassac River southeast of Phnom Penh.

DuPont Walston, Inc., which plans to go out of the securities business, said yesterday that it had signed contracts with 11 member firms of the New York Stock Exchange to take over 62 of its 138 domestic offices.
Frederic E. Richter, who had been a professor of economics at Harvard and Northwestern Universities, died today in a nursing home in Neshanic. He was 85 years old and lived at 79 Bayard Lane.

Restraint has scarcely been a mark of the independent truckers whose strike over high fuel prices has disrupted the national economy, but they will be outdoing themselves in irresponsibility if any substantial number persist in defiance of the tentative agreement worked out by their negotiators and top Federal officials.

The Panama Canal, built 60 years ago, remains one of the world's engineering wonders. It continues to serve as a vital shipping link, used annually for 120 million tons of ocean freight. But to Panama it is, first and foremost, a symbol of "Yankee imperialism." United States control of the waterway and the 550-square-mile Canal Zone, which surrounds it, has been a source of friction almost since the canal was completed on Jan. 6, 1914.

International Prime Minister Heath of Britain took his struggle with the nation's coal miners to the voters by ordering Parliament dissolved and calling a general election for Feb. 28. The campaign, expected to be the bitterest and most divisive in recent British history, will test the Conservative Government's determination to resist what it considers inflationary wage demands and the Labor party's claim that the Government's anti-inflation policy is unfairly directed at workers. LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Prime Minister Heath, taking his struggle with Britain's coal miners to the voters, ordered Parliament dissolved today and called a general election for Feb. 28.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday a 1973 net loss of $18.4-million. It was the fifth consecutive year of deficit operations for the company and brought the cumulative loss for the five years to $167-million.
Although trading continued far below normal levels, prices rose slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. In the over- the- counter market shares also rose in lethargic trading.

Joel Myers, the Penn State University meteorologist, who is the official weather forecasterfor more than 50 snowmaking areas, was in a joyful mood yesterday. An over night snowstorm News had provided the East with its best of ski conditions of Skiing the winter.

Governor Wilson called yesterday for a voluntary statewide program starting Monday in which drivers with odd-numbered license plates would buy gasoline on odd-numbered dates and those with even-numbered plates would do their buying on even-numbered dates.

A witness in the trial of Henry Brown, accused of murdering Police Officers Gregory W. Foster and Rocco P. Laurie on the Lower East Side two years ago, failed to identify Mr. Brown in an unusual courtroom line-up.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 7 -- Westchester's six cities banded together today in a Conference of City Mayors to see if cooperation was better than competition in solving what were essentially common problems.

The second snowstorm in three days piled drifts across the rural roads of the huge Pine Ridge Indian Reservation today but the Oglala Sioux went to the polls in large numbers to select a president. The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had raised its price for gasoline by 3 cents a gallon. At the same time, the company said that it had increased prices for kerosene and No. 1 and No. 2 heating oil, Price including home heating oil, by 4 cents a gallon.
Frank M. Masters Sr., a bridge designer whose company designed many well-known bridges in this country, died today in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived here.
Governor Wilson today asked the Legislature to prohibit discrimination against women in credit transactions, including loans, mortgages and dealings with credit-card companies.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that trading in securities of the, Republic National Life Insurance Company of Dallas be suspended through Feb. 16. It said there was a lack of adeqliate and accurate financial information on the company.

Two policemen were shot to death today in a junior high school conference room by a young man before he was wounded critically in a apartment where he had taken refuge with two hostages, according to the police.

WASHINGTON-Anyone who thinks about health as a public problem knows that an outbreak of bubonic plague is a greater threat than a superbundance of acne. He knows, too, that an epidemic of German measles, because of its effect on pregnant women, is to be taken far more seriously than much loss of teeth in old people.

Early analysis of the deluge of scientific data sent by Mariner 10 as it flew past Venus on Tuesday has lent support to the view that the manner in which that planet was born and matured differed basically from that of the earth, leaving Venus barren of water from the beginning.

Eugenia Honeywell, president of Nixon Newspapers, Inc., and the widow of a Wabash industrialist-philanthropist, Mark C. Honeywell, died today in a fire at her home. She was 77 years old.

After months of careful consideration, the lawmakers of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club have concluded that deliberate spitting is illegal. This represents an about turn by the R. and A. Rules Committee at St. Andrews, the governing body of golf outside the United States.

Brant McDougall, a Middlebury College freshman from Erie, Pa., won the crosscountry event, but Dartmouth moved into the team lead today in the opening event of the 64th Dartmouth Winter Carnival ski meet.
Jimmy Jones's 3point play with 52 seconds remaining lifted the Utah Stars to an 86-83 A.B.A. victory over the San Antonio Spurs tonight.

Six American teen-agers were fined $50 each last night and given three-month suspended jail sentences for committing sacrilege by climbing on a statue of Buddha. The young Americans, members of a tour group from the American high school in Singapore, were tried at Sukhothai in northern Thailand.

The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $739-million, up 12 per cent from the year-earlier $660-million.

The Symbionese Liberation Army, which has boasted of killing an Oakland school superintendent, declared today that it had abducted and still held Patricia Hearst, 19-year-old daughter of a San Francisco newspaper president and editor.

This is a tale of two basketball players from Brooklyn. One, Freddy Mobley of Baldwin School, operates in the obscurity of private school basketball. The other, Gordy McRae of Alexander Hamilton, plays in the Public Schools Athletic League limelight and is acknowledged as one of the finer guards in the city by opposing players, coaches and college recruiters.

Virginia's front line accounted for 78 points, led by George Carter's 32, as the Squires trounced the Carolina Cougars, 120-97, tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

The Senate Banking Committee approved today a housing bill authorizing several hundred million dollars more than President Nixon is seeking in this field. The bill would also continue major housing subsidy programs that the President wants to end.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday took the first step that could lead to criminal indictments of four oil companies and their executives on charges of "contriving"' to create a shortage of home heating oil in the New York area.

Barring a new offer, Dave Wottle will continue to compete as an amateur during the 1973 track and field season. "Right now, I'm an amateur and I'll be an amateur this year," the Olympic 800-meter champion said by phone last night from Bowling Green, Ohio on reports that he was interested in signing a pro contract.

The Skylab 3 crew tonight spent what was to be their last night aboard the orbiting workshop they have occupied for 84 days. Tomorrow the astronauts are to undock their Apollo spacecraft at 6:34 A.M., Eastern daylight time, and ride it to splashdown in the Pacific Ocean at 11:17 A.M.

The widow of a fireman who was struck by a train and killed while responding to a fire in a tunnel of the Penn Central at 96th Street and Park Avenue was awarded a $400,000 settlement by a jury yesterday in a negligence claim against the Fire Department and the railroad.

Gary L. Seevers, a member of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted today that food prices would stabilize or decline in the second half of this year, or at least rise at a slower rate than in the first six months.

The Youngstown Sheet Tube Co. has cut its whitecollar personnel to a four-day work week next week, reflecting the impact of the independent truckers strike. The cutback will affect 1,000 office workers here and 700 in Chicago.

Senator Russel B. Long Democrat of Louisiana, said today that President Nixon was probably not guilty of fraud when he accepted the advice of legal and accounting aides in claiming tax reductions hat he was not entitled to take.
The New York NetsIndiana Pacers scheduled basketball game at Nassau Coliseum tonight was postponed when the Pacer squad was unable to travel from Newark Airport because of the snowstorm.
The Cost of Living Council in Washington cleared the way yesterday for the city to pay retroactive salary increases totaling $950 each to more than 11,000 firemen here.

President Nixon will make a radio broadcast live from the White House at 3 P.M. tomorrow on "transportation initiatives for the nation," the White House announced today.
Gov. Philip Noel submitted to the General Assembly to day record $424.5-million budget that would allow a reluction in business taxes in lopes of attracting industry to Rhode Island.

A detective assigned to investigate a $4.4-million confidence racket operated by Joseph Ferdinando admitted yesterday that he had deliberately withheld from his official reports the names of investors within the Queens District Attorney's office.

Kathy Whitworth and Laura Baugh were the biggest first-round casualties today as the $100,000 Ladies Professionl Golfers Association tournament started with match play.
The army seized power in the West African nation of Upper Volta today, although Gen. Sangoule Lamizana, head of state for eight years, will apparently remain President.

Lajos Portisch of Hungary beat Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union today in the 10th game of their quarterfinal world chess championship match. Petrosian, playing Black resigned after Portisch's 33d move.

The heaviest snowstorm of the winter so far blustered over the metropolitan area yesterday, causing huge traffic jams and hundreds of minor vehicular accidents and prompting the city to declare its first snow emergency in five years.
Congressional supporters of continued American control of the Panama Canal mounted a campaign today against the agreement to eventually transfer sovereignty to the Panamanians.
At a superficial glance, the suit brought by the Justice Department against the State of Arizona on behalf of 24,000 Indians living in Apache County seems a rather routine affair.

A group of Senators set the stage today for a Congressional debate on the Administration's arms-control policies by introduring a resolution calling for mutual reduction of strategic arms by the United States and the Soviet Union.

Henry C. Wallich is a gentle man. Mildmannered, cigar-smoking, pin-striped to his core, the 59-year-old Yale University professor is not one to shake the rafters or upset the establishment at the central bank of the United States.

The director of the Justice Department's "think tank" and almost all of his professional staff members are resigning. Martin B, Danziger, Associate Deputy Attorney General and head of the Office of Criminal Justice, left today to become the director of the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund.
Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, proposed today the creation of a $4-billion Government fund to provide public service jobs if a recession develops this year.
Leaders of Britain's coal miners decided today to go ahead with their national strike Sunday, rejecting an appeal by Prime Minister Heath to postpone it until after the election later this month.

Ira Seret is leaving town, but before the native New Yorker gives up his East Side apartment and goes to Afghanistan to live there's the little matter of some 200 18th-century tent hangings that he wants to sell.

Prime Minister Eric M. Gairy said today that evidence of a plot to assassinate him had been found in the home of an opposition leader. The opposition leader, Maurice Bishop, was arrested on Wednesday on a charge of illegal possession of ammunition. He was released today on $125 bail.
Liechtenstein, a halfhour ski ride from its eastern to western borders, found a place in the ski world today while the United States continued to lose its position.

Federal prosecutors disclosed yesterday that they had obtained two new White House tape recordings for the judge in the trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans.

Most of the striking independent truckers apparently remained off the nation's highways today despite optimistic statements by Administration officials that over-the-road freight traffic would be back to normal soon.

In a move that may affect the balance of influence on national security issues within the Administration, President Nixon is expected to nominate Paul H. Nitze to a high Pentagon post next week.

The National Football League, responding to charges by the Players Association, denied yesterday that it planned to unilaterally cut off life, medical and dental insurance benefits to its players. Bill Curry of the Houston Oilers, president of the National Football League Players Association, charged yesterday that the owners had unilaterally canceled players' insurance and that the move could jeopardize over-all contract negotiations, which are supposed to begin March 16.

Demons and ghosts haunt the work of Wilford Leach, but there is also an antic side to this innovative playwright-director. His latest play, "CORFAX (Don't Ask)," now running at La Mama, combines his gifts for the gothic and the comic.
Governor Byrne promised today to seek additional state funds to help New Jersey's hard-pressed cities, but acknowledged that "we can't give them all the aid that they need."

New pronouncements from China today declared that the "high tide" of the new ideological drive is still to come and that what has been seen so far is "just the beginning."
Buyers in France, West Germany and the Middle East flooded London's gold market today with orders, pushing the metal's price to a new high of $145 an ounce.

The state's index of business activity - a key indicator of the health of New York's economy--reached a record high in 1973 despite the energy crisis, the state's Department of Commerce reported today.

A quick-witted bonsai dealer in Manhattan's flower district yesterday helped the Brooklyn Botanic Garden recover a $7,000 collection of patiently tended miniature trees stolen earlier in the week.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation agent directing the search for Patricia Hearst said today that "it is logical to speculate" that the next demand of the kidnappers will be to exchange men now in jail for her release.

Disruptions of parts delivery by striking truckers and weak consumer demand is causing a substantial drop in domestic auto production this week, according to Automotive News. The industry tradepaper said United States auto makers planned to assemble 120,292 cars this week, down 21 per cent from the 152,522 built last week and down 40 per cent from the 200,675 turned out last year.

Chicago's goalie, Tony Esposito, recorded his seventh shutout of the season and lowered his goals-against average to 2.00 per game tonight as the Black Hawks beat Atlanta, 3-0, in a National Hockey League game.
Cambodian Government forces said they strengthened their positions south of Phnom Penh today, routing rebels from two strategic points and killing more than 120 of them.

Just two nights after scoring their seventh triumph in a row, an 80-73 overtime victory over St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, the Manhattan Jaspers return to Madison Square Garden tonight in the opener of a college doubleheader against Fairfield University.

Senior American officials said today that they hoped next week's Washington energy conference would lay the groundwork for eventual cooperation between oil consumers and producers, resulting in adequate oil supplies at reasonable prices with a good return to the producers.

The election of Felix Kaufman as president of the Institute of Management Consultants, announced here yesterday, may close a rift between two substantial parts of the consultant industry, and certainly reflects changed attitudes, observers agreed.

Weinstein's ruling on the racial imbalance at Mark Twain Junior High School and its environs in Coney Island may stir objections from some factions in this seashore community, but in the long run the proposed integration will greatly improve conditions and become welcomed by all responsible residents.

A Federal judge decided today to recommend a special threejudge panel to review a novel court suit in which the controversial State Consumer Health Director, Dr. Oscar Sussman, has charged that his superiors tried to muzzle him.

Cloudy skies and cold temperatures, possibly accompanied by lingering flurries, are forecast today for the Northeast. Cloudy skies will spread from the Middle Atlantic States across the upper lake region to eastern Nebraska.

Not only are fewer and fewer people buying state lottery tickets, but those who buy tickets are gambling at the worst odds offered by almost any, other form of gambling, legal or illegal, according to new criticism of the setup.

Premier Kim Jong Pil of South Korea asserted today that the imprisonment of political critics who advocated the restoration of democratic rule here was justified to prevent "social disorder and chaos."

State and city officials announced an agreement yesterday under which the state rather than the city will guide the development of seven remaining sites, involving 1,500 apartments, in the West Side Urban Renewal Project.

DENVER, Feb. 8 (AP)--International Business Machines Corporation filed its formal appeal today of a $259.5-million. damage award a Federal judge ordered its to pay its computer competitor, the Telex Corporation.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation reported yesterday the signing of contracts valued at a total of $136-million for construction of four 89,700 deadweight ton tankers. Two will be built for subsidiaries of Overseas Shipholding Group, Inc., and the other two for affiliates of Seres Shipping, Inc. The vessels will be built at Todd's Los Angeles division.

The Defense Department has ruled that military officers can no longer attend the Harvard Business School. The official Pentagon explanation is that the school does not offer a "unique program" of study.

Space officials and the wives of astronauts criticized television networks today for not having provided live coverage of the Skylab 3 splashdown.
Ivo C. Sain, a retired investment analyst who had been a finance minister in the Yugoslav Government in Exile, died yesterday at his home, 143 Beach Street. He was 76 years old.

Retailers of men's apparel are somewhat concerned that their customers may not be in a buying mood. So they're going all out to come up with new ways of stimulating sales in a year of rising prices and an uncertain economy.
"Don Quixote," George Balanchine's richly theatrical pageant for the New York City Ballet, returned Thursday night for a week-long run at the State Theater.

Dick Cavett, expressing astonishment that the American Broadcasting Company had canceled his program with radical leaders of the nineteen-sixties at the last moment Thursday night, said he would not agree to the network's proposal that he edit the 90-minute program down to allow for an additional 30 minutes of opposing viewpoints, in the spirit of fairness and balance.

Manouchehr Eghbal, chairman of the National Iranian Oil Company, said today it was negotiating with a number of American oil companies for refining and distribution of oil in the United States. He did not disclose the names of the companies involved.

The French Line announced yesterday that its flagship, the France, would slow down on its trans-Atlantic sailings this spring and summer to conserve fuel. The ship will make the Atlantic crossing in six days instead of five.

Judith Somogi will become the first woman conductor of the New York City Opera when she makes her podium debut with the company at the New York State Theater at the March 17 performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado." The sprawling Brooklyn Army Terminal, a harbor landmark since the end of World War I, is about to be phased out as a military shipping installation, with its facilities being shifted to Bayonne, N. J.

Mayor Beame will meet Monday morning at Gracie Mansion with representatives of the Rheingold Corporation; its parent, Pepsico, and a group of businessmen headed by Jerry Finkelstein, which has expressed interest in buying the Rheingold Brewery in Brooklyn.

In a gesture that symbolized the mood in many European countries, Sweden's Trade Minister, KjellOlof Feldt, tore up his gasoline ration card with a flourish last week as rationing in Sweden ended after only 22 days.

By refusing to postpone the nationwide coal miners' strike during the three-week election campaign, the National Union of Mineworkers has given an additional push to an already dangerous polarization of Britain. In rejecting Prime Minister Heath's appeal for a delay, the union may also have enhanced the chances of victory for the Conservative Government on Feb, 28.
The Commerce Department placed new quotas today on exports of certain petroleum products, to bring a halt to big increases in exports of petroleum items that are needed at home.

Instead of accepting the reasonable agreement worked out between the White House and negotiators for the independent owner-operators, many strikers are denouncing the pact and seeking to intensify their choke-off of essential deliveries.
Record prices for gold in Europe contributed to new highs in silver futures contracts yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here. March silver closed at $4.81 1/2 an ounce, up the 15 cents daily limit.

The outbreak of measles in New Jersey is getting worse, with 159 new cases reported this week, the State Health Department reported. Last week there were 57 new cases. The total of cases since last Sept. 1 is 860. Dr. Ronald Altman, state director of epidemiology, said: "We are experiencing a rise in cases among teenagers."

Richard Wilson, a 40-year-old plumbing contractor, was reelected president of the Oglala Sioux Indian tribe yesterday, defeating Russell C. Means by 1,709 votes to 1,530. The re-election of Mr. Wilson was unexepected.

The Senate approved without objection today the nominations of Henry C. Wallich to be a governor of the Federal Reserve Board and Irving M. Pollack to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The Federal government expects to issue regulations that will help women in sports, according to Peter E. Holmes, director of the Office of Civil Rights.
The Vatican said today that Pope Paul's decision to remove Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty as an archbishop and hence as primate of Hungary had followed "prolonged, mature and grave reflection."

Food costs in the metropolitan area rose nine-tenths of 1 per cent in December as a result of marked increases in the prices of milk, eggs, dried beans and rice, the United States Department of Labor reported yesterday. The rise in the cost of those items, however, was partly offset by lower prices for meats, poultry, fresh fruits and vegetables.
Dartmouth's alpine skiers vaulted the Big Green into a dominating lead with consistent skiing here today as the Dartmouth Winter Carnival moved through three of four events.

Culte persuaded the City Council the other day, over the protests of some of his own closest supporters, to adopt a long-sought reformabolition of proxy voting at Council sessions.

The Detroit Wheels of the World Football League are beginning to roll. Yesterday the club named Dan Boisture of Eastern Michigan University as coach. Boisture, coach at Eastern Michigan since 1967, signed a three-year contract.

Police departments in some cities were reportedly buying machine guns, helicopters and even tanks and armored vehicles to combat violent action that might be initiated by secret revolutionary groups.
The Michigan House of Representatives voted today to take the state off daylight saving time after this season and return to standard time Oct. 27.

James D. St. Clair, President Nixon's lawyer, met today with Leon Jaworski, the Watergate special prosecutor, in an attempt to resolve an apparent dispute over access to White House tape recordings and documents.

Five Palestinian guerrillas who seized the Japanese Embassy here flew to Aden in Southern Yemen today after releasing their Japanese diplomatic hostages in an operation that angered public opinion here.

The Soviet state prosecutor's office has taken the first legal step against Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn since the publication of his latest book by issuing a summons for the author to meet with investigators, friends of his family disclosed today.
Marshall Dill of Michigan State set a world record for the 300-yard dash tonight in the Spartan Relays with a time of 29.3 seconds, breaking his record of 29.5 set here two years ago.

Now there are signs from various parts of China that a second is about to get under way, and may have already begun.
Only six dogs have been repeat winners at Westminster, and one, a smooth fox terrier, Ch. Warren Remedy, was best in show three years in a row, starting in 1907.

I. as a result of the troubles of a mail-order company that has been charged with grand larceny and deceptive business practices.

Kenneth Edward Bergin, a partner in the law firm of Weil, Lee Bergin and a specialist in corporate law, died Friday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived at 276 First Avenue.

A B-52 Stratofortress crashed and exploded on the runway at Beale Air Force Base last night during take-off. Seven crewmen were presumed 'dead and an eighth survived with serious burns.

Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler, who was Chief of the Army's Corps of Engineers from 1946 to 1949 and directed the clearing of the Suez Canal for the United Nations after the 1956 Sinai campaign, died yesterday at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 88 years aid and lived here.
PLAINVIEW, L, I. - As school boards begin drafting preliminary budgets for the next academic year, eyes are cast more frequently at dwindling enrollment projections and skyrocketing tax rates.

It wasn't planned and it wasn't expected, but the states and the cities of the northeast began a desperate, piecemeal and impromptu kind of gasoline rationing last week for two reasons: nobody else was doing it, and chaos was becoming the norm for millions of drivers.

Stock prices dropped last week as the energy crisis continued to tighten its cold grip on Wall Street. Specific areas of investor disappointment centered on the Arab oil embargo and the work stoppage by independent truckers. Fears of a more rapid rate of inflation in 1974 and uncertainty over the degree of the economic slowdown also played a role in restraining any aggressive tendencies toward buying stocks.

WHEN, a week ago Thursday, the Metropolitan Opera staged, for the first time in its history, "I Vespri Siciliani" by Verdi, the event also marked a minor milestone, duly pointed out in the program notes by Irving Kolodin. Now the Metropolitan Opera is the only theater in the United States ever to hold in its active repertory the final series of operas by the great Italian composer.

Mathias Jr. and J. Glenn Beall Jr., Republicans of Maryland, wins Congressional approval.

Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived at the White House this afternoon for an overnight visit. She had planned to arrive last night, and President and Mrs. Nixon had scheduled a dinner party in her honor.

Mexican -Americans, the nation's second largest minority group, put the highest priority on education as a way to escape their social and economic problems, but, according to the United States Civil Rights Commission, their children are being short-changed in public schools.

Ted Hood, the complete yachtsman, has won the St. Petersburgh-to-Fort Lauderdale ocean race. Sailing in the newest of a long line of distinguished yachts of his design, Hood trounced a dazzling fleet of 98 starters that set sail in Tampa Bay on the west coast of Florida last Wednesday.

Dennis Ralston was renamed captain of the Davis Cup team for 1975 at the United States Lawn Tennis Association meeting today. President Nixon announced this week the nomination of Marshall Green, United States Ambassador to Australia, to serve concurrently as envoy to the republic of Nauru, an island state in the Central Pacific that has been independent since 1968 but has never had an Ambassador from the United States.

Thanks no doubt to Watergate, the Senate Rules Committee has taken the momentous first step toward public financing of Federal election campaigns. In the recent past, reformers have introduced the concept on the floor, but now for the first time a standing committee-and a conservative one at that-has reported a bill favoring it by vote of seven to one, and in support of the principle in its purest form.

ON the morning of Sept. 6, 1972, Josephine Wilmarth arrived in Boston to talk with J. Sterling Livingston about leasing his small hotel on St. Croix-one of the three American Virgin Islands.

Berman and Stephen G. Crockett, filed the suit yesterday in Third District Court and said it was expected to be served on team officials Monday.
Former New York Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller said today that Vice President Ford was in a "very strong position" in any competition for the 1976 Republican Presidential nomination.

Through the intransigence of the National Union of Mineworkers and the visceral desire of right-wing Tories, Britain's general election seems destined to be fought superficially on the issue of "who runs the country?" The real issue is much more complex; and it is one that must be resolved, sooner or later, by every industrial nation trying to reconcile the requirements of a modern economy with those of a free and civil society.

Alfred Mercier, a prominent Canadian newspaper executive, died here early today at the age of 73. Mr. Mercier, who took over management of Quebec Le Soleil in 1937 when it was at a low ebb, developed the daily into one of the most successful and technically advanced in the country. He was active in newspaper associations in Canada, including The Canadian Press, and was a former president of the national news co-operative.
