Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident novelist, who once declared he was "prepared to face even death" to promote the cause of truth, was forcibly Arrested yesterday by a team of Soviet police agents. Seven men, some in uniform and some in civilian clothes, forced their way into the apartment of his family in downtown Moscow in late afternoon and took him away for interrogation, holding him through the night.

An official of the Arabian American Oil Company said today that Saudi Arabia "hasn't approached us at all" with a demand that American Oil companies give up their shares in the consortium for a likely price of $1.5-billion. But Michael Ameen, vice president of the world's largest oil-producing company, also said that it had become obvious that Saudi Arabia would eventually try to take hold of more than 51 per cent of Aramco.

The Negro Ensemble Theater opened its new season with a musical last night, and it is all at once surprising, exciting and bewildering. But then it is very many things all at once. The musical is "The Great MacDaddy" by Paul Carter Harrison, and it is described as a "ritualized African. American event inspired by the African storytelling technique advanced by Amos Tutuola in his famous novel, 'The Palm Wine Drinkard'."

When an executive of the Gulf Oil Corporation was asked why the company has its headquarters in Pittsburgh, the terse (but not unfriendly) reply was, "Why not?" Gulf, which reported yesterday that it had revenues of $9.9-billion last year and a handsome 79 per cent gain in operating earnings,

Marvin Barnes, playing with four personal fouls, scored on a 22-foot jumpshot with 5 seconds left in the second overtime period tonight to lift nationally ranked Providence College to a 75-73 victory over Brown, its crosstown rival. Barnes, who had scored with about a minute left in regulation play to tie the score, 61-61, finished with 28 points, 27 rebounds and 5 blocked shots.

9;06-10 A.M.., WQXR : Piano Personalities John Browning and Shura Cherkassky. Piano Sonata No, 31 in A flat, Beethoven ; Scherzo No. 4 in E. Chopin 10-11. WNCN. Three Etudes Seribin ; Choros No. 5: Alma Brasiliera. Villa- Lobos: 26th Order, F. Couperin : Creole Dances for Pilno, Ginastera ; Funerailles, Liszt.

As the news of Alexsandr I. Solzhenitsyn's arrest spread to Europe and the United States, writers and publishers responded with letters and cablegrams yesterday asking Soviet leaders to free him. A cablegram sent by the American Center of P.E.N., the international writers organization, charged that Mr. Solzhenitsyn "is being persecuted relentlessly by his Government."

Should Joe Frazier take on Jerry Quarry now that Muhammad Ali has pulled out of his date with the white hope from California? "No way, said Eddie Futch, the man who now maps the ring campaign for Frazier. "There's no point I can see for Joe to fight Jerry Quarry.

RAZING AND RAISING Cities hang around until long after what they were has completely changed, a sametitle, different-show sort of business. In the early nineteen - sixties Jane Jacobs wrote a book called "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," a seminal work that prescribed changes in the city-survival approaches that were prevalent.

To the Editor: The Times of Jan. 17 carried a Saigon dispatch captioned "U.S. Envoy Runs Tight Saigon Ship; Curbs News, Strongly Backs Thieu." The concluding sentence of the dispatch declares that Ambassador Graham A. Martin refused to grant requested interviews to The Times' correspondent.

William G. Bardel said last night that he had resigned as director of the Mayor's Office for Midtown Planning and Development to become a vice president of the Lehman Realty Corporation, a newly created subsidiary of Lehman Brothers, the Wall Street investment concern. "After nearly five years, it was time for me to do something else and a good time for the city to make a transition," he said.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation reported yesterday highs in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales and net income for 1973. Leslie H. Warner, chairman, pointed out that an 11.2 per cent increase in share earnings 'surpassed the company's av. erage annual growth objective of 10 per cent for the third Consecutive year."

Government sources here said today that they expected work to be completed by the end of the week on a new indictment naming Howard R. Hughes in an alleged stock fraud case. The indictment, which would be sent to the Justice Department in Washington for study, would supersede one against Mr. Hughes,

Mayor Beame prepared to abandon ship yesterday, saying he would restudy his plans to hold a fund-raising "birthday party" on the Queen Elizabeth 2 moored to a pier in the Hudson River. The plans have prompted protests from the people who run New York City hotels and the union members who work in them.

In an election-year show of support for lower taxes, the Senate today unanimously passed a bill to suspend the 2.5 per cent state income-tax surcharge for a second year and to increase the personal exemption to $700 from $650. The bill, which would save the taxpayers about $120-million, was sponsored by Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader.

Following is an excerpt from the seventh section of "The Gulag Archipelago, 1918-56," made available by the author, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, before his arrest today. The translation is by The New York Times.

The United States has now placed before the other major industrial nations of the world both a generous offer and a clear warning. The offer is to share America's advanced technology in a common effort to solve the world energy crisis,

A young woman who frequently poses for a prominent artist wandered into a gallery the other day to see an exhibition of the artist's paintings. While she was there, a man walked up to her in some agitation and asked if the portrait of a nude on the opposite wall wasn't in fact a portrait of her. She said It was,

, who has been unofficially running for Governor since the last gubernatorial election, formally announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Mr. Samuels, in a statement that is to be followed by a news conference today,

The Government said today that there had been savage fighting between Government battalions and hundreds of Moslem rebels in the last week in the large Sulu and Cotabato areas in the far south. Casualties are believed heavy on both sides and it was reported that the number of displaced civilians could reach half a million.

Nancy Pierce, a cellist from Iowa who currently plays in the New York City Opera orchestra, gave a most refreshing recital Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. In a location where one all too often encounters underdeveloped talents and overdeveloped pretensions,

The General Accounting Office has found no evidence of excessive profits for grain companies in the big 1972 wheat sales to the Soviet Union, but those deals did give the concerns "opportunities to make unusual profits" on other business, the agency says in a report to be released tomorrow.

Like a freshman anxious to get to classes on time, Senator Sam Ervin Jr. marched briskly in the cold winter air from classroom to classroom at Yale University today, sharing his wit, wisdom and wisecracks with enthralled students. The North Carolina Democrat, who at 77 is the hero of Watergate to many students and one of the few establishment figures they trust,

The 13-nation energy conference failed to reach agreement today because of a sharp dispute between France and her eight Common Market allies on how to respond to the American call for joint efforts by oil consuming and oil-producing countries to deal with the energy crisis.

Sal Teta, partner in a Mobil service station near Borough Hall, in downtown Brooklyn, emerged from the second day of odd-even gasoline sales yesterday with an upset stomach and a deep distaste for being an enforcement officer for the new voluntary system. "We bent it a little," Mr. Teta said, his slightly rueful smile accented by a lock of gray-brown hair that hung over his forehead from under an off-center baseball cap.

West Germany's Finance Minister said today that there could be no "papering over" of the fundamental conflict within the European Common Market that has checked progress at the conference of major oilconsuming nations here. The Minister, Helmut Schmidt, and other officials attending the talks, said in interviews arid in briefing sessions that a procedural argument between France and her eight market partners had a larger meaning.

President Nixon, after attending the 90th birthday party of Alice Roosevelt Longworth, said tonight that she had kept young "by not being obsessed by the Washington scene." "If she had spent all of her time reading The [Washington] Post or The Star [Washington Star-News] she would have ben dead by now," he said.

The American League announced today the creation of a Joe Cronin Award for "singular achievements over the course of a season" and named Nolan Ryan, the California Angels pitcher, the first recipient. Ryan, who set a major league strike-out record last season with 383, will receive

More than 10 per cent of the 400,000 employes on the municipal payroll live outside of New York, City Council President Paul O'Dwyer said yesterday. He said he would press for legislation to require all newly hired workers to live inside the city.

The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was working on plans for new small cars for the 1976-77 model years. The program would include new Plymouth and Dodge compact-size cars to be introduced in the fall of 1975 as 1976 models and subcompact Plymouth and Dodge cars for introduction in the fall of 1976 as 1977 models.

Willie Norwood and Dave Bing combined for 51 points tonight as the Detroit Pistons beat Kansas City-Omaha, 113-106, for their seventh straight National Basketball Association victory. Norwood scored 27 points, the third time in the last four games he has scored that total as a replacement for the injured Don Adams.

A retired 80-year-old executive has been awarded more than $12,000 in back pension payments from the Prudential Insurance Company, and the concern has until Feb. 22 to show cause why the payments should not continue. Superior Court Judge Irwin Kimmelman yesterday ordered the insurance company to pay Valentine Howell, a former

The State Court of Appeals today upheld, 6 to 1, the constitutionality of a law appointing up to 68 Court of Claims judges who would then serve as Supreme Court, justices to try narcotics cases under the state's stringent drug laws. The court, the state's highest, acted on appeals of a number of narcotics defendants who challenged the right of the judges to be appointed and to then serve on the bench hearing felony cases.

Pine forests all along the coast, a celebrated feature of Italian scenery, seem fated to die. Writers of the late Roman Empire, Dante, Boccaccio and Byron have all praised the solemn groves on the Adriatic seacoast near Ravenna. Now many thousands of old trees there are withering, their needles turning parched, under the onslaught of oil-laden spray from the sea to the east and of fumes from a refinery complex to the west.

A suit has been filed on behalf of a 16-year-old girl and her 9-month-old son, charging that they were denied admittance to low-cost public housing because the mother was still legally a child. The suit contends that the denial violated her civil rights as effectively as if she had been denied acceptance solely on the basis of her race or sex.

A major racial dispute involving several of New Jersey's most prominent Democratic leaders threatened today to undermine Governor Byrne's nomination of Mayor Patricia Q. Sheehan of New Brunswick as Commissioner of the State Department of Community Affairs. The dispute does not involve Mrs. Sheehan, and her appointment seems secure. Rather,

A plan to tempt Britain's striking coal miners back to work by supplementing their wages with private donations was rejected today by the National Union of Mineworkers. The offer came from unidentified industrialists who would be hard hit if the coal strike, which started Sunday, lasted much longer.

The Rockwell International Corporation announced today selection of the Aerojet Liquid Rocket Company of Sacramento for a $25-million subcontract for space shuttle work. Rockwell's Space Division is developing the shuttle orbiter and integrating the complete system for the National Space Agency.

The 13-nation energy conference in Washington failed to reach agreement because of a sharp dispute between France and her Common Market allies on how to respond to the American call for joint efforts by oil consuming and producing countries to deal with the energy crisis. The delegates decided to extend the conference for a day in an effort to resolve the dispute. [1:8.]

United States District Court Judge Adrian Spears denied a motion today that would have allowed American Basketball Association trustees to meet in Chicago tomorrow to act upon Commissioner Mike Storen's attempts to void the contract between the San Antonio Spurs and the Virginia Squires concerning George Gervin, an all-star forward.

Now many thousands of old trees there are withering, their needles turning parched,

The excerpt was written in 1968 and had not been released for publication along

Capt. Warwood E. Mason, a retired executive of American Export Lines, now American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, died Monday in Orange Memorial Hospital in East Orange, N. J. He was 73 years old and lived at 334 West 85th Street, New York. Captain Mason joined American Export Lines in 1926 as a third officer, became a sea captain in 1932 and was appointed Director of employment and labor relations manager for the line in 1950.

Finance Ministr Takeo Fukoda said today he would selectively tighten monetary controls to squeeze out any excess liquidity that may remain in Japan's economy. Emerging from a Cabinet meeting, he said Premier Kakuei Tanaka had urged a tighter over-all squeeze after having learned that Japanese wholesale prices surged 5.5 per cent in January.

The Symbionese Liberation Army today asked Randolph A. Hearst, the newspaper executive, for more than $230-million worth of free food for the poor as evidence of good faith in negotiating the release of his kidnapped daughter, Patricia. At the same time, the radical group provided Mr. Hearst with a tape recording of his daughter saying,

Garden State Park opened the earliest racing season ever in this state today with an upset in the Betsy Ross, a six-furlong sprint for 3-yearold fillies worth $26,600. Rident Miss, owned by Joseph and William Stavola of Middletown, was the winner, scoring the first victory of her career and earning $17,290.

A lawsuit charging the former Presidential aide, John D. Ehrlichman, with tapping the telephone of Mary Jo Kopechne's roommates is being withdrawnTom Patton, attorney for Margaret Carroll, who brought the lawsuit, said he had concluded that neither Mr. Ehrlichman nor the other two defendants in the suit, John J.

The 39-year-old gum-chewing star with the ninth-grade education was teaching the 40-year-old college-educated rookie how to get around Daytona Speedway today. David Pearson won the pole position two days ago for Sunday's 450-mile Daytona 500 and now was trying out his 1973 Mercury in traffic,

Grace Melzia Bumbry, who sang "La Gioconda" with the Opera Theater of New Jersey here Sunday night, was the first black singer to appear in a major role with the company in its eight years of existence. She will repeat the performance tomorrow evening at the Memorial Auditorium in Trenton.

Corporate bond prices were marked up slightly yesterday, but most of the credit market was closed for Lincoln's Birthday and the increases weren't considered significant. It was a semi-holiday with the banks in New York, California and Illinois closed. The Government securities market was at a standstill.

A jury in Middlesex County Court here was told today that Clark D. Squire, a 35-year-old alleged member of the Black Liberation Army, "executed' Trooper Werner Foerster of the state police in a shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike near here last May 2.

A Brooklyn man who collapsed on a streetcorner on the Lower East Side died yesterday after more than half an hour passed before an ambulance responded to an emergency police radio call. Four policemen from the Seventh Precinct and a nurse from a nearby clinic worked to keep Benedict William, a 43year-old warehouseman, alive through chest massage and resuscitation after Mr. William was spotted at about 11:24 A.M.

The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that its average residential customer would pay $2.23 more this month, or 12.7 per cent, more than in January, for the same amount of electricity because of sharply increased costs of the oil the utility burned. The fuel increase this month is the largest since fuel prices began rising last year,

Bud Harrelson and Jerry Koosman signed their contracts yesterday, leaving the New York Mets with 11 players unsigned. Bob Scheffing, the club's general manager, and Koosman came to terms over the telephone from Koosman's home in Morris, Minn. Koosman had a 14-15 won-lostrecord and a 2.84 earned-run average last year.

Obviously anticipating action against himself in his final day or two of freedom, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn prepared the following statement vowing never, to cooperate with authorities who tried to interrogate, try or imprison him: "In advance, I declare any tribunal of common law on Russian literature, on any of its books, on any Russian author, to be incompetent.

Premier Carlos Arias Navarro today promised Spaniards wider and freer participation in government and union affairs than they have known in the 35 years since the Civil War. In one of the most longawaited announcements in years, Mr. Arias announced that mayors and heads of provincial assemblies, formerly appointed, would now be elected.

Elected officials, labor and industry spokesmen, educators and private citizens today portrayed for a United States Senate labor subcommittee a bleak and apparently worsening employment situation in New Jersey as a result of the fuel shortage. The afternoon session of the special hearing was marked by a prolonged and angry exchange between the chairman, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., New Jersey Democrat,

The Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday announced operating results for 1973. The report indicated a 153 per cent gain in fourth-quarter earnings. Net income for the full year climbed to $800-million, ending a fouryear slide in profitability. Gulf, the nation's fourth largest oil company, did not announce earnings for the last three months.

Daniel Chiarellio did not want to accept a traffic summonse last night, the police said but his reluctance proved costly. After a 20-minute chase through rush-hour traffic, including two trips across the Manhattan Bridge, Mr. Chiarellio, who is 22 years old, was seized at a roadblock and charged with the following:

WASHINGTON-There is the nagging thought here that Washington may have missed a signal indicating that Fidel Castro's Government may be ready to seek an end to the United States' 13-year boycott of Cuba. Various circumstances suggest such a sounding by Havana.

RAINBOW JONES, a musical, with book, music and lyrics by Jill Williams, directed by Gene Person, at the Music Box, West 45th Street, 7. EL ARQUITECTO Y EL EMPERADOR DE ASIRIA, a play in Spanish by Fernando Arrabal, presented by the Spanish Theater Repertory company, at the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, 8.

Under sharp attack by Governor Byrne, commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed today to consider on Thursday whether to withdraw a request for an increase in PATH tube train fares from 30 to 50 cents. Intervening in the Interstate Commerce Commission hearings here on the proposed fare increase,

ALBERTS-Ethel M. Park East Synagogue Congregation Zichron EPhraim sorrowfully mourns the passing of the sister of our steemed Trustec, Nathan Tratzky. Our heartfelt Sympathy to the bereaved family. Rabbi ARTHUR SCHNEIDER. SOL SCHULMAN, President. ALFRED I. SCHLOSSBERG, Chairman of the Board.

A late technical recovery yesterday enabled the stock market to erase many of its earlier losses and finish the session mixed in continued slow trading. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange opened lower and stayed in the minus column until about 1 P.M. when some buying interest developed.

Unler sharp attack by Governor Byrne, commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed today to consider on Thursday whether to withdraw a request or an increase in PATH tube rain fares from 30 to 50 cents. Intervening in the Interstate commercee Commission hearngs here on the proposed fare increase, the Byrne adminisration denounced it as an ill-timed request."

A Federal grand jury in the Eastern District of New York has begun investigating the alleged Republican vote-siphoning scheme for possible violation of the mail fraud statutes, sources close to the investigation said yesterday. Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly Speaker; John E. Kingston, the Assembly majority leader; Assemblyman Alfred Delli Bovi of Queens,

The North Carolina Democrat, who at 77 is the hero of Watergate to many students and one of the few establishment figures they trust,

The General Accounting Office has found no evidence of excessive profits for grain companies in the big 1972 wheat sales to the Soviet Union, but those deals did give the concerns "opportunities to make unusual profits" on other business, the agency says in a report to be released tomorrow. The other profits resulted from rising prices, driven up by thezSoviet deals, and from escalating subsidies,

The idea that public television might become the "fourth network" in the United States has been officially demolished supplanted by a radically new system, going into effectJuly 1, under which each local station would select and pay for national programs It wants.

Iraq has asked for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to deal with the border dispute with Iran that brought fighting this week, a United Nations spokesman announced today. The request was submitted to Louis de Guiringaud of France, the Council President for February.

The 40 squatters and their children who live on Federal land near Tocks Island have received orders from Federal courts here and in Scranton, Pa., that amount to at least a temporary reprieve from earlier eviction decisions. "Now we can stop worrying about eviction and start thinking about spring planting," said one of the squatters, Charles Evans, when asked about the effects of the recent decisions.

With gasoline stations continuing to run dry and with frustration and anger among motorists growing, Gov. Thomas J. Mes kill prepared today to ask the General Assembly in joint ses sion tomorrow to endorse a plan for restricting gasoline sales in the state and to give him extraordinary powers to cope with the shortages.

Mary Graham Bonner, an author of books for children, died yesterday at her home, 706 Riverside Drive. Her age was about 83, according to associates. Miss Bonner won the 1942 Constance Lindsay Skinner Award for "Canada and Her Story," a history written for children in the United States.

Credit Lyonnais, France's ranking business and deposit bank, said today it would participate with three European associates in the creation of the Private Development Finance Company of Indonesia. The partners are Banco di Roma Holding, Luxembourg; Lloyds and Bolsa International Bank, Ltd.; and the Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale.

The American Broadcasting Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had obtained a one-year option to buy the Historic Towne of Smithville in southern New Jersey for more than $9-million. With the purchase, Smithville, a restored Early American community that includes three inns and about 60 shops and buildings set on 2,300 acres,

Five cars of a San Franciscoto-Chicago passenger train derailed tonight, sending about 17 passengers to the hospital, Amtrak said. The derailment took place at 7:40 p.m. 33 miles west of McCook, Neb. "The train and all passengers who didn't want any treatment are continuing," the Amtrak spokesman said.

The rush to buy gold and silver continued in heavy trading on the European bullion markets today amid reports of speculation from the Middle East and massive accumulation by American investors. Silver climbed to a record price for the seventh consecutive session, closing up about 34 cents an ounce at $5.60 in London after touching $6 earlier in the day.

Rafael Kubelik, the first music director in the Metropolitan Opera's history, resigned that post yesterday, effective immediately. However, the company, in making the announcement, said the Czech-born musician would fulfill his conducting assignments for the remainder of the season,...

The United States Embassy here today protested the detention of two United States reporters and accused the Soviet Union of violating the United States-Soviet consular agreements an Embassy spokesman said. The United States charge d'affaires, Adolph Duhs, said that he had protested to the Soviet Foreign Ministry over the detention yesterday of two correspondents

The two leaders of the rubber and paper industries - the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company and the International Paper Company - reported results yesterday for the final quarter and all of 1973. International Paper showed sharply higher sales and earnings for both periods, while Goodyear Tire Rubber had lower earnings despite record sales.

A group of black residents signed an agreement yesterday to purchase radio station WLDB, a National Broadcasting Company affiliate in this resort. The sale to the Atlantic Business and Community Development Corporation, is subject to the approval of the Federal Communications Commission. The station, which has encountered difficulties with the commission, is owned by Mrs. Dorothy Bremmer.

Members of the Consumer Product Safety Commission say they believe publishers should try to verify the safety of the products advertised in their publications. Richard O. Simpson, chairman, and the other commissioners singled out the print media for the strongest criticism at a luncheon session yesterday with reporters

It took Len Carey of Fallbrook, Calif., exactly 10 minutes to name a German short-haired pointer, Ch. Gretchenhof Columbia River, best in show last night before a cheering crowd of 11,000 as the Westminster Kennel Club's 98th edition ended a two-day run at Madison Square Garden. It was the first time that a representative of the breed had taken the top prize at the blue-ribbon event.

Federal District Judge George H. Boldt ruled here today in a long-awaited decision that Washington State fishing regulations were unlawful when applied to 14 western Washington Indian tribes. He ruled that the tribes, whose fishing rights are guaranteed by treaties, could not be regulated in fishing except when it was necessary to preserve stocks of salmon and steelhead trout.

A WOMAN IN THE SKY. By Jnmes Hanley. 224 pages. Horizon Press. $6.95. Lena Biddulph has been kicked upstairs by the Council, the official organ of the British welfare state. She was happy in her little house with the terrace in Gag Lane, but they condemned it-and her, at the same time, to a "life in the sky,"

Representative Shirley Chisholm predicted tonight that President Nixon would resign "most reluctantly" by next April. In a speech at the University of Colorado, the Brooklyn Democrat said the President's decision would not result from Democratic pressure, but from increasing pressure from his own Republican party.'

Mayor Beame sounded what appeared to be an "abandon ship" signal yesterday to campaign fund-raisers who were planning a birthday salute for him aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2. The Mayor-upset by protests from the people who run New York City hotels and the unions whose members work in them - said through a spokesman that he "was not involved in the arrangements" for the party aboard the British liner.

Over a span of 40 years the New York Telephone Company had built a structure of rates and services that had prompted little close examination or criticism, Rates had been fairly stable, and there seemed little need for consumer pressure. In 1969, all that changed, as service in New York City and the surrounding area became increasingly erratic.

The contests for a State Senate seat and for an assembly seat in special elections in Queens tomorrow have developed into a "captains' war," with the regular Democratic organization favored to retain both seats. The turnout is expected to be extremely low, and the parties are relying on their captains, who are aides to the local district leaders, to "pull out" the basic organization vote.

Four major petroleum companies-the Atlantic Richfield Company, Ashland Oil, Inc., the Oil Shale Corporation and the Shell Oil Companytoday submitted a joint bid of $117-million to develop vast tracts of buried oil shale in western Colorado. The bid was below the $210-million submitted jointly last Jan. 8 by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana and the Gulf Oil Corporation on the first tract of shale land.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark.-In a recent television film, Tom Courtenay, playing a missionary priest, inadvertently antagonized a remote Indian tribe by praising education as "a bridge" to the outside world. Within a year, though, the priest had come to share the tribe's feeling that ethnic and cultural solidarity more than compensated for totemism, ignorance, poverty and disease.

Henry Swartz, who graduated from New York University Law School in 1906 and practiced corporate law here until his retirement four years ago, died yesterday at the age of 90 in Veterans Administration Hospital, East Orange, N. J. Mr. Swartz is survvied by his widow, the former Ida Hoffman; a daughter, Mrs. Deborah Laden; two sons, Robert M. and Daniel C.: five grandchildren.

James W. McCord Jr., one of the original defendants in the Watergate trials, has written to the Senate Judiciary Committee requesting to appear at any hearings on the nomination of Earl J. Silbert to be United States Attorney -for the District of Columbia. Bernard Fensterwald Jr., Mr. McCord's lawyer, confirmed today that the letter had gone in the last few days to the committee. Mr. Silbert headed

William E. Simon, administrator of the Federal Energy Office, prohibited service station owners today from discriminating against motorists by selling gasoline only to regular customers or by selling large amounts in advance. "These practices have now been banned by the Federal Energy Office as discriminatory," he said.

Mayor Richard G. Lugar of Indianapolis announced tonight that he would be a candidate for the Republican Senatorial nomination at the state party's convention June 21 to oppose Senator Birch Bayh, a Democrat. In remarks he had prepared for a Lincoln Day dinner,

Nelson Bunker Hunt, the 48year-old son of H. L. Hunt, one of the nation's wealthiest oil men, has apparently been buying silver contracts for many months. The talk among commodity men is that he thinks dollars are safer from inflation these days if invested in the form of silver bars.

A frenzied rush to buy silver coin futures sent prices up the daily permissible limit of $100 for a bag of $1,000 face value on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. But the frenzy was short lived. Only 11 trades of 10-bag lots were effected in the few seconds of trading there before the limits were reached.

Rod Laver and Roger Taylor had to struggle to win, but Arthur Ashe had little trouble as they advanced to the third round of the $50,000 Astor Cup tennis tournament, a World Championship Tennis circuit event. Laver fought off Antonio Zugarelli of Italy, 6-2, 4.6, 7-5.

An organizing convention of the New York State Women's Political Caucus, billed as the state's first women's political convention since 1848, will be held Friday night, Saturday and Sunday at the White Plains Hotel in White Plains. The agenda includes workshops on lobbying and running for office and a dinner honoring women officeholders throughout the state.

Albert Brown, a retired advertising executive, died yesterday at his home here. He was 70 years old. Mr. Brown, a graduate of Dartmouth College, spent virtually his entire career with Best Foods, Inc., and the company into which it was merged in 1959, the Corn Products Company, now CPC International, Inc.

A gross act of self-interest has provided a dismaying initial demonstration of the way in which Governor Wilson intends to exercise his newly inherited dominance in Albany. The steamroller votes, by which the Republican majorities in both houses of the State Legislature changed the date of the primary elections from June to September, had almost nothing to do with good government.

The gloom seems to be getting gloomier for 1974's economic outlook. Yesterday two leading forecasters said that the shrinkage in gross national product expected by the experts this quarter may last through the first halfor longer. Paul W. McCracken, former chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, put the chances of two quarters of negative growth at "better than 50-50." Talking at a lunch.

The Wounded Knee trial opened here today with dramatic statements from the two defendants, Russell C. Means and Dennis J. Banks, that Indians are ready to revolt against having their heritage and traditions crushed by an unfeeling Federal oureaucracy. The two men led last year's armed take-over of Wounded Knee, a sacred Indian village

Piecing together his campaign team, Governor Wilson has hired two more political professionalsHarold Harris, a public-relations specialist familiar with both city Democrats and past Rockefeller campaigns, and James R. Carberry, who was a speechwriter for Mayor John V. Lindsay.

Hearst, the newspaper executive, for more than $230-million worth of free food for the poor as evidence of good faith in negotiating the release of his kidnapped daughter, Patricia. At the same time, the radical group provided Mr. Hearst with a tape recording of his daughter saying,

The Penn Central Transportation Company has asked for $11.1-million from the Federal Government. The company says it needs the money to keep its railroad running. Trustees of the company, which operates the Penn Central Railroad, sent a letter requesting the funds today to the Transportation Secretary, Claude Brinegar.

The 13-nation energy conference failed to reach agreement today because of a sharp dispute between France and her eight Common Market allies on how to respond to the American call for joint efforts by oil consuming and oil-producing countries to deal with the energy crisis. After a day of intensive wrangling, the delegates worked into the night to seek a compromise on a communique acceptable to all.

The caretaker Cabinet of Thailand has given initial approval to a new constitution and sent it to the National Assembly, where extensive debate is expected. The constitution, approved by the Cabinet yesterday, was drafted after the overthrow of former Premier Thanom Kittikachorn, the military strong man who ruled Thailand for nearly a decade.

For the third and new program of its run through Sunday at the Lyceum Theater, the Alwin Nickolais Dance Theater lat night presented "Somniloquy," "Foreplay" and "Scenarioquy." All three works were created, in the fullest sense, by Mr. Nikolais, and this particular bill may be the best of the season.

One of the most flamboyant plays in hockey occurs when the goalie leaves his net to race an opposing forward for the puck. If the goalie loses the race, it's almost a sure goal, so it takes experience and good judgment to venture away from the crease.

LOS ANGELES- is a slender woman of 35 with soft brown hair and hazel eyes. These days the eyes are more likely to be thoughtful than to sparkle the way they did the day five years ago, when she and her husband stood on the balcony of a magnificent beach house in Malibu, guests of honor at a farewell party.

Maurice Parker, lawyer and real estate developer, died late yesterday at the Shadyside Hospital here. He was 57 years old and a resident of Pittsburgh. Mr. Parker was chairman of the Parker-Levitt Corporation, a developer of resort properties in Vermont and Florida, and of the Air Pollution Control Corporation.

Rafael Kubelik, the first music director in the Metropolitan Opera's history, resigned that post yesterday, effective immediately. However, the company, in making the announcement, said the Czech-born musician would fulfill his conducting assignments for the remainder of the season,

While most New Jersey motorists struggle with the rules of the state's new mandatory gasoline sales restriction program, a few are carrying printed state cards that exempt them from any restrictions. The existence of the unpublicized "emergency" cards bearing Governor Byrne's signature was confirmed today by a state spokesman after one of the cards was shown at an Ocean County service station and caught the dealer,

A former co-worker of Mayor Beame's son Bernard, who was his father's campaign manager, was appointed yesterday as head of the Municipal Broadcasting System. Arnold Labaton, 40 years old, now director of operations for the Public Broadcasting Service in Washington, was named to head the municipal agency, which operates WNYC,

Buffalo's fourth-quarter lightning didn't strike the Knicks a second time in two games. The Knicks lost command of tonight's National Basketball Association game against the Braves momentarily in the fourth quarter, but rallied in the last 3 1/2 minutes for a 100-93 victory over the Braves.
The Air Force announced today that it would force 425 officers, mostly reserve Captains, out of the service to meet a Congressionally imposed ceiling on its officer strength.

A subpoena ordering President Nixon's appearance in a Los Angeles court finally got to the right place today--the clerk of the District of Columbia Superior Court. It took eight days to get there. , Swedishborn film actress, died yesterday in Hemet Convalescent Hospital, where she had been living for about a year. The hospital gave her age as 85 and said there were believed to be surviving relatives in Sweden.

Twenty-two cars of a 67-car freight train derailed today in the Detroit-Windsor railroad tunnel under the Detroit River, but no one was injured. A tank car loaded with chlorine gas was of major concern for a time, but it did not leave the tracks and officials of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway said that it had not ruptured.

Howard J. Samuels, who has been unofficially running for Governor since the last gubernatorial election, formally announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Gover nor Wilson tonight signed into law the bill moving the state primary election to September end setting state political con ventions forward to June. Senior Justice Department officials said, however, that the measure would be subject to Federal review before imple mentation under the Voting Rights Act.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said here tonight that his Senate Watergate committee had received information about spying activities allegedly conducted by the office of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, but had acceded to a White House request to refrain from investigating them.

The short release issued yesterday by. the Metropoli.. tan Opera, announcing the resignation of Rafael Kubelik as music director, left several major questions unan. swered: Will the position of music director be kept in the Metropolitan Opera's table of organization?

It will take months and probably years for scientists to puzzle out all the implications of the flood of data about Venus that Mariner 10 has radioed back to earth. It is already evident that information of importance has been received. Mariner 10 photographs have shown that the planet's dense atmosphere has bands and streaks that give clues to wind and weather patterns on Venus.

The Argentine police announced tonight that they had foiled a terrorist attempt to assassinate President Juan D. Peron, his wife, and the visiting President of Uruguay, Juan M. Bordaherry. Another intended victim, the police said, was Mr. Peron's personal secretary, Jose Lopez Vega.

Five derailed freight cars carrying liquid propane gas blew apart here today in a series of thunderous explosions that sent parts of the cars hundreds of feet through the air and left 54 persons, most of them firemen, injured from burns and fractures. Flames consumed seven of the 122 cars of the northbound Delaware Hudson Railroad train that derailed on an embarkment six miles west of here at about 4 P.M. Firemen,

The knocking at the door, so long expected, has finally come. The misnamed "security agents," whose mission is to spread fear and insecurity throughout the populace, have knocked on the door of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's apartment in Moscow. They have dragged him away as his wife and her mother cried out in protest, desperately, hopelessly. The knocking and the cries can be heard around the world.

If consumers were certain that substantial inflation, of say 6 per cent annually, were here to stay, they would go out and spend money faster than the experts are predicting for this year. But so far, consumers lack a consensus. Some expect inflation to disappear entirely this year;...

New York City's motorists were out in force again yesterday in their quest for gasoline, and neither the drivers nor the station operators appeared to see great indications that the new sales-limit system was doing much to ease the problem of long lines at stations. "It's been two days of nothing," asserted Joseph Brownstein, an owner of the Kenmore Getty service center at Ocean Avenue and Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

Goodman's and Mrs. Adele F. Goodman's skye terrier, Ch. Glamoor Gang Buster; 4, Leslie and Jerry Rosenstock's airedale terrier, Ch. Jerilee's Jumping Jericho.

Premier Carlos Arias Navarro today promised Spaniards wider and freer participation in government and union affairs than they have known in the 35 years since the Civil War. In one of the most longawaited announcements in years, Mr. Arias announced that mayors and heads of provincial assemblies, formerly appointed, would now be elected.

Tomorrow is Valentine's Day. Last December, Federal and New York State banking officials made it clear that they would t tolerate discrimination by banking institutions against women in making loans. Put them both together and what have you got? What you've got Is a print advertisement from the National Bank of North America designed to show its good intentions in granting loans to women.

The police yesterday arrested a man who was reported to have confessed to having participated in a shootout a week ago in which four persons were killed at the Ya Sin Mosque in Brooklyn. The suspect, identified as Herbert Leon Pryor, 28 years old, of Richmond,

, who was a guest of Premier Fidel Castro last week, said Yesterday that he believed relations be. tween Cuba and the United States could be resumed cruickly if Secretarv of State Kissinger were to take up the matter with the Cuban leader. "It would be a fine and swift deal," the wealthy 90-year-old industrialist said in a telephone interview from his offices in Cleveland.

John Russell, art critic of The Sunday Times in London since 1950, has been appointed to the staff of The New York Times as an art critic, it was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor. Mr. Russell will take up his duties in New York on April 1, joining Hilton Kramer, who was recently appointed chief art critic.

Israeli forces on the Egyptian front today completed the third stage of their withdrawal from the bridgehead they seized last October on the west bank of the Suez Canal. The area, a strip about 10 miles deep on the southwestern shore of the Great Bitter Lake, was tuned over to Finnish soldiers of the United Nations Emergency Force at 4 P.M.

President Nixon placed a wreath at the Lincoln Memorial today and, in a speech that seemed to draw a comparison to himself, said that the Civil War President, despite vilification, had the character to "stand tall and strong and firm no matter how harsh or unfair the criticism might be."

The American Can Company announced yesterday that it was raising prices on all meatpackaging films and laminations by 12 to 20 per cent, effective with new orders placed after March I and on shipments of April 1. The company said this was the first price increase on the product in 10 years and was due to higher costs of petrochemical-based materials.

Shortly after he was elected chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus recently, Representatlve Charles B. Rangel said he received a visit from a black representative of the Gulf Oil Corporation. "He wanted me to call a dinner meeting of the caucus for the members to listen to Gulf officials explain the industry side of the oil crisis,"

Senator George McGovern said today that an Agriculture Department plan for phasing out direct food assistance could work hardships on undernourished Americans. But an Agriculture Department official says the intent is just the opposite: to better serve the poor and undernourished.

A three-judge Federal court upheld today the constitutionality of Pennsylvania state aid to nonpublic schools in the form of auxiliary services and loans of instructional material. The panel rejected a petition seeking to block expenditures of state funds on grounds that they supported religious schools in violation of the First Amendment.

President Nixon will nominate Carla Anderson Hills, a Los Angeles lawyer, to be assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's civil division, White House press secretary Gerald L, Warren said yesterday. Mr. Warren said that Mrs. Hills will be the first woman to hold the rank of an assistant attorney general since Woodrow Wilson appointed Annette Abbot

The safety of an $8,000 bronze bust of San Clemente's leading citizen, Richard M. Nixon, has become a matter of growing concern, and considerable bickering, among some of the President's West Coast neighbors and fellow townsmen. City officials and civic leaders are divided over what, if anything,

The Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday announced operating results for 1973. The report indicated a 153 per cent gain in fourth-quarter earnings. Net income for the full year climbed to $800-million, ending a fouryear slide in profitability. Gulf, the nation's fourth largest oil company, did not announce earnings for the last three months.

The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that its average residential cus. tomer would pay $2.23 more this month, or 12.7 per cent, more than in January, for the same amount of electricity because of sharply increased costs of the oil the utility burned. The fuel increase this month is the largest since fuel prices began rising last year, and the utility held out no hope for any declines in the future.

Following is a transcript of a tape recording of Patricia Hearst's voice as broadcast today by Berkeley radio station KPFA. The recording was sent to her father Randolph A. Hearst, the publisher, by the Symbionese Liberation Army.

South Vietnam and the Vietcong continued prisoner exchanges today. midafternoon, the Saigon command reported that it had released 136 pro-Communist civilians of the 256 it had promised to turn over to the Vietcong and that the Vietcong had returned 80 of 100 prisoners they were to free.

West German public service employes announced today that they would continue their two-day strike beyond its original deadline of midnight, but negotiations in Stuttgart for higher wages for two million postmen, bus drivers, trash collectors and minor functionaries continued into the evening.

Japan's top newspaper executives today bluntly accused Premier Kakuel Tanaka and his cabinet of failing to stop the nation's spiraling inflation. In an unusual two-hour meeting at the Premier's official residence, 26 executives from Japan's largest papers charged that "the lack of clearcut measures by the Government was responsible for high prices,

In a leveled place where several hundred wooden nouses on stilts once stood, dazed people wandered through the drifting ashes today, searching for missing relatives who are probably dead. When they found bodies they moaned as they burned them on little pyres on the spot because they own so little that they cannot afford to take their dead to pagodas for proper Buddhist cremation.

The Legislature approved extended unemployment benefits for 30,000 New Jersey residents whose regular checks stopped after Jan. 1. The legislation was rushed through both houses and immediately signed into law by Governor Byrne to enable the state to take advantage of the federally financed unemployment program. The Federal Government will contribute $7-million toward the expected $14-million cost of the additional benefits.

The Internal Revenue Service agreed today to surrender records of 2,500 toll calls from the Washington bureau of The New York Times that the agency had subpoenaed on the ground that it was investigating an information leak. To exercise or not to exercise to prevent another heart attack? Two physicians who debated this question at a meeting here yesterday of the American College of Cardiology agreed that no scientific evidence existed to prove conclusively that exercise conditioning delayed the progress of arteriosclerosis and prevented recurrence of heart attacks for patients who had already had one.

For Prime Minister Heath it was a day of speeches, handshakes, smiles, much praise from his admirers, a few jeers from his critics and a complaint from an old woman who said she was hungry. He was on the road this afternoon in the counties of Hertford, Bedford and Bluckingham, northwest of London,

Christopher Temple Emmet, a political writer who was active in the opposition to both Nazi and Communist totalitarianism, died Monday at Doctors Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 901 Lexington Avenue. A descendant of Irish patriots, including Robert Emmet who was executed in 1803, Mr. Emmet was born in Port Chester, N. Y., and attended Harvard University and several universities in Germany.

" The Morning After," tonight's 8:30 movie on the American Broadcasting Company network, is about an alcoholic and, true to the life-style of any alcoholic, it is drenched in cliches. The problem of alcoholism is devastatingly real, but the subject of alcoholism in fiction rarely gets beyond domestic melodrama.

John Chisholm Fraser, a vice president and actuary of the New York Life Insurance Company, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. He was 46 years old and lived at 145 East 27th Street. Mr. Fraser, a graduate of Harvard College, joined the company's actuarial department in 1950, and helped develop a new concept of variable benefit life insurance that was presented to the Society of Actuaries in 1969.

Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, working group on remote sensing of the earth and task force of the working group-10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Human Rights-10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

The Ford Motor Company said today its earnings declined 76 per cent to $57-million in the last three months of 1973 from $240-million a year earlier. The company said the quarter's earnings were down because of reduced big-car sales resulting from the energy-crisis, a strike at a Canadian subsidiary and expenditures to convert plants to small car production.

Stockbrokers should not fear price competition in the commission rates they charge customers, Ray Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said here today. Noting that many in the industry, including himself, grew up "under the shelter of fixed commission rates as one of the immutable propositions in the financial universe,"

Keeping one's head In the face of a bad trump break is vitally necessary in tournament play. Marietta Passell of Yonkers, who will be one of the United States representatives in the world women's pair championship in Las Palmas, the Canary Islands, in May, was in full control on the diagramed deal.

An ice cube with its top surface as large as a football field has been fabricated in Antarctica and, after a succession of mishaps and crises, has proved a successful ship dock. About 5 million pounds of cargo have been unloaded onto it and trucked to the American base on McMurdo Sound.

At the turn of 1974, with formal political election activity at a standstill, more than $24million was piled up and waiting in party and candidate treasuries, a bipartisan research and lobbying group reported today. Fifty year ago yesteday Olin Downes, then music critic of The New York Times, went t Aeolian Hall here to listen to a new work by a young American composer. In his review he wrote: "This composition shows extraordinary talent, just as it also shows a young composer with aims that go far beyond those of his ilk, struggling with a form of which he is far from being master.

Fred Mathews and his dancers are an accomplished group with more physical skills than rewarding choreography. Their program Monday evening at the Cubiculo was marked by a plie and sway calmness that was enjoyable but left little trace in the mind afterward. Mr. Mathews designed four of the six pieces on the program and Jose Coronado the remaining two, "Three Women" and "Fugitive Vision."

National Basketball Association players are hurting. Through yesterday, 43 players, 22 per cent of those in the league had missed a total of 550 games. The toll will grow higher, because some of the injured are sidelined for the season. Some of the biggest name players in the league have been struck down by injuries to knees, shoulders, elbows, ankles and hands.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident novelist, who once declared he was "prepared to face even death" to promote the cause of truth, was forcibly arrested yesterday by a team of Soviet police agents. Seven men, some in uniform and some in civilian clothes, forced their way into the apartment of his family in downtown Moscow in late afternoon and took him away for interrogation, holding him through the night.

Secretary of State Kissinger, whose critics accuse him of not knowing much economics, had a solid and sophisticated economic brief for this week's energy conference in Washington. Mr.Kissinger is generally hailed Economic as a disciple of Analysis such masters of political expedi ency as Machiavelli, Metternich and Bismarck.

America's energy crisis is manageable, it's one time and it's short term," Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, asserted today. THE HAGUE-There are two theories about the effect of detente on dissident opinion in Communist East Europe. One estimates that as tensions slowly ease and there is a relative increase in contacts between that area and the West, the amount and degree of dissent against prevailing authoritarian rule will lessen because the political system itself will become relatively softer.

Feminists to film distributor: "Do you have any children's films about heroines?" Film distributor: "No, we don't do drug abuse films any more." Although they knew it was probably easier to find heroin than heroines in New York City, Janet Sternburg and Karen Sacks, the feminists, refused to call it quits. Like Diogenes, they just kept searching.

The 13-nation energy conference in Washing failed to reach agreement because of a sharp dispute between France and her Common Market allies on how to respond to the American call for joint efforts by oil consuming and producing countries to deal with the energy crisis. The delegates decided to extend the conference for a day in an effort to resolve the dispute. [1:8.]

The old, old sea, as one in tears, Comes murmuring with its foamy lips, And knocking at the vacant piers, Calls for its long-lost multitude of ships. Toray Industries, one of Ja pan's largest producers of plas tics and fibers, has begun a wide diversification to offset the effect of the shortages in petrochemicals and energy, Kizo Yasui, chairman, said hereyesterday.

A wave of bitter and emotional allegations involving corrup tion, "rot" and disillusion with democracy has struck the Indian Government. Two critics have voiced unusually powerful attacks on Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government, and said that the nation was in a deepeningeconomic and moral crisis.

George Foreman, the world heavyweight boxing cham pion, testified in court today that his appearance here for a divorce action might force him to call off his scheduled title fight with Ken Norton March 26 in Caracas, Venezuela.

The gasoline shortage is be ginning to affect shopping in suburban stores sharply in the metropolitan area. Business at the big stores in Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester County has slipped in the last month while sales in stores within New York have held to a steady pacesince November.

The Internal Revenue Service has charged that the United States Gypsum Com pany, a key defendant in a price-fixing suit, owes the Fed eral Government more than $20-milion in back taxes, ac cording to United States Tax Court records. In addition to the tax deficiency, the I.R.S. has as sessed the Chicago-based company $1-million in penalties for "neglegence or intentional disregard" of Federal taxlaw.
Mrs. Frankie James Spitz, who broke into show business in George M. Cohan's "45 Min utes from Broadway" at the age of 14, died today at her home here. She was 72 yearsold.

The new medical facility in Miami that President Nixon will dedicate tomorrow has been the subject of public debate there for years. The President, according to his aides, chose to dedicate the new multimillion-collar addition to the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital because it exemplified the type of approach to health care he advocates: It provides outstanding medical services with private financing insteadof Federal funds.

Officials said today that the, police had arrested 12 men, including two, members of Rabbi Meir Kahane's militant Jewish Defense League, in con nection with the fire-bombing, this week of three Christian,institutions.

An Indian land officer testified under cross-examination in the Wounded Knee trial today that Sioux Indians no longer owned all the land ceded to them by the Federal Government in theIndian Treaty of 1868.
The B. F. Goodrich Company and Uniroyal, Inc., two major rubber producers, reported yesterday increased sales and earnings for the fourth quarter andall of last year.
A 12-year-old boy ventured up to the counter and asked, "Do you have any more Mickey "None, the cheapest Mantle I have left is a dollar," was the reply from Bud Kurzweil.
One of eight defendants was dropped today from a $51.2-million damage suit filed Jan. 29 in the name of Senator George McGovern, Democrat ofSouth Dakota.

Federal health officials, who are now writing the regulations to implement the new Health Maintenance Organization Assistance Act, have run into a conflict with the administrators of many of the programs thatserved as models for the law.

A 2-year-old Brooklyn girl found lying unconscious and face down in her bathwater last night was revived by a passer-by identified by the police as Carmine Tincrono, 50, of 285 Cozine Avenue, in the East New York section ofBrooklyn.

Increased tobacco profits were primarily responsible for the record results reported yesterday by R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., for the final quarter and all of last year. The company derives about'a third of its sales from non-tobacco operations, such as containerized shipping, convenience foods and oil production.

An arm of the American As sociation of University Profes sors assailed yesterday attempts by college students and teach ers to suppress research and debate on the question whether heredity is a major factor inintelligence.

A bill that would allow aggrieved consumers to join together to bring lawsuits was supported today by consumer groups as long overdue and attacked by business and banking spokesmen as leading to the potential "blackmail" of large corporations.

For several weeks last fall, "The Paper Chase," a comedy about a naive Midwesterner grinding his way through his first year at Harvard Law School, was-among the 10 most popular films in thecountry. Seals of local colleges seeking formal approval from Board of Regents toestablish legal programs.

The Soviet Union deported Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn to West Germany today and issued a decree stripping him of his citizenship for "performing systematically actions that are incompatible with being a citizen."

The United States and 11 other major oil-consuming nations overrode strong French objections today and agreed on the need for "a comprehensive action program" to deal with theenergy crisis. Secretary of State Kissinger talking to reporters after agreement with oil-consuming nations was reached. Foreign Minister Michel Jobert of France told of his country's objections to key provisions of communique.

Leftwing Peronist leaders to day vigorously denied any involvement in what was described as a plot to assassinate President Juan D. Peron, his wife, Isabel, and Juan M. Bordaberry, President of Uruguay, who paid a state visit to argentina yesterday.
Foreign oil company holdings in Venezuela will revert to the state within two years after the new government is installed next month, President, elect Carlos Andres Perez said today.

To his supporters, President Park Chung Hee of South Korea is a strong, determined leader. They say, as Premier Kim Jong Pil put it, that he is "the only one who can promise us --the people and the nation a bright future."

Governor Byrne announced to day that legislation would be introduced Friday to provide all members of his cabinet withraises.

A New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered a temporary embargo on the unsold remainder of one million barrels of home-heating oil that the state charges was diverted and "hidden" by four oil companies as part of a scheme to "gouge" residential consumers.

Worried over possible reprisals by Israeli, Lebanese officials are raising anxious demands that an end be put, "once and for all," to Palestinian commando shooting and raiding across the southern border intoIsrael. Commandos have had base area on Mt. Hermon.

Notre Dame's coach, Dick (Digger) Phelps, one of the few men in the last 10 years who can boast of coaching a team to victory over the Uni versity of California, Los Angeles, will try tonight to pick up his first triumph in three attempts over a so-so Fordham team in MadisonSquare Garden.

Richard H. Kuh, Manhattan's new District Attorney, said yes terday that he would establish, "as soon as is feasible," region al offices around the borough so residents could more easilycomplain about crime. Richard H. Kuh speaking after he was sworn in as District Attorney of Manhattan yesterday. Mrs. Kuh is seated in center and in right foreground is Alfred J. Scotti, who had been Acting District Attorney.
Inmates caused about $3,000 damage at the medium security Nevada State Prison yesterday after making demands "relative to the store and trans fer of inmate property."

Alexander's, Inc., one of New York's largest retailers, plans to open its five stores in the city Sunday in what it hopes will be a test case of the state's blue laws, accord ing to authoritative trade reports yesterday.
Connecticut joined New York and New Jersey yesterday in attempting to wrestle with the gasoline crisis on a statewide basis, but stopped short of setting up a mandatory rationing plan.
Prices of all silver bullion futures, except the current de livery, were bid up the daily limit of 15 cents an ounceonce again here yesterday.

Harry Hanbury came upon a sad truth the other day. "It isn't fun anymore," the 48-year-old salesman for a floor tile manufacturer announced. "You have to think about every move you make." Mr. Hanbury's idea of fun is cooking weekend breakfasts for his wife, Leola, 47, and their children, Andrew 12, and Nancy, 10. "Harry makes beautiful breakfasts," Mrs. Hanbry Boasted.
India's steel industry, vital to the country's economic development, has been crippled by a fuel shortage and trans port bottlenecks aggravatedby labor strikes.

John T. Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, said today he didn't think any West ern government, including the United States, knew how to control inflation. "I don't think we know how to restrain inflation," he saidat a news briefing.

DANCE New Yorkers will get their first look this week at "Stimmung," the work that opened in Brussels in late 1972 and that is a col laboration of Maurice Bejart, the choreographer, and Karl heinz Stockhausen, the con temporary composer. "Stim mung" will be done today and tomorrow at 8 in Car negie Hall, 57th Street andSeventh Avenue (CI 7-7459).
Commuters in the New York metropolitan area who travel to work by buses that cross state lines will have to pay higher fares as a result of recent rises in the cost of the diesel fuelthe buses use.

The Teleprompter Corpora tion said yesterday that it had canceled plans to build a cable television system in Newark. The company said it would write off its Newark invest ment of some $2.15 million inits 1973 results.

Charles F. Beck, an art teacher, who had been in charge of the school-museum program of the Board of Educa tion, died Tuesday at the Mem orial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 68 years oldand lived in Cooks Falls, N.Y.

The National Gallery of Art accepted today a large collec tion of prints by the late Dutch printmaker M.C. Escher from Cornelius van Schaak Roosevelt, a local collector and friend of Escher for almost 20 years.

Following is the text of the communique issued today at the conclusion of the 13-nation energy conference here. Italics, supplied by The New York Times, identify the paragraphs that are rejected by France.

Hayley Mills, whose earn ings were handsome in the years she was a child actress in such Walt Disney films as "Pollyanna," has been ord ered by the House of Lords to part with part of themoney. Hayley Mills

Elmer W. Silver, who at this retirement in 1957 was a direc tor, vice president and treasur er of Whitehead Metals, a former subsidiary of the Inter national Nickel Company, Inc., died today. He was 81 years oldand lived here.

The 'West German Cabinet agreed today to an 11 percent wage increase for public service employes, ending an impasse in the strike that has crippled the country's transportation and mail system for three days, aspokesman said.

In the absence of any adequate governmental program for a fair sharing of the sacrifices made necessary by the energy shortage, many groups are immunizing themselves against the pinch of higher fuel costs by sim ply passing along the extra charges to their customers. The automatic pass-through principle received official White House endorsement in the settlement negotiatedlast week with striking truckers.

An across-the-board salary in. crease of 6 per cent, plus bene fits considered crucial by the faculty members' bargaining unit, has been negotiated in a contract between the state and the union for the faculty and academic staff of the eightstate colleges.

Bob McAdoo paced a balanced attack with 30 points tonight as the Buffalo Braves pulled away in the second half for a 129.106 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in the National Basketball Association.

Gov ernor Byrne announced today he would ask the Legislature on Friday to repeal a 1962 covenant. on bonds issued by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, that precludes the bistate agency's involve ment in mass-transit projectsthat could lose money.

Consolidated Edison's increased fuel costs will mean more than twice as much of an increase in electric rates this month for the average residential customer in Westchester County and Staten Island as for the one in the Bronx becausethey use more electricity.
The Arab oil-producing countries today abruptly called off a meeting that was to have considered the lifting of the oil embargo imposed against the United States and the Netherlands.
The dismal showing by the United States team in the re cent world skiing champion ships at St. Moritz, Switzer land, came as a surprise tomany persons.
Confront ing the demon of economic downturn, President Nixon extended his arms, flashed the ancient thumbs-up sign, and pronounced the mystic incantation: "There will be no recession."

It is a cliche that some musicians would have been outstanding no matter on what instrument they chose to perform. It is a cliche that must be applied to Grace Sung-En Wong, a 24-year-old American who lives in New York. She is a harpist, and in her local debut recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, as part of the Carnegie Hall-Jeun esses Musicales series, she established herself as aboveall an exciting musician.

Mrs. Fannie Fisen Seifert. an interior designer who carried on her own business in Forest Hills, Queens, for many years, died of cancer yesterday in Parkway Hospital. She was 75 years old, the widow of Nathan Seifert, a salesman, and she lived at 68-64 YellowstoneBoulevard in Forest Hills.

There was nothing unusu al about homosexuals figur ing prominently in the plot of Tuesday evening's "Police Story." Homosexuals are no longer rare oddities on tele vision series. In this case, the unusual took place off camera.

The United States and 11 other major oil-consuming nations overrode strong French objec tions today and agreed on the need for "a comprehensive ac tion program" to deal with theenergy crisis. Secretary of State Kissinger talking to reporters after agreement with oil-con suming nations was reached. Foreign Minister Michel Jobert of France told of his country's objections to key provisions of communique.

President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, left, and President Houari Boumediene of Algeria sharing a laugh at Algiers airport after Mr. Sadat arrived yesterday to attend a four-nation meeting of Arab leaders.

William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office, took a verbal swing today at Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and in so doing exposed to the nation a personality clash that has had Washington tongues waggingfor weeks.

" Ma-a," Elisha called, But her mother was slow coming to the fourth-story window, leaving Elisha, a dirtsmudged, shabbily - dressed 15-year-old, to stand in the cold wind that brutalized her Bedford-Stuyvesant street.

The Office of Education today extended to April 1 the deadline for needy college students to submit applications for basic educational opportunity grants. Based on the financial need of the student and his family the grants havebeen averaging $260.

A group of women who will run this fall for public offices ranging from Governor of Texas to member of Congress from Brooklyn all pledged today to make public their income tax returns and all details concerning the financing of their campaigns.
Striking coal miners announced a complete ban on replenishing dwindling coal stocks at Britain's power stations today and other unions said they would go along by refusing to transport coal.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J.- The world must await with exceeding ap prehension the first test case of what happens when the resources and econ omy of a vast segment of the world stop supporting a growing populationeven at subsistence level.

City Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta has turned over evidence to District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx of possible forgeries in the handling of campaign contributions to State Senate Joseph L. Galiber, according to sources close to the investigation. Joseph L Galiber

Governor Byrne announced today the would ask the Legislature on Friday to repeal a 1962 covenant on bonds issued by the Port Authority of New York land New Jersey that precludes the bistate agency's involve ment in mass-transit projectsthat could lose money.

The average supermarket, with perhaps 8,000 or 10,000 items on the shelves, can be a confusing place, even for the experienced shopper. Some companies compete not only against one another, but also against themselves.

Lawyers for The New York Times asked the State Court of Appeals to day to reverse an Appellate Division ruling and reinstitute a permanent no-strike injunc tion against New York Typographical Union No. 6.

The Arabian American Oil Company said yesterday that "various statements had been made by Saudi Arabian officials to the effect that the existing plan for the Saudis to take over 51 percent of Aramco no longer represented "a viable objective." But the company said that news reports saying that the Government would shortly demand 100 per cent ownership were "based on speculation."

Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew is in California, reportedly to attend the 80th birthday celebration of Jack Beeny, the comedian, this weekend and to spend some time with Frank Sinatra, the singer, in Palm Springs.

The Cooper Union chose an unusual program for cele brating Abraham Lincoln's birthday Tuesday night at Town Hall. Unusual? Well, let's say bizarre: "Litany," a fragmentary work by Szyma nowski; "Chichester Psalms" by Bernstein and "PsalmusHungaricus" by Kodaly.

Two masked gunmen raided the Brooklyn home of an art dealer last night, stole over $50,000 worth of cash, jewelry and paintings, and then fled leaving the dealer, his wife and 3-year-old. son and a business associate tied hand and foot with adhesive tape across theirmouths. the police reported.

The Internal Revenue Service surrendered today telephone records of the Washington bu reau of The New York Times that were secretly subpoenaed last month, but not those of the home telephone of a Timesreporter, David E. Rosenbaum.

Senator Jacob K. Javits testified at a Federal hearing here yesterday that the city's subway system "was not safe enough" because of inadequate emergency evacuation procedure, crippling noise levels and crime "on the up surge." He told a Federal Railroad Administration hearing officer that riders therefore "are not getting their 35cents worth."

More than four months after Spiro Agnew left the nation's second highest office in disgrace, the former Vice President is still chauffeured and chaperoned by Secret Service agents. Even though the General Account ing Office has told Congress that this costly and pre tentious entourage has no authorization under existing law, Mr. Agnew this week embarked on a vacation trip to California accompanied by a detail of agents and byothers assigned from West Coast headquarters.
The National Religious party, traditional partner of the Labor party in government coalitions, tonight broke off negotiations on entering Premier GoldaMeir's next cabinet.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday on increasing hopes for an early relaxation of the Arab oil embargo but with many of these balanced by renewed fears of further cuts in Arab oil output. In the over-the-counter market, prices dropped in stepped-uptrading.

The latest Soviet campaign to explore the planet Mars with four unmanned spacecraft suffered a setback this week when the first of two craft apparently designed for an orbital mission failed to go into orbit. Thesecond succeeded.

After Muhammad Ali re portedly changed his mind three or four times in the same day, the on-again, off again fight between Ali and Jerry Quarry was called off again. At least, there'll be no Madison Square Garden news conference today to announce the bout that was penciled in for May 13, erased and then reported set as late as yesterday. Muhammad Ali

The Justice Department an nounced today that it was set ting up two new units to deal with increasing mortgage frauds and other frauds includ ing "sophisticated" schemes that reach into foreign countries.

Dan Golenpaul, the creator of "Information Please," the famous radio quiz show that had many imitators over the years, died last evening at his home, 30 East 65th Street. He was 73 years old and had beenill for some time.

Representative Ogden R.Reid during interview.

Billy Paultz, left, and Larry Kenon, right, of the Nets, George Carter of the Squires-and others-going after an elusive basketball at the Coliseum last night.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here has ruled that all mat ters pertaining to the suit of the MCI Communications Cor poration against the American Telephone Telegraph Com pany must be consolidated and heard by the Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, it was learnedyesterday.

Gasoline shortages are biting so deeply into travel on the metropolitan area's major turn pikes that Wall Street analysts for the first time are beginning to worry about the long-term stability of the toll roads.

You tell the banker you need $3,000 for some worth while purpose. He says O.K. and reminds you that he charges 5 per cent, discount ed. When the loan papers ar rive, you discover that in order to get the $3,000 you need, you have to borrow considerably more-and pay all of the interest in advance.

Price control may not stop the rise of food prices, shoppers in supermarket aisles say. Grocery store prices are surging, and it is expected that the weeks ahead will bring the sharpest increase in market-basket costs since last spring.
