Fairleigh Dickinson University's board of trustees approved to day a payment plan under which brothers, sisters, hus bands or wives of full-time students in the school will be charged only half tuition.

Henry Chanin, former national tournament bridge player, died here yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital. His age was 76, and he lived here. Mr. Chanin was a founder and president of the Henry Chanin Corporation, a cottonwaste business in Atlanta.
Den nis DuVal, Syracuse's all America guard from West bury, L.I., scored 30 points to night and helped the Orange to a 76-70 basketball victory over Manhattan at Manlyfieldhouse.

Ten years ago today, on Valentine's Day of 1964, an unknown new record company named Nonesuch announced its first releases. Since then, None such has issued some 400 high quality, budget-priced recordsand has established itself as, Teresa (Tracy) Sterne, who runs Nonesuch, in her office with some of the concern's records.

A suspect linked by ballistics tests to the shooting death of a Fifth Avenue gun merchant on Monday and to the wounding of a policeman the day before was shot and killed yesterday when he returned to a hotel room that had been staked nutby the police.

Gould, Inc., has received a contract from the United States Navy valued at $83.8-million for Mark 48 torpedoes. A $9.1 million contract was awarded to Cham berlin Manufacturing Corporation by the UnitedStates Army for 105-millimeter artillery projectiles.
Howard E. Sternau, a partner in the public-accounting firm here of Sternau Shulman, died yesterday at his home, 15 Midchester Place. He was 68years old.

State Senator Frank Padavan charged today that the State Depart ment of Mental Hygiene had failed to carry out specific se curity measures recommended by the state police for the Wil lowbrook State School of Stat en Island and that serious crimes at the institution hadincreased.

Despite the gasoline shortage and the inconvenience of long lines at filling stations, American commuters have yet to show much movement toward using alternative means of transportation to work, theGallup Poll reported yesterday.

To the Editor: What has happened to the Republi can party? If a Democratic President had betrayed the trust of the party regulars and the mass of voters to the extent that Nixon has, surely the party organization would set off a revolt that would blow that President out of office or at least take its lead from those who would cleanse the politicalscene.

Mark Donohue sat down wearily, a bad cold and self-doubt having eaten away his energy over the last few days. Mark Donohue, right, pushing the Roger Penske Matador driven by Gary Bettenhausen after a practice run at Daytona Beach, Fla., yesterday. The Daytona 500 will run Sunday.
Harry Lebau, executive direc tor of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Asso ciation here from 1926 to his retirement in 1963. died yes terday in the Elizabeth General Hospital.

Mayor Beame announced yesterday that he had ordered a "full review" of Tax Commission procedures in an attempt to eliminate abuses in the assessment of the city's $40-bil lion in taxable real estate un covered last year by the StateCommission of Investigation.

The Getty Oil Company an nounced yesterday price de creases in its Eastern region of 1.3 cents a gallon on fuel oil and diesel fuel. The price of gasoline was unchanged; it had been raised by 4 cents a gallonearlier in the month.
For reasons ranging from the calendar to red tape to Water gate, 1974 is shaping up as a turning point for the Federal role in education.

The Symbionese Liberation Army's multimillion-dollar ran som demand was rejected by Patricia Hearst's. father today as impossible to meet. He promised to present a counteroffer in 24 to 48 hours. Randolph A. Hearst speak ing on TV yesterday.

More than two years after it was initiated, the Mark Rothko case, possibly ...the most discussed art lawsuit since the painter James Mc Neil Whistler sued the critic John Ruskin for libel in 1878, goes on trial here today in Surrogate's Court.

The Symbionese Liberation Army may have borrowed its name from a 1959 novel about an uprising in Chicago's black ghetto. The novel, "The Spook Who Sat by the Door" by Sam Greenlee, concerns a small armed commando unit called the Cobras. The symbol of the Symbionese groupis a seven-headed Cobra..

Two major announcements dealing with advertising and health were made yesterday. The first concerns a new pub lic-service campaign by the Advertising Council, while the second involves a new syndicated television seriescalled Today's Health.
The Federal judge overseeing the affairs of the crippled West gate-California Corporation has approved the sale of its stock in the Golconda Corporation,Chicago.

The Administration proposed today legislation for a $1-billion contingency program that would extend unemployment insurance benefits to workers who lose their jobs in areas of high and persistent unemploynment.

Three teen-agers were arrested yesterday in the slaying of a 57-year-old cab driver Monday in the Bronx during an attempted robbery. The police reported that the youths, two brothers and a friend, were seized in the afternoon and were charged with homicide in the death of Clifton Lynch, of 1713 Topham Avenue, the Bronx. The hold-up took place at East 135th Street and Brook Avenue in the Bronx.

Mrs. Kathleen Montgomery Au burn, the wife of Dr. Norman P. Auburn, former acting presi dent of Polytechnic Institute of New York in Brooklyn and president emeritus of the Uni versity of Akron, died today.She was 65 years old.
A three-judge Federal court ruled here yesterday that the armed services must give notice to next of kin and an opportunity for a hearing before persons missing in action arereclassified as dead.

Stock prices showed no real direction yesterday as volume held to the extremely slow pace of 10.99'million shares. This turnover-the lowest in more than five months-under scored the current degree of apathy that has gripped both small investors and large institutions.

United States supplies of gasoline as of Feb. 8 were up from the preceding week and down from a year ago, the American Petroleum Institutesaid today.

The widows of many veterans received smaller pension checks from the Veterans Administration Feb. 1 because of a provision in the Social Security law that took effect a year ago. Other widows lost their pensions entirely.

A safe purchased for $20 six months ago turned out to hold $2,000 in cash and $213,315.60 in negotiable bonds yesterday after the buyer, a professional mover, asked a Queens lock smith to open it to see whatwas inside.

Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of Cal ifornia is in the capital con firming with the Watergate special prosecutor's office to determine if he is going to be indicted.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn was stripped of his Soviet citizenship and exiled to West Germany for what authorities called "per forming systematically actions incompatible with being a citizen." His banishment was the first forced expulsion of a major Soviet dissident since Leon Trotsky was exiled in1929.

The weather was pleasant ly warm and sunny yester day, providing a pleasant respite from last week's snow, but the high tempera ture of 55 degrees, reached at 4:10 P.M., was still no where near a record for thedate.

The American Broadcasting Company television network, which has been lagging seri ously in the ratingss from Sep tember to January, has signifi cantly improved its competitive position with several programs that were introduced at midseason.

Squire, identified by the police as a member of the alleged Black Libera tion Army, is on trial for mur der in connection with the killing.

Japan had a rec ord deficit of $1.93-billion in her balance of payments for January, the Finance Ministry. announced today. The trade balance showed a deficit of $740-million, the first trade deficit in three years, theministry said.

Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama will not get Federal financing if he seeks the Presidency in 1976 as an independent or third-party candidate the Government said today. In a background summary of the new Presidential Election Campaign Fund Act, the General Accounting Office said that Federal financing of Presidential campaigns in 1976 be limited to the Demoand Republican candidates.

Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will meet with Pope Paul VI when he pays a state visit to Italy next week, the Vatican announced here today. Mr. Gromyke will arrive in Rome Feb 18.

A passer-by got part of the loot yesterday morning when four robbers, fleeing after holding up the Astoria branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company at 21-21 Broadway, dropped some of $29,054they had stolen.

United States auto workers reported yesterday that for the first 10 days of February they sold 145,594 cars, off from last year's total of 218,785. The daily rate in eight selling days was 18,199, compared with 24,310 in nine days last year,a decline of 25.1 per cent.

Dan Rooney, vice presi dent of the Pittsburgh Steelers, said today be planned to appeal a rejection by the Three Rivers Stadium Authority of proposed ticket price increases. Miss Jacqueline Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Hudson Miller, was married here yesterday noon to Lyn Seltzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Seltzer of West Orange, N. J. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

Insurers have been authorized to report their earnings to stockholders on the basis of generally accepted accounting principles, Benjamin R. Schenck, State Insurance Superintendent, said here yesterday.

Max Schaffer, who for many ears operated Hubert's Museum, which included the wellknown flea circus, and other penny arcades on 42d Street, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Clare's Hospital.

Opposition was beginning to develop yesterday to the plan by Alexander's, Inc., to open its five New York City stores Sunday even though the chain's management was still maintaining its silence on the proposed opening.
After a lapse of several years, the Greater New York Bridge Association has decided to revive its special programs for the inexperienced tournament player.

The State Fuel and Energy officee expects delivery of an extra six million gallons of gasoline to stations in the city, on Long Island and in the Hudson Valley to begin this weekend, but officials said it would make little difference in the persistent shortage.

Economists for the Business Council forecast today that growth in the United States' "real" gross national product, adjusted for inflation, this year will be "somewhat less than 1 per cent" compared with 6 per cent in 1973. They also predicted that unemployment would average about 5.8 per cent against last year's 4.9 per cent.
Andres Segovia, who, as everyone must know, is the Colosseum and the Louvre museum of the classic guitar, paid his annual visit to New York on Wednesday night.

Nine patients and four health groups sued the Federal Government today for the release of about half the patient population of St. Elizabeths Hospital here, one of the largest mental hospitals in the country.

The United States supplied South Vietnam with 180,412 tons of munitions for ground forces in the eight months following the cease-fire agreement in January, 1973, the Defense Department disclosed today.

As physician for the B.F. Goodrich chemical plant in Louisville, Ky., Dr. John L. Creech Jr. examines all employes returning to work after an illness. He was struck recently by the large number of serious liver ailments among the workers, compared with patients he saw in his private surgical practice.

King Hussein has proposed that Israel abandon her positions along the Jordan River and withdraw to the western edge of . the Jordan Valley as the first stage in an Israeli-Jordan ian settlement, according to au thoritative Government sources here. King Hussein suggested Israeli withdrawal from Jordan River to line at edge of valley (1). Israelis are thought to be willing to yield only populated northern part of West Bank (2).
A Hose organization of fishermen from Ocean County to Great Neck, L. I., kept their boats docked today in an effort to raise the price of whiting in the New York metropolitan area.
Charles O. Finley closed the sale of the California Golden Seals to the National Hockey League today and admitted his venture into the sport "turned out to be a failure."

Miss Mary Barbara Ludi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Ludi of Longboat Key, was married here this afternoon to Edward W. Scripps 3d, division manager for California for the Scripps League of Newspapers of Seattle.

The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, decided yesterday to ask the Appellate Division to empanel a special grand jury to inquire into possible criminal violations of the state's antitrust laws by major oil companies.

Offhand remarks made today at a news conference by Attorney General William B. Saxbe were described by Randolph A. Hearst as "damn near irresponsible" when considered against the effort to negotiate the release of his kidnapped daughter, Patricia.

The board of governors of the American Stock Exchange approved yesterday a program that would permit members to negotiate commission charges directly with investors on securities transactions involving $2,000 or less.

The assistant United States Attorney in charge of the Federal investigation into a confidence racket masterminded by Joseph Ferdinando suggested to a jury yesterday that Thomas J. Mackell and two codefendants had concealed their knowledge about the scheme from him..

Judge Clarence Newcomer of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia ruled in favor of me and one of my former co-workers and the American Friends Service Committee in our suit against the United States Government, it marked a turning point in an effort my husband and I began 24 years ago.

The cost of borrowing shortterm funds is continuing to decline, according to figures released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. The Federal funds rate, that on overnight interbank loans has gone below 9 per cent for the first time since last June, ending the latest reporting week at 8.93 per cent.

The city's first documented case of chemical pneumonia caused by swallowing gasoline during siphoning from a car was reported yesterday by the Department of Health. The victim, an 18-year-old Brooklyn youth, was admitted Thursday to Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn where he was said to be in good condition.

" The music is 10 years ahead of the way it's presented on radio," said Murray Kaufman, better known as Murray the K, the disk jockey who quit WNBC last week, declaring he had no choice in porgraming the music he played. He is heavily against "restricted lists," which, he says, dominate music radio today.
Foreign business, especially in the pharmaceutical and related health-care operations were chiefly responsible for the record results reported yesterday by the Squibb Corporation.

The Internal Revenue Service, after consultation with the Department of Justice, said today that it would decide tomorrow whether to surrender the home telephone records of David E. Rosenbaum, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

Governor Byrne today proposed a $2.7-billion state spending program that does not include any new taxes or major new programs and is precariously balanced by anticipated revenues that may be undermined by the economic effects of the energy shortage. As part of an exchange program between the Amateur Athletic Union and Soviet Wrestling Federation, the world champion Soviet team will visit the United States in March for a series of six dual matches.

Both as a theater critic and as a Ph.D., I watch the vagaries of the doctorate in American universities. As the owner of a Harvard Ph.D. in comparative literature, I am interested in the development of my stock; as a theater critic, I am concerned with the fate of absurdist farce, the genre to which today's Ph.D. programs belong.

The Business International Corporation issued a report yesterday adding to previous research designed to show that American multinational manufacturing companies have a higher domestic job growth rate than the nation's manufacturing companies as a whole.
Home mortgage frauds and financial swindles will get new Federal attention, the Justice Department said yesterday.
Mrs. David Eisenhower successfully underwent a 44-minute operation tonight for the removal of a benign ovarian cyst, hospital officials said.

Premier Adamantios Androutsopulos announced today that a United States company had struck oil and gas in commercial quantities in the Aegean Sea off the north coast of Greece. One well is already producing 3,000 barrels of crude daily.

Supermarket food prices are rising much faster than Government analysts expected a few months ago. For all of 1974 the increases could match last year's 16 per cent jump, which was the highest in a quarter century.

So obvious are the threats that the energy crisis poses for the environment that it is easy to lose sight of some opportunities it presents to the environment's defenders. Even so dedicated a champion of the environment as the National Audubon Society concedes that "there have already been important gains" from the shortage. With cultivation there can be more.
Arthur Ashe of Miami defeated Onny Parun of New Zealand, 6-4, 6-4, today to advance to the quarter-finals of World Championship Tennis Astor Cup competition.

Continuing his defiance of Washiigton, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill said today that Connecticut would not enforce a two-dayold order from the head of the Federal Energy Office prohibiting gasoline station operators from giving preferential treatment to the regular customers.
American Airlines, Inc., suffeared a net loss in the fourth quarter after realizing a profit in the third quarter for the first time in nine months.

The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday that it would raise the price of its styrene plastic resins 8 cents to 9 cents a pound, effective March 1. In a separate announcement, the Dow Corning Corporation said it would increase prices 4 to 15 per cent on its line of high-temperature resins, paint additives and resin intermediates, effective March 13.

At least $200,000 in contributions for Republican Congressional candidates was diverted in 1972 to the Finance Committee to Re-elect the President as part of an elaborate scheme to "launder" money. promised by milk producers for President Nixon's campaign, according to Congressional sources.

The rise in February's electricity bills for New Jersey's residential customers will be far less than the increase anticipated in New York, according to utility officials here, as a result of the greater use of coal by the state's major public utility.

Chu Ko-Chen, a leading Chinese scientist who attended Harvard and the University of Illinois, died last Thursday inPeking. Hisinhua the official Chinese press agency, reported today. He was 84 years old.
Leo P. Flood, former director of engineering of the Department of Air Pollution Control, which is now the Department of Air Resources, died Wednesday at Flushing Hospital.

Almost unnoticed by a distant world, a cataclysm struck Ethiopia last year as famine swept at least two million farmers and herdsmen, killing uncounted thousands. Victims of the famine at a relief camp in Addis Ababa The Ethiopian provinces hardest hit by famine are Wallo and Tigre.
Julian Chase, a retired automotive editor and author, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Woodbury, Conn.

Gasoline allocations based on the serial numbers of inspection stickers will replace Pennsylvania's present license-plate-number plan, Gov. Milton Shapp said today. After meeting for about two hours with station representatives, Governor Shapp said he agreed with their request for the switch. The Governor refused to disclose further details of the meeting, saying that a full announcement would be made Monday.
Oscar Bonavena, the Argentine heavyweight boxer, is suffering from a liver ailment and will not be able to fight Ron Lyle in Denver, Feb. 28, his doctors said today.

West Germany's Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, said today that France's conduct at the energy conference in Washington early this week was "hard to understand," and he suggested that, in the future, decisions of the nine Common Market countries might better be made by majority rule rather than unanimously.

Frank Sinatra will make 12 concert appearances in nine United States cities. starting in New York's Carnegie Hall on April 8. Mr. Sinatra came out of two years of self-imposed retirement las fall with a television special on the National Broadcasting Company network Nov. 18.

Governor Byrne announced today that Federal energy officials had increased New Jersey's monthly gasoline allocations by 2.5 million gallons to make up for gasoline stocks lost due to the pullout of gasoline suppliers from the state during the last two ears.
Byron B. Brenden, who has been chosen "inventor of the year" for his achievements in acoustical holography, is about to receive a new patent in the field.
The West German Government today confirmed press reports that its anti-trust office had produced evidence of possible price manipulation by international oil companies.

Any major new construction project that attracts large numbers of automobiles, such as a shopping center, airport or sports arena, will be regulated by the states, under rules issued yesterday by the Environmental Protection Agency.
A pilot project to pay in advance for medical services to Medicaid patients is close to implementation, the State Department of Social Services said today.

The outook for drivers in need of gasoline in the metropolitan area over the holiday weekend appeared yesterday to be even grimmer than usual. "One thing's for sure," said an attendant at a station in Queens yesterday. "Won't be no gas in the city by tomorrow night."

A smoky two-alarm fire at the Hunters Point station of the Long Island Rail Road caused the cancellation last night of five trains bound for Long Island. About 1,300 commuters who regularly ride the line from the station, in Long Island City, Queens, had to seek alternative ways home.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy is saying privately, to his closest political associates, that it is extremely unlikely that he will run for President in 1976.

The Soviet Novosti press agency today circulated to foreign embassies and newsmen a translation of a letter in which Lenin vigorously protested the exile of Russian workers by the czarist regime without trial and by administrative means.

Government plans for abandonment of more than 25 per cent of railroad trackage in the Middle West and Northeast "will never leave the drawing board," Senator Vance Hrtke, Democrat of Indiana said yesterday.

Judith T. Younger, associate dean of the Hofstra University School of Law, has been named dean of the College of Law at Syracuse University. Mrs. Younger will be the first woman to head a law school in the state.

Roger Pryor, a former bandleader and an actor of stage, screen and radio who retired in 1962 as a vice president for broadcasting of Foote, Cone Belding, Inc., advertising, died Jan. 31 of a heart attack on a trip to Puerta Vallarta, Mexico. He was 72 years old and lived here.

A high Administration official asserted yesterday that Moscow's expulsion of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn in no way represented a failure of President Nixon's policy of improving relations with the Russians as a means of influencing their treatment of Soviet Jews.
Yields on United States Treasury bills fell slightly in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.

Farrar, Straus Giroux, the publisher, has nearly completed negotiations toward acquiring the rights to a forthcoming largely autobiographical book by the dismissed White Houe counsel, John W. Dean 3d, a highly placed publishing industry informant reported last night.

A New Jersey state trooper testifying in the murder trial of Clark D. Squire vigorously denied today that he had "panicked and ran away from a buddy in trouble" during a shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike last May 2.

Clashes between 'Syrian and Israeli forces were reported' today on the Golan Heights front after a lull of about two days. The Damascus radio said that four Israelis were killed in a clash between Syrian and Israeli patrols in the morning.

Defense motions for a mistrial on constitutional issues raised in the trial of former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens were denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh as the fifth week of the misdemeanor trial ended.

Buyers flooded European gold markets today, driving prices to records in a flurry of speculative trading. The dollar closed marginally lower in most markets.

Brig. Gen. Bernard L. Gorfinkle, U.S.A., retired, who was a bodyguard for President Woodrow Wilson at the signing of the peace treaty ending World War I, died yesterday in a Boston hospital.

By electing to create a three-act full-evening work, "In the Sweet Now and Now," George Faison joins a small group of modern dancers that includes Alwin Nikolais and Martha Graham.

The Government reported today that some 10,000 persons died or were reported missing in fighting over the last, 10 days between Moslem rebels and Government troops at Jolo in the Sulu Islands.
With "a lot of regret," Mark Donohue ended his racing career today With an easy victory in a contest intended to decide the greatest driver in the world.

In a angry protest against the new agreement between the International Lawn Tennis Federation and the World Team Tennis organization, the French Tennis Federation walked out of the international ruling body today.

The University of Cincinnati's Armory Field House is supposed to give the Kentucky Colonels a home-court advantage, but it failed last night as Julius Erving scored 36 points and the New York Nets soundly beat the Colonels, 115-101.

A father's desire to be emulated by his son, a son's desire for individuality are the timeless themes of Michael Smith's new play, "Prussian Suite." The father in this instance is King of Prussia, the son is the Crown Prince, but the play is less a tale about monarchy than about love and the absence of love.

WNBC-TV will stand by With no further comment than the two public apologies made by Dick Schaap, the television sportscaster, for making a remark called "particularly offensive" by Cardinal Cooke, a spokesman said yesterday.

Dr. Peter G. S. Beckett, former resident psychiatrist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., died here Wednesday. He was 52 years old.

Stanley R. Millard, an assistant vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, on an Erie Lackawanna train near Mountain View. He was 56 years old and lived on Decker Lane here.
Two escaped convicts were reported today to be providing the leadership for the mysterious Symbionese Liberation Army, the group that kidnapped 19year-old Patricia Hearst.

Reuben L. Phillips, music director of the Apollo Theater On 125th Street since 1953, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, in San Juan, P.R., where he was playing alto saxophone in a band with a Sammy Davis Jr. show.

One of three executors of the estate of the late painter Mark Rothko testified in Surrogate Court yesterday that he had been pressured by the other two executors and their lawyer into agreeing to a contract that is being attacked in the court by Rothko's heirs.

The continuing drought in the sub-Sahara region of Africa and the hardships it is bringing to the people who live there is one of the great tragedies of our time. New York State driver's licenses issued or renewed after April 1 will be valid for periods ranging from 28 to 54 months, with fees set accordingly, and will expire during the holder's month of birth. The new system is the first step in converting regular three-year licenses to four-year licenses.

Al McGuire, the Marquette basketball coach who sometimes thinks like an oddsmaker, still likes the University of California, Los Angeles to win the Pacific-8 Conference.

The Brown University board of trustees has voted to end student expansion and limit the school's enrollment to the current total of 5,150. "There are only a few other small universities of academic distinction in the country and one of Brown's attractive features is its size and intimate atmosphere," the trustees said Saturday.

The country's biggest indoor junior tennis tournament, with 575 freeswinging boys and girls seeking trophies, ended today and Harry Hopman, the referee, was astounded as well as fatigued.

A construction worker fatally shot his wife and six other relatives today, telling the authorities that he thought he was doing the Lord's bidding, the police said. An eighth relative of the man was critically wounded.
Gen, Manuel A. Odria, President of.Peru from 1948 to 1956, died today of a heart ailment, He was 77 years old.

After meeting with Ismail Fahmy of Egypt and Omar Saqqaf of Saudi Arabia, Mr. Kissinger told reporters at the State Department that he hoped the Arab proposal would lead to the opening of formal talks on disengagement in Syria. [1:3.]

The transfer of the Memphis franchise to Houston and an exchange of player rights of the New York and Boston franchises were' approved by the World Football League today at the second meeting of its board of governors.

Richard F. VanderVeen, a 51-year-old corporation lawyer, yesterday became the first Democrat in 64 years to be elected to Congress from the Fifth District of Michigan.
Richard F. VanderVeen tonight became the first Democrat in 64 years to be elected from the Fifth Congressional District in Michigan. He won the House seat vacated last year by Vice President Ford.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn vowed today to continue his work in exile and said he had as much right to live on Russian soil as those who had "the audacity to physically throw me out."

Frank Johnson, manager of the Arkansas National Wildlife Refuge, said today that the world's wild whooping crane population had dropped to 48th lowest since 1967-but that there was no call for alarm. "There is a normal fluctuation in the population of any bird," Mr. Johnson said. "In 1938 we had 15, and in 1951 there were only 15."
A leading figure of the Peronist right wing died this morning when a bomb exploded in his briefcase. The police said it was not clear what the man had intended to do with the explosive.

The Bank of Italy today confirmed Washington reports that Italy was seeking a standby credit line of one billion Special Drawing Rights, equivalent to $1.2-billion, from the International Monetary Fund.

The Utah Stars picked up their 14th straight American Basketball Association victory tonight, a 121-110 conquest of the Carolina Cougars.
A Rhode Island consulting concern has been awarded a Federal contract to make an environmental impact study on the proposed John F. Kennedy Memorial Library.

When Iselin High School won its first basketball game for Ray Neuman five years ago, the team's reaction, as the coach recalls it, was somewhat like winning the seventh game of a World Series. For what preceded the victory were 33 consecutive losses, the. last four under Neuman, then serving his first year as coach.
Statistics show that at least 14,325 New Englanders have emigrated to Canada since 1966, first because of the Vietnam War and now because of Watergate, according to the Canadian consul here.

Dr. Theis was a staff member of Nyack Hospital and of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary in New York. He obtained his medical degree from New York Medical School in 1930.

A $200,000 contribution by Associated Milk Producers Inc. that wound up in President Nixon's re-election fund was intended for Republican Congressmen, the organization's president, John Butterbrodt said yesterday.

Arthur Elrod, an interior designer whose work on be seen in nearly every major city in the country, died in a car accident here yesterday. was 49 years old.

Despite a new threat of a Presidential veto, the Senate approved today a compromise emergency energy bill rolling back domestic crude oil prices. The measure, which has been stalled in Congress since December, passed by 67 to 32 after the Senate rejected three attempts to send it back to a Senate-House conference committee to be rewritten for the second time in three weeks.

The bodies of two boys missing since Monday night were found yesterday under the ice in Rainbow Pond in Lakehurst. The boys, James Walpole, 10 years old, and his brother, John, 9, were found by a sheriff's officer about 8:30 A.M. The cause of death was not announced, pending an autopsy. The pond is about a half mile from the motel where the boys had been staying with their parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Walpole.

The 1973 testimony, given to a grand jury, involved a scheme run by Joseph Ferdinando, whose prosecution Mr. Mackell is charged with hindering.

Two more victims of a rare liver cancer have been uncovered among vinyl chloride workers in a B. F. Goodrich Company chemical plant in Louisville, Ky., bringing to six the known cases there of the invariably fatal disease.

The tenuous leadership of Premier Golda Meir was dealt a severe blow yesterday with the decision of Defense Minister Moshe Dayan to give up his ministerial post unless his political terms are accepted. The Government has lost its bid for a review by the Supreme Court of a tax dispute with Walt Disney Productions. The Government says the case could result in an annual loss of $400-million to $500-million in taxes from the movie industry.

Despite a new threat of a Presidential veto, the Senate approved today a compromise emergency energy bill rolling back domestic crude oil prices. The measure, which has been stalled in Congress since December, passed by 67 to 32 after the Senate rejected three attempts to send it back to a Senate-House conference committee to be rewritten for the second time in three weeks.

The Polaroid Corporation, which has put $350-million into the research and development of the SX-70 compact camera in the last six years, has finally crossed the break-even point on it, with the camera and film realizing a profit last month, the 1973 annual report disclosed yesterday.

Legislation that appears intended to surpress all opposition was laid before the South African Parliament today by Prime Minister John Vorster's Government. The Government has a firm majority in Parliament.

Government troops reportedly made two attempts to clear insurgent forces out of areas just south of Phnom Penh today, but were stopped by heavy fire.

Saudi Arabia has agreed to supply oil to South Vietnam and its military forces despite the embargo against its American backers, high-ranking South Vietnamese officials reported today. Madison Square Garden boxing officials announced yesterday the pairings for Felt Forum feature matches on Monday and March 4. Heading Monday's card will be a 10-round welterweight bout between Harold Weston Jr. of New York and Dario Hidalgo of Miami. Weston is an Army private on furlough from Fort Hood, Tex. On his last leave, he stopped Vito Antuofermo in the fifth round for the only defeat Antuofermo has suffered.

NAIROBI, Kenya--The leopard, long held by some wildlife organizations to be an endangered species, has been found in recent studies still existing in abundant numbers in every African country south of the Sahara.

State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr., and former Assemblyman Brian T. Kennedy, taking opposing sides in a debate over legalizing gambling in New Jersey, agreed today that the public should have the right to a referendum on the question.
Inge Sand, soloist of the Royal Danish Ballet who made her American debut in 1954, at the Jacob's Pillow DanceFestival near Lee, Mass., died of cancer last week in Copenhagen. She was 45 years old.

Fred Perry, a three-time Wimbledon champion in the nineteen-thirties, is in New York to commemorate the 100th anniversary of tennis. He rates the late Bill Tilden the greatest player of all, considers today's women players far superior to those of his day, but warns that the sport currently is being threatened by various group Dower struggles.

Laurence H. Silberman, nominated to be Deputy Attorney General, said yesterday that he would resign rather than carry out any Presidential order to dismiss Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski, except for gross improprieties.

The Army reported progress today in developing an allvolunteer force that it said was of better quality and more combat-ready than the Army was when the draft ended slightly more than a year ago.

The American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., celebrating its 20th anniversary, is changing its name to the American Shakespeare Theater. No longer is it simply a summer festival, but an almost year-round institution, touring as well as playing on its home ground, producing modern plays as well as Shakespeare and with some of its actors working a nine-month season.

Turkey has asked the United States to undertake a joint re-examination of the ban on cultivation of opium by Turkish farmers, Foreign Ministry sources said today.

Seventh-ranked Pitt sank 11 of 12 shots from the foul line in the last four minutes tonight to defeat Temple, 56-49, and gain its 22d consecutive college basketball victory.

Kermit Kegley, a former Broadway actor and stage manager, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Fenton, Mo., in the offices of Communico, a concern producing industrial shows and displays, where he was production manager.

The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted today a rule permitting investment companies to offer to shareholders the privilege of reinvesting proceeds of a redemption of company shares without the usual sales charges.
A resolution to rename the University of Georgia's Sanford Stadium in honor of the late football coach, Wally Butts, has passed the Georgia Senate, but may have rough going when it gets to the House.
Dr. Charles Beck, a psychiatrist affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital since 1948, died of cancer there on Tuesday. He was 58 years old and lived at 49 East 96th Street.

Rhode Island lost nearly $173-million in salaries to military and civilian workers last year as a result of Navy cutbacks in the area, a Navy report said today..

All three were dismissed following the alleged incident on Nov. 13 at the Bergen County institution in Paramus, but one, LeRoy Blakely, 29 years old, went to work in Passaic.

New productions of Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle" and Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" will be introduced by the Metropolitan Opera during its 1974 June Festival, which is to begin on May 27 and run for three weeks.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday a 152 per cent increase in its fourth-quarter earnings and a nearly sevenfold improvement in annual profits last year. Maria Callas and the tenor Giuseppe Di Stefano were greeted at their recital here tonight by a standing ovation and showers of roses from the balconies. But about 400 seats in the 2,800-seat Massey Hall were empty when the concert began.

The date for President Nixon's expected trip to Western Europe is still open, the White House said today. Gerald L. Warren, deputy White House press secretary, denied published reports that Mr. Nixon had postponed the trip from this spring to September.

President Nixon told a group of 15 Boy Scouts at his White House office today that all the problems Scouts were working on, including the energy shortage, "fortunately are problems of peace."

Well-placed sources said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was looking into an apparent excision from a White House document subpoenaed by the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski.
East Germans upset the favorites, the Soviet Union and Norway, today to win the 40-kilometer men's relay in the world Nordic ski championships.
Secretary of State Kissinger today began talks with 24 LatinAmerican and Caribbean foreign ministers with a call for the creation of a new "Western Hemisphere community" of nations.
Mayor Beame made public yesterday his mandatory plan for alternate-day gasoline sales, providing for fines up to $250 and jail terms of up to five days for violators.
Don Luce put in a late thirdperiod goal tonight, his second of the game, as the Buffalo Sabres rallied from a three-goal deficit to tie the Atlanta Flames, 4-4.

Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., pulled the upset of the $44,000 World Championship Tennis tournament today by beating the top-seeded player, Rod Laver of Australia, 6-3, 5-7, 6-4, to advance to the semifinal round.
Wil Jones hit a season-high 26 points tonight to lead the Memphis Tams to a 111-106 victory over the Denver Rockets in the American Basketball Association.

The emergency mass-transit aid bill agreed upon by a House-Senate conference committee represents an extraordinary breakthrough on behalf of public transportation throughout the country. Its benefits would be of special value in the New York metropolitan area, which accounts for 40 per cent of the country's transit riders.
The American Petroleum Institute reported today slight increases in petroleum imports last week and increases in both production and stocks of gasoline.

An official of the ArabianAmerican Oil Company said today that Saudi Arabia warned the United States last August of a new Middle East war and an oil embargo "within six months" but was ignored.
The first intercollegiate driving championship became a reality this morning as horses and post positions were announced for tomorrow. night's two-division pacing competition at Roosevelt Raceway.
Tom Seaver became the highest paid pitcher in base. ball history today when the New York Mets signedd him for $170,000.

The trustee of the Equity Funding Corporation of America has identified and eliminated from the company's books $143.4million of fictitious or fraudulently inflated assets.

Slow but significant progress was made yesterday in the selection of a jury for two former Cabinet officers accused of obstructing a major investigation, with 15 persons receiving preliminary clearance by the judge.

A heavy flow of strong earnings reports from British banks and industrial companies in the last few days has raised a new campaign issue in the national elections because of the sharp con- c trast with the current state of the economy.

Milton S. Samuels, a vice president of RKO-Stanley Warner Theaters, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 57-61 Cloverdale Boulevard in Bayside, Queens.

The New York Rangers got back to National Hockey League business tonight against the Los Angeles Kings, with Emile Francis cracking the whip as coach again. The Rangers--in pursuit of the East Division runner-up spot--hoped to restore their old domination over the Kings.

Associates of Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that they doubted that he would agree to serve in the minority government announced by Premier Golda Meir last night, despite her repeated requests that he remain.

Nick Buoniconti, Miami Dolphins' linebacker, underwent surgery today for removal of bone chips in his right elbow. A team spokesman said Buoniconti would spend a day or two recovering in Mercy Hospital.
Charles B. Allen, partner in Allen Brown, tax consultants here, died Feb. 14 in Silver Spring, Md. He was 87 years old and lived in Arlington. Va.

Secretary General Waldheim said today that "peoples and countries could disappear from the face of the map" in West Africa if the world did not help with longrange efforts to make the subSahara region self-supporting.

Funeral services to be held at 2 P.M. on Friday Feb. 22 at Halvorsen's, 53d St. and Eighth Ave., Brooklyn.
A 21-year-old man died of gunshot wounds in his head and chest last night after he was found lying in a street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn shortly before midnight, the police said.

Over the stubborn opposition of President Nixon and the oil lobby, who have fought a delaying action against the emergency energy bill, a two-thirds majority of the Senate this week passed a compromise conference version of the bill calling for price rollbacks on oil and measures to conserve energy. It also gave the President standby authority to order fuel rationing.

The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose sharply to 231.0 from 223.2 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 144.6 on Feb. 20, 1973.

The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week was an estimated $733-million, up 7 per cent from the year-earlier $731million. Tota retail store sales were about $8.876-billion, up 2 per cent from last year's $8.687billion.

Gasoline retailers here threatened today to extend thei rtwo-day-old shutdown indefinitely as the protest spread to two other towns and strike sentiment appeared to be growing throughout the state.
Melvin R. Laird, who was President Nixon's domestic affairs adviser and his Secretary of Defense, agreed today to head a $-million private study of the fuel shortage's impact on national life.

The indictment by a Federal grand jury of six Nassau County Republicans, including a United States Representative and the Supervisor of Oyster Bay, was seen here today as perhaps the most severe blow ever suffered by the - county] G.O.P.

Frederick Paul Keppel, a former member of Price, Waterhouse Co., certified public accountants, died yesterday at Maryland General Hospital in Baltimore after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived in Westminster, Md.

Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, turned over to the House impeachment inquiry today a list of evidence gathered or subpoenaed from the White House by his office over the last eight months in its investigation of the Watergate scandal.
The official Chinese Communist newspaper warned yesterday, in a strikingly moderate editorial, that the current mass campaign in China should "avoid getting entangled" in certain questions.

The Cross-Bronx Expressway was to be closed between Bruckner Boulevard and the Major Deegan Expressway until 8 A.M. today to repair damage caused last evening when several manhole covers were blown off, bringing down part of the concrete support of the Arthur Avenue overpass.

The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 4.6 per cent over the corresponding period last year. Tonnage last week was 5.5 per cent over the immediately preceding week.
A co-founder of Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America was sentenced to a year in prison and fined $10,000 today for his part in what a Federal Judge called "the biggest swindle I've ever seen."

The United States Appeals Court heard arguments today that the Federal Communications Commission was misusing the fairness doctrine by imposing its news judgment over broadcasters in investigative reporting.

Controls on compensation of executives would continue for as long as a year after general wage and price controls are ended April 30 under the Administration's detailed legislative proposals published today by the Cost of Living Council.
An in-depth analysis of American advertising, present and future, has just been published by a Manhattanbased market research company.
Governor Byrne said today that he hoped to close Trenton State Prison during his administration.

Delaware County Judge Domenic D. Jerome rejected today a defense motion to disqualify the state's special prosecutor, Richard A. Sprague, in the murder trial of W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers.

Only two years ago India's Prime Minister Indira Gandhi enjoyed popularity and power exceeding even that of her father, the late revered Jawaharlal Nehru. After India's triumph over Pakistan in the Bangladesh war, Mrs. Gandhi's New Congress party scored stunning victories in state elections across the country, routing a divided and dispirited opposition. Her triumph raised effusive hopes that India would enjoy a new era of progress under strong, united leadership.
Poor people who shop with food stamps may find their coupons buying less in the latter part of the year if prices keep going up as expected, Agriculture Department sources indicated today.

The RCA Corporation reported yesterday a new high of $1.18-billion in fourth-quarter sales. This represented a gain of 11.3 per cent over the $1.06billion reported in the final quarter of 1972. Net income rose 19.7 per cent to $53.4-million, or 70 cents a share, from $44.6-million, or 58 cents a share on fewer shares, in the like 1972 period.

The United States dollar weakened sharply today against most European currencies in foreignexchange dealings as the price of gold continued its steady upward march to records. LOS ANGELES. The San Fernando Valley is probably the best example of the spectacular suburban growth that has blanketed the "sunbelt" states of the West and the South since the war. Thirty years ago it was an isolated area of orange groves and truck farms, untouched by the freeways that have since slashed through the Hollywood Hills, binding the valley in their concrete grasp to the fortunes of the Los Angeles metropolis.

At Covent Garden from the mid twenties to the end of the thirties he had no serious rival as Siegmund, Siegfried or Tristan. Only the outbreak of World War II ended his ascendency at that house.

THERE is a growing sense of unease, tension and discontent throughout the land over the state of the nation's economy that seems hardly warranted by its over-all performance and prospects. 'What certainly is justified, however, is grave concern over the horrendous pattern of the various price indexes.
A special blood drive will be held by the Upsala College community on March 4 in an effort to help extend the lives of two Parsippany brothers who are hemophiliacs.

Republican political strength among voters for the Congres. sional elections this fall remains at the loweat level in the 38-year history the Gallup Poll has taken such readings. The survey shows that the Democratic party currently holds a 2 to 1 lead, 58 per cent to 29 per cent, over the Republican party in a comparative measurement of national Congressional appeal, with 13 per cent undecided.

The Commissioner of Social Services of Rockland County, Noah Weinberg, has been accused of being a New York City slumlord who has cheated both' the welfare clients who lived in his buildings and the city's Department of Social Services.

AT first, Julio Mitchel's current exhibit at the Midtown Y Gallery, "Two Wards," appears to consist of separate and unrelated essays. The first of these deals with crowds on New York City streets, while the second explores the texture of life at Goldwater Memorial Hospital, which specializes in chronic diseases.
The engagement of Miss Caroline Lee Palmer to John Tompkins Mickle of Norwalk has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lee Palmer of Darien and Delray Beach, Fla., parents of the future bride.
Long Island's share of state cultural funds was reduced slightly for 1973-74 as the New York State Council on the Arts distributed $451318 among 56 organizations in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

Senior officials of the Federal Energy Office said yesterday that if the Arab. oil embargo was not lifted by the end of April, a gasoline drought could hit wide areas of the country by, late spring or early summer.

From the beginning of the nation's energy crisis, efforts to cope with it have produced confusion, recriminations and an atmosphere of official scrambling to combat rising prices and inadequate supplies.
Mrs. Robert S. Wasserman has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Abby Lois Wasserman, to Daniel Paul Jaffe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Jaffe of Chevy Chase, Md.

"The Glory Game" presents to American readers a world as esoteric as "Paper Lion" did to readers in England. The grass roots of soccer in the United States are growing at a pace which suggests that in 20 years, it could .become a major national sport.

Bill Taylor is La Salle's top scorer. The Explorers are usually content to have him score and not tire himself on defense. The situation was different yesterday. La Salle needed someone to stop Phil Sellers of Rutgers, the man with many moves.

Manfred Schmid and his brother, Rudolf, of Austria took first and second, respectively, today after the opening heats of the international luge competition here. The finals are scheduled for tomorrow.

Miss Georgia George, daughter of Mrs. John P. Umbach of New York and Spyros George of New Port Richey, Fla., was married here yesterday afternoon to Andreas Eleftheriou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Costas Eleftheriou of Brooklyn, formerly of Nicosia. Cyprus.

President Idi Amin has named a former princess as his Foreign Minister. Elizabeth Bagaya, a former princess of the Kingdom of Toro, a former fashion model and the first Uganda woman to qualify as a lawyer, replaces an army officer.

The police recovered almost $700,000 in ransom early today after arresting and charging an exconvict and his wife in the abduction of J. Reginald Murphy, the 40-year-old editorial-page editor of The Atlanta Constitution.
Lieut. Gov. Lester G. Maddox formally announced today his intention to reclaim the Georgia: governship.

While Istaeli Premier Golda Meir has tried to salvage a minority government from the confusion and disunity of Israeli politics, her Arab opponents appear for the moment to have gotten together. Rider College will institute a "minimester" this June, prior to the opening. of its regular summer sessions. The new program will run from June 3 to 14, with final examinations scheduled for June 17.

A word or two on this venture into starting seeds indoors. The tendency for the tenderfoot is to rush things. If he wants to race his neighbor and have the first tomato crop on the block, he reasons that he should plant his tomato seeds indoors early. Then he will have huge plants to put outdoors, and win the challenge.

The Federal Governmnent's Office of Coal Research will be reorganized and expanded to lead an accelerated drive to convert coal into clean energy, Rogers C. B. Morton, Secretary of the Interior, has announced.

LONDON. "Sir," the letter in The Times read, "the time for decision has come. The Government must stand firm. If the miners go on strike-and the signs are that they will-then the Government must act swiftly, firmly and effectively." The writer, Andrew Vincenti, went on to suggest that all picket lines be broken, the troops called out and the miners be drafted, if necessary.

Checkerhall, scoring his first stakes victory, upset a field of six 3-yearolds today at Garden State Park to capture the $26,000 Princeton Stakes. Ridden by Carlos Barrera, Checkerall, an 8-1 shot, moved into a comfortable lead on the backstretch, then was hand ridden through the stretch to win by three-quarters of a length.

Secretary of State Kissinger leaves tomorrow on another trip to the Middle East, hoping to bring about negotiations between Israel and Syria on the separation of their military forces on the Golan Heights.

"I rank seventh," Charles O. declared proudly. "Your players rank first," Marvin Miller said. At the end of the long table in a San Francisco office building, the Federal arbitrator, Howard S. Block, smiled.

The kidnappers of Patricia Hearst again made no response today to the Hearst Corporation's offer to add $4-million to a free food program in exchange for her immediate release.

Disorder subsides in this capital today after the Government acted to ease some of the grievances that caused a week of rioting. The Government ordered small decreases in the price of gasoline and other fuels yesterday. It also ordered a pricecontrol system for basic necessities.
Mickey Redmond scored three goals, the final one into an empty net with 22 seconds remaining, as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the New York Islanders, 5-3, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

The American Dredging Company of Philadelphia is challenging the consitutionality of New Jersey's 1970 wetlands law and its implementation, in a test case to determine the state's powers to protect t local wetlands.

Edward M. Kennedy Jr., 12 years old, was released from Children's Hospital Medical Center today after tests and treatment to prevent recurrence of bone cancer that led to the amputation of his right leg last year.

Congress has been disappointed and so are other proponents of the new agency, this newspaper included.

Dr, Irene Barnes Taeuber, a senior research demographer at the Office of Population Research of Princeton University and a past president of the Population Association of America, died yesterday at her home in Hyattsville, Md. She was 68 years old.

When Will Puentes recently became the first Montville High basketball player to score 1,000 points in a career, the game ball was given to his No. 1 fan-his father. The elder Puentes, who lost both legs in World War II, has not missed a game, in which his son has played. Coach Pat Houston immediately detected the special relationship between the two when he met the Puentes family.

The National Football League delayed again today on the matter of adding new teams to its present line-up of 26. At the annual meeting of the owners,it was decided to postpone any action on expansion until a special meeting late April in New York City.

Edward G. Robinson Jr., the son of the late screen actor, died yesterday. Mr. Robinson, who was 40 years old, was found unconscious by his wife, Nan, in their West Hollywood home. His death was attributed to natural causes.

Joe Vitelli, 31 years in the needle trades, son of a dressmaker, a former paratrooper and a guard at the postwar Nuremberg trials, lightly touched the azaleas under the somber portrait of the late Mrs. Mary Williamson Averell Harriman. "Sol," he said to a friend, "these flowers are real."

On the eve of a vote in the House Interior Committee on an attempt by the coal industry to Weaken proposed Federal regulation of strip mining, industry representatives opposing strict controls suffered a setback today.

The Soviet Union today announced special decorations for troops in the tense Chinese border area, possibly an indication of new troubles along the frontier. The announcement came In a decree by the presidium of the Supreme Soviet published in the Communist party newspaper Pravda.

The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, denied yesterday that the central bank deserved major blame for the country's record-breaking inflation rate. He rejected the charge of a Federal Reserve critic, Prof. Milton Friedman of the University of Chicago, who said earlier this week that loose monetary policy was the major cause of price pressures now sweeping through the economy.

A municipal plan to waive the extra costs charged motorists paying parking tickets issued prior to 1973 during a month-long amnesty period here, may be foiled unless the proposal receives proper judicial approval.
President Nixon refused on constitutional grounds today to appear as a witness at the trial in California of John D. Ehrlichman, his former adviser.
After a slow start, prices on the American Stock Exchange picked up steam during the day and closed higher in slightly stepped-up trading. A similar situation prevailed in-the overthe-counter market.

Col. Parker F. Hennessey, Commissioner bf Public Safety and chief of the State Police for eight years, died yesterday in the Augusta General Hospital. He was 62 years old.

A group of current and former Government officials just back from a tour of South-Vietnam said today that the only danger to the Saigon Government was from an "outpouring of propaganda" in the United States.
Two natural gas transmission companies asked the Federal Power Commission today for permission to construct a $212.5-million pipeline through Idaho, Washington and Oregon.

Kyle Rote Jr., a 23year-old ministerial student and soccer player, won the annual Superstars' tournament today. For finishing first in the two-day competition, he received the $25,000 top prize. In addition, he won bonus and qualifying money for a total of $53,400.
Andrew Soltis, the chess reporter for The New York Post, has scored 6-3 to win the seventh annual Goldwater-Marshall masters' chess tournament at the Marshall Chess Club here.

For the most part, Jorge Bolet gave a hyphenated concert in Carnegie Hall on Monday evening. Bach-Busoni; Strauss-Tausig; StraussSchulz-Evler; Wagner-Liszt. (Somehow the 24 Preludes of Chopin's Op. 28 also managed to Srieak in.) Mr. Bolet's action was quite deliberate.

Smoke from a smoldering mattress, believed to have been ignited by a cigarette, killed a 36-year-old woman and her two sons today. Iris Jimerson and her children, Eric, 8, and Bruce, 7, died of smoke inhalation, firemen said.
Vietcong and Saigon negotiators agreed today to free all remaining Vietnamese prisoners of war by March 6, a Government military spokesman said.
The State Court of Appeals has given final approval to rent increases of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many of the city's one million rent-controlled apartments.
A Manhattan grand jury has absolved six members of a Marxist group here of charges of having unlawfully imprisoned a member of the group, Alice Weitzman.

Geoffrey and Ann Ball live on a quiet square three blocks from Hyde Park, Their house, one of a row of expensive new town houses, has four floors. Whatever small domestic anarchies may be produced by their three daughters are kept well out of sight.

Everett W. Newcomb, retired treasurer and vice president of the Georgia Kaolin Company, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, Wolfeboro, N. H. He was 80 years old and lived in Tuftonboro, N. H.
The New York Islanders and the Vancouver Canucks played to a 1-1 tie in their National Hockey League game tonight in the NassauColiseum before many dissatisfied fans in the crowd of 11,121.

The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday a 16.8 per cent jump in its earnings in the 12 months to Jan. 31, and its directors voted to increase the June quarter dividend from 47 1/2 cents to 50 cents a share.

The State Education Department will begin to implement a controversial new approach next year to teacher-training that places greater emphasis on actual teaching in the classroom and less on formal course requirements, a department official told a committee of the State Board of Regents here today.

The Nixon Administration was accused by the General Accounting Office at a Senate hearing-today of failing to provide the research and development funds necessary to meet the clean water standards of the 1972 Water Pollution Control Act. At the same hearing, a leading national environmental organization charged that the Environmental Protection Agency had failed to implement several provisions of the act.

The Right Rev. William Henry Mead, seventh Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Delaware, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 53 years old.

Ruth A. Sonneborn, author of books for children and manager since 1936 of the bookstore of the Bank Street College of Education, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. She was 74 years old.

Samuel J. Byck, the would-be hijacker who died attempting to commandeer an airliner at Baltimore last week, intended to crash the aircraft into the White House, the columnist Jack Anderson reported today. In a preview of an Anderson column for tomorrow, the Washington Post said Mr. Byck had disclosed his plans in a tape recording mailed to Mr. Anderson "a few hours before the attempted hijacking."

The state charged yesterday in Supreme Court here that seven major oil companies In New York had continued their practice of offering anticompetitive "discriminatory rebates" to some service stations despite the companies' contention that the practice was halted with the onset of the gasoline crisis.

A senior American official said that a team of United States Navy demolition experts had been sent to the Suez Canal at Egypt's request to advise on clearing mines and other explosives. The waterway, closed since 1967, is due to be reopened this year. Newsmen were told of this action, the latest apparent sign of improved Egyptian-American relations, shortly before Secretary of State Kissinger landed in Damascus. [1:1.]
What may be known in years to come as a historic confrontation in the law of defamation -- Maheu v. Summa Corporation - opened in United States District Court here today.

Stock prices rallied late yesterday with glamour issues leading. Joining in the recovers Mere oil, fertilizer and nonferous metal issues. Trading volume improved along with prices .
The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday major management changes and corporate restructuring, including the election of John R. Opel as president.

Today is Ash Wednesday, the beginning of the penitential season of Lent for most of the world's Christians. Many Roman Catholics and some Episcopalians and Lutherans will receive crosses of ashes on their foreheads as reminders of their mortality.

The gasoline situation being what it is, parents are understandably reluctant to use the precious stuff for Sunday afternoon excursions. Taking the family for a bicycle ride is a suitable alternative. That's true even if there aren't enough bicycles in the family to go around. There are plenty of rental places that, at least before the warm weather rush starts, have adequate supplies, including bikes with chair seats for toddlers.

The American commercial center, opened formally with great fanfare last Oct. 3 by Secretary of Commerce Frederick B. Dent, now sits empty and idle, crippled by lack of funds for the equipment to operate it.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board issued today its final regulation to permit Federal savings and loan associations to issue flexible-payment mortgage loans. The normal payment on an 8 per cent, 30-year, $30,000 mortgage is $220 a month. Under the flexible-payment plan, the borrower could pay as little as $200 a month for the first five years and then $230 a month for the remaining term.
The Xerox Corporation advised its domestic commercial customers by mail yesterday that prices for most of its business products would be increased by an average of 3 per cent.

The Jose Lim6n Dance Company ended its mini-season at the City Center Downstairs on Monday night. In this basement setting, the company gave 14 different works in four programs-a formidable achievement.
An all-day conference attended by some 100 businessmen and several Government officials yesterday found the two groups often behind separate battlements.

The White House said today that President Nixon regretted naming Jerome B. Wiesner, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, on national television as among those who claimed a tax deduction for papers donated to the National Archives.
Benjamin Adler, a cotton broker known for his accuracy in forecasting price fluctuations of the raw fiber, died Monday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.
A modified municipal job freeze has been imposed to help the city control a budget that is running in the red by $300million.

Frank Assunto, a jazz trumpeter and leader of the Dukes of Dixieland, died yesterday after a brief illness. He was 42 years old. Mr. Assunto founded his group in the late nineteen-forties. His father, Papa Jac, played banjo and his brother, Freddie, trombone.
It was Cochran Day at Whiteface Mountain today. Two members of the famous ski-racing family from Richmond, Vt., Bob and Barbara, scored impressive Can-Am slalom triumphs in sub-freezing weather.

Alfred J. Scotti was at his home in Garden City, L. I., yesterday, showing his scrapbooks, talking about his life, and remembering bad guys he had sent to prison, or as he sometimes called it, the can.

A month-long investigation by district attorneys in six cities has "fairly well established in our minds" that independent gasoline retailers have been systematically eliminated, a spokesman for the prosecutors said yesterday.

Francisco Rodrique, a 16year-old problem youth said to have made 20 escapes from juvenile authorities -- including a leap last Thursday through a courtroom window - was recaptured last night hiding in a barrel.

Countess Bela Hadik, a daughter of the late Count and Countess Laszlo Szchenyi and a descendant of the Vanderbilt family, died yesterday in Lisbon, apparently of a stroke. The countess, who was 63 years old, was taken, off a flight from Boston to Lisbon when the plane landed and was taken to a hospital.

The gold rush continued throughout the European bullion markets today as the metal surged through the psychologically important $175 barrier and touched $184 an ounce here before settling back at the close.

Social Note: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Jackson Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., are enjoying a few days rest in Venice, Fla. Nine days ago Mr. Snead tied for second in the $150,000 Glen Campbell Los Angeles open golf tournament and collected $13,875.

A 3-year-old girl from Alden, N. Y., who was given a second liver in a transplant operation employing an experimental technique last November, died Monday night at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Center. Hospital spokesmen said the death was apparently unrelated to the organ transplant.
The National Association of Broadcasters announced today that President Nixon would appear March 19 at its convention in Houston and would participate in a question and answer session.
Judge Lawrence A. Whipple said today in the Federal District Court that he would sequester the jury in the trial of Nelson G. Gross, the former State Republican Chairman, on campaign fraud charges.

The United States Olympic Committee has warned all college athletes that they could lose their Olympic and Pan-American Games eligibility if they followed the National Collegiate Athletic Association ruling allowing them to be professionals in one sport and amateurs in another.

American Airlines received approval today from the Civil Aeronautics board on a plan to, suspend certain flights between the United States and the South Pacific pending a decision on a proposed exchange of routes with Pan American World Airways.

Kyle Rote Jr., a 23year-old ministerial student and soccer player, won the annual Superstars' tournament today. For finishing first in the two-day competition, he received the $25,000 top prize. In addition, he won bonus and qualifying money for a total of $53,400.

Penney Company announced an 11.8 per cent rise in its net on increased sales for the year ended Jan. 26.

One of the most divisive and confusing British election campaigns of the century will end at the polls tomorrow with not only the results but the pattern of government for the short-run future very much in doubt. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger stopped off briefly in London on his way to the Middle East. He stayed at Claridge's, with a marine outside his door all night; watched President Nixon's press conference on the B.B.C.; talked briefly on the phone with Jeremy Thorpe, the Liberal leader; called on Foreign Secretary Sir Alec Douglas-Home; had lunch with Prime Minister Heath, and flew off.

Since the Watergate scandals began, there has been an implicit conflict of interest between Mr. Nixon, occupant of the Presidency, and Mr. Nixon, potential defendant in a criminal indictment. Much of the trouble in which he now finds himself had its origin in his evident certainty that the power and prestige of the Presidency would always provide an impenetrable shield for questionable or even clearly illegal acts.

Sixth-seeded Patrice Dominguez of France became the first upset victim in the $50, 000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today when he lost, 6-4, 6-0, to Mike Estep of Dallas in the opening round.

Paul H. Sample, artist-in-residence emeritus at Dartmouth College, died today in Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital at the age of 77. He had suffered a heart attack yesterday at his home in Norwich. He leaves his wife, the former Silvia Howland, and a son Timothy.
More than 300 representatives of art organizations across the state gathered in the State Capitol today to lobby for the $30.5-million for the arts requested in 'Governor Wilson's 1974-75 budget.

BONN-Chancellor Willy Brandt is not as pessimistic about strengthening the European Community as are some of his colleagues in other countries who have begun to feel rather gloomy as a result of resurgent French nationalism and the West's failure to unite on a common oil policy during the energy crisis.

BRAMSON-Harry A. The Congress for Jew ish Culture records with sorrow the pass ing of Harry A. Abramson, our longtime executive board member, and devotee friend of Jewish Culture. Our hearties sympathy to the family. A memorial meet ing will be arranged at the time of his "Shloshim."

The Federal grand jury investigating the shootings at Kent State University began to focus this week on the higher officials who made the decisions to bring National Guardsmen on the campus.

North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops have overrun two Government bases in the Mekong Delta and inflicted heavy casualties on the defenders, reports from the field said today. Nearly 150 of the estimated 1,000 men defending the two bases were reported killed, wounded or missing, a casualty rate of nearly 15 per cent. Communist losses were not known.

Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that next year's military budget was increased at the last minute by more than $1-billion by the White House to help provide a stimulus to a lagging domestic economy.

Governor Wilson today proposed a record state highway appropriation with the, addition of $64.5-million more, as his office expressed the hope that by the time the highways were built there would be enough gasoline to drive on them.
