Blood taken from a hibernating animal in winter has been found to contain a substance that initiates off-season hibernation when it is later injected into an animal of the same species.

Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski said today that he believed his office now knew the full story of the Watergate affair and predicted that major indictments in the cover-up phase of the case would come as early as Thursday or Friday.

President Nixon's declaration that the energy "crisis" had subsided to the status of a "problem" drew heated contradictions today from Democratic Congressional leaders and a mild endorsement from the Federal Energy Office.

Delays in New York City's welfare eligibility recertification program are costing more than $100million a year, and at the present .rte, the program will not be completed for more than seven years, State Controller Arthur Levitt asserted today.

To the Editor: Your Feb. 4 editorial endorsed the. draft proposals for reorganizing the House of Representatives but noted that there would be opposition. Opposition does indeed exist, but on far more substantial and rational grounds than mere maintenance of the status quo.

What appeared to be an unofficial allocation program instituted by seven youths was interrupted in Brooklyn yesterday. They were charged with using an electric pump to transfer gasoline from somebody's else car to their own.

They packed up their elaborate stadium models today, waved good-by to the last owner, paid the hotel bills heavily weighted with entertainment costs and went home empty. They are the pitchmen, the people seeking what some regard as the absolute ultimate in life, an expansion franchise in the National Football League.
The Warner-Lambert Company posted record results yesterday for last year and its fourth quarter. Foreign sales accounted for about 40 per cent of the total and about a third of annual profits.

President Nixon's declaration that the energy "crisis" had subsided to the status of a "problem" drew heated contradictions today from Democratic Congressional leaders and a mild endorsement from the Federal Energy Office.
The United States Air Force said today that it had advised crews flying regular missions to keep their eyes open for a missing American balloonist, Thomas L. Gatch Jr., presumed down at sea.

A former Post Office official testified in Federal Court here yesterday that Representative Frank J. Brasco agreed in 1968 to take a secret $17,500 kickback from a financial agent who had been negotiating a loan to a Bronx trucking company controlled by an alleged Mafia captain.

Mory's, the legendary New Haven restaurant frequented by generations of Yale University students and faculty members, has lost its liquor license in the face of a court challenge by Women's Rights Activists.

John W.- Burke, the Oyster Bay Town Supervisor who was indicted by a Federal grand jury last week on a charge of perjury, reiterated today that he would remain in office despite requests that he suspend himself pending the outcome of a trial. The Town Board unanimously supported his stand.

Governor Wilson, who was 60 years old today, celebrated instead "the 21st anniversary of my 39th birthday." He sliced up a cake on his ceremonial glass-topped desk in the Red Room for newsmen, who ate it and engaged in the usual picture-taking banter about "slicing up" his budget
Twentysix American members of the United Jewish appeal rode Into Egyptian captivity today while on a bus tour of the Suez Canal area. They were freed after 10 hours.

Setting the stage for a potentially troublesome floor vote in an election year, a divided Senate committee recommended to day that members of Congress forego a proposed pay rise over the next three years while other top Federal officials receive salary increases.

Leading supporters of Chile's late President, Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, are being held in a desolate "concentration camp" on Dawson Island in the Strait of Magellan, according to a report last week in Brazil's leading political magazine, Visao.

Republicans and Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee challengedd today President Nixon's assertion that he could not be impeached except on the basis of evidence that he had violated criminal law.
Nadeen Peterson, one or the better known women on the creative side of the agency business, is leaving Lord Geller Federico Peterson, where she has been creative director, to join Kenyon Eckhardt.

Things fell flat yesterday for early-bird motorists waiting upwards of two hours in the gloom and chill at one of the West Side's biggest gasoline stations on the first day of mandatory gasoline allocations.
Mr. and Mrs. Guy Wingfield have been voting for the tiny Liberal party for years. After the election Thursday, they think, it will no longer be tiny.

Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's close friend, changed envelopes containing a $100,000 campaign contribution from Howard Hughes to avoid "additional problems" for the President's re-election campaign, according to sworn testimony by Mr. Rebozo filed in Federal court here today.

While Thursday is election day in Northern Ireland as it is in the rest of Britain, the focus here has not been on economic issues. Here the issue is still how the majority Protestants, and the minority Roman Catholics can be prevented from bombing and shooting each other.

The Secret Service said it had seized $115,000 in counterfeit $50 and $100 bills in Newark and arrested a lithographer who allegedly had printed them. The bills, and plates and negatives used to make them, were found at Gerard Litho Inc., of Newark, a Secret Service spokesman said. The counterfeit ring "was apparently gearing up for a sizable operation on the East Coast," he asserted.

Joe Vitelli, 31 years in the needle trades, son of a dressmaker, a former paratrooper and a guard at the postwar Nuremberg trials, lightly touched the azaleas under the somber portrait of the late Mrs. Mary Williamson Averell Harriman. "Sol," he said to a friend, "these flowers are real."

Assemblyman J. Edward Meyer, a former Republican who joined the Democratic party three months ago, said today that he was a candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated by Ogden R. Reid, another former Republican. Mr. Reid, who changed parties in 1972, is running for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.
Mines producing 100,000 tons of coal a day were shut down today as miners in West Virginia and Virginia complained that they could not get enough gasoline to get to work.
Warren Baker scored a season-high 31 points tonight to lead West Virginia to a 101-100 doubleovertime college basketball victory over Manhattan.

Eric M. Leyton, a staff engineer at the David Sarnoff Research Center here, died yesterday in Geneva while attending the International Radio Consultive Committee meeting at the request of the State Department. He was 58. years old and lived here.

The Assembly today passed and sent to the Senate a bill prohibiting corporate names that are "coarse, indecent or obscene," that "ridicule or degrade" any individual, group, or government agency or that "indicate or imply an unlawful activity."

MONTGOMERY, Ala.--The case of the United States of America v. Dr. Virgil B. Chrane might be comical if the consequences were not so serious -the consequences being the loss of his livelihood and probably his liberty as well.

Federal Judge Inzer B. Wyatt yesterday ordered the United States Attorney for Maryland to appear in Federal Court here Saturday morning to clear up a dispute over a missing tape in the corruption-conspiracy trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn.

Governor Byrne today declined a specific opportunity to express his army support for Secretary of State other J. Edward Crabiel, reputedly a them, major target of the state grand the e jury investigation of alleged broad corruption involving highway mara construction.
Irving Goldman, head of the Shubert real-estate and theater empire, was appointed yesterday as the city's $1-a-year Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.

The polls will be open from 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. today throughout Britain-England, Scotland and Wales-and Northern Ireland. RESULTS First results are to be declared about midnight. Results in 441 ,of the 635 contests will be announced by about 4 A.M. tomorrow, Then counting stops. Counting resumes about 10 A.M., with all results except those from a few Scottish islands complete by noon or so.

Secretary of State Kissinger flew to Israel from Syria, bringing a list of 65 Israeli troops held prisoner by Syria since the October war. This and Syria's promise to allow the Red Cross to visit the prisoners opened the way for the start of negotiations on the separation of Israeli and Syrian forces on the Golan Heights. The auto insurance industry, increasingly concerned about the clamor for rate cuts because of the reduction in driving, has begun to talk seriously of the strong possibility that rates will not go down but may go up.
Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, a key figure in the Congressional debate over campaign financing reforms, said today that he opposed public subsidy of House and Senate campaigns.

Gasoline rationing is opposed by more than half the American public. according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday. Fifty-three per cent of the 741 adults surveyed nationally Feb. 15 to 18 answered negatively to the question, "Do you favor or oppose a law requiring gas rationing?"

Premier Golda Meir today obtained another postponement of the deadline for presenting a new cabinet to President Ephraim Katzir. Informed sources said that Mrs. Meir had asked that the deadline be put off until next wednesday to leave her free to focus this week on talks with secretary of State Kissinger and to give her a chance to consolidate and enlarge her proposed governing coalition.

Groups representing tenants in rent-controlled apartments here, defeated in court, said yesterday they now would concentrate all their efforts on the Legislature to overturn the city's maximum-base-rent program, which permits rent rises of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many controlled apartments.

The Murray Louis Dance Company, which now has only a very few performances left at the Lyceum Theater, is one of the most interesting of the major modern-dance troupes. It very skillfully combines nonliteral drama- a kind of dramatic accent--with choreography that, unlike most American modern-dance choreography, owes a debt to the German school of Mary Wigman.

Secretary of State Kissinger brought Israel today a list of prisoners held by Syria sinco the war last October. In re. sponse, Israel agreed to hold talks with the Syrians aimed at separating their forces on the Golan Heights front.

North Vietnam's leaders have begun an ambitious two-year economic reconstruction and development plan and, at the same time, appear to have decided upon a "holding pattern" in the South, according to information from Hanoi.

Former. Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller has vigorously de. fended political appointees in the 'Rockefeller and Wilson ad. ministration who seldom show up at their state jobs although they are often paid $25,000 to $40,000 a vear.
A district judge today banned flights at Osaka International Airport between 10 P.M. and 7 A.M. because of the noise and ordered the Government to compensate 264 persons living near the field.
A military mutiny in the northern city of Asmara spread yesterday, and the Cabinet of Emperor Haile Selassie resigned under pressure of the mutineers' demands.

The defense in the trial of Thomas J. Mackell asked the jury yesterday to find the former Queens' District Attorney not guilty because, it said, if Mr. Mackell had been inclined to violate the law he could have done so with such efficiency that his office would never have become involved in criminal proceedings.

Secretary of State Kissinger brought Israel today a list of prisoners held by Syria since the war last October. In response, Israel agreed to hold talks with the Syrians aimed at separating their forces on the Golan Heights front.

The First Banc Group of.Ohio, Inc., a bank holding company, announced yesterday it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire the First National Bank of Toledo for stock valued at more than $32-million.

Not for years has the House Rules Committee done anything. as high-handed as its sudden and completely unexpected knifing of major legislation calling for land use planning. After years of consideration and study, a bill to this purpose was passed by the Senate last June by a vote of 64 to 21. The House Committee on the Interior recently approved it, 26 to 11, and urged its "early consideration."

On Sherif Street in the heart of Cairo's business district a visitor's eye was caught by a book in the display window of a small stationery store. "Hebrew Self-Taught," it said in bold letters. It was standing prominently between similar primers for English and French.

Charles D. Breitel, the state's Chief Judge. today proposed' sweeping changes in the state's court system, including the appointment of all judges of the major trial parts, and the merger of the major courts' of first instance with the Supreme Court.
, one of the nation's top jockeys, was freed in $1,500 ball yesterday following his arrest for allegedly shooting his wife, Debra, in a family argument at home in Garden City, L. I.
The National Education Association broke off merger talks tonight with the nation's other major teachers' union, the American Federation of Teachers the association announced.

Whitney Travis, the manager of the Yale Club, sighed a stoic sigh and addressed himself to a question about the Health Department's report yesterday that it had found mouse excreta in the club's restaurant kitchen.

The director of the Federal prison system told a Congressional subcommittee today that behavior modification was an "in. tegral part" of many prison programs and that it would continue to be used on inmates "whenever appropriate."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass.-Detente is frayed. 'The Soviet Union's recent activities in the Middle East give us somewhat less than full assurance that it is a force for peace. The United States goes on worldwide military alert in response to what it considered a Soviet provocation.

Talks between India, Pakistan and Bangladesh are expected shortly in an effort to work out travel, communications and diplomatic ties among the three nations. Did Mark Rothko, the abstract- expressionist painter, Intend the 800 paintings he left to be sold commercially after his death or disposed of to museums and other selected buyers under circumscribed conditions?
"Guarded optimism" about the economic outlook for 1974 was expressed yesterday by John D. deButts, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest business enterprise.
Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's wife said today that Soviet authorities had told her at least a month was needed to approve export of his personal library. She said she would not leave without the books.

Gasoline-buying lines were markedly shorter throughout the city yesterday on the second day uuder the state's mandatory allocation program, but the announcement of reduced supplies of some brands next month caused concern among the dealers affected.

The first of what is expected to be a series of suits growing out of a chain of accidents last Oct. 23 that killed nine persons and injured 40 others has been filed in Superior Court here against the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

The Roman Catholic Bishop of Bilbao, the Most Rev. Antonio Afioveros Ataun, was reported early this morning to have been detained by the police in his home following a call for greater freedoms for the Basque people that was issued in dozens of Basque churches over the weekend.

Essex County Freeholder Donald M. Payne today announced that he would not 'run in this year's race for Mayor and declared instead his candidacy for a Congressional seat that does not. exist.

Newark Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson told a panel of government and business officials that, with innovative planning and cooperation between government, industry and the academic community, the city could become "the major transportation center in the northeast." The Mayor also said he had formed a special transportation study panel headed by Harry Wheeler, Newark's Manpower Administrator.

The price of almost every commodity traded for future delivery slumped yesterday, often by the daily permissible limit, after weeks of unprecedented advances.

Analyses of recordings made during the 1971 earthquake that took 59 lives in San Fernando, Calif., have shown that the jolts to buildings by such quakes or those of greater magnitude were twice as severe as had been expected when the California buildings codes were drafted.

The Pingry School, situated here for more than a century, has stepped up efforts to sell its 32-acre campus as part of a program under which the prestigious independent institution hopes to move 28 miles west to a site in Bernards Township.

The Lincoln National Corporation, a holding company for the Lincoln National Life Insurance Company and seven other life insurance companies, reported yesterday higher net income for last year although the fourth-quarter net was down somewhat because of a loss on investments.

Until today, only the pitcher and catchers of the Oakland A's were required to sui themselves at training camp. But their slim shortstop Bert Campaneris, has preferred to perspire with them. President Anwar el-Sadat has agreed to allow five Palestinian guerrillas accused of an attack on a Pan American World Airways jetliner at the Rome airport last December to come to Cairo from Kuwait, the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahrarm reported today.

ABRAMOFF-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Abraham and Doris Kaufman. Loving grandmother of Howard, David, Jodle, Laura, Ellen and Brenda. Dear mother-in.law of Lenonre and Richard. Services 10:30 AM., Friday, at Forest Park .Chapels, at Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd.

Glenn R. Miller and Gordon H. McCollum, former officials of the investment - banking house of Walston Co., were each fined $40,000 by a United States District Court Judge here yesterday for stock fraud and conspiracy Involving Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc.

An Australian aboriginal held two Government officials at gunpoint today in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The incident followed by one day a warning by an aboriginal leader that thousands of black demonstrators heading for Canberra where Queen Elizabeth opened Parliament today might include militants "loaded with firearms."
Perhaps more than ever before teen age players are making their mark in tournaments here, as evidenced by the Grand National Knockouts last weekend for which three young experts were qualified.

A "full review of the cultural-affairs policies of the city government" will be undertaken by a committee of city and foundation officials named yesterday by Mayor Beame. The committee Will study the problems of the arts here and make recommendations to him about what the city can do about solving them.

Premier Pierre Messmer and his Cabinet resigned today, and President Pompidou promptly reappointed him to form a new and streamlined one. The move put an end to months of speculation about impending changes in the French leadership.

A military mutiny in the northern city of Asmara spread yesterday, and the Cabinet of Emperor Haile Selassie resigned under pressure of the mutineers' demands. Rejecting the demands of the Asmara troops for big pay increases, the Emperor sent the army chief of staff and two other generals to negotiate with them, but the mutineers took the envoys into custody.

Homer F. Glover, who started the Glover Packing Company in 1941 and built it into a national beef and pork distribution company with plants in several states, died Monday. He would have been 66 years old today.
Many married couples and family members like the idea of joint bank accounts. In case of sickness or accident, a joint account can provide ready access to money for the alternate owner.

A high United States official said today, that more than 200 American intelligence agents were stationed abroad posing as businessmen. He said that some were fulltime intelligence operatives and that business enterprises providing them with cover received payments from the United States Government to defray the costs of running their offices.

Policemen and villagers said today that they had seen what appeared to be the balloon of the American adventurer Thomas Gatch, missing on a transAtlantic flight, but the sighting could not be confirmed.

Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay could reach an agreement to act as a bloc of beef-exporting countries to obtain a relaxation of the tariff barriers imposed by the European Economic Community, sources close to the Uruguayan Foreign Ministry said today.
The Senate. Judiciary Committee approved today a bill establishing conditions under which the death penalty could be imposed for certain serious Federal crimes.
America Jane II, a new 39foot sloop from Newport Beach, Calif., was declared today winner of the wild and fast Miami-Nassau ocean race, in Which one yacht sank.
Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, showing a new burst of vigor in Soviet Middle East diplomacy in an apparent effort to avoid being upstaged by the United States, flew unexpectedly to Syria today.

Mayor Peter Flaherty of Pittsburgh, a popular party maverick, said yesterday he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat now held by Richard S. Schwelker, a Republican. Mr. Flaherty said he would run as an independent, and was not interested in his party's endorsement.

A City Charter provision forbidding business dealings between the city and its employes was .bent yseterday when the Board of Ethics ruled that a city fire fighter could sell an unusual life-saving device to the Fire Department.

A Rome court today sentenced three Arabs to prison terms of five years and two months for terrorist activities, and then freed them on bail. The three also were fined $2,500 each.

The Swedish Parliament today overwhelmingly approved a new Constitution downgrading the monarchy and making King Carl XVI Gustaf a ceremonial figurehead. The vote was 321 in favor and 19 against the new Constitution, which replaces that of 1809.

Representative Angelo D. Roncallo and four Nassau County officials pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of participating in a kickback scheme to extort money from a Long Island contractor for the benefit of the Republican party.

A five-man variant of the Red Onion Jazz Band, a group that has been playing off and on around New York for 20 years, began one of its infrequent steady engagements this week at Barney Google's, 225 East 86th Street.

Frederick Piket, composer, conductor and music publisher, died Thursday of cancer in Boulevard Hospital, Long Island City, Queens. He was 71 years old and lived at 33-23 Clearview Expressway in Bayside, Queens.

During the past few months the great superstructure of Presidential government that Richard Nixon built has slowly collapsed: a landslide here, a cave-in there, leaving billows of dust to hover over the ruins. Regardless of weather or folk lore, March is not ushered in by a lion, but by a lamb, a spring lamb, to be precise. Only from the beginning of March to the first Monday in October can lamb, from animals three to six months old, be marketed as "Genuine Spring Lamb," an official United States Department of Agriculture label. The lamb sold all year round is usually five to 11 months old.

Federal officials began an urgent re-examination yesterday of previous troubles encountered by DC-10 jumbo jets. The review, particularly of the three turbo-fan engines, was merely a precautionary move.

Alstrom-Sogerca, tne nuclear engineering branch of Compagnie General d'Electricite (C.G.E.), said yesterday it had received an order from Electricite de France, the state power company, to build two 995,000-kilowatt nuclear power reactors. A preliminary agreement between the two was announced last December covering eight reactors using the General Electric Companys b'oiling-water reactors Total value of the contract is $700-million.

BARTOLOMUCCI-Aminda. Beloved wife of the late Gregory, mother of Louis, Carlo, Ralph, Tony and Mary Carbone. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 71st St., Monday arid Tuesday, 2 to 5 P.M. and 7 to 9 P.M. Funera mass, Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Ave. at 84 St., Wednesday, 10 A.M. Please omit flowers.

The Bank of America has agreed with British and French shareholders in its jointventure, merchant - banking houses in London and Paris to consolidate the enterprises in a new Luxembourg corporation to be called Bank of America International, S.A. Pierre-Paul Schweitzer will be chairman of the new company.
Following, in an unofficial translation from the French, is the text of a proposal issued to: day by the Common Market countries on cooperation with the Arab nations.

Secretary of State Kissinger returned tonight from an eightday trip to the Middle East and Eufope, refusing to predict whether his diplomatic efforts would lead to a lifting of the Arab oil embargo against the United States.

Harvey Stone, a nightclub comedian and actor, died yesterday in his sleep on the Cunard ship Queen Elizabeth 2 in the Bahamas, according to word from the company to the Lambs Club, of which he was a longtime member. He was 61 years old and had spent much
A conscientious objector who chose two years of civilian serylce rather than be drafted into the armed forces is not eligible for veterans' educational benefits, the Supreme Court ruled today.

Campaign money is at the root of so many of the Nixon Administration scandals-both the buying of Government favor with campaign contributions or their extortion on pain of disfavor-that national sentiment has swung sharply toward public financing of the election process. Congress gives increasing signs of readiness to respond to this pressure for change; the problem is how to get quick action on reforms that will prove effective, not harmful.

Chapter XI petition for an arragement by: MANGEL STORES CORPORATION, doing business as "Shoppers Fair," "Mangels" and "Polly Perrey,"-operates a chain for ladies' apparel shops and discount department stores, at 115 W. 18th st., N. Y. Business organized in Delaware. Signed by Joseph H. Lamm, president.

George Edward Blair, who retired in 1955 as a national advertising salesman for The New York Times after 23 years of service, died at his home Friday at Eastbourne, England. He was 76 years old and had lived in Greenwich Village.
Massachusetts, the defending champion, got off to a weak start today in the first round of the United States curling championships, edging Connecticut, 10-9, in an extra end.

U.C.L.A., the giant of college basketball, may have more trouble in its effort to repeat as the regular-season national champion, but it proved yesterday it still has a firm grip on the individual talent pool.

The Mangel Stores Corporation, which operates Shoppers Fair discount stores and Mangel apparel shops, formally filed a petition yesterday for an arrangement under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York.

The Dayton Flyers, with a record home crowd of 13,528 chanting "Good-by Irish, we hate to see you go" in the background, upset second-ranked Notre Dame, 97-82, tonight. Dayton led all the way and Donald Smith of the University of Dayton shooting over Gary Novak of Notre Dame during game at Dayton last night. Smith scored 32 points to help his team to an upset victory over the Irish. Score was 97-82.
One man was killed and two were injured when part of the cement facing on a cafe toppled to the sidewalk, according to the Chelsea police. Dead was Dominque Matys, 53 years old, of Chelsea.

The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today that it planned to develop mandatory safety standards for television sets, which are suspected of causing hundreds of house fires with many injuries and deaths each year.

MOVEMENTS Dr. Benito Ortolani, who is a theater professor at City University, became a Japanese-theater buff somewhere along the line. He was thoroughly taken with the body movements the Japanese are so expert at. Tonight at 8, he will tell all Eric Bentley

President Nixon assured the Soviet leadership today that nothing was more important this year than a new agreement with Moscow to limit the arms race and pledged to "spare no effort" to achieve that objective. Walter J. Stoessel Jr., left, new U.S. Ambassador to the Soviet Union, shakes hands with President Nikolai V. Podgorny after presenting his credentials in Moscow. At right is Mikhail P. Georgadze, secretary of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet.

For the first time in months, no lines were reported at gasoline stations in the metropolitan area yesterday. But Federal and state officials and dealers warned against overoptimism, saying the lines could recur in the middle of the month. Handicapped persons in the Avenue of the Americas at 55th Street blocked traffic during demonstration outside offices of Governor Wilson. Group's demand for exemption from gas sales restrictions eventually was accepted. Page 19.
Rescuers today reached the wreckage of an aircraft carrying seven persons and found two young boys alive. Five persons were killed.
The police declined to say today whether they were searching for a link between the murder of 18-year-old Cynthia Leslie, whose body was found here yesterday in a wooded area Cynthia Leslie

Haldeman declared himself not guilty in the Watergate scandals today but said it was "obvious some things were wrong." In Los Angeles, H: R. Haldeman held an outdoor news session on subject of Watergate charges. Inside home, his wife filmed scene from window at top left.

Lubomir Kavaiek did not let his third-place finish in the Philippines International Tournament in Quezon City deter him from entering-and galloping off with first prize in -the Marlboro Classic, which followed in Nalinac. The separation of forces along the Suez Canal front was completed ahead of schedule today. The last Israeli troops pulled back to new lines in the Sinai Desert and Egyptian forces took over both sides of the waterway for the first time since the 1967 war.

This city's longest-sitting urban renewal egg is about to be hatched, amid heated debate over whether it will produce a phoenix or an albatross. Site of the proposed Park Plaza development in Boston is in foreground, and includes streets. Common is at top left. Black area denotes urban renewal.

Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, says a President can be impeached for political Wrongdoing. Speaking last night at Illinois State University, Mr. Muskie said the act of impeachment gives "the people the right to remove the President for a great political offense."
The jokes came first, then the skepticism. Now, having established her credentials as a first-class athlete, Ellen Minkow finds male jealousy has joined the wolves' whistles.
William Colby, director of Central Intelligence, testified today that the manuscript of a book about the C.I.A. contrained security breaches "which are very serious indeed."

Facing a threatened lawsuit from Pan American World Airways, the Federal Energy Office moved yesterday to place imported, duty-free jet fuel used by international airlines under Federal price and allocation controls for the first time.

Russell W.H. Kridell, the former president of the Student American Medical Association which met here this weekend, is certain he will be a doctor in another year. Exactly what kind is not clear to him.
There was no response-today to a plea by Patricia Hearst's parents that the kidnapped girl be permitted to write to her family, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent said.

Edward L. Rosenbaum. a former director of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, who retired last year as head of RosenbaumSchwartz Associates, a company agency at 680 Fifth Avenue, New York, died today at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach Fla.

Neither the nervousness of the Israeli leadership nor the jockeying for influence by various Arab governments can obscure the essential point that the belligerents in the Middle East are moving, step by step, toward the brink of a political settlement that no one would have thought possible just a few months ago.

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: ABORTION Declined to review a decision denying the acknowledged father of an unborn illegitimate child an injunc-. tion to prevent the mother from obtaining an abortion (No. 73-1133, Jones v. Smith).

William Greenfield, founder and chairman of the Federal Distributing Corporation of New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old and lived also at 40 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn. Federal Distributing, which
Spectators and reporters were barred yesterday afternoon at the murder trial of Henry S. Brown, and the courtroom doors were locked during the testimony of an unidentified witness.
The nine European Common Market countries made a joint offer of long-term economic, technical and cultural cooperation to the Arab world today.

Even by the antipublic standards long characteristic of the domineering unions that represent New York City public employes, the current leadership of the Uniformed Firefighters Association is notable for its arrogance and obtuseness. Last Election Day, in defiance both of law and of a secret-ballot mandate by the rank and file, the union leaders called a strike that exposed the city to incalculable hazard.
President Gibvanni Leone began formal consultations with political leaders today before designating a Premier for Italy's next Cabinet.
The board of directors of Chock Full O'Nuts authorized its chairman, William Black, yesterday to proceed with arrangements for the acquisition of Rheingold Breweries from Pepsico.
Interest rates moved eratically yesterday in the money and credit markets. Federal funds traded in an 8 15/16 per cent-9 1/8 per cent range all day, with no Federal Reserve transactions in the way

The Landmarks Preservation Commission announced yesterday that it Would hold a hearing March 22 at 10:30 A.M. to consider designating the two Gothic revival houses on Fourth Avenue, which form part of the Grace Church grouping, as official city landmarks, According to Beverly Moss Spatt, commission chairman, the decision to hold the hearing was made yesterday after preservation efforts intensified during the weekend.

The State Division of Human Rights yesterday ordered a Syracuse hospital to pay workmen's compensation benefits to a former woman employee for a six-week period when she took maternity leave in the fall of 1972.
The Peruvian Government will lift tomorrow its yearlong ban on anchovy fishing. The taking of anchovy made Peru the No. 1 fishing nation in the world in the late nineteen-sixties.

To many Brooklyn residents, wi the sight of the dark green Pilgrim Laundry truck was as much a part of the borough as, were Ebbets Field, Ebinger's Bakery or the Rheingold Brew- bo ery. But the truck, its sides In the 1920's, the Pilgrim Laundry had a fleet of more than 30 electric trucks, such as the one above.
Horace Clarke succeeded Bobby Richardson as the Yankees' second baseman in 1967, and some people have wanted the Yankees to find someone to replace Clarke ever since.

The Milwaukee Journal was named today as winner of the William Allen White Foundation's 1974 editorial excelience citation. The paper's editorials during 1973 were judged by the Inland Daily Press Association as those best exemplifying the standards of the late editor.
The Commercial Solvents Corporation said yesterday it had engaged Georgeson Co., a leading stockholder-relations concern, "to solicit rejections of the tender offer made by Beker Industries."

Following are excerpts from material written by Andrei D. Sakharov as a foreword to a forthcoming collection of his statements to be published in the United States by Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. Andrei D. Sakharov at his home in Moscow.

The Government declared today that international news agencies and foreign newsmen "shall have unimpeded freedom" in working in the Philippines.

Mrs. Gertrude Hassall Williams, I wife of Harold Williams, who founded and headed the Lumelite Corporation here, which became a division of Richardson-Merrell, Inc., in 1963, died Saturday at her home on North Quaker Hill. She was 80 years old.

The State Senate gave swift and unanimous approval today to a measure that would move the state legislative elections from the bottom of the ballot up ahead of local and judicial contests to attract greater voter interest.
Mrs. Anne Souders, the 56year-old widow who has been jailed twice for her refusal to connect to the local sewer system here, had her water supply shut off today. She thus faces
An excursion boat with some 35 persons aboard capsized on a canal in city-owned park yesterday, spilling the passengers into the water and drowning

One month before the start of the baseball season, the New York Mets took stock today and decided that it would take fewer injuries and more victories this year to repeat their minor miracle of 1973. Bud Harrelson--looking for his "40 long ones"

Federal drug agents were seeking a fugitive who is charged with participation in five murders and the sale of cocaine when a 25-year-old Kearny, N.J., teacher was shot last Thursday night by an agent in a mistaken-identity case, a Federal spokesman said yesterday.

Dr. W. Kenneth Riland, osteopathic physician to President Nixon, former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, went on trial in Federal Court here yesterday on income tax evasion charges.
Mexico's major political force, the Institutional Revolutionary party, celebrated its 45th anniversary today with a membership of more than 6 million.
The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, announced yesterday that it was increasing prices by "less than 5.5 per cent" on a variety of iron and steel products.

State Banking Commissioner Richard F. Schaub told the Assembly Banking and Insurance Committee today that New Jersey's higher 8 3/4 per cent home mortgage rate had revitalized the sagging real estate market.

WASHINGTON--There has been a great deal of confusion about how we are going to celebrate our upcoming bicentennial year. All of this could have been avoided if only the House Judiciary Committee staff report on "Constitutional Grounds for Presidential Impeachment" could have been written at the same time as the Constitution.

Michel C. Bergerac, president of ITT Europe, Inc., has been named a corporate executive vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the company, announced yesterday. Michel C. Bergerac

Residents of this tiny village overlooking Long Island Sound just above Northport met tonight to consider a proposal that could double the community's population and alter the local ecology. The meeting adjourned without voting any recommendation.
Mayor Beame held out hope yesterday that the 35-cent transit fare could be saved until the end of December, 1975, with continuing Federal subsidies, if the necessary legislation was forthcoming.

The Mets held their breath when Cleon Jones tourned a pitch off his left foot in batting practice and hit the dirt. He is still nursing a chronic case of sore feet anyway, and wears tennis shoes in camp except when he switches to baseball spikes for batting. The International Harvester Company announced today it had signed an $8.5-million contract with Traktor export Moscow for the sale of 39 pay loaders, part and attachments to the Soviet Union.

Frank Wilcox, a character actor who appeared in more than 150 movies and played such varied television roles as Mr. Brewster in the "Beverly Hillbillies" and Elliot Ness' boss in "The Untouchables," died Sunday at his suburban home. His age was 66.
